DOC.HEAD: Politics Will Be A City Game in '91
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The campaign trail leads to city pavement in 1991, when Chicago, Philadelphia and several other of the nation's largest cities will be electing mayors. Four states will be electing governors, including one - Arizona - that tried but failed to pick one in 1990. Among the others are Louisiana, where gubernatorial politics is a blood sport, and Kentucky, where Gov. Wallace Wilkinson hopes to be succeeded by his wife. There are no congressional elections scheduled, and political activity in many states is confined to minor municipal or court races. Nationally, political insiders will be laying strategy for the 1992 presidential race and scouting the field of potential Democratic contenders. In Chicago, Mayor Richard M. Daley will try to win his first full term in office after serving out the last two years of the term of Mayor Harold Washington, who died in office. Daley's announced opponents in the Feb. 26 Democratic primary include former Mayor Jane Byrne, a three-time electoral loser since serving as mayor from 1979 to 1983. Byrne has been accusing Daley of displaying a lack of leadership in the mayor's office, but polls suggest that most voters disagree. In Philadelphia, two-term Mayor W. Wilson Goode is barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term. That may be a good thing for him, given the city's fiscal condition. A half-dozen candidates are already vying for the opportunity to lead the nation's fifth largest city away from the brink of bankruptcy. Philadelphia is counting on $150 million in emergency short-term loans from city banks and two public employee pension boards to stay afloat for the time being. The best-known candidate so far is former two-term Mayor Frank Rizzo, a tough-talking former police officer who is running as a Republican. Four Democrats are expected to be in the running, including former District Attorney Edward Rendell, who lost to Goode in the 1987 primary and also failed in a 1986 try for governor. Also running is former City Councilman George Burrell, who played football for the Denver Broncos. Denver's mayoral race was thrown wide open last month when two-term Mayor Federico Pena made a surprise announcement that he wouldn't seek re-election. City Auditor Wellington Webb is the only announced candidate so far, but several others are edging toward the ring. There also will be a new mayor in Kansas City, Mo., where recently imposed term limits bar Mayor Richard Berkley from seeking re-election, and in Nashville, Tenn., where Mayor Bill Boner has been the butt of jokes over his affair with and subsequent marriage to singer Traci Peel. The mayor of Memphis, Tenn., Richard Hackett, is expected to seek a third term. He may get a challenge from Rep. Harold Ford, Tennessee's only black member of Congress. San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos is expected to seek a second term, and already has announced opposition from county Supervisor Tom Hsieh. In Baltimore, Mayor Kurt Schmoke is expected to run again. In Columbus, Ohio, Mayor Dana Rinehart plans to run for a third term despite revelations that he had an extramarital affair with a member of his Cabinet. Several mayors have yet to announce their plans, among them Salt Lake City Mayor Palmer DePaulis and Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut III. Las Vegas Mayor Ron Lurie is in the off-again, on-again category. He said he wouldn't seek re-election and then said he might. In Chicago, Dallas and Los Angeles, minorities hope to make gains following lawsuits that challenged electoral district boundaries. The Chicago and Dallas cases are still pending, but Hispanic groups have won their fight in Los Angeles, where a federal judge redrew one district on the powerful county Board of Supervisors. A special election Jan. 22 is expected to result in the election of the first Hispanic member of the board. Arizona voters will try to settle their governor's race Jan. 26 in a runoff between Republican J. Fife Symington and Democrat Terry Goddard. Symington received about 4,000 votes more than Goddard in the November general election, not enough for the majority needed to win. Louisiana Gov. Buddy Roemer intends to run for another term and may face a challenge from former Gov. Edwin Edwards, the fellow Democrat whom Roemer ousted in 1987. Former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke, now a state representative, has said he will seek the Republican nomination. Kentucky's governor is barred by law from seeking a second term, so his wife, Martha Wilkinson, is running in his place. Her opponents for the Democratic nomination include her husband's archrival, Lt. Gov. Brereton Jones. Republican hopes seem pinned on U.S. Rep. Larry Hopkins, who hasn't announced whether he'll run. Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus will try to do what no other Mississippi governor has done this century - win a second consecutive term. His main competition is expected to come from a fellow Democrat, former U.S. Rep. Wayne Dowdy. Finally, in Corpus Christi, Texas, a hotbed of anti-abortion activity, voters will decide on Jan. 19 whether to pass a city charter amendment declaring that human life begins at conception.

DOC.HEAD: What A Year: Olympics, Super Bowl - and Jane Fonda, Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY305 of Dec. 27.
DOC.TEXT: Winning the Olympics alone would have given Atlanta reason to crow this year. But then the heavyweight championship? And what about landing a Super Bowl? And a spot on the ``most liveable'' list? And now - grits meets glitz! - Jane Fonda, too? This city's triumphs finally gave substance to its boosters' old nickname. In 1990, it was ``Hotlanta,'' indeed. True, the Olympics fireworks burst over a city that would pass a curfew to save its children from drug dealers. True, the mayor had to challenge preliminary census figures indicating his city was losing people. But even if the ticker tape snowed on a cooling economy and on troubles common to urban area, Atlanta celebrated as it hadn't since the curtain went up on ``Gone With the Wind'' half a century ago. In September, a few months after being picked as the site of pro football's 1994 Super Bowl, dark horse Atlanta beat out Athens, Greece, as host for the 1996 summer Olympic games. The confetti was barely swept up when hometowner Evander Holyfield brought boxing's heavyweight title to the city tagged Losersville for its sorry teams. Billboards around the nation's 13th largest metropolitan area saluted hard work and chutzpah. Headlines hollered, ``It's Atlanta!'' On sidewalks and in grocery lines, natives beamed. At the Atlanta Historical Society, executive director John Ott didn't know of another time when two parades had streamed down Peachtree Street within six weeks. ``It may make Atlantans like Texans: you know, `We're the best, we're the greatest, we're the biggest,''' he said. ``We do have the sense that we have the wherewithal to capture things.'' ``A City of Dreams,'' proclaimed Atlanta magazine - profiling its own parade of locals who realized grand visions, from Martin Luther King Jr. to Ted Turner. The latter's Atlanta-based Cable News Network, which many credit with raising the city's profile, marked its 10th anniversary in 1990. And in December, Ted and Jane (Fonda, that is), whose causes and caresses filled the daily people columns, announced their engagement. Along the way, there were high marks for Atlanta from arbiters as different as the Population Crisis Committee (tied for second highest score on list of world's most liveable cities) and the Fortune Industrial Survey (first among executives' likely picks for future plant sites). Only three U.S. cities attract more conventioneers, and Atlanta's high profile this year will only enhance that, said John Jackson, vice president of the Atlanta Convention and Visitors Bureau. ``A few years ago I was in London ... and a gentleman told me we needed to get our boardwalks fixed. People associated Atlanta with Atlantic City,'' Jackson said. ``That's not going to happen anymore. Atlanta is on the world map.'' The 1988 Democratic National Convention provided a smaller-scale dress rehearsal for events the city is now committed to staging, he said, adding that Atlanta managed the attention well then. Some 15,000 reporters descended on the city and ``95 percent or more of the stories were positive.'' In 1989, however, Atlanta led the nation's large cities in serious crime, according to FBI statistics. Even though the city has shed that dubious distinction as crime figures declined this year, some reporters continue to cite it, said Angelo Fuster, press secretary for Mayor Maynard Jackson. ``It's terribly frustrating,'' he said. In November, the City Council restored a curfew for children 16 and under that hadn't been in effect in nearly a decade, prompted earlier by the so-called ``Atlanta child murders'' cases. In calling for a new curfew, a sponsor cited killings in her district, including that of a 4-year-old girl. Civil libertarians doubted the curfew was constitutional, but the mayor said it would ``help us fight drugs and protect our children.'' City Hall damage controllers went to work after preliminary figures from the U.S. Census Bureau said Atlanta's population fell from 425,000 to 384,000 between 1980 and 1990. The city, contending it had grown to 437,000, said census takers overlooked many, and undercounted others. It demanded a recount. Cracks even began to show in the smiling facade of unanimity that helped win the Olympics. Residents near the proposed sites of certain venues protested that their neighborhoods would suffer. Some activists worried that officials would try to sweep lingering problems like homelessness from visitors' view, rather than working to solve them. ``There are blighted neighborhoods in the path of stadiums all over Atlanta that are going to have to be gentrified,'' complained Anita Beaty, director of the cty's Task Force for the Homeless, which counted 47,000 individuals who sought emergency housing last year. Ms. Beaty said she's concerned that money which could go toward shelter and other needs will instead be used for superficial beautification. She called for more public involvement in planning. ``I'm no longer saying we don't want the Olympics. That's useless,'' she said. ``I'm saying how can we benefit? ... How can we manage the impact?'' The Super Bowl and the Olympics are new chapters in an old story of self-promotion and courting outsiders that has helped define the city that grew from a railroad terminus. Torched by Gen. William T. Sherman in the Civil War, Atlanta adopted the motto, ``Resurgens,'' Latin for ``rising again,'' and never forgot that goal. After the Civil War, Atlanta editor and orator Henry Grady trumpeted a ``New South'' - ``less splendid on the surface but stronger at the core - a hundred farms for every plantation ... and a diversified industry that meets the needs of this complex age.'' Northerners liked what they heard, and Yankee investment poured in to the New South's capital. That typifies Atlanta's style - ``welcome anybody, particularly if they've got a few dollars,'' said Jack Spalding, former editor of The Atlanta Journal. ``People say, `The Olympics? Good God, how can you handle it?' '' Spalding said. But he cited precedents, notably a civic showcase mounted just three decades after Sherman's destruction: the 1895 Cotton States and International Exposition. It attracted 800,000 people, nearly 10 times the city's population. Other than to get attention, ``there was absolutely no justification for it,'' Spalding said, a smile wrinkling his eyes. ``Atlanta's always had a lot of imagination.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeast regional reporter, based in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Farmer Devises His Own Affirmative Action
With PM-A Question of Land
DOC.TEXT: ``In this country, there aren't enough white people to handle all the managerial positions,'' Johann Haasbroek said. ``You have to use people of other cultures.'' Driving a pickup over bumpy trails cut through maize and wheat fields northwest of Johannesburg, the 57-year-old farmer explained why he began promoting black workers more than a decade ago. Such radical action was considered suicidal in the right-wing world of South African farming, but it worked for Haasbroek, who runs a successful family farm and is setting up another for his son. He employs five whites and ``about 60 or 70'' full-time blacks at the main farm. Some of the black workers hire seasonal work crews and manage specific areas of the operation. ``When I was young, you'd very seldom get a black man who wanted to be a foreman,'' Haasbroek said. ``There was a lot of superstition, more than now, among the blacks. They thought something would happen to them.'' Then need and ambition combined, and ``about 12 years ago, one of my black workers said he was willing to train as a foreman,'' he said. When pressed, the farmer acknowledged encouraging the man. ``I said, `You know it would be much easier if I could have one of you guys as foreman; it would take a lot of responsibility off my hands','' he recalled. New responsibilities led to new commitment on both sides, Haasbroek said. Workers displayed a better attitude, he said, and he let them open a school for their children on the farm. Some of the workers attended courses on farm management at government training centers, at their employer's expense. ``They give the basics of how it should be done, not only seen from a job point of view, but communication among themselves and other things,'' he said of the training centers. The result of it all, in Haasbroek's view, is a stable group of workers who take pride in the farm. ``I'd never say it was expressed in words, but in their way of doing things, taking responsibility and doing it for themselves, they're all very proud of the farm,'' he said. ``For instance, we have two soccer teams. They always want to win. They're very proud of the team.'' People are like trees, Haasbroek said, with some growing taller and straighter than others. ``The big thing is to be able to identify the bloke who can do it,'' he said. ``There's a lot of potential in these people waiting to be developed.''

DOC.HEAD: Somewhere Over the Rainbow-Colored Bridge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For Stan Edmister, bridges are a canvas. Where an engineer sees a mass of concrete and steel, he sees a potential masterpiece. ``If paint is going to be put on a bridge to sustain its life, why should it be brown or gray or pastel green, when it could be a lively combination of colors?'' says the 51-year-old artist. Two years ago, Edmister won a $10,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts to design a color scheme for the Guilford Avenue bridge in Baltimore. The result was so pleasing, one NEA official said, that Edmister was awarded a second $10,000 grant to select colors for 15 other bridges that cross Interstate 83. As the bridges are rehabilitated, they will be painted according to Edmister's design. Jeff Soule, special project manager at the NEA in Washington, said the award committee hopes Edmister's work will spur other cities to treat their public works as art. ``We felt it would be a national model in improving the appearance of ordinary structural elements in the urban environment. It is a very, very pragmatic application of art. It elevates public works and at the same time, it makes art accessible,'' Soule said. He's uncomfortable with muted hues that allow behemoths to settle anonymously into the background. So he experiments with vibrant greens, yellows, oranges and foil appliques that change color. He selects colors to highlight the design of a bridge and its setting, he says. He wants to treat the bridges over Interstate 83 as a continuum - related, yet each with its own temperament. ``Driving under and through the city, there is a series of tunnel arches or bridge covers that sets up a natural rhythm. There should be some sort of color theme uniting them, but there should not be a bland blanket similarity from one to another,'' he said. The arches of the Guilford Avenue bridge are bright green, gray and henna. Vertical yellow bands link arch to deck. Girders on the underside are green and yellow. Iridescent green stripes along the bridge's gray fence appear to change color when the sun strikes them. The painting was part of a $3.8 million bridge rehabilitation. City officials say they don't know whether the special treatment cost more than if a single color had been used. Harry McCullough, chief of Baltimore's interstate bridge division, said the city sought just one contract and didn't seek a comparison bid. The cost of cleaning and painting the bridge was $137,000, well below the engineer's estimate of $210,000, he said. The federal government provided 85 percent of the rehabilitation money. Porter Barrows, division administrator of the Federal Highway Administration in Maryland, said the government allowed the special painting after determining the additional cost would be minimal. ``I don't want to say that the cost isn't important, because it is,'' he said. ``But we felt the proposal was legitimate and interesting. It resulted in some interesting comments, I think.'' The federal government must approve Edmister's colors, which include the vibrant green used for road signs and the bright yellow used for center lines. Foils must be used in moderation. The government toned down Edmister's initial idea for the Guilford Avenue bridge, fearing it would be too distracting to motorists. Not everyone approves of his concepts, Edmister said, although the Guilford bridge has converted some skeptics. ``I remember a few engineers who said they disliked an artist tampering in their arena and certainly didn't like a carnival-like color scheme being used,'' he said. ``Now that the bridge is done, and the newness is starting to settle in, or the familiarity is becoming apparent, these same engineers are accepting it.''

DOC.HEAD: For Combat Pilots, What Counts Is Scorecard on Perfect Landings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD THE USS JOHN F. KENNEDY (AP)
DOC.TEXT: For combat pilots on the carrier USS John F. Kennedy, what counts most is the large ``greenie'' scoreboard in every squadron that shows who landed perfectly and who didn't. ``The thing that scares us most, even more than flying in combat and dying really, is the fear of failing in the eyes of fellow pilots or ourselves,'' said Navy Lt. Wes Huey, 25, of Pensacola, Fla., who's been an F-14 pilot for just more than two months. In the elite circle of combat aviators, there is no greater skill than a perfect carrier landing - catching the third of four wires stretched across a rolling, pitching deck with a hook under the tail of an F-14 interceptor or A-7 light-attack aircraft. To do it on a moonless night is the pinnacle of precision flying ``with no exaggeration,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Val Diers, 33, of Norman, Okla., who's mainly been flying A-7s for 12 years. On carriers like the 82,000-ton Kennedy, whose key feature is its compact runway - which is always moving with the ship - a bad landing can spell disaster. Hence, there is a premium on perfection. The ``greenie'' boards hold a prominent position in the ready rooms of every squadron where pilots gather and wait for their next takeoff. The boards not only record the quality of every landing but promote the competitive edge crucial for combat aviators. ``That's how we grade ourselves,'' Diers said. ``Each landing is critiqued and it's a big deal for a Navy pilot.'' Every time a landing cycle starts on the carrier, pilots from each squadron stand on the side of the flight deck, guiding their planes in and grading the landings, which can be watched on television. Slowing down from several hundred miles an hour to catch the No. 3 wire and come to a complete stop in seconds gets a big green mark on the board. An average landing, slightly short on the No. 2 wire or too long on the No. 4, gets a yellow mark. An orange or red mark means a safe but below-average landing. A white mark with a large B in it means a ``bolter,'' missing all four wires and having to try again. Uusually, it's the newer pilots who miss. As Diers looked at the board on the back wall of his A-7 squadron, VA-46, he pointed with pride to the large field of green, with a scattering of yellows and reds and just a few whites. ``Most of them hit that target wire - they're that good,'' he said. There is stiff competition between the junior and senior pilots in Huey's F-14 squadron, VF-32, and its board had a similar emerald hue. ``It's all just a competitive experience from the minute you wake up to the minute you go to bed,'' said Huey, a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy. His father was an F-4 pilot. ``Where else in the world do you find people berating their fellow workers with things they've done wrong, but in the fighter pilot profession?'' he asked. ``It's all sort of a stress test that we go through when we're not actually out there flying in the arena where stress is the way of life. We sort of try to bring that into our daily routine, so that it's not such a shock when we do get into combat,'' he said. Like Huey, many pilots on the Kennedy said they're ready for war with Iraq but hope for a peaceful solution. Lt. Dan Turner, 29, of Jacksonville, Fla., said he hoped he'd never have to use the laser-guided bombs or anti-radiation missiles on his A-7. ``By being out here, hopefully we're providing the punch to make him pull back,'' he said of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Lt. Timothy J. Naughton, 27, of Sheldon, Iowa, an A-7 pilot like his father - who is now NASA's chief of operations at the Johnson Space Center - said ``no one ever wants to go to war.'' ``It's always fun to drop bombs ... if you know there's no one around and no one shoots back at you. But no one wants to get shot at,'' he said.
