DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with closing dollar. Picks up 4th pvs, `The dollar's ...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Monday despite some recovery from its sharp decline earlier. The Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed for the New Year holidays. The dollar closed at 135.40 yen, down 0.65 yen from Friday's close of 136.05 yen. It opened at 134.10 yen and ranged between 134.10 yen and 135.45 yen. The dollar's early plunge in Tokyo followed heavy selling in the Sydney market, which opened before Tokyo, on rumors and news reports suggesting the possibility of a peaceful solution in the Mideast, dealers said. By mid-morning, however, the dollar narrowed its losses in Tokyo as some investors bought it back following profit-taking, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. Except for the position adjustments, dealings in Tokyo were ``extremely thin and almost nothing is happening because there is no market-affecting news here,'' she said. ``Also, few Japanese investors are participating becauseof the New Year holidays.'' All markets will be closed Tuesday through Thursday. Michiaki Lee, a Citibank dealer, said the dollar's decline resulted from resurfacing concerns about the state of the U.S. economy.

DOC.BYLINE: LA Police Say They Foiled Gang Plot to Kill Officers ^By MICHAEL WHITE
DOC.TEXT: Police said they foiled the plans of a ``pencil-necked, pimply-faced street gang'' to kill police officers tonight for stifling the drug trade. Officers arrested three alleged gang members and seized two rifles, one handgun and 163 rounds of ammunition during raids early Saturday in the suburban San Fernando Valley. Police Lt. Jim Vojtecky declined to identify the gang. But he described it as ``a local pencil-necked, pimply faced street gang'' with about two dozen members. Authorities said gang members boasted about their assassination plans on fliers posted around the San Fernando Valley. ``I consider them a flock of idiots to tell you the truth,'' said Cmdr. William Booth, a Police Department spokesman. Informants also tipped off police, Vojtecky said. ``As early as September, we began getting information that local street gangs were getting ... a little irritated, and we had indications they were going to attempt to kill a cop because we were screwing up their drug operations in the streets,'' he said. Gang violence in Los Angeles reached a record level in 1990, accounting for 315 deaths through the first 11 months of the year, compared to 303 in all of 1989. Police said Sergio Camarena and Cesar Reveles, both 18, were booked for investigation of conspiracy to commit murder. Hector Aleman, 18, was booked for possession of a sawed-off rifle. Camarena and Reveles were held without bail and Aleman remained in jail Sunday after failing to post $1,000 bail. Although authorities said the plot was foiled, they urged officers on patrol in the San Fernando Valley New Year's Eve to be aware of it.

DOC.HEAD: Country Bitterly Divided on Pardons
DOC.TEXT: The Argentine nation is bitterly divided over President Carlos Menem's weekend pardon of key figures in the 1970s military dictatorship that conducted a ``dirty war'' on leftists. A key figure in the leftist terrorism of the era, Mario Firmenich, the 42-year-old co-founder of the Montonero movement, was also pardoned by Menem. But the outcry Sunday was over the military figures freed. About 40,000 people - a broad cross-section of ages, income levels, political parties, unions, professionals, students - gathered outside Menem's office Sunday afternoon, waving banners and shouting derisory chants. ``We're here to tell him that we haven't forgotten what happened, and we won't forget,'' said protester Daniel Sossa. He said his aunt was arrested during the 1976-83 dictatorship and never heard from again. Menem, himself jailed without charge during the period, told reporters: ``They can have all the marches they want. ... That doesn't bother me. I believe it was best for my country. Period.'' Human rights groups called for national mourning and protest marches. But there was joy in a group representing families of victims of leftist killings at the release of six ex-generals, including former presidents Jorge Videla 65, and Roberto Viola, 66, and five other former officials. Roman Catholic Bishop Jaime de Nevares said the pardons mocked justice, broke the law and trampled on human rights. Another church leader, Archbishop Antonio Quarracino, said they were necessary and ``make me happy.'' The two rival factions of the General Labor Federation, Argentina's major labor group, were also divided. Recent polls had indicated that up to 80 percent of Argentines would oppose the pardons, which Menem said would ``close a sad and black stage of Argentine history'' in announcing them Saturday. Videla, freed Saturday after more than five years in prison, attended Mass at a chapel near his apartment Sunday and handed reporters a short statement that said in part: ``I ask God to extinguish forever the hatred among Argentines with the goal that we all may reconcile ourselves in peace, union and liberty.'' Viola, Videla and six other senior officers were pardoned for crimes including torture, illegal detention and murder. Former finance minister Jose Martinez de Hoz and two former civilian officials, all of whom had been jailed on other charges, were included in the pardon. Menem said the pardons, by ending a justification for military restiveness, would allow Argentina to look ahead. But many said they merely reopened wounds. ``The pardons do not leave the past behind, but take us back to the worst failures of our past,'' said former President Raul Alfonsin, leader of the main opposition party, the Radical Civic Union. ``This is the saddest day in Argentine history,'' he said. Urban terrorist attacks in the 1970s and the military junta's heavy-handed response still wrench Argentina's national psyche seven years after the return to democracy with Alfonsin's election in October 1983. Menem was elected last year. Alfonsin and the Congress gave amnesty to hundreds of lower-ranking officers, after three military uprisings against his government to protest pending trials of soldiers accused of rights abuses. A fourth rebellion to protest Videla's imprisonment was crushed by the government Dec. 3. Menem had earlier promised the military that the pardons were in the works. The military insists it was forced to use unconventional methods to stop the leftist guerrillas. But many claim the military used the insurgency as a pretext for repression. At least 8,960 alleged leftists disappeared and were presumed executed. Human rights put the death toll at about 30,000.

DOC.HEAD: Government Scraps Plan to Pardon Ex-Dictators
DOC.TEXT: Responding to a formidable public outcry, the government has reversed itself and decided not to go ahead with announced plans to pardon leaders of the 1967-74 military dictatorship. Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis had said Friday that he decided for humanitarian reasons to pardon nearly all the jailed former members of the junta, some of whom are serving life sentences. That provoked cries of outrage from socialists, Communists and other leftists, both in Greece and on the island of Cyprus. It also drew criticism from members of the governing New Democracy party, Cabinet members and other prominent conservatives. On Sunday, the government said it was backing down in order to avoid ``political tension.'' ``The universal condemnation both in Greece and on Cyprus by ... the overwhelming majority of the people forced the government to a hasty retreat,'' said Andreas Papandreou, the leader of the main opposition socialists. Approval had been expected by a government committee this week, but newspapers reported Sunday that President Constantine Caramanlis would not sign the necessary presidential decree. His office would not confirm the reports. Most politicians, conservative and left-wing, were jailed, tortured or exiled during the seven years of military rule. The government's change of heart came at a Cabinet meeting, its announcement said. ``The government believed and believes that democracy in our country is so strong that it can show its humanity,'' the announcement said. But it said that ``in order to avoid turning this issue into the object of artificial political tension, it decided to not advance the procedures for the granting of a pardon.'' A protest against the pardons had been planned for today. Papandreou, whose elected socialist government was in power from 1981 to 1989, had said he would request an emergency debate in Parliament on the issue. Leftists accused Mitsotakis of repaying a political debt to a pro-junta rightist group that has backed his New Democracy Party. The former rulers had themselves never sought pardon or amnesty. But junta supporters have lobbied for an amnesty since the officers were sentenced. Eight members of the junta are serving prison terms ranging from 20 years to life imprisonment, convicgted of treason, torture, or the murder of pro-democracy student protesters. Those serving life sentences include Col. George Papadopoulos, 71, who led the 1967 coup; his brother Constantine; 69; and former Brig. Dimitris Ioannides, 67. Ioannides, ex-chief of the dreaded military police, overthrew Papadopoulos in a 1973 coup. Under Mitsotakis' proposal, the only junta member who would not have been pardoned was Ioannides, who also engineered a failed 1974 coup in Cyprus by right-wing supporters of the island's union with Greece. The disastrous coup attempt prompted an invasion of Cyprus by Turkey, which partitioned the eastern Mediterranean island. It also caused the junta's collapse and the restoration of democracy in Greece. On Cyprus, nearly all political parties condemned the proposal to pardon the leaders. Government spokesman Akis Fantis said Cypriots will always hold the Greek military dictators responsible for the island's division.

DOC.HEAD: Stolen Gulf Papers Found in Trash
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secret documents used by the commander of British forces in the Persian Gulf were stolen and later found dumped in the trash, apparently discarded by a thief who didn't examine them, police say. A briefcase containing the documents - said to concern British war plans against Iraq - was delivered to police after being spotted in a north London dumpster by a passing doctor, police say. Defense Secretary Tom King said Sunday that all the documents were recovered ``but it is a serious matter and it is a matter for police investigation.'' The documents could have compromised allied interests in the gulf, King said, but apparently were not examined. The Times of London and other media reports said the documents were used by Air Chief Marshal Sir Patrick Hine, commander of British forces in the gulf, to brief Prime Minister John Major on Dec. 17. After the briefing, the documents were handed to Hine's personal staff officer, Wing Cmdr. David Farquhar, to return to Royal Air Force Strike Command at High Wycombe, northwest of London, the news reports said. Farquhar and his driver stopped the car in west London and got out to look at some used cars. In the few minutes they were away, a thief opened the trunk and stole the briefcase, a dictaphone, a portable television and money. The defense ministry said Farquhar had been moved to unspecified ``other duties'' pending an investigation. Anthony Beaumont-Dark, a Conservative legislator, said Farquhar should be court-martialed for failing to strap the briefcase to his wrist.

DOC.HEAD: Court Blocks Father From Moving Daughter in Right-to-Die Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, bgng `Dr. Ronald Cranford...' to CORRECT typos in Ms. and Busalacchi. pick up 13th graf pvs, `Ms. Cruzan's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ST1 of Dec. 30.
DOC.TEXT: The director of the hospital where Nancy Cruzan died won a court order against the father of another patient who wants to remove his brain-damaged daughter's feeding tube. Pete Busalacchi wants to transfer his 20-year-old daughter, Christine, from the Missouri Rehabilitation Center to Minnesota, where she could die under a state provision that recognizes ethical decisions by doctors. The hospital's director fought the move, claiming Ms. Busalacchi has a better chance of recovering than Ms. Cruzan did. Ms. Cruzan died at the Missouri hospital Dec. 26 after her parents won a landmark court battle to have her feeding tube disconnected. Pro-life advocates predicted a ``tidal wave'' of euthanasia cases after her death. Since a 1987 car accident in St. Louis, Ms. Busalacchi has been in a vegetative state similar to that of Ms. Cruzan, the subject of the Supreme Court's first right-to-die ruling. ``I really sometimes feel with Chris that the light's on but no one's home,'' Busalacchi said Sunday. ``I believe my daughter is dead, and all I have left in the hospital is a machine.'' Judge Scott Sifferman of Lawrence County Court issued a temporary restraining order Saturday after the center's director, Don Lamkins, said there is ``scientific and observational evidence'' that Ms. Busalacchi is aware of her surroundings. Lamkins said the 10-day restraining order would allow doctors to examine her further. Sifferman scheduled a Jan. 8 hearing to review the doctors' findings. Lamkins said Ms. Busalacchi waved at him after a nurse ordered her to, but her father said there is no indication she responds to commands. ``Yes, her fingers can move. But it doesn't happen on command,'' he said. ``They also say she can smile at you, but it's no smile that you or I would recognize. It isn't my daughter's smile.'' Dr. Ronald Cranford of Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis, a neurologist and medical ethicist, said Ms. Busalacchi is incapable of conscious thoughts or deliberate actions. Ms. Cruzan's parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan, fought a three-year legal battle to have their 33-year-old daughter's feeding tube disconnected. The Supreme Court ruled last June that Ms. Cruzan, severely brain damaged in a 1983 car accident, could be allowed to die if there was ``clear and convincing'' evidence she would want to. Although she had left no written instructions on her intentions, former co-workers testified that she said she would never want to live like a ``vegetable.'' Busalacchi said he does not have such proof. ``Certainly this has set off the tidal wave we warned about, since there is no clear and convincing evidence in Christine's case that she would want to die,'' Rita Marker, director of the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force, said Sunday from Steubenville, Ohio. Busalacchi said a doctor told him two years ago that his daughter's condition was hopeless. ``I asked him to compare Chris' condition with Nancy Cruzan's,'' he said. ``He responded with two words: `The same.''' He said he was encouraged Sunday by a telephone call from Joe Cruzan, who ``offered to help in any way he could.'' ``I've tried to be strong in all of this, but I don't have anybody to lean on but myself. Sometimes I get angry and frustrated. When that happens, I do try to think about Chris as she was.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Who Saved Family in Fire Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 14-year-old girl who saved five family members from their burning home has died of injuries suffered when she went back in the house, apparently to rescue her pets. Jennifer Olson died Saturday at Brookside Hospital in San Pablo. Firefighters found her unconscious in a smoke-filled bedroom at the family's Alameda home on Dec. 23. Minutes before, she had led her grandfather, 3-year-old sister and three brothers, ages 2, 5 and 6, to safety after the younger children accidentally started a fire with papers stuffed into a plastic doll house. Fire officials said she also tried to save the family's dog, cat, parakeet and hamster. Only the dog survived. ``For her age, she did very well, did wonderful,'' said fire Lt. David LeMoine. ``She got her sisters and brothers out and her grandfather. She made a mistake going back in. The animals might have been saved anyway.'' However, her aunt, Christine Nickoley, 21, said she believed Jennifer returned to telephone for help. ``She loved animals but she wasn't stupid,'' Ms. Nickoley said. ``She would have never come outside and gone back for the animals.'' A tape of a 911 call indicates a dispatcher told Jennifer to break a window, but she was overcome by smoke. Jennifer, a sophomore at Notre Dame High School, was remembered as vivacious and studious. The Friday before the fire, she played the role of gun moll Breathless Mahoney in her school's production of ``Dick Tracy.'' ``She was a very pretty girl,'' said hospital spokesman Jim Beaver. ``She was bright, one of those special kinds of kids who was having a lot of fun.''

DOC.HEAD: No New Year's Eve Break From Youth Curfew
DOC.TEXT: Young people should hold their New Year's Eve celebrations indoors or include a chaperone if they want to party until 1991, police say. The city's youth curfew is in effect tonight - despite the holiday - and extra officers will be on patrol, police said. The curfew bars people under 17 from the streets between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. weeknights, unless participating in school activities, returning from work or accompanied by an adult. Parents of repeat offenders could receive up to 60 days in jail and $1,000 in fines. Some local hotels, wary after a luxury tower was pillaged in a drunken row last year, say they plan to turn away people under 21 who are not registered guests. ``If there is a celebration outside, police will be looking at that situation,'' said Atlanta police spokeswoman Marion Lee. ``That's what we do anyway. There'll be nothing different.'' The main outdoor New Year's is held downtown. Police expect 130,000 people to gather in a 2{-block area. Any youths out past 11 p.m. without an adult or parental permission will be escorted home by police, Ms. Lee said. Officers intend to check with parents to confirm any child's story, she said. ``If kids have the justification for being out on the streets outside the time limit, if we get a confirmation from a parent, we have no problem with that,'' she said. ``It's for those loitering, hanging around, without an obvious purpose. That's who we're concerned about.'' Thirty-one violators have been detained and 24 parents have been given warnings since the curfew took effect Nov. 19, according to police records. Supporters say the curfew is needed to help curb violence. FBI statistics show Atlanta had 210 reported serious crimes per 1,000 residents during 1989, higher than any other U.S. city. Security will be tight at the Marriott Marquis hotel, the site of a destructive fracas last New Year's Eve. Fifteen people were injured and 50 were arrested when celebrating young people hurled furniture, potted plants and debris off high-rise indoor balconies into the lobby. Managers were to monitor the Marquis' entrances, said general manager Ted Renner. The Hyatt Regency was to close its doors at noon today, said spokeswoman Nancy Ziprik. After that, only guests or others with official hotel business were to be allowed in.

DOC.HEAD: Better Late Than Never for Procrastinators Club's 1990 Predictions
DOC.TEXT: The Procrastinators Club could get a bad name for this. It released its 1990 predictions a day before the year ended. ``Normally, we wait until the very last minute to make these predictions. But we want to get this year over with,'' said president Les Waas, who released the list on Sunday. The club's annual ``forecasts'' have been completely accurate for the past dozen years. Among the latest predictions: -``A lip-synching pop group named Milli will mourn the loss of its beloved Grammy.'' -``An NFL team will show more of its stuff in the locker room than on the field.'' -``The biography of a dog named Millie will outsell one written by a former resident of the same house.'' -``A TV star will grab more than attention while singing our national anthem.'' -``Liz Taylor will parlay one scent into many dollars.'' -``A Trumped-up fortune will crumble as a Donald ducks.'' And perhaps most outlandish of all: East and West Germany will reunite. The club formed in 1956 and now has has 8,500 members. Waas estimates a half million potential members haven't gotten around to joining. He said the club would never make advance predictions. ``It doesn't make sense,'' he said. ``By doing it our way, in one year we make more correct predictions than all of the other major prognosticators. ``Our theory is if you wait until the last minute to do something, it still gets done, and look at all the time you save,'' he said. ``Let's say you do your income taxes at the last minute. That takes about three hours. If you start to do them now, it'll probably take the next three months, and you'll be worrying about them all the time, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed lower against the Japanese yen in slow trading today despite some recovery from its sharp decline earlier in the day. The Tokyo Stock Exchange was closed for the New Year holidays. Both the stock and foreign exchange markets will begin 1991 trading on Friday. The dollar closed 1990 trading at 135.40 yen, down 0.65 yen from Friday's close of 136.05 yen. It opened at 134.10 yen, its low for the day, and ranged as high as 135.45 yen. The dollar had finished 1989 trading at 143.40 yen. During 1990, it ranged between 124.40 yen and 159.95 yen. Monday's spot trading totaled $3.09 billion, compared with Friday's $5.5 billion. A dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the dollar's sharply lower opening resulted from investors' low expectations for the U.S. economy. Last week, the dollar had been rising on purchases for year-end settlements. Today's trading was quiet, with not much market-affecting news, the dealer added. Another dealer said the dollar's early plunge in Tokyo followed heavy selling in Sydney, where trading started earlier, on rumors and news reports suggesting the possibility of a peaceful solution in the Middle East. Fears of Middle East war had weakened the yen because Japan imports almost all of its oil, and 70 percent of it comes from that region. The dollar also is seen as a safe haven in troubled times.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Phone Numbers to Have Eight Digits
DOC.TEXT: The new year brings double trouble for the absent-minded in Tokyo. Along with remembering a new date, they'll have to remember new telephone numbers. Telephone numbers in the metropolitan area will expand to eight digits to cope with an overwhelming demand for more telephone lines, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. said today. After 2 a.m. Tuesday, callers will have to dial a ``3'' before the current seven-digit local Tokyo numbers. Beepers and phones in some areas of Tokyo already have eight digits, but most Japanese numbers currently have seven. The change will affect about 6.14 million telephone numbers. The seven-digit system has the capacity for 10 million numbers, but ``with eight-digit numbers, we won't have to worry about the lack of phone lines for a long time,'' said NTT spokesman Haruo Maeda. NTT has spent some $37 million on the switchover, including yearlong mechanical changes and public announcements since September. Some confusion is expected at first. ``Since people have been used to the 7-digit numbers for so long, it might be difficult to switch to the new system right away,'' said Masatoshi Inadome of NTT's customer service. ``Many will have to learn after at least one failure,'' he said. ``We are afraid many people may forget to fix numbers programmed into their fax machines, personal computers and telephone sets,'' he said. ``The problem is that callers can hear our recorded reminder when they forget to add the extra digit, but fax users won't,'' Inadome said. In addition to the pre-recorded tape service to remind those who forget to add the extra ``3,'' dozens of NTT staffers will stay overnight in their branches nationwide to help callers. Kokusai Denshin Denwa Co., the nation's leading long distance carrier, will also provide tapes in Japanese and English to remind callers of the change, Inadome said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Appeals to Syrian President for Westerners' Release
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Frank Reed has appealed to Syrian President Hafez Assad to help free 13 Westerners still held in Lebanon. ``I beg you and all nations within the community of man to reach into their wells of justice and sense of humanity and come to their rescue,'' Reed wrote in a letter to Assad. He wants to meet with the Syrian president. ``What a perfect season for Syria to demonstrate to all Americans and the world that its sense of humanity and human caring goes beyond standing guard together in the sands of Arabia,'' the letter said. Reed said Sunday he discussed the hostages during a 30-minute meeting in Washington Dec. 14 with Syrian Ambassador Walid Al-Moualem. He gave Al-Moualem letters for Assad and followed up with a mailgram Dec. 27, but said he has received no reply. Al-Moualem had greeted Reed when he was released in Damascus, Syria, last April after 44 months in captivity. Six of the 13 are Americans, but no Americans have been freed since Reed and Robert Polhill were released within nine days of each other. ``Bothering me was the enormous attention paid in the media and by our administration to people who were detained in Iraq and living in special conditions that in no way could be comparable to what the situation was in Lebanon,'' Reed said. ``So I decided to take it upon myself and go to the Syrian government.'' Reed noted in one letter that it was the sixth Christmas in captivity for Terry Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, and Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut. Peggy Say, Anderson's sister, plans to travel to Lebanon in January and has vowed not to return without her brother. ``I would probably do the same thing after all this time,'' Reed said. ``Her presence will possibly remind everybody there her brother is a hostage and should be released.'' The other American captives are Joseph Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut; Edward Tracy, 59, West Beirut resident; Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, and Jesse Turner, 42, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College. The hostages are believed to be held by pro-Iranian Islamic Shiites. Syria has about 40,000 troops in Lebanon and has tightened its grip as the major power broker there.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troop Commander In Eastern Germany Fired After Officers Desert
DOC.TEXT: The commander-in-chief of Soviet troops in what was East Germany was fired after two senior officers deserted and stole missiles and other armaments, the government newspaper Izvestia reports. Gen. B. Snetkov was fired after the desertions of Lt. Col. M. Kolesnikov, a regimental commander, and Capt. G. Moiseyenko, leader of a supply unit, Izvestia said Sunday. Also fired were Gen. A. Kolinichenko, chairman of the political department of the troops stationed in eastern Germany; Maj. Gen. A. Zhurov, whose position was not given; and the chairman of the personnel department, Maj. Gen. Shipilov. Izvestia did not give a specific date of Kolesnikov and Moiseyenko's desertions and it did not say when Snetkov was fired. It said the desertions were discovered on Nov. 29 when a new regimental commander was sent to replace Kolesnikov, who had been ordered back to Moscow. ``They did not leave with empty hands,'' Izvestia quoted Col. A. Korotkov of the military procurator's office as saying of the deserters. Korotkov said three anti-tank missiles, anti-aircraft weapons and other armaments were missing. He said the armed was conducting a criminal investigation. Izvestia quoted him as saying the crime rate within Kolesnikov's regiment had risen recently, and that the commander was recalled to Moscow because ``he could not perform his duties'' and had ``developed a great passion for enriching himself.'' Izvestia said 145 servicemen have deserted the Soviet units stationed in eastern Germany and 49 have applied for political asylum.

DOC.HEAD: UC Berkeley Students Unearth Greek Monument
DOC.TEXT: A group of archaeology and history students made a ``one in a million'' find when they uncovered an ancient monument that the Greek historian Plutarch had written about, their professor said. The monument commemorates a battle in east-central Greece in 86 B.C. at which the Romans defeated invaders from Asia Minor. It was uncovered last February by students from the University of California, Berkeley, said John Camp, a Berkeley professor of archaeology and co-director of U.S. excavations in Greece. ``The odds of finding a historically attested inscription must be one in a million,'' Camp said. He reported the find Sunday at a meeting of the Archaeological Institute of America. Plutarch, who lived from about 46 to 120 A.D., referred to the battle at Chaironeia and the monument in his book ``Life of Sulla,'' a biography of the Roman general. Two local men, Homoloichos and Anaxidamos, were credited with leading Roman troops up a hidden path and surrounding the invaders. The monument's Greek inscription proclaims: ``Homoloichos and Anaxidamos are heroes.'' The students found the monument while searching through piles of rock near what was known as Mount Thourion, near where they believed the battle had occurred. ``To actually be able to put your hands on this physical thing that is the proof of an ancient story is very exciting,'' said Gretchen Umholtz, one of the students. The announcement of the discovery was delayed until paperwork required by the Greek government was completed, Camp said. The Greek government promised to put the monument in a museum and the students were invited to submit an article on the find to the American Journal of Archaeology, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rap Comes Back to Oakland Stage After Yearlong Moratorium
DOC.TEXT: Amid police barricades and metal detectors, rap music returned to one of the city's largest auditoriums after a yearlong ban imposed to curb violence at concerts. The moratorium ended Saturday when Too Short and Ice Cube played under unusually tight security for 3,000 fans in the Henry J. Kaiser Auditorium. It was the first such show since violence prompted officials at the auditorium and the Oakland Coliseum to ban rap concerts for a year. The Coliseum has yet to book another rap show. ``I'm glad it's back,'' said fan Tom Armstrong, 27. ``Rap is good for Oaktown. It's what's happening here.'' Concert promoter Bill Graham said he increased his security force by about one-third and the auditorium's managers designed a special security plan for the concert. A police helicopter hovered overhead, lighting the parking lot with a bright beam. Barricades circled the parking lot and fans were ushered through a maze of metal gates before they reached the hall's entrance, where they were searched and then scanned by a metal detector. At the end of the show, the crowd was herded out past a line of police officers and security personnel. ``Just another Saturday night dance,'' Graham quipped. ``We want to let the negative element know we're here to take care of things.'' A fight between rival gangs at a 2 Live Crew concert in December 1989 capped a series of violent incidents that led to the ban, including a fracas at the Coliseum during which one person was shot. Too Short, known for biting and sometimes raunchy lyrics, repeatedly reminded fans to stay calm Saturday night. There were no major incidents, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other major currencies in early European trading today. Gold rose. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.65 yen to a closing 135.40 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 135.83 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: -1.4960 German marks, down from 1.4970 -1.2770 Swiss francs, down from 1.2780 -5.0900 French francs, down from 5.0930 -1.7008 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6890 -1,130.50 Italian lire, up from 1,127.75 -1.1607 Canadian dollars, unchanged In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9320, compared with $1.9220 late Friday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $391.00 per ounce at midmorning, from $385.75 bid per ounce late Friday. The Zurich stock exchange was closed Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.22 to close at a bid $390.65. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.16 a troy ounce, from Friday's $4.14.

DOC.HEAD: Tent City in Kremlin's Shadow Dismantled
DOC.TEXT: For more than five months, protesters from across the country tested the tolerance of Soviet authorities with a tent city that went up just 200 yards from the Kremlin. In several hours Saturday night, police with bulldozers cleared it away. ``The order was to clear it out by New Year's and give the impression that all the issues were resolved,'' Vadim Shilov, a 22-year-old resident of the tent city, said in a telephone interview. The protesters pressed a variety of causes reflecting the social upheaval in the Soviet Union. Some of the signs that adorned the tents and shacks denounced the Communist Party; others told of losing homes and jobs because the protesters had dared to criticize their bosses. Rumors had been floating since September that authorities would clear away the nearly 30 plastic and cardboard shacks erected in front of the giant Rossiya Hotel. According to several sources, police and bulldozer crews moved in Saturday night, acting on orders of the Moscow City Council. Shilov said riot police wearing bulletproof vests took away about 50 people, beating some with truncheons. His account could not be independently confirmed. Two city police dispatchers, refusing to give their names, said Sunday that some of the squatters were bused to police centers for people not registered at any address. Others who were registered were given tickets home. One of the police dispatchers offered the only official explanation of the city council decision. ``Those people violated sanitary norms,'' he said. Neither dispatcher was able to give a number of the squatters, but a reporter had seen about a dozen at the tent city earlier Saturday. The collection of shacks and protest posters was a symbol not only of the social turmoil caused by Gorbachev's reforms, but also of his moves toward democracy that included an unprecedented tolerance of dissent. Before Gorbachev, the eyesore - located so close to the country's most sacred governmental shrines - would have been torn down immediately and its instigators jailed for years. Official doctrine maintained that such phenomena could only exist in the West, where exploitation and injustices were rampant. ``The tent city originally was supposed to demonstrate what democracy is like in the Soviet Union. We are a litmus paper of Soviet democracy,'' Zhanna Fedina, a 54-year-old former regular at the tent city, said Sunday in a telephone interview. She said she did not witness the removal of the squatters. The protest began July 2, when the demonstrators put up the tents and shacks, hoping to attract official attention and help in their struggles with government. They generally arrived at 8 a.m. and left at 9 p.m. The initial targets were delegates attending a congress of the Communist Party in the nearby Kremlin in early July. Passersby would slowly walk past the tents, some of which were merely poles with clear plastic sheets draped over them. Others were more elaborate: store-bought, olive green canvas tents with stones carefully placed outside to form a makeshift porch. It was the first thing tourists leaving the Rossiya saw, with the colorful St. Basil's cathedral and the Kremlin forming a backdrop.

DOC.HEAD: President Reaffirms Goal of Doubling GNP in New Decade
DOC.TEXT: President Yang Shangkun today reaffirmed the Chinese government's goal of doubling the gross national product in the coming decade. ``I am fully confident in the realization of this goal,'' Yang said in New Year's greetings over Radio Beijing, China's state-run international radio. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping in 1978 set the goal of quadrupling China's GNP by the turn of the century. The GNP doubled during the booming 1980s and economists say that even with moderate growth, China's GNP should reach the goal of $538 billion by the century's end. Moderate growth is what the ruling Communists mandated in the economic and social blueprint for the 1990s they released Sunday. The document suggests no dramatic new reform initiatives, urging instead a return to basics. Economically, that will mean more funds for agriculture, raw materials industries, the infrastructure and the military. Politically, the emphasis will be on ideological discipline and collective labor. ``For a long time to come, we must persist in ... building the country through thrift and diligence,'' the party Central Committee exhorted in the communique adopted at a secret, six-day meeting that ended Sunday. The document filled the front pages today of all leading newspapers. Several newspapers also carried editorials applauding the party for the ``complete success'' of its meeting, which had been delayed months by internal debates. In the end, the conservatives appeared to have dominated, if only by sheer force of numbers. In addition to 278 full and alternate members of the Central Committee, the meeting was attended by 268 members of the Central Advisory Commission and Commission for Discipline Inspection, party bodies made up largely of elderly ideological hard-liners. While leaving the door open to further market-style economic reforms, the document stresses that the goal is to make the socialist system work better, not replace it with capitalism. The communique did not mention directly the collapse of socialism in most other countries, but reflected the siege mentality that has developed among China's aging revolutionaries since they crushed a democracy movement at home last year and watched similar movements succeed in Eastern Europe. Western observers believe the party's difficulty in drafting the plans for the 1990s reflects a leadership vaccuum. Senior leader Deng, 86, appears to have lost considerable prestige since the massive 1989 democracy movement and bloody crackdown that followed. The communique made only a single, perfunctory mention of Deng's historical contributions. It failed to mention his recent call for ``better, more rapid and more effective'' reform. Reform was one of the key issues dividing the committee. Party elders such as 86-year-old Chen Yun, who helped implement initial market-style reforms in the 1980s, argued that private enterprise and free markets should not be allowed to replace the state sector. The communique echoed Chen's position by urging efforts to strengthen the inefficient, debt-ridden state sector and establish more collective companies in the service sector, now dominated by private entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Orders 17-Year-Olds To Report For Military Duty
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today ordered 17-year-old males to report for military duty, escalating preparations for war as the U.N-ordered Jan. 15 deadline to leave Kuwait draws closer. A brief announcement by the General Mobilization Headquarters instructed Iraqi men born in 1973 to sign up with the nearest recruitment center between Jan. 2 and Jan. 10. The announcement, carried by the official Iraqi News Agency and Baghdad Radio, threatened those who fail to respond to the callup with unspecified ``legal action.'' It was the fourth major callup of reserves in recent weeks. Those drafted earlier included an unspecified number of men aged 30, 31 and 32. The London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies recently reported that the country of 17 million has about 1.1 million males ranging in age from 13 to 17, some 900,00 ranging in age from 18 to 22 and 1.3 million ranging in age from 23 to 32.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Warms In Much of Nation; Flooding in Ohio, Tennessee Valleys
DOC.TEXT: Most of the nation emerged from two weeks of frigid cold today, but as the snows melted, floodwaters swamped parts of the Ohio and Tennessee valleys and the Appalachian mountains. Snow fell in parts of New York, the Midwest and the South early today, and subzero temperatures made it shivery cold in Iowa, North Dakota and Nebraska. But overall, temperatures were much warmer than they were at the beginning of the weekend. A band of showers was moving along the Eastern Seaboard, from Maine to Florida, but rain was not expected to move very far inland in most areas outside the South. More snow was expected in hard-hit Washington state and the Upper Great Lakes region, however. Elsewhere, the forecast generally called for cloudy skies but pleasant temperatures. Highs in the 50s were expected for most of the East Coast and Southwest today, ranging from the 20s to the 40s in the Midwest, getting up to about 10 degrees in the Great Lakes region, and reaching the 40s and 50s in California. DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0471 to CORRECT writethru sequence
Arab Woman Killed Handling Bomb In Marketplace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with more police, witness quotes; other unrest; changes priming to handling in lead to conform with police statement. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A bomb ripped through a toilet at an outdoor market in the heart of Jewish west Jerusalem today, killing an Arab woman who apparently was handling the explosives, police said. They said the victim was a 24-year-old woman from the occupied West Bank. ``Apparently the person who was handling the charge was killed in this toilet stall,'' said police commissioner Yaacov Terner. She was alone in the toilet and there were no other casualties, he said. The explosion occurred at about 11:30 a.m. at the Mahane Yehuda market. Terner said the woman was ``torn to pieces'' but a witness said she was still alive immediately after the blast. Shopkeeper Meir Cohen said he ran into the toilet and found the woman lying under a fallen door. ``She was alive, the woman. I lifted her head. She moved her head as if she wanted to speak, wanted help,'' he said. Cohen said she had something in her hand which he feared might be another bomb, so he ran to nearby police to summon help. Shahar Ayalon, a senior police officer, said a bag of vegetables was found beside the woman, and ``it is reasonable to assume that she intended to plant the bomb in the bag and place it on one of the adjacent streets.'' The explosion apparently was relatively small. A cookie vendor 30 feet from the toilet said he heard a muffled pop that did not even shake his stall. The only exterior sign of damage to the toilet was a shattered window. Police sealed the immediate vicinity of the toilet, but there was no panic. Hundreds of shoppers continued about their business. The blast occurred on the eve of the 26th anniversary of the first armed attack inside Israel by Fatah, the mainstream guerrilla arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Asked whether he thought the bomb was linked with the anniversary, Terner said: ``I have no doubt it is connected.'' Terner said police were making ``a huge effort'' to forestall trouble in Jerusalem and elsewhere. Appeals were broadcast over the market's public address system for shoppers to ``be wary of suspicious packages and report anything suspicious to the police immediately.'' Knots of young men, many of them ultra-orthodox Jews, gathered at the market, occasionally waving their fists and chanting ``Death to the Arabs.'' Someone tossed into the air a handful of leaflets of Kach, the extreme anti-Arab movement founded by the late Rabbi Meir Kahane. Mahane Yehuda has been a bomb target before, most recently in May, when an explosion killed an elderly man and wounded nine other people. On Sunday night, a 19-year-old Palestinian was killed in an explosion near Israeli military government headquarters in the West Bank city of Nablus, the army said. It said the bomb exploded as he was priming it. The occupied Gaza Strip, scene of serious clashes Saturday in which four Arabs were shot dead, was almost entirely under curfew today to head off Fatah anniversary celebrations. It was the 22nd time the Gaza Strip has been under blanket curfew since March 1988, near the start of the three-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. A 23-year-old man was found dead today in a valley outside his West Bank village of Shuyukh, near Hebron, Arab reports said. They said Mohammed Yunis Hussein was murdered for allegedly collaborating with Israel. His death raised the number of alleged collaborators killed during the uprising to 323. Another 786 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis soldiers and civilians, and 57 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Precede RIYADH
Vice President Assuring Troops, Seeking Continued Saudi Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs Quayle visit to troops, trims previous
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle today told Marines preparing for war near the Kuwaiti border that ``you have been patient enough and so has President Bush'' in waiting for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The fact is that a policy of indefinite patience only could lead to a policy of appeasement,'' which would make Iraq's President Saddam Hussein the victor in the gulf standoff, Quayle told the gathering of Marines. Quayle, on a New Year's morale building-mission, visited the Third Marine Aircraft Wing, the closest fixed-wing aircraft group to the border of occupied Kuwait. His tour, by helicopter and military truck through the deep desert sands, also took him to the Army Third Armored Cavalry Regiment out of Fort Bliss, Texas, which is closer to the border than any other troops President Bush has sent to the gulf. Quayle visited a base 40 miles from Kuwait. On Sunday he met Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, who gave assurances that his country would provide more cash and services to support the anti-Iraq coalition, senior administration officials said. Quayle, in brief remarks to the Marines, criticized members of Congress who urge waiting longer for the U.N.-imposed sanctions to force Saddam to withdraw his troops from Kuwait. ``You have heard some voices at home urging patience. They say wait a year or two, let the sanctions work,'' Quayle said. ``But the sanctions have not gotten Saddam out of Kuwait. You have been patient enough and so has President Bush.'' ``Saddam Hussein may not withdraw unconditionally, and if he doesn't he will be forced out of Kuwait by military action,'' the vice president said. Quayle reiterated Bush's promise that any force will be speedy and decisive and will not lead to a drawn-out conflict as in Vietnam. ``It may turn out that the only language Saddam Hussein understands is the language of force.'' Quayle mingled with the Marines and Army troops at the two sites where heavy action would be expected if war does occur, said Army Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller. At the Marine base he inspected Harrier fighter planes that Marine Maj. Jim McCLain said are only three minutes flying time from the border of occupied Kuwait. Quayle received a cordial greeting from the troops, most of whom told him they were prepared to do their job and were anxious to get it over with. His entourage inspected cluster bombs that had slogans inscribed on them such as ``Merry Christmas, no New Year.'' ``I'm nervous and scared. I'm not afraid to say that any more. We're sitting right on the verge of where there might be fighting,'' Lance Corp. Richard. Kamoe of Honolulu told a reporter. Quayle mentioned in his speech that his father and brother were both in the Marine Corps ``and not withstanding my own service in the Army National Guard, the Marines in the Quayle household are no.1,'' he said to applause. The controversy over Quayle's National Guard service seemed to make little impression on the young troops serving here. Quayle was accused when Bush selected him as his running mate of having used family connections to get a position in the Indiana National Guard and avoid being drafted and going to Vietnam. ``Other people have done worse things than him,'' said Marine Cpl. Kimberly Gender, of Bloomfield, Ind. Waller, who caused a firestorm of controversy by saying on December 19 that the troops would not be fully ready for combat by the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, escorted Quayle on his tour of the desert bases. Waller was reticent to discuss his earlier comment that he would recommend against launching an attack until mid-February. ``The component commanders have said they are ready,'' he told a reporter. ``My job is to support'' Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. operation here and the commanders of each of the services. Asked if he would be making a recommendation on whether to make a strike, he replied, ``no,... everyone has all the information they need to make that decision.'' Quayle's trip is also aimed at seeking continued financial support from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait's deposed rulers. He was assured Sunday by King Fahd that with the looming possibility of war, Saudi Arabia will offer more cash and services, said senior administration officials traveling with the vice president. ``There seems to be no problem'' with getting more money from Fahd, said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Quayle was assured by Fahd that the king had ``no reticence'' regarding a military conflict should that be needed to oust the Iraqis, said the U.S. official who briefed reporters on the meeting. Quayle and Fahd were in ``virtually complete agreement on what needs to be done'' to force Iraq out, but did not discuss details of what would happen after Jan. 15, the official said. In the meantime, Quayle told reporters he would impress on the Saudis and the exiled emir of Kuwait, when he meets him Tuesday, that ``they will have to be making more contributions'' to support the deployment of some 300,000 American troops. ``This crisis is going to continue,'' he said. An official who attended the Quayle-Fahd meeting said, ``The impression that was left was that (the Saudis) would continue to be forthcoming'' in financial and other support, such as free fuel. ``They don't want any perception of any reluctance on that issue.'' So far, Saudi Arabia has contributed $9 billion, nearly half of it in cash and the rest in material support, according to the State Department, and Kuwait has given $2.5 billion. Administration officials have estimated the operation will cost $30 billion in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Punk Rock Band's Concert Canceled After Melee
DOC.TEXT: Promoters called off a concert by the punk rock band Bad Religion a day after angry fans trashed a theater and damaged neighboring storefronts. Organizers said the concert at the Whisky A-Go-Go in West Hollywood was canceled Sunday night to avoid a repeat of the melee that erupted Saturday night after the group's concert at a North Hollywood theater was shut down. Fans hurled bottles, smashed store windows and ripped out seats after fire officials ordered the Classic Theater closed because of overcrowding. Two police officers and several people in the crowd suffered minor injuries in the fracas. Four people were arrested for investigation of vandalism. Lead singer Greg Gaffin said the melee was at odds with the message that Bad Religion is attempting to spread. ``What we try to do in our songs is make people responsible for their own actions,'' Gaffin said during the disturbance. The owners of the Classic Theater were cited Sunday on charge of overcrowding and improper use of the facility, which fire officials said was not licensed for live entertainment. Police estimated damage to the theater and surrounding businesses at $20,000. Fire officials said the theater was ordered closed after an inspector counted as many as 1,900 people in the building. The theater is permitted to seat 1,261, said fire spokesman Tony Ennis.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Marine Dies In Accidental Shooting
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine has died from an accidental gunshot wound inflicted when another Marine's M-16 rifle discharged, U.S. military officials said today. The shooting occurred Saturday morning, and an investigation into the incident is being conducted. The Marine was a member of the 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment. Officials did not identify the victim. The Marine was taken from a forward field position to a U.S. military medical facility where he was pronounced dead on arrival. He was under a doctor's care during transit, the officials said on condition of anonymity. His death brought the number of U.S. servicemen killed in Operation Desert Shield to 82, 77 of those deaths accidental. Three people died of natural causes and two of self-inflicted wounds.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Claims 4,200 Citizens Died Because Of Embargo
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's health minister claimed Monday that more than 4,200 people have died because of shortages in medical supplies brought on by a U.N. embargo. Western officials have repeatedly challenged similar Iraqi claims. Western officials say Iraq has received 120 tons of medicine from humanitarian groups since mid-October, and have dismissed Baghdad's claims on infant deaths since the embargo. The minister, Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said, accused President Bush of ``criminal action'' depriving the Iraqi people of their needs. In a statement carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, Said claimed that since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, said 2,042 children under age 5 have died of malnutrition or diseases that spread because vaccines could not be obtained. The statement, monitored in Cyprus, said 2,182 Iraqis over 5 have died because of shortages in medicines ``for various cardiac problems, cancers, diabetes and high blood pressure.'' Shipments of food and medicines for humanitarian purposes are not banned by the U.N. embargo begun after the Iraqi invasion. But Baghdad claims many governments have refused to allow export of goods, even medicines ordered and paid for before the sanctions. Western diplomats suggest that the government might be stockpiling medicine in case of war, and that some of the reported shortages resulted from profiteering. The claims of shortages have increased markedly since the U.N. Security Council passed a resolution on Nov. 29 authorizing military action against Iraq if it does not withdraw from Kuwait by mid-January.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Carrying Sludge Hits Molasses-Loaded Ship
DOC.TEXT: More than 1 million gallons of sludge seeped into New York Harbor after a municipal barge collided with a ship carrying molasses, the Coast Guard said today. The molasses didn't leak. The 380-foot barge Lemon Creek collided Sunday morning with the 433-foot-long Lodestar King as the ship was about to dock at an anchorage in the upper bay, said Petty Officer David Cook, a Coast Guard spokesman. The sludge leaked from an 18-inch hole below the barge's water line, Cook said. There were no leaks on the Lodestar, he said. The cause of the collision was not immediately determined, but fog definitely was a factor, Cook said. At the time of the collision, the Lemon Creek was being towed to the nearby Gravesend anchorage in New York harbor. The barge is normally used to transport municipal sludge to a dumping site 106 miles out to sea, he said. Early today, the ship was moored at Bay Ridge anchorage and the barge was at Gravesend anchorage, Cook said.

DOC.HEAD: Good Samaritan Locked in Car Trunk, Thieves Joyride
DOC.TEXT: A couple locked a good Samaritan in the trunk of her own car and then went for a joyride in it, laughing and talking for hours while she lay bound and gagged, authorities said. The victim was found Saturday, more than 24 hours after she was kidnapped, when someone noticed the parked car rocking up and down. The woman, whose name was withheld, told police that a man asked for her help outside a car repair shop about 11 a.m. Friday, saying he was having car trouble. The woman with him held a baby, said police spokeswoman Carmine Menchel. She told police the man got into her car, then pulled a gun and demanded her belongings. She gave them to him, said Menchel, and he forced her into the trunk, stuffed a towel into her mouth and taped it and her hands with masking tape. The victim, who is in her 30s, told Menchel the couple laughed and talked as they drove around for hours. When the car and the talking stopped the woman tried to scream but was unable to because of the gag, Menchel said. She rocked the car back and forth, and finally heard a passerby say, ``There's somebody in there.'' That person called police, who were able to open the trunk, Menchel said. The victim was treated at the scene, Menchel said.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Pursuit of Justice, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0430,0610
DOC.HEAD: Father Helps Crack Son's Murder After Four Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to delete `scumbag' vulgarism.
DOC.TEXT: Frustrated with the slow pace of justice after his only son was murdered four years ago, Joseph Viscido spent $50,000 investigating the case on his own. His dogged detective work finally paid off. Three men are jailed and awaiting trial on first-degree murder charges in the shooting death of Joseph Viscido Jr. Two of the defendants are to be tried in February. A third is fighting extradition to Florida from Rhode Island. ``I couldn't let them kill my son and get away with it,'' Viscido said. On Oct. 12, 1986, the younger Viscido was beaten and shot in the head in his Deerfield Beach apartment by two men who came to steal cocaine, police said. He was buried the day before his 28th birthday. Unlike many parents of murdered children, Viscido, a used-car dealer who had leased out his car lot, had both the money and the time to pursue the case after the official investigation bogged down. His surveillance and interviews took him as far away as Canada, New York, and Ohio. His information helped build a 1,300-page file and led last September to the indictments of Peter Dallas, Carl Stephen Rosati and Phillip Roussonicolos. During a recent interview at his Pompano Beach home, Viscido, 59, said avenging his son's death became an obsession. Depressed and frustrated after the slaying, he resumed smoking, after quitting 10 years ago. ``I felt I had three choices: I was either going to get killed, die of a broken heart or get enough evidenc to bring them to justice,'' Viscido said. The younger Viscido worked in the body shop of his father's used-car lot and dabbled in construction. But his life took a dangerous turn when he began using drugs and selling them to his friends, his father recalled. Viscido began his probe by talking to his son's friends. Several weeks after the murder, police gave him composite sketches of the gunmen. Viscido won't divulge many details of his tactics because the case awaits trial. However, he said police put a hidden microphone on him several times when he met with potential suspects or witnesses. Other times he took notes, which filled four notebooks. ``As I went along I got more professional,'' he said. When the case first came before a Broward grand jury in early 1989, no indictment was returned. But a second proceeding resulted in murder and robbery indictments against Rosati, 30; Dallas, 27; and Roussonicolos, 29. Dallas and Roussonicolos are in the Broward County Jail without bond, while Rosati is fighting extradition from Rhode Island. Roussonicolos set up the robbery and Dallas and Rosati were the gunmen, police alleged. Police and prosecutors give Viscido credit for cracking the case. ``He had perseverance beyond belief,'' said Sgt. Bill Murray of the Broward Sheriff's Office. However, Fort Lauderdale attorney John Howes, who is defending Roussonicolos, said prosecutors have a case only ``because the boy's father goes out and tape records conversations, which he probably doesn't have a right to do.'' Viscido and attorneys refused to say what the tapes contained. Viscido, who spent about $50,000 on the investigation, is writing a book about it. He encourages victims' families to help police, even when things seem bleak. ``For a while there I didn't think I could make it,'' Viscido said. ``I now have peace of mind knowing ... that they're going to pay.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Removes Harvard Scholar from Scrolls Project
DOC.TEXT: Israel today announced it has fired the American academic who led an effort to translate the Dead Sea Scrolls, the oldest known copies of the Old Testment. The decision came after the professor made anti-Jewish remarks. The announcement cited ``health reasons'' for removal of Harvard University professor John Strugnell from the project, but the 60-year-old scholar has been sharply criticized for an interview containing anti-Jewish remarks published in November in the Hebrew daily Haaretz. The project also had come under increasing fire for the slowness with which the scholars' work is being published. Strugnell has worked on the scrolls for more than three decades and has been editor of the scrolls project since 1987. Earlier in December, other scholars working on the project voted to have him replaced. The scrolls, some of which date to 100 B.C., were found starting in 1947 in caves near the Dead Sea. They contain the oldest known copies of the Old Testament, other biblical writings, ancient literature and poetry. In his announcement Monday, Amir Drori, the director of the Israel Antiquities Authority, said Strugnell was being relieved at the suggestion of the agency's three-man Scrolls Advisory Committee. Strugnell, who has been in ill health, was reported hospitalized in the United States. Drori said the remaining manuscripts would be edited by Emanuel Tov, an Israeli named to work with Strugnell in October. Tov, a professor at Hebrew University, is on a sabbatical in the Netherlands and could not be reached for comment. Magen Broshi, who is one of the members of the advisory committee, estimated that about 80 percent of the scrolls have been published and that what remains is complicated because it requires piecing together thousands of fragments. Still, he said, Strugnell before his removal had agreed to a timetable that should see the remaining documents published by 1997. Broshi is curator of the Israel Museum's Shrine of the book, where eight scrolls are displayed. The remainder are in the Rockefeller Museum. In the interview published Nov. 9 in Haaretz, Strugnell, who is Roman Catholic, described Judaism as ``a Christian heresy'' and suggested that its adherents should convert.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Calls Up 17-Year-Olds; EC Prepares To Talk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Yugoslav foreign minister conferring with Italian, German counterparts after meeting with Saddam, Iranian threats against U.S. and allies. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XRIY3
DOC.TEXT: Iraq today ordered 17-year-old males to report for military duty in the fourth major callup of reserves in recent weeks. European officials said a meeting with Iraq's foreign minister might be in the works. Saddam Hussein, in a New Year's message, condemned the United States and Saudi Arabia, where most of the multinational forces massed against him are deployed. ``In this confrontation, there have been those who betrayed Jesus Christ and who betrayed the principles and values of Islam, one luring and leading the other,'' the Iraqi president said. `May God curse them all.'' Saddam's 15-minute message was carried Sunday on CNN, which provided English subtitles. In Saudi Arabia, Vice President Dan Quayle today told Marines near the Kuwaiti border that ``you have been patient enough and so has President Bush'' in waiting for a peaceful solution. ``The fact is that a policy of indefinite patience only could lead to a policy of appeasement,'' which would make Saddam the victor in the gulf standoff, Quayle told the Marines. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from the emirate or face possible military action. Quayle, who arrived in the region Sunday, pressed Saudi Arabia's King Fahd for more financial support for the U.S. military buildup. Following Quayle's meeting with Fahd late Sunday, a U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there ``seems to be no problem'' on the issue. On the diplomatic front, there was a flurry of European activity. European Community foreign ministers announced plans to meet Friday in Luxembourg in an emergency session on the gulf crisis. Yugoslavia's foreign minister, Budimir Loncar, conferred by telephone with his Italian and German counterparts today, a day after meeting in Baghdad with Saddam, the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug reported. Diplomats and news reports said the Iraqi president rejected an appeal by Loncar on behalf of the non-aligned movement to withdraw from Kuwait. But Loncar was also quoted as saying he believed Saddam was interested in dialogue aimed at achieving a peaceful solution. Luxembourg's foreign minister, Jacques Poos, said some states in the community might well push for a meeting between him and his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz. Luxembourg takes over the community's rotating presidency on Tuesday. Poos said he would be ready to go to Baghdad if the foreign ministers made such a decision Friday. Asked if he thought he would be meeting Aziz in the near future, he replied: ``Yes, I think so.'' The community canceled a meeting with Aziz earlier this month after the United States and Iraq failed to agree on dates for direct talks. Poos said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. he expected there would be contact with Iraq either ``through diplomatic channels or a private talk.'' In Bonn, German officials speaking on condition of anonymity also speculated that European Community foreign ministers would discuss opening ``indirect talks'' with Iraq. However, Luxembourg Prime Minister Jacques Santer said today his country would not suggest any new EC peace initiative. He said the meeting should reaffirm the EC solidarity with the international community against the invasion. Luxembourg takes over the community's rotating presidency on Tuesday. Iraq's order for 17-year-old males to report for military duty came amid escalating preparations for war. The announcement, carried by the official Iraqi News Agency and Baghdad Radio, threatened those who fail to respond to the callup with unspecified ``legal action.'' Also today, Iraqi officials disclosed that 10 civil defense drills were conducted sucessfully in recent days in the northern Duhok province along the border with Turkey. The province's chief civil defense officer told the government newspaper Al-Thawra that the drills were aimed at ``preparing the population for war, air raids and mass-destruction weapons.'' In other developments: -Iran's spiritual leader today called the presence of U.S. troops in the gulf an ``aggression'' and said countries in the region would united against them. ``The Americans must know that the Islamic countries and world nations are disgusted with and deplore their presence in the Persian Gulf,'' said Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, in comments reported by the official Islamic Republic News Agency and monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. ``All Americans and their allies must know that the nations of the region will break the legs of each single aggressor.'' -Iraq's health minister claimed today that more than 4,200 people, about half of them children under 5 years old, have died because of shortages in medical supplies brought on by a U.N. embargo. The minister, Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said, accused the United States of ``criminal action'' in enforcing the economic embargo. Western officials have in the past expressed skepticism about similar Iraqi claims. The embargo allows for humanitarian shipments. -A U.S. Marine died from an accidental gunshot wound inflicted when another Marine's M-16 rifle discharged, U.S. military officials said today. The shooting, which occurred Saturday, is being investigated. The Marine was a member of the 3rd Battalion, 3rd Marine Regiment. He was not identified. The death brought the number of U.S. servicemen who have died in Operation Desert Shield to 82.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf At-A-Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at the latest developments in the Persian Gulf Crisis: --- Iraq on Monday ordered 17-year-old males to report for military duty in the fourth major callup of reserves in recent weeks. The order came amid escalating preparations for war. A brief announcement by the General Mobilization Headquarters instructed Iraqi men born in 1973 to sign up with the nearest recruitment center between Jan. 2 and Jan. 10. The announcement, carried by the official Iraqi News Agency and Baghdad Radio, threatened those who fail to respond to the callup with unspecified ``legal action.'' --- Iraq's Saddam Hussein, in a New Year's message, condemned the United States and Saudi Arabia, where most of the multinational forces against him are deployed. ``In this confrontation, there have been those who betrayed Jesus Christ and who betrayed the principles and values of Islam, one luring and leading the other,'' said Saddam. `May God curse them all.'' --- In Saudi Arabia, Vice President Dan Quayle told Marines on Monday near the Kuwaiti border that ``you have been patient enough and so has President Bush'' in waiting for a peaceful solution. ``The fact is that a policy of indefinite patience only could lead to a policy of appeasement,'' which would make Saddam the victor in the gulf standoff, Quayle told the Marines. --- Quayle, who arrived in the Gulf region Sunday, pressed Saudi Arabia's King Fahd for more financial support for the U.S. military buildup. Following Quayle's meeting with Fahd late Sunday, a U.S. official said there ``seems to be no problem'' the Saudi government would contribute more to the military buildup. The official spoke on condition of anonymity. The Pentagon has projected the cost of the deployment at $30 billion through the end of 1991, and much higher if there is war. Saudi Arabia has contributed $9 billion in cash and military support, and Kuwait has given $2.5 billion, U.S. officials said. --- On Sunday, the European Community decided to call an emergency meeting of its 12 foreign ministers in Luxembourg on Friday. The EC initiative was proposed Saturday by the German foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher. Luxembourg takes over the EC's presidency on Tuesday and its foreign minister, Jacques Poos, said some states in the community might well push for a meeting between him and his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz. --- Luxembourg Prime Minister Jacques Santer said on Monday his country would not suggest any new EC peace initiative. He said the meeting should reaffirm the EC solidarity with the international community against the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Wind Damages Jet, Cargo Building at Boston Airport
DOC.TEXT: Wind gusts damaged a passenger jet and a cargo building at Logan International Airport this morning, forcing at least one flight to be canceled and a terminal gateway to be closed. No injuries were reported. An unoccupied USAir 737-200 was pushed against a jetway in the incident, which occurred at about 4 a.m., said airline spokeswoman Susan Young. The leading edge of a wing was damaged, forcing USAir to take it out of service for at least a day and cancel an early-morning flight to Charlotte, N.C. The jetway, at Gate 8 of the terminal building, also was damaged and the gate was shut down, Young said. The airport authority said there was also damage to the roof of a freight and cargo building owned by the Hill Management Co. Company officials were inspecting the building, which is near the airport's Hilton Hotel, and were not available for comment. The wind cracked a window at the National Car Rental car-return building, and three cars had broken windshields, said John Grasso, a National spokesman. He estimated the damage at about $700. The National Weather Service reported wind gusts of 50 mph in the area at the time.

DOC.HEAD: 12 Guerrillas Killed In Israeli Air Raid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with police, PLO saying all 12 guerrillas killed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Israeli planes bombed a PLO guerrilla base near Sidon early today, killing all 12 of the fighters manning it, police and the PLO said. It was the highest death toll in 21 such attacks this year. The police report said the jets destroyed a one-story base belonging to Yasser Arafat's Fatah, the Palestine Liberation Organization's largest faction. The base was in a lemon grove 7{ miles southeast of Sidon, a southern port city that is the Palestinians' main stronghold in Lebanon. In Jerusalem, the Israeli military command said its planes returned safely to base after hitting ``a launching pad for attacks on Israel.'' The air raid came a day after Soviet-designed Katyusha rockets landed in Israel's self-designated security zone and across the border in northern Israel. The rockets caused no damage or injuries. Police and the PLO confirmed in separate statements that all the guerrillas were killed. ``There were no survivors. Those dug out alive died in ambulances before reaching hospital,'' a police spokesman said. He could not be named in line with standing rules. Police say 28 people were killed and 82 wounded in the 20 previous Israel raids into Lebanon this year. A PLO military communique issued in Tunis and sent to The Associated Press claimed the raid was part of a ``massive military operation'' Israel was planning in southern Lebanon. It said Israel pushed troop reinforcements ``estimated at two brigades'' into its self-designated security zone in southern Lebanon three days ago, but gave no other details. The reported buildup could not be independently confirmed. Fatah, the largest and oldest of nine groups under the PLO, marks the 26th anniversary of its foundation on Tuesday. Israel created the security zone in 1985 when it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon, ending a three-year occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Routs Hundreds in Indiana, Pennsylvania; One Killed In Rainstorms
LaserPhoto NA1
DOC.TEXT: Flooding caused by a weekend of rain and melting snow kept hundreds of people out of their homes today in the Ohio River Valley. A canoeist drowned in a flooded stream in Pennsylvania. About 100 deaths have been blamed on the weather since Dec. 18. Nearly every major stream in Indiana was flooding today and more than 1,000 people had fled their homes statewide. No injuries were reported there. About 450 people had fled their homes in western Pennsylvania. Flooding was occurring along every major river in Indiana, said Al Shipe, a hydrologist with the National Weather Service in Indianapolis. ``We'll be having a major flood on all of them. For the extensiveness, this is extremely unusual,'' Shipe said this morning. People had been evacuated in 17 of Indiana's 92 counties since Saturday and high water closed roads in at least 50 counties, authorities said. Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh issued a special directive Sunday night placing the National Guard on alert and ordering guardsmen to make armories available to flood evacuees. ``We basically have more locations where we have high water than we have signs to even mark it,'' said Joe Loughmiller of the state Department of Transportation. In western Pennsylvania, gauges at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport measured a record 2.49 inches of rain Sunday, pushing the month's rainfall to 8.24 inches, 2 inches greater than the previous record. The record-busting rainfall forced 450 people from their homes in Allegheny, Beaver and Butler counties because of high water. Emergency officials said most turned to relatives or friends and some spent the night in shelters at schools or volunteer fire departments. Some evacuees were allowed to return home today in parts of Ohio as rain ended or turned to snow. In LaRue in north-central Ohio, about 40 residents of a senior citizens' home were evacuated Sunday night after the Scioto River overran its banks, Mayor Kelly Davids said. In the Cleveland suburb of Valley View, about 75 people who were evacuated from their homes Sunday were still not permitted to return early today, said Fire Chief Joe Sway. ``The water has been receding, probably by 6 feet, but a good deal of the village is still impassable,'' Sway said. ``Plus, there's a freezing problem now, a coating of ice in some places.'' Streams also overflowed in parts of West Virginia but few evacuations were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Speaker Of Texas House, Indicted On Ethics Charges, Turns Self In
DOC.TEXT: Texas House Speaker Gib Lewis, indicted on two misdemeanor ethics charges, was booked today and released on his own recognizance, authorities said. Sgt. James Johnson of the sheriff's department said Lewis turned himself in at the Travis County jail about 7:30 a.m. and was released 20 minutes later. Glenn Smith, a publicist working for Lewis, said the speaker had no immediate comment but might issue a statement later in the day. Lewis, a Democrat from Fort Worth, was indicted Friday by a Travis County grand jury on misdemeanor charges. He is accused of receiving a gift from a San Antonio law firm, Heard, Goggan Blair & Williams, and not reporting report the benefit on his public financial disclosure statement. The charges stem from a tax payment made by the law firm for business taxes owed by Lewis, said Travis County District Attorney Ronnie Earle. The booking was ``rather a quick process,'' said Sheriff's Capt. Melissa Caldwell. She said Lewis was wearing a suit and tie and accompanied by three other people. Lewis' attorneys claim the indictments were politically motivated and said earlier that he would plead innocent. If convicted on the two counts, Lewis faces a maximum of 18 months in jail and $3,000 in fines. The grand jury investigation is continuing, and Earle says it has expanded to include more legislators and lobbyists. Lewis said he plans to seek an unprecedented fifth two-year term as speaker when the 1991 Legislature convenes on Jan. 8. On Sunday, The Dallas Morning News reported that Lewis shared an $800-a-night hotel suite with a 24-year-old receptionist from Heard Goggan during a Mexican vacation paid for the firm. Lewis and Toni Barcellona, a former receptionist for the law firm who is now a lobbyist, were among six men and six women who spent three days together in April 1987 at a resort near Acapulco, Mexico, the paper said. The newspaper said it gleaned details of the trip from interviews with people who went along and with some people who have been questioned by the Travis County grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: London's Christmas Tree Attacked with Chain Saw
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with tree restored to position, man jailed, motive. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: The Christmas tree in London's Trafalgar Square was attacked with a chainsaw early today, hours before the 100-foot Norwegian fir was to be the centerpiece of a huge New Year's party on the square. The attacker was arrested and jailed. He told police the attack on the tree, a gift from Norway, was a protest of Norway's legal system. Tree surgeons announced they had managed to save the tree.
