They lifted the fir by crane and trimmed damaged parts of the trunk, police said. It had now been restored to its usual position, police said. Magistrates at London's Bow Street court jailed Patrick Harwood-Duffy, 36, of Brixton, south London, for four months after he admitted causing criminal damage estimated at $6,100 to the tree. Harwood-Duffy told police he was protesting against the ``unfairness'' of Norway's legal system, where he served a jail term for heroin smuggling. His lawyer, John Hardy, said Harwood-Duffy was frustrated by the long delay before his case was heard. He had been released in August after 11 months in solitary confinement, Hardy said. Scotland Yard said Harwood-Duffy jumped over barriers around the tree early today and managed to saw a good way through the trunk. Police at first thought it may have to be scrapped. The tree, which stands in the square through Christmas and New Year, was under police guard today in advance of the raucous street party traditionally staged in Trafalgar Square on New Year's Eve. A tree is shipped annually from Norway as a gift to the British people for their efforts in World War II to defeat the Germans, who had invaded and occupied Norway.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Fighting Reported in Somali Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with conflicting reports over who controls city; diplomat says heavy fighting continuing, prime minister's appeal. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Heavy fighting broke out today in Mogadishu, the capital of the east African nation of Somalia, and there were conflicting reports over who was in control of the city. Rebels claimed to have seized the presidential palace and nearly all of the city, but said there were still ``pockets of resistance'' around the capital, according to the Italian news agency Ansa. But a diplomat contacted by telephone from Rome said the palace was still in the hands of the government forces. The diplomat said there was fighting in the city center with bazookas, mortar fire and light cannon. He said there had been casualties, but did not have a figure. The diplomat also said Prime Minister Mohamed Hawadleh Madhar had made a radio appeal for government forces to retreat to their barracks. In Washington, a senior State Department official described the situation in the capital as ``very fluid.'' ``I don't think anybody controls anything. Nobody really knows who controls what,'' the U.S. official said on condition of anonymity. He added the government's control of the country has been very tenuous for some time. Most official Americans have long since left the country as a precautionary measure, leaving the U.S. Embassy operating with a very small staff. The official said fighting appeared to have subsided by the evening. Earlier today, a group representing more than 100 leading Somali dissidents and former politicians called for a cease-fire and the formation of an interim government, according to the BBC. The dissidents, calling themselves the Manifesto Group, called for the army to be confined to barracks and for the rebels to lay down their arms, the BBC reported. Somalia's President Mohamed Siad Barre, who is normally under heavy guard by an elite unit of fanatically loyal soldiers, was holed up in a bunker at the international airport, according to the Mogadishu-based diplomat and other sources. The rebels claimed to have taken control of large areas around the airport, according to Ansa. The BBC reported that today fighting was a continuation of battles that broke out Sunday after armed attackers broke into a warehouse and killed a senior army officer. t least 20 people were killed Sunday and more than 50 wounded, according to the BBC. Shooting was heard throughout the night in Mogadishu and machine gun and rocket-propelled grenade fire could be heard during the day, according to sources in Nairobi, the capital of neighboring Kenya, and the BBC. The BBC reported artillery fire could be heard around the presidential palace. The diplomatic sources were in sporadic contact by radiotelephone with their embassies and offices in the Somali capital. Regular telephone and telex lines were not working. Gunbattles have been reported in Mogadishu almost every day for the past two weeks, and most aid organizations and Western embassies have withdrawn all but essential staff because of the accelerating breakdown in order. The United Somali Congress, a recently formed group which springs from the large, central Hawiye clan, were reportedly fighting within 30 miles of the capital. However, rebel supporters and representatives could be found in Mogadishu, according to recent visitors. In addition to the United Somali Congress, Siad Barre is challenged in the north by the more established Somali National Movement, which draws its strenth from the Isaaq clan. It has been fighting since 1982 for the removal of Siad Barre, a member of the Marehan clan who seized power in a bloodless 1969 coup. The rebel groups are loosely coordinated. They have twice rejected government calls for negotiations in the past month, saying they prefer to remove Siad Barre at gunpoint. The United States has been Siad Barre's strongest ally since the late 1970s. In recent years, major human rights organizations have increasingly accused Siad Barre's government of a long list of abuses, including massacres, torture, imprisonment of political prisoners without charge or trial and corruption. Somalia, which had been colonized in the north by the British and in the south by Italy, became independent and united in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Carbon Dioxide Leak from Tanker Injures 18
DOC.TEXT: Carbon dioxide gas leaked from a truck Monday in a busy industrial zone, injuring 18 people, police and a hospital official said. Ahuva Ivri, a city police spokeswoman, said the non-toxic gas apparently seeped out of a valve on the vehicle, which was parked in the Nahlat Yitzhak Quarter. Police had not determined whether the leak was accidental, Ivri said. Streets in the area were blocked off, tying up traffic in the heart of Israel's business capital, Israeli radio said. Dr. Bianca Lederman of Ichilov Hospital said 15 people were admitted suffered slight breathing difficulties and three others were in moderate condition. All were treated with oxygen masks, she said on Army radio. Ms. Lederman said the gas was expected to evaporate near the site of the leak without causing further injury.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officers Arrested in Murder of Greek Shipping Executive
DOC.TEXT: Three federal police agents have been arrested in the slaying of a Greek shipping executive, major newspapers reported Monday. ``It was not the federal police who committed this crime but bandits, cancerous cells that infiltrated the force,'' federal police director Romeu Tuma told the daily newspaper Rio de Janeiro. Tuma said a 9mm pistol, believed to be the murder weapon, and nearly $20,000 of up to $80,000 stolen from the victim had been recovered. Konstadinos Petychakis, a representative for the Greek company Tsakos Shipping and Trading, was found shot to death on Dec. 20, two hours after he was seen getting into a federal police car at Galeao International Airport, authorities say. His bullet-ridden body was found in a field near a road from the airport to downtown Rio. Petychakis had arrived from neighboring Uruguay with a briefcase full of cash to pay the crew of a tanker leased to the state oil monopoly Petrobras.

DOC.HEAD: Fourteen People Die In Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: A bus fell off a winding cliff highway in northeastern Colombia, killing 14 people, police said on Monday. The bus was carrying holiday travelers on Sunday near the town of Cimitarra when it apparently moved over too far on the highway to let another vehicle pass, a police report said. The bus knocked down a metal railing lining the highway and fell about 330 feet, the police said.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Slowdown Could Cost An Additional 1 Million Jobs in 1991
DOC.TEXT: The New Year will bring tough economic times, according to many forecasters who say 1991 will begin with America in a mild recession that could cost an additional 1 million jobs. Inflation will moderate somewhat in 1991 according to these estimates, and interest rates for mortgages, car loans and other purchases should drift downward in the coming months. These economic forecasters express optimism that the recession could end sometime in midyear, in part because of expanded export sales and improvements in the housing industry. But there's a catch: a war in the Persian Gulf that damages oil production facilities could lead to a deeper, more severe downturn. ``Anything that gets the crisis over with in a hurry, whether it is a quick war or a quick peace, helps the economy,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill Inc. ``But if the crisis drags out and it keeps oil prices high and consumer confidence low, then that will make the recession worse.'' Other dangers could scuttle hopes that the recession will be a brief one, ranging from the huge consumer, business and government debt left over from the 1980s to signs of serious weakness in the nation's banking system. And the most recent indicators are discouraging. The government announced on Friday that its chief economic forecasting gauge, the Index of Leading Indicators, fell 1.2 percent in November for the fifth monthly drop in a row. ``The basic message is there's no light down there in the tunnel that we can see,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Co. in Chicago. ``The recession is clearly in place and clearly has further to go.'' Not everyone is as pessimistic. ``There is a list of risks to the forecast as far as the eye can see,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``But the most optimistic prospect is that by midyear some sort of recovery will be emerging.'' ``By this time next year, I believe we will all feel a little better about our economic opportunities and the pessimism that seems pervasive now will be a distant memory,'' said Mark Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates of West Chester, Pa. For the record, the arbiter of recessions, the National Bureau of Economic Research, has not officially declared that the country is in a downturn but the group of distinguished academics has come awfully close. In a statement released last week, they said it was likely that the bureau would end up pinpointing a month between June and September as the start of the country's ninth recession since the end of World War II. However, the panel said that it did not have enough information yet to make such a call and would meet again after Jan. 25. That is the date the Commerce Department releases its first look at overall economic activity in the quarter from October through December. Many economists believe the report will show the gross national product declined sharply during this period. The general definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of declining GNP. While the Bush administration has yet to use the word recession, it too is inching closer. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has talked of a serious slowdown in the fourth quarter and said there was a possibility that the weakness would continue into the first three months of 1991. Following is a look at how analysts believe a variety of economic barometers will perform in 1991: -GNP: Estimates on the amount that the total output of goods and services will shrink during the recession range from less than 0.6 percent to above 2 percent. The average drop in output in the eight previous post-World War II recessions is 2.6 percent. Given the fact that analysts believe there will be a rebound in the second half of 1991, they are forecasting a modest GNP increase of around 0.4 percent for the year as a whole. -UNEMPLOYMENT: The jobless rate, which had fallen as low as 5.2 percent earlier in 1990, rose to 5.9 percent in November as the economic slowdown showed up in layoffs and production cutbacks. Analysts predicted that the unemployment rate would rise to around 7 percent before beginning to improve. Each percentage point increase in the jobless rate translates into about 1 million more people out of work. -INFLATION: The one bright spot for 1991 is the widespread belief that consumer prices, which shot up at an annual rate of 6.4 percent in the first 11 months of 1990, will moderate. Many forecasters are predicting the Consumer Price Index will rise less than 4 percent in 1991 although they caution that this prediction is based on an assumption that the Persian Gulf crisis will be resolved without pushing oil prices higher for a sustained period. -INTEREST RATES: The Federal Reserve, which has already pushed short-term interest rates down by a full percentage point in the past two months, will keep lowering rates to rekindle economic growth. Sinai said he was looking for banks' prime rate, the benchmark rate for many business and consumer loans, to be around 8.5 percent by next summer. The prime rate at many banks is currently 10 percent. Analysts were also forecasting that mortgage rates, currently at 9.6 percent for fixed-rate loans, will drop as low as 9 percent next year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Plans Quiet New Year's Eve At Camp David
DOC.TEXT: President Bush plans to spend a quiet New Year's Eve with his wife, his daughter and two grandchildren at Camp David, the White House said Monday. The Bushes have not invited any outsiders to ring in 1991 at the presidential retreat in the Cacoctin Mountains of Maryland about 60 miles from here, aides said. The president went to Camp David before Christmas. He has remained there throughout the holidays, coming back to Washington only for one day to handle paperwork. Bush plans to return to the White House Tuesday. Aides said they had no idea whether Bush would stay up for midnight. Joining Bush for New Year's Eve are First Lady Barbara Bush, Dorothy Bush LeBlond, his daughter, and her two children, Sam, 6, and Ellen, 4. Dorothy LeBlond is divorced from her husband. Bush's four sons were with the family for Christmas, but have left Camp David. Bush's low-key New Year's Eve is a sharp contrast from the annual party that former President Reagan attended in Palm Springs, Calif. The celebrity-studded event was hosted by publisher Walter Annenberg.

DOC.HEAD: Scots Get Haggis, French Fois Gras, But New Year Low-Key
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT spelling of foie gras in 1st, 12 grafs; RECASTS 2nd graf to show that military strike is possible after Jan. 15 but not definite; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Scots dined on haggis, the French had foie gras and the Americans enjoyed steak and a radio special by comedian Robin Williams. But New Year's celebrations for the gulf troops were generally low-key. The important date for the troops is Jan. 15, the U.N. deadline for Iraq to get out of Kuwait or face a possible military strike to drive it from the emirate. Although soldiers yearned for a cup of kindness, New Year's was non-alcoholic because of Saudi Arabia's strict Muslim ban on liquor. ``There's no booze. What are you going to do? Have another Coke?'' said Marine Col. M.L. Haiman, 49, of the Bronx, New York. ``People have their eye on the 15th of January.'' The troops in the multinational force have been on heightened alert throughout the holidays in case Iraqi President Saddam Hussein launches a pre-emptive strike. ``It's a prime time for the other side to come after us, on our holidays when they think our guard might slip. If they think that, they're wrong,'' said Haiman. The only official celebrations were by the approximately 3,000 men of the Scottish regiments in the British 1st Armored Division, made up of the 4th Armored Brigade and the 7th Armored Brigade, the famed Desert Rats. ``All the Scots will want to celebrate Hogmanay,'' said division spokesman Capt. James Myles, using the Scottish term for the holiday. The Scots ate a traditional meal of haggis and mashed turnips, ushered into the camps by bagpipes. Haggis is made of the heart, liver and lungs of a sheep or calf, and minced with onions, oatmeal and boiled in the stomach of an animal. The 6,000 French troops toasted with ``Saudi champagne'' - a mixture of apple juice and Perrier. ``Our own costs a lot more, but for that we'll have to wait for our return,'' said Adjutant Robert Simon, spokesman for the French forces. Special food like chocolate and foie gras - duck liver pate - had been flown in from France, he said. Many U.S. troops said they had not even thought about the holiday due to their fierce training schedules, but there were some small celebrations. Many units barbecued steaks left over from Christmas. ``I'm going to get myself a six-pack of near-beer and have a near-party and sit around and play some cards,'' said Staff Sgt. David Hebert, 30, of Brickton, N.J., in the 3rd Platoon of the Army's 595th Medical Company. Many troops planned to tune in to a Robin William's special, pre-recorded for the Armed Forces Radio Network. Williams, re-enacting his radio role of Adrian Kronauer in the film ``Good Morning, Vietnam,'' yelled, ``Good Maaawwwrning, Saaauuudi'' and then told jokes like, ``Is it just me, or does Yasser Arafat look like Ringo Starr?'' While Saudis educated in the West tend to celebrate New Year's with private parties at home, as do foreigners living here, it's not an official Moslem holiday The Muslims follow a lunar calendar and their new year marks the date when the prophet Mohammed, founder of the faith, emigrated in the 7th century from Mecca to Medina, both now holy shrines in Saudi Arabia. Their new year falls on July 12, 1991, on the Christian calendar. There was one almost universal New Year's resolution among the troops. ``They're all the same. I know what they all are: To leave and go home,'' said Staff Sgt. Johnnie Montgomery, 27, of Annaston, Ala., of the 96th Civil Affairs Battalion.

DOC.HEAD: Steps Taken To Speed Extradition Of Supremacist Charged with Evers Murder
DOC.TEXT: White supremacist Byron De La Beckwith was arrested for a second time in less than two weeks today on a warrant stemming from the 1963 slaying of civil rights leader Medger Evers. In a move intended to speed his transfer from Tennessee to Mississippi, Beckwith, 70, was arrested on a murder warrant, and an extradition hearing was scheduled for Wednesday. He had been arrested Dec. 18 on a fugitive warrant from Mississippi, where he has twice been tried for the murder of Evers. The arrests followed a new murder indictment returned by a grand jury in Hinds County, Miss. Evers was field secretary for the NAACP when he was killed by a sniper's bullet in front of his Jackson, Miss., home on June 12, 1963. Both of Beckwith's previous trials were heard by all-white juries and ended deadlocked. The charges were dropped in 1969 but the was reopened amid charges of jury and evidence tampering. His extradition hearing had been set for Feb. 22, but that was moved up to Wednesday after extradition papers were signed by Gov. Ray Mabus of Mississippi and Gov. Ned McWherter of Tennessee. Hamilton County Detective Linda Clark called the matter ``one of the fastest extradition proceedings on record.'' Beckwith is due to appear Wednesday before Criminal Court Judge Joe DeRisio in Chattanooga. Beckwith had been free on bond pending an extradition hearing. No bond was set for Beckwith when he was arrested today. Beckwith has vowed to fight extradition, calling the new charges ``nonsense, poppycock and just something to stir the people up.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Bombs PLO Bases, 12 Guerrillas Killed
DOC.TEXT: Israel unleashed its deadliest air attack of the year on Lebanon Monday, killing 12 PLO guerrillas in a predawn raid near Sidon. Police and the Palestine Liberation Organization confirmed in separate statements that there were no survivors among Yasser Arafat's Fatah guerrillas at the base. The Lebanese police report said two F-15 fighter-bombers struck 20 minutes past midnight Sunday. They dropped two 1,500-pound bombs that flattened the two-story villa occupied by the guerrillas. It was Israel's 21st raid on Lebanon this year. The Israeli command said its planes returned safely after hitting ``a launching pad for attacks on Israel.'' Fatah, the largest and oldest of nine groups under the PLO, marks the 26th anniversary of its founding on Tuesday, New Year's Day. The base was in a lemon grove 7{ miles southeast of Sidon, a police spokesman said. ``There were no survivors. Those who were dug out from the rubble alive died in ambulances before reaching hospital,'' the spokesman said. He could not be identified in line with standing rules. A PLO statement issued in Sidon said the bodies of all 12 Fatah fighters were recovered before bulldozers were brought in to clear the rubble. Guerrillas dispatched from Sidon's Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp looked through the debris for hours to salvage weapons and ammunition from the destroyed base. ``It was a disaster. Our comrades were caught unawares,'' one guerrilla told reporters. He refused to give his name. By police count, 28 people were killed and 82 wounded in the 20 previous strikes this year. The heaviest death toll came in a strike on Arpil 20, when six guerrillas of the pro-Iranian fundemantalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, were killed. A PLO communique telefaxed to The Associated Press in Nicosia, Cyprus, warned that Israel was preparing for a ``massive military operation'' in southern Lebanon. The communique claimed Israel pushed troop reinforcements ``estimated at two brigades'' into its self-designated ``security zone'' in southern Lebanon three days ago. But security sources in the region said there were no abnormal Israeli military movements in the zone. They also claimed that no surface-to-surface missiles were deployed in the zone or elsewhere in south Lebanon. Israel carved out the zone in 1985, when it withdrew the bulk of its invading forces from Lebanon, ending a three-year occupation. The enclave covers 440 square miles from the Mediterranean coast to the foothills of Mount Hermon. Western military sources say that about 6,000 PLO guerrillas are based in and around Sidon, the provincial capital of southern Lebanon 25 miles south of Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: San Diego Zoo's Official Greeter For 64 Years Dies
DOC.TEXT: King Tut, a grand-old cockatoo that greeted millions of visitors to the San Diego Zoo during the bird's 64 years as official greeter, has died. King Tut was at least 67 years old, spokesman Jeff Jouett said. The salmon-crested bird had fallen from its perch and was found Sunday after zookeepers heard odd squawking noises from the bird yard, Jouett said. Veterinarians tried to revive the male bird with oxygen and cardiopulmonary resuscitation. It was donated to the zoo in 1925 and was named King Tut because its arrival came shortly after the discovery of King Tutankhamen's tomb in Egypt. The bird delighted more than 100 million zoo visitors from his perch next to the flamingo lagoon with antics that included whistling and imitations of crying babies, meowing cats, clucking chickens and other species of birds. It also appeared in motion pictures and television shows, including an early episode of ``The Mickey Mouse Club.'' Bothered by arthritis and cataracts in both eyes, King Tut was retired from the greeters' perch just inside the entrance in June 1989. It was then moved to the education department and appeared at special events, school programs and zoo tours. The life expectancy of cockatoos generally is three to four decades, said Jouett. Some have lived into their 60s, and Jouett knows of one that was in its 80s before dying.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Workers Hurt in Scaffolding Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts throughout to UPDATE with 10th worker rescued, move up size of boiler, give full name of `Con Ed.' No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A scaffolding collapsed this morning inside a huge boiler at a Staten Island power plant, injuring 10 workers including one who was trapped in debris nearly 2{ hours, authorities said. Marty Gitten, a spokesman for Consolidated Edison, said the scaffolding partially collapsed shortly after 10 a.m. The men were working inside a boiler that was being overhauled at the utility's Arthur Kill 3 generating unit, he said. The fire department put the height of the scaffolding at more than 100 feet. Tom Kelly, a fire department spokesman, said the last worker to be rescued was pulled out at 12:30 p.m. ``He's conscious, talking and being evaluated,'' Kelly said. Of the 10 workers, at least two were seriously injured, the city's Emergency Medical Service said. Gitten said it was not immediately apparent what caused the accident at the plant, which is located on the western side of the island.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless `Family' Cares for Each Other
LaserPhoto BX5
DOC.TEXT: They are homeless, but three couples and a man they took in have made a home out of a ramshackle camp on an unused railroad track. Every day, Reggie and Isabelle Evon, Jeannette and Donald Benson, Jimmy and Terri Kelly and Eugene Sullivan laugh, talk, eat and argue together. And in a world that seems not to care for them, they care for each other, like a family. ``We're homeless but we're not homeless,'' said Evon, the group's informal leader. ``Once in awhile we have arguments, but everybody has a good time here.'' They have held jobs and lived ``normal'' lives in the past. But somewhere along the line a job was lost or the rent was raised, and they found themselves on the streets. But while they want to return to their old lives, they'll choose an independent life in the camp over a homeless shelter any day. ``I've had it with shelters,'' said Ms. Benson, 44. ``You have no privacy there. They go through your personal belongings, or they throw your stuff out. Here I don't have to go to bed at 9 o'clock like a little kid.'' The camp sits in a ravine at the end of an unused Conrail track. Planted squarely on the track is the Evons' house, a large plywood shack that Evon built with scrap supplies. Sullivan and the other couples live in more modest tents. And there are 14 stray dogs and cats. The group is bound by ties of family and marriage, and by the solidarity born of life on the streets. Isabelle Evon, 32, and Terri Kelly, 31, are sisters who grew up in Boston. Both had several husbands before meeting Reggie and Jimmy. Reggie Evon, 37, was a truck driver before coming to Boston from Colorado four years ago. Jimmy Kelly, 35, came from Oklahoma City to be a house painter. But there was never enough work. Along the way they met Jeannette and Donald Benson, 46, from Malden, who have worked odd jobs and been in and out of shelters together for years. Sullivan joined the group when Evon found him sleeping under a bridge on a rainy day. ``He was shivering real bad, and I said, `Come on over,''' Evon said. Sullivan, in his 50s, came to Boston from Tennessee 15 years ago. He married, had several children and was divorced. He has been on the streets since 1987. Some go out ``canning'' - collecting recyclable aluminum cans for the deposit money. Evon does odd jobs at a nearby produce market for food, and Kelly sometimes finds work in day labor pools. Meals can be found at soup kitchens and shelters. ``I get up, grab a bite to eat and go canning. Then I come back and argue with everybody,'' Kelly said, laughing. ``It's tough in the winter; you wake up in the morning and the water is ice,'' he added. ``But I can get showers at friends' houses. And the labor pools keep me in beer and cigarette money.'' The source of their troubles is not just economic. Kelly said he has had run-ins with the law. A psychiatrist told Ms. Benson she is chronically depressed. Benson drinks cheap wine before noon. Joking and laughter fill the camp. But the veneer of cheeriness is punctured when a reminder of the past comes flooding in. For Ms. Evon, that happens once a week when she and her husband have a 90-minute visit in a state agency with their two daughters, ages 1 and 2. The girls were placed in foster care when officials decided the shack wasn't a home. She lost three other children to the state in the same way. ``I was being discharged from the hospital and they said I couldn't take my baby home,'' Ms. Evon recalled. ``I started crying and trying to punch everyone in sight.'' Without a child to mother, she snuggles one of the skinny kittens under her coat. Sullivan thinks about his old life whenever his daughter visits him at the camp. ``I don't like this life, I didn't want to stay here,'' he said. ``You can't go back, though. You can't walk in looking like a bum.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Authorities Investigating Alleged Price Fixing of Baby Formula
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to restore dropped budget designator
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities investigating alleged price fixing in the baby formula business have subpoenaed company records and the files of an infant health group that opposes formula advertising on grounds it would discourage breast feeding. Company officials said Monday the subpoenas were issued by the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Competition. Antoinette Parisi Eaton, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, said the records subpoenaed from the academy dealt mainly with its position in opposition to infant formula advertising. ``Breast feeding rates in this country are already going down,'' Ms. Eaton said. ``We have concerns that massive advertising campaigns promoting infant formula are going to further reduce the number of women who will consider breast feeding.'' Debbie Feinstein, assistant to the director of the Bureau of Competition, said she understands there has been limited advertising of baby formula, but ``certainly it is not the kind of thing that you see on TV.'' ``To the extent that there is any kind of agreement not to advertise, that would be something that would be a cause for antitrust concern,'' Ms. Feinstein said. ``We are not taking a position on whether or not advertising is good or bad or infant formula is good or bad, but the things we have heard are that infant formula is a very concentrated industry and one of the reasons it might be hard for people to enter is because there is not any advertising,'' she said. Ms. Feinstein said the investigation was launched in late May after the bureau received price fixing allegations from state welfare officials and consumer advocates. Infant formula is a major ingredient of food packages given to low-income families who qualify for the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children. The federally funded program, known as WIC, serves about 4.4 million people a month and accounts for one-third of the infant formula sold in the United States. Kevin J. Arquit, director of the bureau, testified before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee in May that the agency had received complaints from state directors of the program about alleged anti-competitive practices in the industry. Company officials testifying before the subcommittee said their prices are fair. Audrey Ashby, a spokesman for Wyeth Ayerst Laboratories, one of the principal manufacturers of formula, said the company received the FTC subpoena in September and has begun turning over the requested documents. ``We set prices independently and compete vigorously and independently in all aspects of the infant formula business,'' Ms. Ashby said. Wyeth-Ayerst is a division of the American Home Products Corp. According to a story in The New York Times on Monday, records were also subpoenaed from Ross Laboratories, a division of Abbott Laboratories; the Mead-Johnson Nutritional Group, a division of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.; the Carnation Co., a subsidiary of Nestle S.A.; and the Gerber Products Co. Officials of some of the companies could not be reached because of the New Year's holiday, and Ms. Feinstein said the FTC could not confirm that subpoenas had been issued. Mead Johnston, Ross Laboratories and Wyeth Laboratories make about 90 percent of the infant formula sold in the United States, according to testimony before the Senate subcommittee. The domestic market has been estimated at about $1.3 billion a year. ``This is a high-priority investigation,'' Ms. Feinstein said. She said it was not possible to say how long it could take before the commission decided whether any price fixing had occurred. Dennis Bach, who heads the WIC program in Iowa and the National Association of WIC Directors, said, ``Over the last 10 years there has been a fairly consistent pattern of the major companies increasing their prices on the average of once a year, often within a day or two of each other and often by virtually the same percentage.'' Bach said the wholesale price of formula had increased by about 150 percent during this period and now stands at around $1.90 for a 13-ounce can of concentrate. He said retail prices vary from 5 cents to 50 cents above that.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Bush Greetings to the Soviets
With Bush-Presidential Greetings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's videotaped New Year's greetings to the Soviet people, to be broadcast on New Year's Day: It's a great a pleasure to wish President and Mrs. Gorbachev and all the peoples of the Soviet Union a happy and healthy New Year. In your country, and in mine, the start of a New Year is a good time to reflect on the many achievements of the past and to look ahead with hope. This year our two countries, as well as those around the world, have much to be grateful for. First and foremost, the improved and strengthened relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. Our countries have made great progress, particularly in important political and arms control areas. And we've taken a common approach to a new challenge in the name of stability and peace. I applaud, the world applauds, the decisive action of the Soviet Union in strongly opposing Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression in the Gulf. But just as important as these new areas of cooperation between our two nations are the increased contacts between the Americans and Soviet peoples. Tens of thousands of Soviets have had contact with Americans now, and the numbers are growing. Barbara and I are thrilled to see our two peoples meeting and getting to know one another as friendly neighbors. On this New Year's Day, as you celebrate with your friends and family, I also want to applaud the Soviet Union for the important steps you've taken in building a new society, for the determination with which you are pressing forward with difficult political and economic reforms. It's an arduous journey, but one well worth making, for it is a path that leads to a brighter future for your nation. The American people look with hope to the year ahead. Our two nations have set out on a new course making a better life for both our peoples and a better world of peace and understanding. On behalf of the American people, I wish President Gorbachev and all the wonderful people of the Soviet Union a happy, prosperous New Year.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede ATHENS
Hundreds More Albanians Cross Border Into Greece
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with more than 600 Albanians crossing today into Greece. Pickup 4th pvs, `Israeli media...'
DOC.TEXT: Surprised Greek officials struggled to put up hundreds of newly arrived Albanian refugees in makeshift shelters today, and Albanian Jews were arriving in Israel under relaxed travel restrictions. Hundreds more Albanians trekked across frozen mountains and rivers today in the biggest exodus from their country since its Communist government promised reforms last summer. Military sources in the northwestern Greek border town of Filiates said today that 632 Albanians, most of them ethnic Greeks, had crossed the frontier since daybreak. On Sunday, at least 500 Albanians arrived in northern Greece seeking political asylum. In addition, 37 Jews flew to Rome from the Albanian capital of Tirana en route to Israel. So far this month, more than 1,600 people from the tiny Balkan nation of 3.3 million have fled into Greece across the once tightly sealed 100-mile frontier. Israeli media reported today that four Albanian Jewish families had arrived in Israel and dozens more were expected in coming weeks. Israel radio said the Albanian immigration was made possible by a recent agreement by Italy with Albania, the last of the hard-line Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. But Israeli government officials were tight-lipped about the immigration of Albanian Jews, apparently fearful of harming the effort. ``This is going to save Albanian Jews from total extinction. Had they remained there, they would have been wiped out in a generation,'' said Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum, a consultant to the American Jewish Committee in New York. The Albanian Jewish community numbers only about 1,000, officials said. The arrival of the Albanian Jews comes as Israel struggles to cope with a huge wave of arriving Soviet Jews. Greek officials, too, were overwhelmed by the sudden influx. ``It looks like there are whole villages crossing - it's a madhouse up here,'' said a police spokesman in the Greek border village of Filiates on Sunday. ``Our police station has become a refugee center,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We don't know what to do with all these people.'' He said it appeared the Albanian government had opened its frontier with Greece. ``There can be no other explanation,'' he said. ``A mosquito couldn't get across the border before.'' Police have reported that Albanian border guards killed at least five people trying to cross the frontier in recent weeks. Last week, the Greek government charged that Albanians were murdering many ethnic Greeks who tried to flee. Greece claims that more than 350,000 ethnic Greeks live in southern Albania. The Albanian government says the figure is 60,000. The Albanian Jews who left Sunday were the first in a planned operation dubbed ``Flying Carpet'' to take an estimated 500 Jews out of Albania, said Shula Bahat, a spokeswoman for the American Jewish Committee in New York. Vladimir Prela, head of the Albanian Foreign Ministry's press office, said in a telephone interview from Tirana on Sunday that a new government policy allows anyone to leave Albania if they wish. In Israel, army radio quoted a Tel Aviv man who said the entire Jewish community of Albania was packed and ready to leave for Israel. He said some of his 60 Albanian relatives had arrived in Israel over the past two months. It said immigrants from Albania had arrived in recent days at an absorption center in the southern city of Beersheva. Tirana newspapers on Sunday published a new draft constitution that guarantees freedom of movement, as well as freedom of religion and private ownership, according to Albanian state radio. The radio said the draft establishes multiparty elections. Under the new constitution, the president will be selected by parliament to serve a five-year term and can only be re-elected once. Elections are scheduled for Feb. 10. Pressures for reform in economically backward Albania began building on President Ramiz Alia in July when about 5,000 Albanians sought asylum in embassies in Tirana and were allowed to flee to Italy. An exodus of thousands of East Germans to the West last year also helped bring down former East Germany's Communist government. Pressured during street protets earlier this month, Alia allowed the formation of an opposition party. He has also tried to steer the nation out of decades of self-imposed isolation, and relaxed a ban on religious practice. The Communist government also recently ordered the dismantling of statues and other images of Josef Stalin, and the renaming of some institutions bearing the Soviet dictator's name.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Visits American Troops on Kuwaiti Front
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf to restore dropped vowel in `are'
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told U.S. troops Monday he shares their frustration with Saddam Hussein's refusal to budge from Kuwait, saying the time for patience is about up. Touring Saudi desert outposts nearly five months after Iraq's president sent invasion forces into neighboring Kuwait, Quayle sounded pessimistic about prospects for a peaceful settlement. ``You have heard some voices at home urging patience. They say wait a year or two. Let the sanctions work,'' he said, referring to the United Nations-imposed economic sanctions against the Baghdad regime. ``But the sanctions have not gotten Saddam out of Kuwait. You have been patient enough and so has President Bush,'' Quayle told Marines and Army forces in remarks at two desert bases not far from the Kuwaiti border. If war comes and the U.S troops drive Saddam's forces from Kuwait, he said, ``The whole world will be grateful.'' ``You are our heroes!'' Quayle declared. On the second day of a three-day trip to Saudi Arabia, the vice president flew by military helicopter and plowed through desert sands in military convoy vehicles to visit bases bustling with massive war preparations. The tent bases he visited - one with Harrier jet aircraft that can reach the border in three minutes are expected to be involved heavily in hostilities if war breaks out, military officials said. At the Third Armored Calvary Regiment base, some 40 miles from the border, Quayle inspected the new M1A1 heavy armored tanks recently brought in to upgrade the older models. He played basketball and volleyball with the troops, ate with them, talked by telephone to their families at a special desert satellite phone center, and inspected their readiness equipment. The personnel Quayle met seemed mostly resigned to the prospect of war and eager to get it over with. ``We were scared when we first got here. Right now we're just bored,'' Kenneth Merrill, an enlisted Army man. The troops received Quayle cordially. Some said they liked the fact that he came to see them; others were indifferent. ``If he could get me out of here, that would be real nice,'' said Marine Lance Cpl. Richard Kamoe of Honolulu, whose job is firing Stinger missiles. Sgt. Michael Collins, of Buffalo, N.Y., alluded to the controversy during the 1988 presidential campaign surrounding allegations that Quayle had used family connections to get enlisted in the Indiana National Guard rather than being drafted during the Vietnam War. ``Honest. We laughed a lot about it,'' Collins said. But many of the troops said they didn't give Quayle's military background much thought. ``He is the vice president,'' said Capt. Norbert Jocz of Blacksburg, Va. Quayle was accompanied by Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller, who stirred a controversy for the Bush administration when he said Dec. 19 that the U.S. forces would not be ready for military action by Jan. 15 - the deadline in a U.N. resolution demanding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. Waller on Monday seemed reticent to talk to reporters, saying his job was to support Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of Operation Desert Shield. Schwarzkopf had recently countered Waller's comments, saying ``they are ready'' for combat. Waller, who earlier had said he would recommend to Bush that the U.S. forces not strike until mid-February, said Monday he would not be making a recommendation at all because ``everybody has all the information they need'' to make the decision. ``The armed forces are prepared for whatever decision the president might make,'' Quayle told reporters traveling with him here. Speaking to a few hundred pilots and other personnel of the 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, the most forward deployed fixed aircraft wing of the U.S. forces, Quayle said, ``The fact is that a policy of indefinite patience only could lead to a policy of appeasement'' that would leave Saddam Hussein victorious. ``Saddam Hussein may not withdraw unconditionally, and if he doesn't then he will be forced out of Kuwait by military action,'' Quayle told the Marines. The vice president sought to reassure them that Bush would not send them into a long Vietnam-like conflict. ``If force is necessary it will be quick, massive and decisive. You will do your job and then go home to your loved ones,'' he said to applause. But Collins remained unconvinced. ``I don't think things are going to be as easy as he makes them out to be,'' he said. ``We're ready to go,'' the sergeant said, but he speculated that a war could go on for several months.

DOC.HEAD: New Year Bringing Big Pay Raises for Top Federal Officials
DOC.TEXT: The salaries of Vice President Quayle, federal judges, members of Congress and other top government officials jump by tens of thousands of dollars as of Tuesday because of legislation Congress enacted last year with the support of President Bush. The president's salary of $200,000 was unaffected, but those of Quayle, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., and Chief Justice William Rehnquist increase nearly 30 percent to $160,600 a year. Rank-and-file House members will see their salaries increase from $96,600 in 1990 to $125,100 in 1991. Federal district judges would get the same boost, with appeals court judges getting $132,700 and associate justices of the Supreme Court $153,600. Cabinet-level officers in the executive branch would receive up to $138,900. The salary increases in the House and judiciary were tied to new limits on outside income, including a ban on accepting fees for speeches. The Senate passed up on the big pay boost in order to keep its outside income from speeches. Senators will join most rank-and-file federal workers and take a cost of living increase. The new Senate salary will be $101,900, up from $98,400 in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ambassador Returns To Post With Tough PR Job Ahead
DOC.TEXT: When the Iraqi ambassador returns to his posting next week, he will find himself back on the hot seat, performing one of the most difficult public relations jobs in the world. Mohamed Al-Mashat is assigned to deliver a message Americans find repugnant: defending Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He has performed his task with dedication, arguing his case forcefully and stridently on myriad television news shows. Since coming to Washington, Mashat has also built bridges with members of Congress. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., telephoned Mashat in Baghdad last week, hoping to get the ball rolling on the diplomatic front in an effort to avert war in the Persian Gulf. Mashat told Dole Saddam might be willing to compromise on a date for diplomatic talks, thus raising optimism about a break in the impasse over direct U.S.-Iraqi discussions. Since Aug. 2, Mashat has embraced his public relations role with relish. With his pitch-black hair and roguish cigarette holder, he's a figure who's hard to miss. ``I never turn down an invitation,'' Mashat said recently at a panel discussion sponsored by the alumnae of Skidmore College. It was one of three engagements to which he had committed that evening. Whatever he was expecting, Mashat did not find a sympathetic audience. Some people shouted at him as he relentlessly propounded Iraq's position: the former foreign hostages were ``guests;'' the Kuwait-Iraq dispute must be solved by the Arabs; the United Nations sanctions are hurting Iraq's children; the Kuwait crisis must be solved in conjunction with the Arab-Israeli crisis. ``Iraq will never fire the first shot,'' Mashat said. But, if attacked, Iraq will fight to the bitter end. The gulf crisis is an ``Arab problem and solutions should come from the Arabs,'' he said. The volatile Mashat became so upset when the moderator cut him off that he threatened to walk out. A top news executive also complained that Mashat was completely inflexible and ideological when the newspaper invited the ambassador to a round-table luncheon. ``He wouldn't stop talking,'' said the executive, who asked to remain anonymous. Mashat says he is trying simply to explain his country's position. He blames the news media for distorting what is happening inside Kuwait and for fomenting trouble by siding with Israel. ``Even the most skilled diplomat would have a tough time'' handling the task given Mashat, said Marshall Wiley, a former U.S. ambassador to Iraq who knows him. Mashat's public relations show operates without much backup since his embassy staff was reduced from 55 to 16 in September in tit-for-tat expulsions with the United States. From time to time, Mashat is summoned to the State Department to be dressed down by American diplomats. Although Mashat, 59, presents Iraq's point of view in a belligerent tone in public, he is a big fan of America and Americans. He studied at the University of Maryland and the University of California. Mashat's first wife was American. He lives in the nation's capital with his second wife and their three children. `The American people and the Iraqi people have not problems personally,'' Mashat says. Before the invasion, he traveled around the United States frequently. He is particularly fond of California. Before he came to the United States, Mashat had served as his country's ambassador to London, Paris and Vienna.

DOC.HEAD: Duryea Group Turns to Bank Loan to Buy Historic Car
DOC.TEXT: Residents have rounded up all the money they needed to buy one of the last remaining examples of a three-wheeled car believed assembled in Peoria in 1898. The Bring Home the Duryea Committee fell short in its fund-raising efforts but obtained a loan to complete the purchase price for the automobile built by Charles Duryea, a spokesman said Sunday. John Parks, co-chairman of the committee, said a $125,000 check will be sent next week to the owner of the 1898 Duryea Motor Trap. Parks said the group was able to raise only $103,000 to buy the Duryea from L. Scott Bailey of Gloucester, England, founder of Automobile Quarterly magazine. The committee obtained a six-month loan for the rest of the amount, Parks said. Bailey had given the Peoria group until Tuesday to raise the money. ``We still haven't determined a final place to exhibit the car,'' Parks said. It's been on display at the Peoria Public Library. Parks said the committee must turn its attention to building a continuing fund to pay for a display location and to maintain the car. The Smithsonian Institution recognizes Charles Duryea and his brother, Frank Duryea, as the fathers of the American automobile. They built the first gasoline-powered automobile in the United States in 1883 in Massachusetts. That vehicle is in the Smithsonian. The committee says 12 Traps were built in the Peoria area and just two still exist. The other is in the Henry Ford Museum in Greenfield Village, Mich. Duryea moved his production operations to Reading, Pa., after falling on hard times in Peoria.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Chairman: Review of Dartmouth Review Shows No Bias
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of New Hampshire's Human Rights Commission said Monday he found no evidence of discrimination against blacks, women, homosexuals or Jews in an off-campus Dartmouth College newspaper. Barry Palmer said he reached his conclusion after reading two years of The Dartmouth Review. Palmer said he conducted the study as an individual, not on behalf of the commission, after continued criticism of the paper by Dartmouth President James Freedman. Freedman has said the paper published by conservative students consistently attacks those groups. The Review, published since 1980, has been vilified for years for its views on women, homosexuals, blacks and Indians. Palmer said the five-member commission acts as a body on policy only, that investigations and reviews are conducted by one of the three commission investigators or the commissioners individually. Criticizing blacks, women, homosexuals or Jews is not prejudice as long as the criticism is aimed at performance, and not sexual or racial status, Palmer said. Kevin Pritchett, editor of the weekly newspaper, said that ``from the very start, the Review has criticized people, not because of their race or sex (but) because of the way they performed.'' Freedman was away and not available to respond to Palmer's findings, but college spokesman Roland Adams disagreed with Palmer's assessment. ``Just this particular summer, the Dartmouth Review equated the lives of 1,400 Moslems with 7,000 penguins,'' he said. ``It said the deaths of each were equally tragic. They apologized for that, but then, the Review seems to be apologizing all the time.'' Palmer, who also is a copy editor for The Union Leader newspaper of Manchester, said the commission ``is very sensitive to anything which takes away from a human being's self-worth and is always seeking evidence of such bias, whether in print or verbal form.'' ``I read every single thing they wrote about teachers. I reviewed editorials and editorial cartoons. And I didn't find any hint of bigotry or prejudice,'' Palmer said. ``After reviewing two years of the publication, I began wondering what all the fuss was about.'' Palmer said he undertook the review after Freedman raised questions of discrimination. Earlier this year, on Yom Kippur, Judaism's most solemn day, a quote from Adolf Hitler was inserted into the Review's masthead, infuriating people on and off campus. The quote read: ``Therefore, I believe today that I am acting in the sense of the Almighty Creator: By warding off the Jews, I am fighting for the Lord's work.'' Trustees and staffers said the quote was the work of a saboteur and apologized. Backlash from the quote led the newspaper's president and two staffers to quit. Freedman called the quote an ``egregious expression of anti-Semitism'' and ``appalling bigotry.'' William Cole, a black music professor, resigned in August after The Review attacked him for seven years as a mediocre teacher. Cole said his effectiveness was compromised by the attacks. Review staffers also were involved in a 1986 sledgehammer attack on shanties that were eected on the campus green as part of a protest against segregation in South Africa. Several staffers were suspended.

DOC.HEAD: INS Plans Express Lane at Some Border Crossings, for a Fee
DOC.TEXT: The Immigration and Naturalization Service says it plans to charge a fee to motorists who use new express lanes along the Canadian and Mexican borders. A pilot program is scheduled to be established next spring by the INS at a few locations along both borders. The participating border crossings and how much travelers will be charged for using the optional express lanes have not been determined yet, INS spokesman Duke Austin said. The lanes would be staffed with extra inspectors to speed border crossings. A fee plan was ordered by Congress in the 1991 Appropriations Act, which passed in October, to offset the recent traffic increase at border crossings. Money generated by the tolls would be used to hire more inspectors and expand inspection stations, Austin said. ``We are stressing that use of the fee lanes is voluntary,'' Austin said Saturday. ``There will still be non-fee lanes for those who choose not to pay.'' But immigrant rights groups are criticizing the fund-raising method, contending the plan may lead to a tax on anyone entering the United States - similar to what's done with international air travel. ``That's a heck of a way to balance their budget,'' said Mario Moreno, an attorney for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. The INS plans to submit program guidelines for congressional approval in February. About 13 million vehicles passed through U.S. border inspection points in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Editor of Dead Sea Scrolls Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Antiquities Authority on Monday dismissed a Harvard scholar as chief editor of the Dead Sea Scrolls, citing health problems. The professor recently created an uproar by making anti-Jewish statements. The editor, British-born divinity professor John Strugnell, was replaced by an Israeli professor. Strugnell also had been criticized for the slow pace of publication of the leather scrolls, discovered by a Bedouin shepherd in 1946 in a cave near the Dead Sea. The ancient manuscripts are among the most significant archaeological finds of the century because they include the oldest known texts of the Old Testmant and shed light on the origins of Christianity and the history of Judaism. In his announcement Monday, Amir Drori, the director of the Israel Antiquities Authority, said Strugnell was being relieved at the suggestion of the agency's three-man Scrolls Advisory Committee. Strugnell, 60 and in ill health, remains hospitalized in the United States, associates said. He could not be reached for comment. He created a storm in Israel following an interview published on Nov. 9 in the Haaretz newspaper. Strugnell, who is Roman Catholic, described Judaism as ``a racist religion ... just like Hinduism'' in India. Asked what bothered him about Judaism, he said: ``The fact that it survives. It should have disappeared. ... The solution to the Jewish problem in my view is mass conversion to Christianity and this is, of course, Christian theology and not my dear option.'' Strugnell denied he was anti-Jewish, saying ``I don't love or hate Jews more than I love or hate anybody else. There are Jews I can't stand and there are Christians, Catholics even, that I can stand even less.'' He was severely criticized for the comments. The weekly Jerusalem Report magazine headlined its article ``The Jew-Hater who Controls the Scrolls,'' and several editorials questioned whether a man with his opinions should continue as editor. It was Strugnell's health problems that prompted an international editing team, including professors Frank Cross of Harvard and Eugene Ulrich of the University of Notre Dame, to recommend earlier in December that Strugnell be replaced. The international team had recommended that he be replaced by three ``general editors,'' but Drori's announcement named just one of the men, Israeli professor Emanuel Tov, as the editor in chief. The team also had recommended Ulrich and Father Emile Puech, a French scholar working at the Ecole Biblique in Jerusalem. Tov is the only Israeli among the three. A Hebrew University professor, he had been named as co-editor by the Antiquities Authority in October. He is on sabbatical in the Netherlands and could not be reached for comment. A Hebrew University scholar said on condition of anonymity that the change in editors means ``we are going to try and move things along with more speed.'' He praised Strugnell as ``a very fine scholar, a very learned person'' but said that his ``personal problems'' had begun to interfere with the project. Strugnell has done research on the scrolls since 1952 and was editor since 1987. Magen Broshi, one of the members of the advisory committee, estimated that about 80 percent of the scrolls have been published and that what remains is complicated because it requires piecing together thousands of fragments and interpreting them. Still, he said, Strugnell had agreed to a timetable that would see the remaining documents published by 1997. An estimated 800 scrolls have been recovered, but many are in fragments. Eight scrolls are displayed at the Israel Museum. The remainder are in the Rockefeller Museum.

DOC.HEAD: Healthy Child is March of Dimes National Ambassador for 1991
LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: The March of Dimes has chosen a healthy youngster as its annual poster child. The girl, who was born more than three months premature, proves miracles can happen, the charity said. Laura Krumwiede was given a 40 percent chance of surviving after her birth in 1984. She weighed less than 2 pounds, her lungs were unable to function, and she spent the first days of her life hooked to a respirator. Today, the suburban Chicago youngster is a healthy kindergartner, looking forward to meeting President Bush and fulfilling her other duties as the 1991 national ambassador for the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation. The charity planned to introduce Laura to the nation Tuesday on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America.'' ``Laura is our everyday reminder of the miracle of a healthy child, and of the fact that sometimes we have to make that miracle happen,'' said Jennifer L. Howse, March of Dimes president. ``Programs and treatments developed by March of Dimes researchers helped save Laura's life.'' Selecting a healthy poster child reflects the March of Dimes' new focus on ``a healthy birth for every baby,'' the charity said in a statement. Laura's new celebrity status hasn't gone to her head, said her mother, Candyce, of Naperville, west of Chicago. ``She just takes it in stride,'' Mrs. Krumwiede said of her daughter, a budding ballet dancer who is learning to read. ``She's excited about seeing President Bush because she loves Millie the dog.'' The March of Dimes was founded in 1938 to fight polio, and for decades it chose disabled youngsters as poster children to symbolize the struggle against the crippling disease. In 1958, the organization expanded its programs in an effort to fight birth defects and low birthweights. More than 250,000 babies each year are born weighing less than 5.5 pounds. Low birthweight is related to 60 percent of all infant deaths and is closely associated with birth defects, the charity said. The poster children were given the title of national ambassador in 1986 to reflect their role as messengers of good will. As the 1991 ambassador, Laura will attend charity events nationwide and appear with celebrities to raise awareness of the March of Dimes. ``Laura was going to be my New Year's baby'' of 1985, Mrs. Krumwiede said. But Laura was born on Oct. 2, 1984. She suffered several life-threatening health problems associated with low birthweight babies, and her parents were not sure they would ever be able to bring her home. Laura was put in a neonatal intensive care unit, and given a hormone to help her lungs develop. The March of Dimes said it led the development of the units for high-risk infants, and its researchers have studied the effects of the type of hormone Laura was given. Laura overcame the odds. ``The miracle of Laura is not just the fact that she lived. The miracle is that she has virtually no problems as a result of her prematurity,'' Mrs. Krumwiede said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Michael Crawford is back in the role he left eight months ago in what was thought to be his final bow as ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' ``I'm making friends with the stage again,'' Crawford said in an interview before his New Year's Eve debut at the Ahmanson Theatre. Crawford left the production in April, saying he was exhausted after 1,069 performances. ``I was so tired. You have to pay things back to yourself, to your mind and body,'' Crawford said. Now, he's refreshed and ready to replace Robert Guillaume, who had been his replacement. ``It's like going back to college after missing two terms. Or like an athlete who hasn't run for awhile. When you start running again, you're a little sore,'' said Crawford, who is scheduled to perform through March 31. Crawford wore the Phantom's mask when the show opened at the Ahmanson on May 31, 1989. He originated the role in London and performed it on Broadway, where he won a Tony Award. --- ATLANTA (AP) - You start by dating actress Jane Fonda, then .... Time has run out for entering cable television magnate Ted Turner's $500,000 save-the-world contest. More than 1,000 manuscripts on the theme of the survival of the planet had arrived by New Year's Eve, Turner Publishing Inc. spokeswoman Marcia Dworetz said. Entries had to be postmarked by Monday. The Turner Tomorrow Awards seek fiction set in the near future with themes of ensuring the survival and prosperity of all life on the planet. The top winner will receive $500,000 and be published. Turner, who is engaged to Ms. Fonda, announced the iterary award, one of the world's richest, in 1989 to stimulate ideas to improve the ecology and human relations. The winners will be announced June 3. Turner, chairman of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System Inc., is not involved in the judging, Ms. Dworetz said. ``A number of themes do crop up,'' she said. ``They range from grass roots - communities working together to solve problems - to `a child shall lead them' - children showing adults the errors of their ways.'' --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Singer Bobby McFerrin kicked off a 24-hour chanting and humming spiritual event at Grace Cathedral atop Nob Hill. The white-robed McFerrin, whose hits include ``Don't Worry Be Happy,'' began the chant, dubbed ``Singing for Your Life,'' standing inside a circle of 22 people in the nave of the church Sunday night. ``I've become very fascinated with religious and spiritual significance of music in Third World countries, where everything is celebrated and honored,'' said the singer. ``There's a reverence toward everyday life that our modern living with its fast tempo is rapidly losing.'' McFerrin, who has won nine Grammy Awards, lined up about 300 singers for the event, said the Rev. Lauren Artress, pastor at the Episcopal cathedral. ``What Bobby is doing here, with the singing and the meditation, is in the tradition of an ancient Christian vigil,'' Artress said. ``The point is to open up.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Representatives of Martha (Sunny) C. Auerspberg von Bulow, the socialite woman who has been in a coma for 10 years, have donated $60,000 to a charity on her behalf. A committee of her three children, her lawyer and an executive from Chemical Bank, where her account is handled, decided to donate the money to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Mrs. von Bulow fell unconscious on Dec. 21, 1980. Her husband, Claus, was accused and eventually acquitted of inducing the coma with a shot of insulin. Mrs. von Bulow's doctors at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York have said that she will not recover from her coma. The $60,000 donation was one of the largest of the year to the fund, which also received checks of $150,000 each from Paul Newman and from the Starr Foundation in Manhattan and a gift of $125,000 from the Willard T.C. Johnson Foundation Inc. in Manhattan. The proceeds from the charity go to seven charities to aid the sick and the poor. ``We could think of nothing that she would want to do more than help those that cannot help themselves,'' Annie Laurie Isham, Mrs. Von Bulow's oldest daughter, said in a statement. ``Mother loved Christmas, and this holiday season has been a particularly harsh one for the sick and the poor.''

DOC.HEAD: Conductor in Chicago Provides Unique Ride
DOC.TEXT: Conductor John Cameron gives passengers aboard his elevated train a smile and tidbits of history aboard his ``Love Train.'' Cameron, 43, who introduces himself as ``The Rapper'' to first-time passengers, says he started his routine 12 years ago to brighten up otherwise dreary trips on the Chicago Transit Authority train. ``Good morning,'' his voice booms over the train's intercom before it departs the line's Howard Street station, the starting point of an hour-long trip to Chicago's South Side. ``The time is 8:26, and the temperature is 32 degrees. Welcome aboard the Love Train. ``Sit back, relax and enjoy the ride, 'cause you're riding first class down Electric Avenue,'' he continues. `` Driver says I'm going to make you look good, feel good and smell good 'cause I'm the doctor who's going to cure all your aches.'' Startled passengers who haven't heard Cameron's spiel look up from their papers or break free of glassy-eyed stares. Veterans smile knowingly. ``This guy is like a walking tourist map,'' said Arthur Rooks, 22. ``The first time I heard him, I thought he was kind of kooky. But after you listen to him, you pick up little tidbits about the city that you didn't know, even after living here for a while.'' On any given trip, passengers might learn that the train passes under the Chicago River at one point, or that one station was designed by architect Frank Lloyd Wright. Even the trendy nightspots get attention. ``Clark and Division,'' Cameron says at one stop. ``The Gold Coast, the nightlife, the good life. Church on Sunday, the cabaret on Monday, but it's nobody's business what you do.'' Cameron has appeared on local television and radio shows and on Oprah Winfrey's and Phil Donahue's talk shows. ``I didn't start this for all the publicity or honors,'' Cameron said. ``I figure it's what the world needs right now. We need a whole lot of love, and I figure whatever little bit I can do will help.''

DOC.HEAD: Is Yellowstone Too Crowded?
DOC.TEXT: Two years of record tourism have shown that Yellowstone National Park didn't lose its luster in its 1988 forest fires, but the crowds also raise the question of how many people the park can stand. ``We've seen in the last few years much higher visitation in the spring months and in the fall,'' said Ed Lewis, executive director of the Greater Yellowstone Coalition, an environmental group. ``In the past when you had very high visitation in the summer, at least the resources in the park ... had a chance to recover before the next press of visitors. ``That's becoming increasingly less of a case. I know just from talking to people in the middle of the summer, you just have endless traffic jams in the park, worse than before. The period of high use is getting extended each year.'' In 1987, 2.58 million people visited. The fires held 1988 visitation down to about 2.2 million. In 1989, people flocked to the park to see the effects of the fires, pushing visitation to a record 2.68 million. In 1990, 2.8 million visited the 2.2 million-acre park, according to park officials. Lewis maintains that Yellowstone is approaching its carrying capacity of humans, but park Superintendent Bob Barbee disagrees. ``People come from a long way away, and I guess I feel that we're somewhat fortunate that we're not besieged by tremendous numbers. And if we were we would have to deal with it,'' Barbee said. ``Right now, I don't see any big problem.'' Lewis points to the strain he sees people placing on grizzlies that are rising in number in the park. The bears flock toward Yellowstone Lake to feed on cutthroat trout spawning in the spring and come into conflict with tourists staying at the campgrounds and hotels surrounding the lake. When those conflicts arise, the bears are relocated, he said. ``These are bears that are doing what comes naturally,'' Lewis said. ``And we're seeing them moved more and more ... and we've seen from past experience, the more you move a bear the more likely that bear becomes a fatality.'' Barbee agrees there are times during the summer when traffic jams occur on the ``Grand Loop,'' which circles the park's interior. But he doesn't see a need now to limit visitation. ``A lot of it is a matter of perception. But I honestly do not think, that except on isolated circumstances on certain days of the year ... that we have a crowding problem,'' the superintendent said. Lewis wants the National Park Service to institute additional measures to ease the crowds. One possibility, he said, would be to alter seasonal openings, such as delaying the spring opening of Lake Hotel and its surrounding cabins. The Greater Yellowstone Coalition also wants the Park Service to look at what kind of toll burgeoning winter tourism industry is having on the park. ``For years we have been asking the park to do further analysis and planning of the winter season,'' said Lewis. ``We're really concerned. We're very concerned that the analysis has not been done to determine the impacts of this increased winter visitation.'' Park spokeswoman Joan Anselmo said the park's winter use plan, to be released in its final form in March, will address some of those concerns. And she notes that the park has closed part of the Fishing Bridge campground, removed cabins from West Thumb, and has reduced the number of cabins at Old Faithful. The growing number of tourists and their impact are not being overlooked, Barbee said. ``We're trying to manage the situation and deal with it realistically and prudently and sensibly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: In Broadcast to `Wonderful Soviets,' Bush Boosts Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release 4 p.m. EST; INSERTS grafs 7-12, bgng: Gorbachev, in xxx with Gorbachev messages to Soviets and Americans; trims one graf at end
DOC.TEXT: In a videotaped New Year's greeting to ``all the wonderful people of the Soviet Union,'' President Bush offered a word of encouragement Monday to a beleaguered Mikhail Gorbachev, saluting him for undertaking ``an arduous journey'' toward a new society. The president, welcoming the Soviets as partners in the attempt to force Iraq to give up its conquest of Kuwait, also hailed the Soviet-American ``common approach to a new challenge in the name of stability and peace.'' ``I applaud, the world applauds, the decisive action of the Soviet Union in strongly opposing Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression in the Gulf,'' Bush said. Despite their previous close ties to Iraq, the Soviets have supported the United States in the U.N. Security Council but declined to send troops to join an allied army in Saudi Arabia. On a more personal level, Bush said he was thrilled about the warmth developing between ordinary Soviet and American citizens as a result of the relaxation of tensions in the aftermath of the Cold War. ``Tens of thousands of Soviets have had contact with Americans now, and the numbers are growing,'' the president said. ``Barbara and I are thrilled to see our two peoples meeting and getting to know one another as friendly neighbors.'' Gorbachev, in a TV message to the American people, said he expected his Moscow summit with Bush in February to give impetus to the removal of ``old obstacles'' still hampering Soviet-American relations. ``Economic and scientific and technological cooperation still do not respond to the spirit of the time,'' he said. But, looking back, he summed up 1990 as a momentous year: ``The Cold War is over. There is no more danger of nuclear catastrophe. The horizons of peace have been widened.'' He called Saddam Hussein's ``aggression'' an obstacle to peace and said the international community ``should find strength to overcome this obstacle.'' And, addressing his own people in a television message scheduled for midnight, Gorbachev said 1990 was ``one of the most difficult years in our history.'' ``Crisis phenomena in economics, the lowering of people's personal safety, a weakening of order and discipline affected the conditions of life,'' he said. Bush's New Year's message was taped last week for broadcast on New Year's Day in the Soviet Union. At the same time, some U.S. television stations will carry Gorbachev's message to the American people. Cable News Network said it would air the two messages at 1 p.m. EST. The exchange continued a custom established, at America's suggestion, by Gorbachev and then-President Ronald Reagan in 1986, dropped in 1987 and resumed in 1988. In that first message, Reagan defended the American people's ``strong interest in humanitarian issues,'' saying that this country was ``founded on the belief in the sanctity of human life and the rights of the individual.'' Gorbachev, in his 1989 message, called the exchange a ``meaningful symbol of our mutual willingness to go on moving toward each other'' and stressed the Soviet people's interest in peace, ``having suffered for it'' in World War II. In this year's remarks, Bush said the reform path on which Gorbachev has embarked ultimately would lead to a brighter future for the Soviet people. He made no reference to Gorbachev's struggle to keep his nation from splintering, as some of the Soviet republics assert uncompromising claims to sovereignty. Nor did Bush mention the way Gorbachev's economic reforms have bogged down or the food shortages which impelled Western countries to send emergency food supplies this year to the Soviet Union. ``On this New Year's Day, as you celebrate with your friends and family, I also want to applaud the Soviet Union for the important steps you've taken in building a new society, for the determination with which you are pressing forward with difficult political and economic reforms,'' Bush said. ``It's an arduous journey, but one well worth making, for it is a path that leads to a brighter future for your nation.'' He concluded: ``On behalf of the American people, I wish President Gorbachev and all the wonderful people of the Soviet Union a happy, prosperous New Year.''

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Says Israel Is Pushing U.S. Into Gulf War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 6th pvs, `The United...' to ADD PLO position on Iraqi invasion. Pickup 7th pvs, `Israeli officials...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat said Monday that Israel is pushing the United States into a war against Iraq because it wants to destroy Iraq's military and economic power. ``We are not reading the future, but this is what Israel wants - to annihilate Iraq's military and technical power,'' Arafat said in an interview with The Associated Press. The Palestine Liberation Organization leader said the only end he foresaw to the gulf crisis was through negotiations on all Middle East problems, including the Palestinian issue. He urged the European Community to avert war in the region. The foreign ministers of the 12 European Community states are to meet in an emergency session Friday to discuss the crisis, and officials say they could decide to open talks with Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has insisted on linking a settlement of the crisis with the Palestinian problem. The United States has refused such linkage as a condition for peace talks. The PLO has supported Saddam in the gulf crisis. Arafat's backing was based on the premise Saddam was the only Arab leader who could force a solution to the Palestinian problem.
Israeli officials would not comment on Arafat's statements. But when asked about his country's position regarding the United States and the gulf, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud said: ``We don't advise, we don't suggest and besides the U.S. makes its own decisions.'' Israel has repeatedly said that any solution that left Iraq with its military might intact would threaten it. But it also has said that it is not pushing the United States to make any decisions on the gulf. The U.N. Security Council has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face the possibility of a military attack by the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region. ``Time is running out for us, Iraq, the United States and everybody,'' Arafat said. ``How can we resolve it peacefully without talks and without negotiations?'' Arafat ruled out the possibility of an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait without talks between the United States and Iraq on other Middle East issues. ``Before talks there can be no solution or compromise,'' he said. Saddam has invited U.S. Secretary of State James Baker III for talks in Baghdad on Jan. 12, but the Bush administration has rejected the proposal, saying the date is too close to the U.N. deadline. Arafat arrived in Iraq on Sunday. He has held talks with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on the situation in the area and the Israeli occupied territory. Arafat, who heads the PLO's mainstream Fatah guerrilla faction, denied that the gulf crisis has adversely affected the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. ``Some people believed that the gulf crisis has eclipsed the intefadeh (uprising) and others have said the Palestinian issue has been shelved,'' he said. ``But look and see how the Palestinian question has topped all issues on (the) world agenda.''
