Tuesday marks the 26th anniversary of the first armed attack inside Israel by Fatah. The Palestinians will continue their struggle against the Jewish state until they achieve their goal for an independent state and self determination, Arafat said. Earlier Monday, Israel killed 12 Fatah guerrillas in a raid near Sidon in southern Lebanon. A PLO communique warned that Israel planned a ``massive military operation'' in southern Lebanon and had sent reinforcements to its self-proclaimed ``security zone'' just north of the Israel-Lebanon border. Security forces in the region said there had been no such buildup.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Quayle Bjt
Army Calls up National Guard Combat Unit, Support Elements
DOC.TEXT: The Army said Monday it is ordering to active duty 2,667 National Guard and Army Reserve members from 15 states, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico in support of Operation Desert Shield. Among the units being mobilized is the 2nd Battalion, 142nd Field Artillery of the Arkansas National Guard, based at Fort Smith. The other units are being called up for noncombat services such as public affairs, maintence and law enforcement. Maj. Cissy Lashbrook, a spokeswoman at the Arkansas National Guard headquarters in North Little Rock, said about 450 members of the 2nd Battalion already are training at Fort Sill, Okla., the Army's main artillery training center. She said the unit is scheduled to deploy to Saudi Arabia and that lead elements already are there. More than 125,000 members of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps reserves have been called to active duty for Desert Shield since late August.

DOC.SECOND: AM-NBC News Channel, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0550,0520
DOC.HEAD: NBC News To Begin Beaming Video Around the Clock ... From Charlotte
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final two grafs with three grafs to UPDATE with union comment
DOC.TEXT: NBC News is launching its new 24-hour News Channel on New Year's Day, feeding video of late-breaking news, sports and features from a new base in Charlotte to network affiliates for local use. Until now, the network had been feeding its affiliates several times a day from New York City. ``We were better off getting out of New York and creating our own identity,'' said Bob Horner, a former CBS News bureau chief who's now in charge of what he describes as ``a video wire service.'' Real estate costs, climate and access to a major airport also played a role. ``Charlotte is a thriving city with a good business climate,'' he said. ``It's also blessed with strong local media.'' NBC News Channel will feed raw and edited footage, including foreign, domestic and regional material, to local stations, which can then edit the reports for use on their newscasts. ``Local stations want more variety,'' Horner said. ``Some smaller companies, like CNN, have been more aggressive in using satellite technology to help individual stations.'' For now, Horner and his staff of about 50 producers and editors are working out of temporary offices. Later this year, the NBC News Channel will move into a 10,000-square-foot wing of the new studio of the local NBC affiliate, WCNC. Two weeks ago, NBC News signed the Nippon Television Network (NTV) as the News Channel's first overseas affiliate. In exchange for exclusive rights to news material from the NBC News Channel, NTV will give NBC News the same rights to all Japanese and international news material of NTV, Japan's largest private broadcast network. Horner said his staffers are experienced professionals who are used to working behind the scene. ``(CBS sportscaster) John Madden would love this team,'' he said, a reference to the former NFL coach's affection for unheralded football players, particularly linemen. ``It's not particularly glamorous work but it's very interesting,'' Horner said. ``I look for people who want to get the news on the air.'' He said locating in Charlotte was not an effort to get away from unions. ``Although I know people have attributed different motives to this, that really isn't the problem. The work that was being done in New York was done by people who weren't in the union,'' Horner said. But the president of the New York local of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians' disputed that. ``Mr. Horner may be correct in claiming that Charlotte is a thriving city with a good business climate,'' said John Clark, whose union represents some NBC employees. ``But he chooses to ignore the prime reason that NBC moved its skycam operation from New York, and that was to avoid paying union protected wages mandated in the broadcast capital of the world - New York City.''

DOC.HEAD: Relations With Military Still a Risky Issue for Young Chilean Democracy
DOC.TEXT: Relations are strained between the civilian government and the military that ruled for almost 17 years, but the real test is soon to come. The government is expected to issue reports in the next few weeks on financial and human rights investigations of the military. But Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who relinquished the presidency in March, remains army commander and has not adjusted easily to the reduction in his power. On Dec. 19, Pinochet put the army on alert to protest what it calls unfair news coverage of a series of corruption accusations involving military men. Pinochet later described the action as ``just an exercice on security, readiness and coordination.'' President Patricio Aylwin said the alert ``had no justification whatsoever, and shows the military lack an understanding of what democratic life is all about.'' Aylwin summoned Pinochet to the presidential palace to demand an explanation. The president later admitted the alert was a sign of military unrest. While government officials and politicians from right to left say the situation does not pose a threat to the newly restored democracy, they also say it must be taken seriously. ``It is a serious situation,'' said Julio Dittborn, president of the Independent Democratic Union, a far-right party that supported Pinochet's 16{-year authoritarian government. The alert showed Pinochet's strong support in the army, according to Dittborn. Pinochet, 75, turned over the presidency to Aylwin, an elected civilian, on March 11. However, under a special clause in the 1980 constitution, written by the military government, Pinochet remains commander of the 60,000-member army and Aylwin is prohibited from firing him. Sergio Bitar, a socialist leader in Aylwin's governing coalition, also described the situation as serious. ``These are hurdles in the democratic transition,'' he said in an interview. ``But what is clear is that there are no conditions in the country for a coup attempt.'' ``There will be more difficulties, but there is no reason for fear,'' Bitar added. He said the government has no problems with the navy, air force and the national police. Bitar and government officials say they expect the real test in government-military relations to come in the next few weeks, when reports are to be issued by two special panels investigating the military. The first one is a congressional group investigating the army's payment of $3 million to a son of Pinochet for the purchase of an arms factory in financial trouble. That panel's report is due by mid-January. On Feb. 9, a report will be issued by a special commission formed by Aylwin to investigate widespread human rights violations during the Pinochet years. Both investigations are expected to lead to trials involving military officers. A judge investigating an illegal savings and loan organization that operated inside the army has already indicted eight officers, seven of them retired, on charges of breaking banking laws. The news coverage of all three cases has clearly bothered Pinochet and the military, and was widely seen as a a key reason for the army alert. Retired Col. Cristian Labbe, one of Pinochet's closest aides and allies, told the Santiago daily La Tercera that the alert ``was a message, and the government has clearly understood it.'' Government officials and news reports say the army has asked the government to request reporters to play down coverage. During the talks, the reports say, the Army even suggested Pinochet might be prepared to retire in exchange. Most observers see Pinochet's strong personality as a key element in the dispute. A government official who witnessed the general's interview with Aylwin the day after the alert, said Pinochet interrupted the president when he told him, ``General, I've summoned you ... '' ``Invited me, Mr. President, you have invited me,'' Pinochet said, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Interviewed by the state television last month, Aylwin said Pinochet has trouble adjusting to a subordinate post ``after ruling the country as an absolute master for 17 years.'' However, Aylwin later said he had changed his opinion of Pinochet ``as a human being,'' and that he now thinks his predecessor respects his authority. ``I must say that I respect the courage with which he has faced the reduction of his position from president to commander in chief,'' Aylwin told the government newspaper La Nacion.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Quayle Bjt
Secretary of State Said Returning To Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will likely visit Saudi Arabia and other Gulf nations to consult with U.S. allies before a mid-January deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, an administration official said Monday. Baker also is considering a visit to Europe during that time, said the official, who was traveling with Vice President Dan Quayle on a three-day visit to Saudi Arabia. The purpose of the trip would be to ``touch bases'' with the Gulf leaders prior to the deadline, after which the United Nations has authorized use of force to eject Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's army, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Officials accompanying Quayle said it appeared unlikely that Baker would meet with Saddam by Jan. 3, the end of the time frame that President Bush set for such a face-to-face talk in Baghdad. However, the possibility remains that if Baker did travel to the Middle East to see other leaders, Saddam could invite him to Baghdad at that time, one official speculated. Baker's visit to the region would be in the way of a final consultation, although all plans for military readiness are already in place should Bush decide to launch an attack, the official said. Saddam has suggested that Baker meet with him on Jan. 12, a date the Bush admnistration contends is too close to the Jan. 15 deadline. Administration officials have said that even if Baker does meet with Saddam, the purpose would be only to reiterate in person the United States' demand for Iraqi acceptance of a U.N. resolution demanding full withdrawal from Kuwait, with no compromise. There are some signs of flexibility on the part of the two sides in the disagreement over timing. The State Department has not ruled out a Baker trip to Baghdad after Jan. 3. At the same time, Iraqi Ambassador Mohammed Al-Mashat told Senate Minority leader Robert Dole, R-Kan., over the weekend that Saddam is not wedded to a meeting on Jan. 12, according to Dole. In Washington, State Department press officer Mark Dillen said Baker, who has been on vacation in Houston, plans to return to Washington Tuesday night. Meanwhile, Al-Mashat reportedly was returning to Washington Monday night from consulations in Baghdad. Al-Mashat was one of a number of Iraqi diplomats who took part in the Baghdad discussions but Iraq has denied that a peace initiative was in the works. Dillen said Al-Mashat is not on the schedule of any State Department official either Tuesday or Wednesday. Dillen also was asked about the possibility of a meeting between European Community representatives and Saddam. He recalled that when a similar initiative was proposed earlier this month, Baker said then he supports initiatives aimed at achieving a diplomatic solution provided they are consistent with implementation of U.N. Security Council resolutions on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Six Workers Hurt in Scaffolding Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Rescue crews pulled nine workers from the wreckage of a scaffolding platform that collapsed Monday inside a power plant, authorities said. Six were injured, but only four were admitted to a hospital. Crews pulled the last worker from the rubble less than four hours after the accident Monday at the Consolidated Edison plant on Staten Island, said Joe McGee, a Fire Department spokesman. The workers were performing maintenance on a boiler when the 100-foot-high scaffolding inside the boiler gave way, said Marty Gitten, a Con Ed spokesman. ``It looks like a giant erector set which crumbled,'' said McGee. The cause of the accident was under investigation. The four admitted to a hospital were listed as stable, Staten Island Hospital officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Offers Aid Restoration if Iraq Pulls Out of Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan is ready to offer economic aid to Iraq if it withdraws peacefully from Kuwait, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said in a New Year's statement. Japan, which had been Iraq's top aid donor, froze $2.96 billion in assistance to the Baghdad government after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The United Nations has given Iraq until Jan. 15 to withdraw or face possible military action by U.S.-led international forces. ``I hope that Iraq will make a decision for a peaceful solution. If it does, then Japan is prepared to extend economic cooperation,'' Kaifu told Japanese reporters in a news conference to be broadcast on New Year's Day. Japan has pledged $2 billion in aid to the international forces, and another $2 billion to nations suffering from the international embargo against Iraq. But Kaifu had to abandon a proposal to send members of Japan's military for non-combat roles with the international forces. Critics said it would have violated the nation's peace constitution. In a separate New Year's message, Koshiro Ishida, chairman of Japan's second-largest opposition party, said Japan should come up with a policy for taking part in U.N. peacekeeping activities. But Takako Doi, chairwoman of the biggest opposition party, the Socialists, said Japan should become an ``exporter of peace.'' She said it is important to spread the principles of Japan's constitution, which renounces war as a means of solving international conflicts. The Persian Gulf crisis also figured in a poem composed by Emperor Akihito to mark the New Year, in which he referred to Japanese formerly held hostage in Iraq. In it, he expressed concern for the fate ``of those detained in a foreign land.''

DOC.HEAD: Texas Speaker Surrenders, Released on Bond
DOC.TEXT: Texas Speaker Gib Lewis surrendered Monday to face two misdemeanor ethics charges. After his release on bail, he said he would still seek a record fifth term as House leader. Lewis surrendered at the Travis County jail and was released 20 minutes later on a personal recognizance bond of $10,000. Lewis said the indictments will not deter his plan to seek an unprecedented fifth two-year term as speaker when the 1991 Legislature convenes Jan. 8. ``I have seen nothing that would indicate that I should not. I don't think anybody else has either,'' Lewis said. He said the charges were unfounded, and he denounced a newspaper report that in April 1987 he shared a Mexican resort suite with a female receptionist from the law firm linked to his indictment. ``That's just a trashy allegation. That's not even good journalism. That's not even good politics,'' said Lewis, a Democrat from Fort Worth. The Dallas Morning News reported Sunday that Lewis, 54, and Toni Barcellona, 27, now an Austin lobbyist, were among the six men and six women who spent three days together on the vacation paid for by the law firm of Heard Goggan Blair & Williams. The law firm has denied wrongdoing. Ms. Barcellona has not returned several telephone messages by The Associated Press. Lewis was indicted Friday by a grand jury on misdemeanor counts of receiving a gift from Heard Goggan and of failing to report the benefit on the public financial disclosure statement that must be filed by officeholders. The charges stem from a tax payment made by the law firm for business taxes owed by Lewis, said Travis County District Attorney Ronnie Earle. Lewis' attorneys say Earle, who has vigorously criticized state ethics laws as being too lax, is on a vendetta to topple the speaker. Lewis said he has been wrongly accused of trying to kill ethics reforms. ``I'm the only person that has sat down with Ronnie Earle and asked him for his recommendation on what he thinks should go into a plan, and all of sudden I get bushwhacked by somebody saying, `He is against ethics,''' Lewis said. If convicted on the two counts, Lewis faces a maximum of 18 months in prison and fined $3,000. Lewis' attorneys said the speaker will plead innocent. The grand jury investigation is continuing. Earle says it has expanded to include more legislators and lobbyists.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Prices for Raw Products Declined in December
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products ended 1990 with a 0.7 percent decline from November to December, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Lower prices were reported for milk, hogs and lettuce, although higher prices for cattle, peanuts and eggs helped ease the decline of the other commodities. However, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said fruit and vegetable prices were recorded before unseasonably cold weather hit California about Dec. 21. Consequently, the report did not reflect the freezing cold that hit California citrus and vegetables before Christmas. Record high monthly prices were reported for cattle, but hog prices were down again, the report said. ``Oats and wheat were each at their lowest level for the month of December since 1972,'' it said. ``Corn increased slightly from November while the soybean price decreased slightly.'' Most prices are mid-December averages which will be revised next month. No new figures were released to show how much farmers paid to meet expenses. Those are adjusted quarterly. Department economists forecast 1991 consumer food prices will climb an average of 2 percent to 5 percent, compared with a 6 percent gain in 1990. Larger output of some major commodities is expected to help cool the price climb. The net cash income of farmers in 1991 has been forecast by USDA at $55 billion to $60 billion, which could put it down from the record of $59 billion in calendar 1990. As used by the agency, net cash income is simply the difference between gross cash income and cash expenses. In another way of accounting, 1991 net farm income may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with the 1990 record of $49 billion. The report said: -Cattle averaged $77.60 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $75.30 in November. A year earlier cattle averaged $71 per hundredweight. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. -Hogs averaged $47.60 per hundredweight, down from $50.20 in November. A year earlier hogs averaged $48.20. -Corn, at $2.18 per bushel, was up a penny from November but was down 9 cents from a year earlier. -Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $2.38 per bushel, compared with $2.39 in November and $3.79 in December 1989. -Rice averaged $6.26 per 100 pounds, compared with $6.30 in November and $6.95 a year earlier. -Soybeans were $5.74 per bushe, compared with $5.78 in November and $5.64 in December 1989. -Upland cotton was reported at 67.3 cents per pound, compared with 68.2 cents in November and 61.9 cents a year earlier. -Eggs were 76.5 cents per dozen, compared with 72.9 cents in November and 82.8 cents a year earlier. -Broilers were 28.8 cents per pound, live weight, compared with 28.2 in November and 28.6 cents a year earlier. ----

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Sends New Year's Greetings to Soviet, American People
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail Gorbachev said Monday in his New Year's address to the Soviet people that 1990 was one of his country's toughest years. In a speech broadcast nationwide just before midnight, Gorbachev said the ``passing year was one of the most difficult in our history. ... Crisis phenomena in economics, the lowering of people's personal safety, a weakening of order and discipline affected the conditions of life.'' In a remark that would have been uncharacteristic of his predecessors, Gorbachev admitted the leaders of this country of 285 million residents had made mistakes but he did not specify what they were. In the coming year, the Soviets are to vote in a nationwide referendum on whether to join a federation of sovereign republics. The issue is crucial to whether this vast nation of 11 time zones is fractured into individual states, as Lithuania and several other independence-minded republics want. ``There is no more sacred matter than the preservation and renewal of the union in which all people would live voluntarily and well,'' the 59-year-old Kremlin chief said. The Soviet leader, in office nearly six years, called on the people in the 15 republics to achieve ``civil and inter-ethnic accord'' and to work hard together to overcome difficulties in 1991. In a separate New Year's address to the American people on Monday, Gorbachev welcomed February's superpower summit and renewing his call for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Gorbachev acknowledged that 1990 was a difficult year for the Soviet people, but said short-term disruptions were necessary for longterm stability. ``The outgoing year, 1990, as well as the 1980s, was filled with events of great importance,'' he said. ``The Cold War is over. There is no more danger of nuclear catastrophe. The horizons of peace have widened.'' However, the Soviet president said, ``much has not been completed,'' including an end to the crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``The international community has run into a serious obstacle ... the aggression in the gulf,'' he said. ``It should find strength to overcome this obstacle, not to discontinue the advance toward a peaceful period of civilization.'' Gorbachev said he expected his Feb. 11-13 meeting with President Bush in Moscow would give ``new impetus'' to Soviet-American relations, still hampered by some ``old obstacles.'' ``Economic and scientific and technological cooperation still do not respond to the spirit of the time,'' he said.'' On domestic matters, Gorbachev said 1990 was ``a year of principle changes in society, a year of the most difficult but the most necessary decisions.'' ``They will allow this great country - and it remains such - to overcome the critical situation and to follow the path of stable democratic processes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: 17-Year-Olds Called Up in Iraq as Jan. 15 Deadline Nears
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the threat of a U.S.-led attack just 16 days away, Iraq on Monday ordered 17-year-olds to prepare to leave their schools and report for military duty. It is the youngest age group ever drafted in modern Iraq. Even during the 1980-88 war against Iran only 18-year-olds were put into battle, normally at the end of their 18th year. The General Mobilization Headquarters instructed males born in 1973 to sign up with the nearest recruitment center between Wednesday and Jan. 10. It threatened those who fail to enlist with unspecified ``legal action.'' Iraqi teen-agers abroad are not exempted, the agency said. Jan. 15 is the deadline set by the U.N. Security Council for Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. After that date, the multinational forces are authorized to oust Iraq by force. It was the fourth major call-up by Iraq authorities since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. An unspecified number of reservists ages 30, 31 and 32 had been ordered to active duty in previous announcements. It wasn't known how many youths would be affected. The London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies recently said the nation of 17 million has about 1.1 million males aged 13-17, 900,000 ages 18-22 and 1.3 million ages 23-32. Iraq has a regular army of 500,000 with 480,000 reserves, nearly all of whom have been mobilized for the gulf crisis. A 28-nation, U.S.-led multinational force of about 480,000 troops is confronting an estimated 510,000 Iraqis deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq. Also Monday, officials disclosed that 10 civil defense drills were conducted sucessfully in Iraq's northern Duhok Province, along the border with Turkey, after Ankara reportedly reinforced its army in the region. The Duhok Civil Defense officer, Qassim Ahmed Mustafa, told the government newspaper Al-Thawra the drills were aimed at ``preparing the population for war, air raids and mass-destruction weapons.'' Duhok Gov. Mohammed Peroz was quoted as saying that ``contingency plans have been drawn to face up to any eventuality in the event of war.'' Duhok is home for 300,000 Iraqis, most of them ethnic Kurds. Drills were also conducted in recent days in Baghdad and the southern city of Basra. They involved a complete evacuation of the two cities to safe hideouts several miles away. Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said claimed Monday that more than 4,200 people have died because of shortages in medical supplies caused by the U.N. embargo. Western officials have repeatedly challenged similar Iraqi claims. Western officials say Iraq has received 120 tons of medicine from humanitarian groups since mid-October, and have dismissed Baghdad's claims on infant deaths since the embargo. Shipments of food and medicines for humanitarian purposes are not banned by the U.N. embargo begun after the Iraqi invasion. But Baghdad claims many governments have refused to allow export of goods, even medicine ordered and paid for before the sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Acreage Reduction Program Spelled Out by Yeutter
DOC.TEXT: An acreage reduction program for wheat, corn and other crops were among the details of the 1991 commodity programs announced Monday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. Much of the programs were spelled out in the five-year 1990 farm law recently enacted by Congress. The 1991 programs include an ``acreage reduction program'' requirement of 15 percent for wheat; 7.5 percent for corn, barley and sorghum; 5 percent for upland and extra-long staple cotton; and zero percent for oats. The acreage reduction program, or ARP, indicates much of a farmer's base acres must be taken from production in order to qualify for federal price support benefits. Yeutter said farmers can begin signing up at local offices of the Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service in early March. He said specific dates will be announced later. A central feature of the new law will allow farmers greater planting flexibility. Some highlights: -Producers may plant crops other than the program crop - wheat, corn, sorghum, barley, oats, upland cotton and rice - on up to 25 percent of any participating program crop acreage base. This will be known as ``flex'' acreage. -Permitted crops on flex acreage are: any program crop, any oilseed, any designated industrial of experimental crop, and any other crop except fruit or vegetables, including potatoes, dry edible beans, lentils and peas. -The secretary may, however, prohibit the planting of any crop on flex acreage and is required to make available a list of prohibited crops. -The first 15 percent of the flex acreage will be known as ``normal flex acreage,'' or NFA, and the other 10 percent will be known as ``optional flex acreage,'' or OFA. Further details of the 1991 crop programs will be available from local ASCS offices. ----

DOC.HEAD: Beckwith Arrested On Governor's Warrant In Evers Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A white supremacist arrested here Monday could be returned to Mississippi this week to face a third trial for the 1963 slaying of civil rights leader Medgar Evers. Byron De La Beckwith, 70, was arrested on a governor's warrant charging him with first-degree murder and was jailed without bond. Beckwith's attorney, Russell Bean, filed a writ of habeas corpus seeking his release and a hearing was set for Wednesday before Hamilton County Criminal Court Judge Joe DiRisio, who will decide on extradition. If DiRisio finds the governor's warrant is in order, he could immediately turn Beckwith over to Mississippi authorities, said Hamilton County Chief Deputy Jim Hammond. ``The purpose of that hearing is basically just to try to keep (Beckwith) from going to Mississippi by (his attorney) saying it's improper paperwork,'' Hammond said. Beckwith was tried twice in 1964 for the slaying of Evers, field secretary for the NAACP, who was killed by a sniper's bullet in front of his Jackson, Miss., home on June 12, 1963. Both trials ended with the all-white juries unable to reach a verdict, and the murder charge was dismissed in 1969. The case was reopened in 1990 amid charges of jury and evidence tampering in those trials. Beckwith, an avowed racist, has denied killing Evers and contends the indictment is ``nonsense, poppycock and just something to stir the people up ... and incite the lower forms of life.'' Beckwith, who has lived on nearby Signal Mountain for nearly eight years, was arrested on a fugitive warrant Dec. 17 after a Hinds County, Miss., grand jury indicted him again. Beckwich, who vowed to fight extradition ``tooth, nail and claw,'' had been free on $15,000 bond since a Dec. 18 hearing before Hamilton County General Sessions Judge H. L. Smith. Smith had ordered Beckwith to return to court Feb. 22, but the quick processing of the governor's warrant, which was signed by both Mississippi Gov. Ray Mabus and Tennessee Gov. Ned McWherter, eliminates the need for that appearance. Beckwith ``is now ready to travel unless he can block it through some legal maneuver,'' Hammond said. Beckwith did not resist when two officers served the warrant Monday morning at his home, Hammond said. ``I think he was surprised it was this soon, but I think he's been expecting to hear something,'' he said. Beckwith's wife, Thelma, said her husband had vowed to ``stand taller than any of them'' if he is extradited. ``This is not fair to him,'' she said. ``There is a certain political element that is doing this to him. It's politically motivated.'' Sheriff's deputies were not allowing telephone calls to Beckwith on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Bouterse Offered Reinstatement as Suriname's Military Chief
DOC.TEXT: Cmdr. Desi Bouterse, Suriname's most powerful figure the past decade, has been asked to return as its military chief by a government selected by coup leaders, political sources said Monday. The sources said the military asked President Johan Kraag, who took office over the weekend replacing ousted President Ramsewak Shankar, to reinstate Bouterse as commander of the armed forces. ``It's just a formality. Bouterse will accept,'' the sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bouterse, a former dictator, officially resigned as army chief hours before the Christmas Eve coup that overthrew Shankar. Bouterse was widely believed to have been behind the coup, and his reinstatement would seem to confirm that view. President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela said Monday that his country had broken relations with Suriname because its government ``brings shame upon the dignity of the Americas.'' Perez, in his New Year's Eve address in Caracas, compared Suriname with Kuwait and called it ``intolerable'' that the world risked war over ``a small nation in the gulf'' yet overlooked the unseating of democracy in Suriname. Suriname's military has promised to hold popular elections within 100 days of the coup, with Kraag, a veteran politician, as the interim president. The ethnically diverse nation of 400,000 people on the northeast coast of South America is a former colony of the Netherlands that won independence in 1975. It has suffered a progressive economic crisis since 1980, the year Bouterse staged a coup. The Dutch government suspended a $1.5 billion aid program after Bouterse killed 15 of his political opponents in 1982. The economy has also been hurt by a guerrilla war and plunging world prices for bauxite, the main export. In 1987, a three-party coalition led by Shankar defeated Bouterse's candidate in popular elections. Shankar took office the next year, but Bouterse remained as army chief and chairman of the five-man Military Authority, the equivalent of a military high command. Shankar and Bouterse have often been at odds and their feud culminated last week. Bouterse accused Shankar of colluding with Dutch authorities who refused to grant him a visa when he landed at the Amsterdam airport.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Denies Report of Bomber Production Freeze
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force on Monday denied a published report that it has abandoned plans to build more B-2 stealth bombers in 1991. The Wall Street Journal said Air Force Secretary Donald Rice had decided to freeze B-2 production at the current level of 15 planes, and that the $4.1 billion approved by Congress for the B-2 program in 1991 would be spent to continue assembling and testing only those planes already approved for production. The Air Force issued a brief statement in response to the Journal report. ``No final decision on how the Air Force will apply fiscal year 1991 B-2 funds has been made,'' the statement said, adding that Congress would be notified once the decision is made. The Air Force said it remains ``strongly committed'' to pursuing the full production run of 75 B-2 bombers as approved by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, and that it believes ``the revolutionary advantages of stealth'' radar-evading technology will be borne out in 1991. ``The B-2 continues to enjoy the confidence of the Air Force and remains its highest priority,'' the statement said. The B-2 incorporates much novel technology and has been plagued by cost overruns as a result. Each plane of the production run of 75 would cost an estimated $850 million. The Air Force said it is still trying to figure out the intent of Congress on the B-2. Until the last minute, the House version of the defense budget barred construction of the 16th and 17th B-2, which the Pentagon had planned for the current year, while the Senate version authorized those planes. The compromise version that was signed by President Bush was silent on the issue. Some members of the House have said the Pentagon may not spend money on the additional aircraft while other members have said the Pentagon could go ahead in the absence of an explicit prohibition.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Drafting Teen-Agers; Europeans Ready to Talk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Baker plans to visit gulf countries, perhaps Europe before Jan. 15 deadline. CORRECTS time element to December, not earlier this month, in 10th graf `Poos said ...' Picks up 11th graf, `Poos also ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XRIY3, MLA2,4,6, FRA1, LaserColor XRIY103
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Monday ordered 17-year-olds to report for military duty, the youngest yet to be called for possible combat in the Persian Gulf. European officials indicated they were ready to hold both direct and indirect talks with Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will probably visit Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations to consult with U.S. allies before the United Nations' Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, a Bush administration official said Monday in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. Baker may expand his visit to include Europe, said the official, who was traveling with Vice President Dan Quayle on a three-day visit to Saudi Arabia. World leaders, in New Year's messages, expressed hopes for peace in the gulf. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev praised international resolve in confronting Saddam Hussein. Japan held out the prospect of renewed financial aid if Iraq quits Kuwait. On ships at sea and in desert encampments in Saudi Arabia, tens of thousands of American troops marked another holiday far from home. Like last week's Christmas celebrations, New Year's Eve festivities in the desert were muted and alcohol-free in deference to Saudi sensibilities. French troops toasted the new year with ``Saudi champagne'' - apple juice and Perrier. Quayle called U.S. front-line troops in Saudi Arabia ``heroes'' and told them ``the whole world will be grateful'' if they fight to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. A day earlier, Quayle lobbied Saudi leaders to come up with more money to help pay for the huge U.S. gulf deployment, expected to reach 420,000 troops in the next few weeks. Senior administration officials said King Fahd gave assurances that the kingdom would provide more cash and services to support the multinational force. With only two weeks remaining before the U.N. deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face potential military action, the Europeans were leading fresh efforts to talk instead of fight. European Community foreign ministers plan to meet in emergency session on Friday to discuss the gulf crisis, and Luxembourg's foreign minister, Jacques Poos, said Monday that some might push for a meeting between him and his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz. Luxembourg will take over the EC's rotating chairmanship on Tuesday. Poos said if the foreign ministers decided to send him to Baghdad for talks, he would be ready to go. The community in December canceled a meeting with Aziz after the United States and Iraq failed to agree on dates for direct talks. Poos also said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. he expected there would be contact with Iraq either ``through diplomatic channels or a private talk.'' In Bonn, German officials speaking on condition of anonymity also raised the possibility of ``indirect talks'' with Iraq. But the Europeans sought to dispel any notion they were splitting away from the U.S.-led alliance against Iraq. Luxembourg Prime Minister Jacques Santer said Friday's meeting should reaffirm EC solidarity with the international coalition. In another piece of stage-setting for the EC talks, Jordan's King Hussein was to travel to Europe this week, and Jordanian officials said he still hoped for a peaceful resolution of the crisis. ``Time is running out and we do not want to see war erupting in this region,'' a high-ranking Jordanian official said on condition of anonymity. French President Francois Mitterrand, in a New Year's address, said comprehensive talks on Mideast problems including the Israeli-Palestinian conflict could come only after an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. ``It's necessary that Iraq must be convinced - Kuwait occupied, nothing possible; Kuwait evacuated, everything can happen,'' Mitterrand said. Bush and Gorbachev, in televised New Year's greetings, hailed international solidarity in the face of the gulf crisis. ``I applaud, the world applauds, the decisive action of the Soviet Union in strongly opposing Saddam Hussein's brutal aggression in the gulf,'' Bush said. Gorbachev said the international community ``should find strength to overcome this obstacle, not to discontinue the advance toward a peaceful period of civilization.'' The Japanese offer to resume financial aid to Baghdad came in a broadcast by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, taped for New Year's broadcast. ``I hope that Iraq will make a decision for a peaceful solution. If it does, then Japan is prepared to extend economic cooperation,'' he said. Japan, once Iraq's biggest aid donor, froze nearly $3 billion in assistance after the invasion. Iraq's order for 17-year-old males to report for military duty was the fourth major callup of reserves since it seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. It was unclear how many draftees were involved, but it was one more indication of Baghdad's growing preparations for possible war. Iraqi officials disclosed Monday that civil defense drills were conducted in recent days in a northern province along the border with Turkey. In other developments Monday: -The Pentagon said five U.S. troops died in separate incidents in the Persian Gulf in recent days. The deaths raise to 93 the number of American troops who have died in Operation Desert Shield. -PLO chairman Yasser Arafat said Israel is pushing the United States into a war against Iraq to serve its own ends. ``We are not reading the future, but this is what Israel wants - to annihilate Iraq's military and technical power,'' Arafat said in an interview with The Associated Press in Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Historic Commission Designation Violates Freedom of Religion
DOC.TEXT: A landmark commission's attempt to regulate changes inside a Jesuit church in the city's historic South End violated the free exercise of religion, the state's highest court ruled Monday. ``The government interest in historic preservation, though worthy, is not sufficiently compelling to justify restraints on the free exercise of religion, a right of primary importance,'' the state Supreme Judicial Court said in a unanimous opinion. The dispute revolved around the designation of the interior of the Church of the Immaculate Conception as a landmark. ``There are fewer finer examples of classic mid-19th century church design,'' the court said in its opinion. The National Trust for Historic Preservation, the American Jewish Congress and the Council on Religious Freedom were among groups that filed friend of the court briefs in the case. In 1986, the Jesuits developed a plan to renovate the aging church and build an office, counseling and residential space. When the renovation work began, 10 registered city voters promptly petitioned the Boston Landmarks Commission to designate the interior of the 127-year-old church as a landmark. The granite church is located near Boston City Hospital, and once served Boston College students before the school moved out of the city, said Father Paul Kenney, a spokesman for the Society of Jesus of New England. ``It's overall impression is one of light,'' Kenney said of the structure's interior. In 1987, the commission approved the landmark designation for portions of the church. The designation made any permanent alteration of the nave, vestibule, chancel and organ loft on the main floor, as well as other architectural details, subject to the commission's approval. Under the designation, the Jesuits were only allowed to install non-permanent furnishings and to conduct routine maintenance inside the church. The commission eventually allowed the Jesuits to make some renovations to the interior. But in the meantime, the Jesuits filed a lawsuit contending the landmark designation was unconstitutional. In a unanimous ruling, the Supreme Judicial Court agreed. But the court framed the decision narrowly, referring only to a section of the Massachusetts constitution. The decision did not refer to federal guarantees of religious freedom. The court also made no ruling on the preservation of church exteriors, noting the case dealt only with a church interior. ``Under our hierarchy of constitutional values we must accept the possible loss of historically significant elements of the interior of this church as the price of safeguarding the right of religious freedom,'' the court said. Edward Hanify, an attorney who represented the Jesuits, said the case represents a key decision for all denominations. ``I'm delighted that we have what I would say is a historic and compelling decision about religious freedom,'' Hanify said. John Kenneth Felter, the attorney for the landmark commission, said he could not comment on the case until he discussed the outcome with his clients. Andrea Ferster, an attorney for the National Trust for Historic Preservation, said the ruling is narrow enough so that its impact nationally is muted.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Cross Border Into Greece, Albanian Jews Also Leaving
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Refugees arriving...' to ADD that refugees say they began their trek after hearing by word-of-mouth that guards were not keeping people from crossing the border; pickup 7th graf pvs, `But in...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Albanians trekked across frozen mountains and rivers Monday to seek refuge in Greece despite the promise of reforms by their Communist government. Albanian Jews also were leaving for Israel. Meanwhile, a government spokesman announced that Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis will pay a two-day visit to Albania on Jan. 13. He will be the first Greek prime minister to visit Albania. Military sources in this northwestern Greek border town said more than 600 Albanians, most of them ethnic Greeks, had crossed the frontier since daybreak. More than 700 braved sub-freezing temperatures, snow and craggy terrain to walk across the frontier Sunday, bringing the weekend total to more than 1,500. ``It's been increasing geometrically in the last few days. I have the distinct impression that they have opened the borders,'' regional police chief Brigadier Andreas Vergis said as he struggled to count the Albanians swarming into his three-room police station. Many refugees said they encountered no resistance on the frontier and that they began the journey after hearing by word-of-mouth that they would not be shot if they tried to cross the border. Some said guards also were defecting, allowing the flow of refugees to snowball along the once tightly guarded frontier. But in Tirana, the Albanian capital, a government official described as absurd reports alleging that the country's border is being opened for visa-free passage. The official warned people against trying to cross it ``by force.'' Albanian radio, monitored in London by the British Broadcasting Corp., said the reports of the border opening were made by foreign media in an attempt to incite Albanians to leave the country illegally. In addition to the ethnic Greeks, many in Albania's small Jewish community were making their way out. Israeli media reported Monday that four Albanian Jewish families had arrived in Israel and dozens more were expected in coming weeks. Israel radio said the Jewish immigration was made possible by a recent agreement between Italy and Albania, the last of the hard-line Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. But Italian government officials reached Monday said they had no knowledge of any such agreement. The Italian Embassy in Tirana said it had issued 37 visas for Albanian Jews and that it did not have any applications for others. Israeli government officials were tight-lipped about the immigration of Albanian Jews, apparently fearful of harming the effort. ``This is going to save Albanian Jews from total extinction. Had they remained there, they would have been wiped out in a generation,'' said Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum, a consultant to the American Jewish Committee in New York. The Albanian Jewish community numbers only about 1,000, officials said. Greek Foreign Minister Andonis Samaras appealed to ethnic Greeks to remain in Albania ``and enjoy the fruits of democracy'' as reforms are introduced. The Albanian government of President Ramiz Alia has promised such reforms as allowing religious services and the establishment of opposition parties. But the refugees say they do not have faith in the promises. ``We didn't believe Alia,'' said Zisis Karkasainas, a 26-year-old economics graduate. Greek officials estimate about 350,000 of Albania's 3.3 million people are ethnic Greeks. The strain of the sudden influx can already be seen in the border towns. ``I've been working 24 hours a day for a week now. We don't have enough food for all these people,'' said a woman who identified herself only as Anastasia. She was in charge of a kitchen in an old orphanage that has been trying to feed all the Albanians who have crossed the border in the last two days. Dozens of refugees waited in a long line outside the orphange. Police estimated that 95 percent of the Albanians who crossed the border are ethnic Greeks who lived in frontier villages. Ethnic Greeks are given temporary residence permits while the other Albanians are taken to a United Nations refugee center outside Athens. Most of them crossed the border near Filiates, a town of 5,000, because the terrain is less mountainous than elsewhere along the 100-mile border. ``They should declare a state of emergency up here, we can't cope any more,'' said Father Zilis, the town priest. He and three other residents formed a committee to help the refugees with food, clothing and shelter. The mayor, Pantelis Koufalas, on Sunday sent a telex to Premier Constantine Mitsotakis pleading for assistance. A small Greek army border detachment began cooking for the refugees after a makeshift soup kitchen ran out of food and groups of refugees tried to force their way into the orphanage. ``Look at them, your heart breaks, but what more can we do?'' committee member Nikolas Georgopoulos said. Most of the refugees, wearing donated clothes, sat in the mud outside the orphanage. Shepherd Ilias Bouros brought his wife, two infant children, a 65-year-old grandmother and a nephew to Greece from the town of Sarande. ``I walked 18 hours to get here, with my family,'' he said. ``We're tired but happy to get out of Albania.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire on Rioting Prisoners; 1 Killed, 15 Wounded
DOC.TEXT: Jail guards opened fire Monday on hundreds of rioting prisoners, killing at least one inmate and wounding 15 prisoners, police and news reports said. The prisoners demanded former President Hussain Muhammad Ershad be hanged and claimed they were unfairly imprisoned under martial law. They wanted to speak to leaders of the opposition coalition that forced Ershad's resignation Dec. 6. The riot in this southeastern port's main prison followed a similar incident Saturday in Dhaka in which three prisoners were fatally shot by prison guards. Officials at the Chittagong Central Jail said prisoners brandishing iron rods and and sticks attacked policemen who were serving dinner. At least 20 policemen were injured in the violence that appears to have been inspired by the Dhaka Central Jail riot, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was not immediately clear how the prisoners armed themselves, they said. Hundreds of prisoners rampaged through the jail, disconnected the electricity and broke open doors of several cells, releasing ``dangerous prisoners,'' the officials said. The United News of Bangladesh news agency said two prisoners were killed in the firing. Chittagong Police Chief Wahidul Huq confirmed one death and injuries to 15 to 20 prisoners. The conflicting death toll could not be immediately reconciled. ``It may take time to persuade the prisoners to return to their lockups,'' a senior jail official said speaking on condition of anonymity. He said 2,190 prisoners were packed in the jail meant for 726 people. In Dhaka, 135 miles northwest of Chittagong, chaos continued in the Dhaka Central Jail. On Monday, prisoners handed over to authorities the decomposing bodies of the three inmates who were killed Saturday, jail officials said. At least 100 more inmates were injured when police there opened fire to stop an attempted jailbreak by 4,800 inmates. The prisoners refused to return to their cells and also asked to talk to leaders of the two top political parties. There was no immediate comment from the two top politicians, Sheik Hasina of the Awami League and Khaleda Zia of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. At least 22 inmates have escaped amid the administrative collapse that followed the riots, news reports said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Incoming Gov Faces Fiscal Crisis Similar To One Dukakis Found
With AM-Cuomo's Third Term, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Gov. Michael S. Dukakis took over Massachusetts from a Republican governor, the economy was spiraling downward and the state budget was mired in red ink. Sixteen years later, Dukakis passes the reins to another Republican and returns the fiscal favor. The economy is in the cellar and the Duke's successor, William Weld, faces painful budget cuts or tax increases. Dukakis leaves office Thursday as the longest serving governor in state history. His three-term tenure - interrupted for four years from 1979 to 1983 - is studded with accomplishments and controversy, political heights and electoral disaster. But the fiscal and economic condition of Massachusetts that Dukakis leaves behind mirrors the circumstances he inherited in 1975 as a hard-charging, can-do reformer. ``It looks to me, as an outsider, as though it's a hell of a lot worse mess now,'' said former Gov. Francis W. Sargent, who planned to attend Thursday's inaugural and welcome in the first Republican governor of Massachusetts since he lost to Dukakis. ``When the Duke came in, I think he had an idea that he was going to be able to bring the budget home and spread it out on the kitchen table and figure out where he could cut,'' Sargent said. Dukakis promised no new taxes in his 1974 gubernatorial campaign. And when he took office he adopted as a symbol a meat cleaver that he said would be needed to cut state government down to size. He promised ``a Herculean effort to reduce expenditures, to eliminate waste.'' But Dukakis and his fiscal advisers discovered that the state was in deep financial trouble. Hundreds of millions in Medicaid bills were unpaid, the state welfare department was in debt. A modest surplus of six months earlier became, early in 1975, a deficit of between $350 million and $500 million - a huge chunk in a state who's total budget was about $3 billion. With unemployment at 11.2 percent and with oil prices soaring amid the Arab oil embargo, the state economy was in no condition to bail out state government. Less than a year after taking office, Dukakis had to eat his campaign promise and back the largest tax increase in the state's history. The parallels in Massachusetts today are startling. Oil prices are again on the rise, pushed by a different crisis in the Mideast. Unemployment is increasing, though it has not yet reached the double-digit levels of the mid-1970s. And, once again, the problems confronting Massachusetts coincide with a national economic slump and with similar fiscal crises elsewhere. Dukakis disputes those who predict he will leave behind a large deficit. ``There is no comparison,'' Dukakis said in an interview Monday. ``In 1975 we were looking at a budget deficit that was 25 percent of the total.'' In the past few months, Dukakis has been able to present his successor with a detailed appraisal of the state's fiscal condition. ``In '75 we didn't have that kind of information,'' Dukakis said. ``Nobody paid attention to monthly revenue estimates back then.'' Still, Massachusetts does face the prospect of a sizable deficit. Some state legislators have estimated the state would wind up some $300 million in the red at the end of the fiscal year next June. Governor-elect Weld said this week his advisers put the deficit as high as $750 million. Weld bound himself to a no-new-taxes promise. Much as Dukakis did in 1975, Weld is talking about laying off public employees to balance the books. And the state Legislature is in no mood to consider a tax increase. In 1975, the Legislature was dominated by liberal Democrats who had no qualms about raising taxes and, indeed, urged Dukakis to abandon his no-new-taxes pledge. Today's Legislature still has a majority of Democrats and some surviving liberals. But they're wary of voters who are in no mood to shell out more tax dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Talk About Religious Police, Women Drivers, War Fears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to ADD more background on significance of news conference; pickup 16th graf pvs, `Since the...'
DOC.TEXT: Six prominent Saudi men, in a rare public airing of views, spoke Monday of overzealous religious police, a demonstration by women drivers that backfired and fears that war would destroy their country. The significance of the news conference was not so much in the Saudis' views - which largely reflect the government's positions - but in the fact that they agreed to talk on the record. News conferences by Saudi citizens were unheard of before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait because few journalists were allowed into the country and because Saudis are reluctant to freely state their opinions. The hour-long news conference covered everything from gas masks for foreign workers to the possibility of a permanent U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia, as well as windfall profits from rising oil prices and production. But it was the possibility of war with Iraq - an Arab brother nation that the Saudis had supported with $20 billion during the eight-year war with Iran - that stirred their emotions. The United Nations has set a deadline of Jan. 15 for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face a possible military attack. Salih A. Al-Toaimi, secretary general of the Chamber of Commerce in Riyadh, said he was praying for ``a miracle'' - that Saddam Hussein will withdraw peacefully from Kuwait. ``I personally think it will happen,'' he said. ``Nobody wants war. I think the highest price ever paid by everybody will be much, much cheaper than the consequences of war so we all should do our best to avoid it,'' he said. ``All people ... are concerned and hate to see our country, and even Iraq, destroyed.'' Dr. Ali Al-Namlah, an associate professor at Imam Mohammed Bin Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, said the Saudis are ready psychologically to face the consequences of war, but hope for peace. ``We are waiting for miracles to happen. We are waiting for a tough decision by the ruler of Iraq,'' he said. The deployment of more than 300,000 U.S. troops has opened a window, however small, in this conservative Moslem country, where alcohol is banned and women must be completely covered in public. Dr. Fahad Al-Samari, a professor of economics and political science at the Islamic University, said he had studied the presence of U.S. troops in Vietnam and there was a definite difference in their behavior here. ``We have seen the American troops are behaving very well,'' he said. ``They have been briefed. They are following the rules, respecting the culture, respecting the Saudis, respecting the norms and traditions here.'' But like the other Saudis, he said, all foreign troops must leave as soon as Kuwait is liberated and the country must build a large army to defend itself. ``Every society doesn't want any foreigners to stay in that military aspect,'' he explained. ``If you have a house and you have a soldier by your house, you want it from the family, not outside the family who doesn't know your system or understand you.'' The Ministry of Information arranged the news conference in response to requests from some of the hundreds of journalists covering the U.S. military buildup who wanted to get a Saudi civilian perspective on the Gulf crisis. All six of the participants spoke fluent English. Since the arrival of U.S. troops, there has been a Western-style demonstration by about 40 Saudi women who drove through Riyadh to protest a ban on women driving. There has also been a crackdown by the religious police, called the muttawa, who have invaded several private homes where parties were being held. Al-Namlah said the muttawa's role was to ``control society for anything which violates Islamic law'' and they probably had authorization to break into people's homes. But Ibrahim Al-Touq, chairman of the Riyadh Chamber of Commerce, said the muttawa just had a role in keeping certain traditions and religious teachings and ``in certain instances I think they overdo it.'' ``Many Saudis don't agree with people breaking into houses without any reason,'' he said. ``We were very much concerned about this becoming more extreme - or more the rule rather than the exception - and we expressed our views to the departments concerned and I'm sure they understood the concern of the people.'' Although there is nothing in Islamic law against women driving, the ban is a Saudi tradition and Al-Touqsaid the women should have tested public opinion first and tried to win support instead of springing the protest. ``The very conservative people were surprised and were scared of such a thing. They thought this was maybe the beginning of, let's say, a revolution, or something very bad happening,'' he said. Some of the women who were professors have been suspended from their jobs, and all the women have been banned from traveling outside the country.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Woman Killed Planting Bomb in Jerusalem
LaserPhoto JRL3
DOC.TEXT: A young Arab woman was killed Monday when a bomb she apparently was carrying exploded in a public toilet at the crowded Mahane Yehuda outdoor market in Jewish West Jerusalem, police said. She was the only casualty and little damage was caused other than a broken toilet window. Shahar Ayalon, a senior police officer, said a bag of vegetables was found beside the woman, and ``it is reasonable to assume that she intended to plant the bomb in the bag and place it on one of the adjacent streets.'' Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner linked the explosion to increased Palestinian protests expected for Tuesday's anniversary of the first armed attack in Israel by the mainstream Fatah faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1965. ``I have no doubt it is connected,'' Terner told Israel radio. Authorities added police reinforcements and imposed widespread curfews on the occupied territories to head off violence. The underground leadership of the 3-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation urged marches, firebomb-throwing and lighting of torches for the anniversary. ``We salute the revolution of the rifles, the revolution of armed struggle,'' said a leaflet issued Monday by the PLO-backed uprising leaders. Also Monday, police arrested a 19-year-old Israeli and said he confessed to shooting and wounding a Palestinian doctor; the doctor's sister and her 9-month-old daughter last week in the West Bank, Israel radio reported. The attack caused a furor among Palestinians since a previously unknown group calling itself the Jewish Avengers claimed responsibility and pledged to carry out more such actions. The suspect's name was not released, but police told Israel radio the man acted alone as revenge for the slaying of a relative by an Arab. The national news agency Itim said he was a soldier whose brother was fatally stabbed by a Palestinian. Police identified Monday's explosion victim as a 24-year-old Palestinian woman from the Bethlehem area in the occupied West Bank, but refused to give her name. Palestinians said she was Amal Mustafa Itabbi, a resident of the Aida refugee camp who was pregnant and married to a man jailed for 15 months during the uprising. The explosion occurred about 11:30 a.m. ``Apparently the person who was handling the charge was killed in this toilet stall,'' Terner said. He said she was alone and was ``torn to pieces'' by the explosion, but shopkeeper Meir Cohen said she was still alive moments after the blast. Cohen said he ran into the toilet and found her under a fallen door. ``She was alive, the woman. I lifted her head. She moved her head as if she wanted to speak, wanted help,'' he said. Appeals over the market's public address system warned shoppers to ``be wary of suspicious packages and report anything suspicious to the police.'' Knots of young men gathered, many of them ultra-orthodox Jews, waving fists and chanting ``Death to the Arabs!'' For the 22nd time during the uprising, the seaside Gaza Strip, home to 750,000 Palestinians, was placed under virtually blanket curfew, as was Nablus, the West Bank's largest city, and many villages and refugee camps.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's 200,000th Immigrant of Year Arrives
LaserPhoto TLV1
DOC.TEXT: Israel's 200,000th immigrant of 1990 stepped off the airplane on Monday into a celebration that some immigration officials called inappropriate. Igor Goldfarb, 25, an engineer from the Ural Mountains region in the Soviet Union, was met by Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon and other legislators. Peretz handed Goldfarb an Israeli flag as an accordion played and Sharon said, ``I hope that in the not too distant future we will be standing here and celebrating the arrival of the 2 millionth immigrant.'' Goldfarb and his mother plan to live with his brother, who has an apartment in Petah Tikva. He told reporters in Russian he wants to marry an Israeli. About 90 percent of the immigrants who came in 1990 are Soviets. Officials say they expect 400,000 Soviets to arrive in each of the coming two years. Missing from Monday's singing and dancing was Simha Dinitz, chief of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, responsible for transporting and absorbing immigrants. Dinitz said he would celebrate only after Israel successfully absorbed all prospective immigrants, granting them housing and employment. ``We are very happy and glad that so many people are coming,'' said Jewish Agency spokesman Gad Ben Ari. ``But this is the time for work and not for celebrating.'' Dinitz's absence underlined government inability to agree on how to handle the wave of Soviet Jews expected to total 1 million in the next two years. Israel's population now is about 4.5 million. Sharon, chairman of a special Cabinet committee overseeing immigrant absorption, disparaged a plan Peretz introduced on Sunday to put immigrants in tent camps. ``I don't find anything clever in this idea,'' Sharon told Israel radio Monday. He urged instead that Israelis with unrented apartments make them available to immigrants until new housing is built. Plans for starting construction on 45,000 new housing units in 1990 have been derailed by similar disagreements and bureaucratic delays. Peretz has refused to attend meetings of Sharon's committee, and Soviet immigrants groups have accused the government of failing to anticipate the strain on housing, jobs and social services. Israelis also grumble about the burden they have to bear as the government plans to raise taxes and cut the minimum wage. ``From the minute the immigrants will come it will get worse. Our youth will be pushed aside and first of all the immigrants will be taken care of,'' Shimon Mizrahi said on Israel television. Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai said Monday that as more immigrants pour in, the Israeli public have to make bigger sacrifices. The national insurance company Bituach Leumi released its annual report Monday counting 118,000 families below the poverty line, and said 110,000 more families would fall into poverty in 1991 if the burden on the population increased, Israel TV said. The rush of immigration follows liberalized exit policies by the Soviet government and tighter rules for entry into the United States. Some officials say immigration totals could hit 1 million in 1991 alone. Legislator Michael Kleiner, chairman of Parliament's immigration committee, left Monday for Ethiopia and said he hoped all 20,000 Ethiopian Jews could be brought to Israel in the next year. The small community of about 1,000 Albanian Jews also has begun emigrating under liberalized policies in the Eastern European country. Peretz calls inadequate Sharon's plan for putting immigrants in rental apartments and mobile homes. Sharon said Israel managed to house the many immigrants who arrived in the past year - ``We absorbed 200,000 people and no one is out on the street.'' New arrivals are being housed in army camps and hotels.

DOC.HEAD: Council Consults on Violence, But No Accord to Criticize Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, The latest ... CORRECTING that anniversary not of Fatah's founding but of Fatah's first armed attack in Israel. Picks up 9th graf, `Diplomats said ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council held urgent consultations Monday about violence in the occupied territories but failed to agree on a PLO statement condemning killings by Israeli security forces. It was the council's final session of 1990. A resurgence of violence in which more Palestinians died could put Israel and the Security Council on a collision course and pressure the council to impose sanctions on Israel, as it has upon Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. Israel thwarted U.N. efforts to investigate after at least 17 Palestinians were killed in rioting on Temple Mount on Oct. 8. That lead to a council decision to involve itself in Israel's treatment of Palestinians and to request the secretary-general to conduct urgent monitoring of their treatment. ``It is time for the United Nations to act and to implement relevant resolutions protecting Palestinians. But unfortunately, the United States blocked action by the council,'' said M. Nasser Al-Kidwa, acting U.N. observer of Palestine. U.S. diplomats declined comment but Western diplomats said they would seek more time for study before approving a hastily proposed statement requiring consensus by the entire 15-member council. The sources spoke on condition of anonymity. Yemen, outgoing president of the council for December, called the meeting to discuss what it said were the shooting deaths of six Palestinians and the wounding of 120 over the weekend. The Israeli army said four Palestinians were killed and 90 wounded in the unrest. It amended its earlier report that five were killed, saying one death turned out to be from a heart attack. The latest violence was reported to stem from anniversary celebrations of the first armed attack in Israel by Fatah, the mainstream branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization, on Jan. 1, 1965. Diplomats said after closed consultations that no agreement emerged, that the United States sought more factual information about the violence and Britain and other governments did not have instructions. The issue is expected to be considered this week when Zaire becomes council president for January. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar issued a statement from an undisclosed vacation site, saying he was ``deeply concerned'' by weekend clashes in the Gaza Strip, where Palestinians ``were shot and killed and many were injured by Israeli security forces.'' He asked the U.N. Relief Works Agency, which cars for Palestinian refugees, for information about incidents that occurred in Palestinian refugee camps. General Assembly President Guido de Marco will visit refugee camps in the occupied territories and in Jordan from Wednesday through Monday. Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War and still occupies those territories.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala President Accepts U.S. Extradition Request
DOC.TEXT: President Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo said Monday that Guatemala is prepared to extradite three men wanted on drug charges in the United States if courts approve the extraditions. U.S. officials are seeking the extradition of Zacapa Mayor Arnoldo Vargas Estrada and businessmen Victor Manuel Escobar and Otto Quiroz, who were arrested Thursday and are charged with conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States. The defense minister, Gen. Juan Leonel Bolanos Flores, told reporters Monday the government had received another request to extradite three military officers who were recently dishonorably discharged because of drug allegations. But James Dickmeyer, a spokesman for the U.S. embassy, said he was unaware of any extradition request for the three military officers. The cases of former Col. Carlos Rene Ochoa Ruiz and Capts. Leonel Perez Franco and Jose Maria Flores Montes are now before Guatemalan civilian courts. Under Guatemalan law, extradition petitions go to the supreme court, which assigns the case to a lower court judge for study. If he finds the petition has legal merit, it goes to the president, who decides whether to approve or deny the request. Vargas was arrested in Zacapa, 90 miles east of the capital. Police said they confiscated 287 kilos of cocaine valued at $57.4 million. Vargas, 52, was recently re-elected to a five-year term as mayor on the National Center Union ticket. He has claimed the drug charges are a frame-up to discredit his party's presidential candidate, Jorge Carpio Nicolle, who faces Jorge Serrano Elias in a Jan. 6 runoff election. In early December, Guatemalan citizen Rufino Arriaza Cordova was extradited to Miami to face drug charges.

DOC.HEAD: Soprano Dame Joan Sutherland Bids Emotional Goodbye to London
DOC.TEXT: Dame Joan Sutherland, one of the great sopranos of the century, bade an emotional farewell to her British admirers at the Royal Opera House on New Year's Eve. Dame Joan was showered Monday with bouquets thrown from the orchestra stalls and with carnations from the boxes above the stage when she sang with her friends Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti and American mezzo soprano Marilyn Horne. At one point Dame Joan wept as Pavarotti sang directly to her. The 64-year-old Australian diva offically retired in a performance at Sydney Opera House in October but expressed a wish to sing once more in Covent Garden, where she made her debut in 1952. The opera house arranged a special interlude in ``Die Fledermaus'' by Johann Strauss so the three singers could appear together.

DOC.HEAD: President Pledges End to Lebanese Civil War Amid Cabinet Boycott
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi pledged Monday to accelerate the peaceful reconciliation of Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, but three leading Christian Cabinet members boycotted the New Year's address. ``We shall consolidate security in greater Beirut and transform it into a dynamic peace proces to bring the civil war to an end,'' Hrawi said in his address, broadcast nationwide on radio and television. ``Your newly formed government is committed to accelerating the process of peace to regain Lebanon's full sovereignty over its entire territory,'' Hrawi said. In November, militias withdrew from Beirut and handed control of the capital to the government as a first step toward ending the civil war that has claimed 150,000 lives. `The capital is now united in greater Beirut with the army in full control and all militias out,'' Hrawi said. But seven of the Cabinet's 30 members were absent from the Monday night meeting. At least three of them - Telecommunications Minister George Saadeh of the Phalange Party, Labor Minister Michel Sassin of the Liberal Party, and Minister without Portfolio Samir Geagea of the Lebanese Forces - boycotted the meeting. Geagea and Saadeh, both leaders of righ-wing Christian groups, have said they would reject their appointments in the government. They have said the government is pro-Syrian and therefore incapable of ending the civil war. Sassin had said he would not take his post unless Geagea and Saadeh assumed theirs. In his speech, Hrawi called on the three to join the government. His aides said the president was confident that behind-the-scenes intermediaries would persuade Geagea and Saadeh to drop their boycott. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon and has strongly backed Hrawi's government.

DOC.HEAD: Cold in the West Continues, Record Warmth for the East
DOC.TEXT: A bitter cold wave that has blitzed much of the West and the nation's midsection persisted on the last day of 1990. Temperatures dipped below freezing across most of the West early Monday. Snow and blustery winds brought winter storm warnings to the Pacific Northwest and the northern Rockies. A winter storm warning was in effect through New Year's Day for parts of northern Idaho, eastern Idaho and northern Montana west of the Continental Divide. Morning lows above freezing were mainly confined to the Gulf Coast while subzero readings prevailed from the northern and central Plains to Upper Michigan. The coldest spot in the Lower 48 states was Hibbing, Minn., where the barometer dipped to 30 below. Sunshine and southerly winds helped moderate temperatures in the central Plains region where readings hovered above freezing at midday. Sunny skies and light wind prevailed across the Southwest. Some of the low records set Monday included 8 below at Delta, Utah, 18 degrees at Redding, Calif., 26 at Sacramento, Calif., and 7 below at Salt Lake City. In stark contrast, early morning temperatures were balmy in the Southeast, and parts of the middle and northern Atlantic Coast. Richmond, Va., recorded a record high for the date of 70 degrees early Monday, and Portland warmed to 53 degrees. Unseasonably warm weather continued ahead of the Arctic front. Temperatures were still in the 60s and 70s in much of the southeast, with readings in the 80s over much of Florida. A strong northwest wind ushered cold Arctic air into the middle and northern Atlantic Coast. Wind gusted to 53 mph in Boston and gusts reached 78 mph at the Blue Hill Observatory. The strong wind produced snow squalls in the Great Lakes region. Light snow showers or snow flurries extended from the Tennessee Valley to New York state. Recent heavy rains in the Ohio valley swelled rivers from Indiana to New York state. In western Pennsylvania, river flood warnings are in effect through Tuesday for the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio rivers.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: ``In this confrontation, there have been those who betrayed Jesus Christ and who betrayed the principles and values of Islam, one luring and leading the other. May God curse them all.'' - Saddam Hussein in a New Year's message to his people. --- ``You have heard some voices at home urging patience. They say wait a year or two. Let the sanctions work. But the sanctions have not gotten Saddam out of Kuwait. You have been patient enough and so has President Bush.'' - Vice President Dan Quayle to Marines and Army forces in Saudi Arabia not far from the Kuwaiti border. --- ``It's necessary that Iraq must be convinced - Kuwait occupied, nothing possible; Kuwait evacuated, everything can happen.'' - French President Francois Mitterrand in a New Year's address.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrations, Appeals For Peace Mark New Year
LaserPhotos TOK1, SYD1, NY22
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with New Year in China, Paris, Israel, Dublin, Albania. Picks up 8th graf, `The mood...'
DOC.TEXT: Millions of people around the globe bade farewell to a tumultuous 1990 and embraced the new year with fireworks and gala celebrations, while their leaders appealed for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Paris celebrated the 12th stroke of midnight noisily, with whistles, honking horns and the pops of thousands of champagne corks. The Champs-Elysees, Clichy, the Place St. Michel and St. Germain des Pres were crowded. New Year's is traditionally a time in Paris for eating oysters, and tens of thousands were consumed at the city's best fish bars. Long lines of tourists formed outside dance halls like the Moulin Rouge and Lido for midnight shows. On the more serious side, President Bush praised warmer U.S.-Soviet relations and the nations' alliance in the effort to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said the Cold War was over, but that there would be no lasting peace until the gulf crisis was resolved. The Iraqi embassy in London wished the world a peaceful and prosperous new year and complained that a completely different message emanated from Bush - ``a message of further aggression, destruction and war. ... As for Iraq, it will always carry the olive branch and sing songs of peace and curse war.'' Australians were among the first to ring in 1991. Hundreds of thousands of partiers jammed Sydney Harbor to watch fireworks and a laser show. Temple bells, ship's whistles and fireworks welcomed the Year of the Sheep in Tokyo. Millions of Japanese headed for shrines to pray for success. Others gathered around bonfires at neighborhood shrines to drink sake, or rice wine. Night spots in Beijing reverberated with rap music, love songs and rock'n'roll.
