Many Chinese spent New Year's Eve quietly with friends or relatives, eating special dinners and playing mah-jong into the early hours. China's major new year holiday comes Feb. 15 - the Chinese Lunar New Year. But most Beijing residents will take off from work Tuesday and Wednesday, when banks, most shops and government offices will be closed. In Spain, a television electrician accidentally broke the legendary clock that rings in the Spanish New Year in Madrid's popular Puerta del Sol square. But it was fixed in time for the arrival of 1991. At midnight on New Year's Eve, Spaniards seek good luck by swallowing one grape with each of the 12 chimes of the 123-year-old clock - either gulping the grapes during a huge party in the square or while watching the live TV or radio broadcast. For the first time since the early 19th century, north Dublin in Ireland was without the New Year bells of St. George's Church, whose chimes were heard by Leopold and Molly Bloom in James Joyce's ``Ulysses.'' The church was closed in 1990 and its bells sold to a suburban church. Dublin's New Year was ushered in with a peal of ``Grandsire Triples'' by the ringers of Christ Church Cathedral, with the 12 strokes of midnight tolled on the tenor bell by ringing master Leslie Taylor. Albanian President Ramiz Alia said Monday night he believed 1991 would be a turning point for Albania, and appealed for unity and order as the Communist-led country moved out of its isolation toward democratization. His New Year message was broadcast on Albanian radio. On Israel army radio, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir sent Bush New Year's greetings that wished him victory in the gulf, ``to free the Middle East from the threat of tyranny and aggression.'' The mood was somber in Pakistan after Islamic fundamentalists denounced New Year's Eve celebrations as a product of the decadent West. A group calling itself ``The Tigers of Allah'' strung banners throughout the city of Karachi, emblazoned with skull-and-crossbone insignias and the warning: ``Beware.'' Fundamentalists demanded there be no dancing, drinking or mingling with the opposite sex at parties. Threats prompted all the city's hotels to cancel their festivities. In Manila, Philippine police went on alert and hospitals expected casualties from fireworks and the firing of illegal weapons. Germans began their first year in decades under one nation, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged support for Soviet reforms to maintain peace on the continent. ``No one has a bigger interest in that than we Germans in the heart of Europe,'' Kohl said in a New Year's Eve speech. Germany has been the staunchest European supporter of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whom Germans largely credit with helping eliminate the major obstacles to unification. In a message on Soviet television, Kohl extended ``heartfelt greetings and our good wishes'' to the Soviet people for the New Year. Gorbachev said Monday in his New Year's address to the Soviet people, ``The passing year was one of the most difficult in our history. ``Crisis phenomena in economics, the lowering of people's personal safety, a weakening of order and discipline affected the conditions of life,'' he said in the speech to be broadcast nationwide just before midnight. In a message to Americans, the Soviet president welcomed February's summit with President Bush and said there was ``no more danger of nuclear catastrophe.'' But, he added, ``much has not been completed,'' including a resolution to the crisis caused by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In a videotaped greeting to ``all the wonderful people of the Soviet Union,'' Bush saluted Gorbachev for undertaking ``an arduous journey'' toward a new society. The U.S. president, welcoming the Soviets as partners against Iraq, hailed the Soviet-American ``common approach to a new challenge in the name of stability and peace.'' Bush said he was thrilled about the warmth developing between ordinary Soviet and American citizens as a result of the relaxation of tensions. French President Francois Mitterrand, in his New Year's Eve address, also urged Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and the world to help settle outstanding Middle East disputes, including the Israeli-Palestinian problem. In the Persian Gulf, celebrations were low-key as troops focused on Jan. 15, the U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave conquered Kuwait or face possible use of force. Iraqis welcomed 1991 with parties and bands in major hotels and nightspots in Baghdad, but most stayed home and celebrations were subdued. In Tokyo, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu marked the start of the 50th anniversary year of Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor with a call for reflection. ``It is important to make clear to the United States and the world that Japan is determined never again to wage a war of aggression,'' Kaifu told Japanese reporters in a news conference taped for a New Year's Day television broadcast. Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, brought the United States into World War II. Japan surrendered on Aug. 15, 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Attack Military Barracks As Cease-Fire Nears
DOC.TEXT: Rebels attacked a military barracks next to the presidential palace only two hours before their promised cease-fire went into effect Monday. The army said one soldier was wounded. Guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, launched three rocket-propelled grenades that hit a dormitory wall in the communications brigade in the southern part of the capital, the military said. The attack apparently violated an earlier, holiday cease-fire the rebels had said would last through Jan. 1. The rebels said Friday they would begin another unilateral cease-fire starting Monday at 6 a.m. The rebels gave no explanation for the overlapping cease-fires. Rebels said the truce was aimed at reopening peace negotiations in the 11-year-old Salvadoran civil war that has claimed 73,000 lives. They gave the same motive for starting a Nov. 20 offensive, saying it was necessary to push President Alfredo Cristiani's right-wing government to the bargaining table. Negotiations supervised by the United Nations throughout 1990 stuck on guerrillas' demands for major reductions in the armed forces and removal of officers and soldiers implicated in human rights abuses. The army doesn't want any outside meddling in its structure. The FMLN said its six-week offensive caused 1,190 army deaths and injuries. The government said 600 died and 1,000 were wounded, including military, rebels and civilians. Rebels for the first time downed two government planes with surface-to-air missiles during the offensive, alarming both the Salvadoran government and its U.S. backers. The Salvadoran military is heavily reliant on its air force to prevent large-scale rebel attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Berliners Made 1 Billion Marks Off German Unity, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Communist-run businesses and currency speculators in Berlin cost the government $666 million by manipulating aspects of German unification, an official said Monday. Berlin Justice Sen. Jutta Limbach said officials have identified 54 specific cases where people managed to make vast amounts of money off the economic merger of the German nations. But she said it will take at least six months to sift through evidence needed to bring criminal charges. West Germany's powerful currency replaced East Germany's nonconvertible Communist currency on July 1 and the two nations united on Oct. 3 Even though the Communist currency was considered worthless outside the East bloc, it was exchanged for the Western mark at a 1-1 rate for small personal bank accounts and at a 2-1 rate for corporate and large accounts. Limbach said her office has turned up about 1 billion marks, or $666 million, in economic damage caused primarily by former Communist-run businesses that doctored their financial records. All of the suspected fraud took place in former East Berlin, she said, and 700 million marks, or $466 million, in fraud was blamed on businesses that had Soviet rubles in their bank accounts. The government allowed East German businesses to convert rubles in their bank accounts to West German marks at a 2-1 rate for recent transactions, even though the ruble was worth only a fraction of that. Officials have charged that many businesses altered their records to make it look like older transactions took place recently, allowing the enterprises to convert large amounts of rubles in their accounts at the 2-1 rate. She said other losses were caused by currency speculation and illegal property sales. Officials have said that economic crimes related to German unification probably will reach billions of marks nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Redskins Football Coach George Allen Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of background, career and reax. Minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: George Allen, who transformed two professional football teams from losers to winners, then came out of a five-year retirement to take over a struggling, small-college team, died Monday. He was 72. Allen, who coached the Los Angeles Rams and Washington Redskins of the NFL, also served as chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness from 1981, going on television to exhort Americans to shape up. He died at his home here of natural causes, said his son, Greg. He is survived by his wife Etty, a daughter and three sons. Allen was alone at home when his wife returned in the early afternoon and found him dead in the kitchen, said Mike Tracy of the Palos Verdes Estates Police Department. She had last seen him alive at 10:30 a.m. Allen, who also coached two teams with the short-lived USFL in the early 1980s, had ended a five-year retirement to coach at Long Beach State in December 1989. He said at the time he missed the challenge. Allen ranks as the winningest coach in team history for both the Rams and the Redskins and had the third-best winning percentage of .712 among NFL coaches with 100 or more victories. He was 49-17-4, or .742, with Los Angeles from 1966 to 1970, and 67-30-1, or .691, with Washington from 1971 to 1977. Although he had excellent records in the pros, he never was able to produce a National Football League champion. The closest he came was with the Redskins in the 1972 season, when they lost 14-7 to the Miami Dolphins in the seventh Super Bowl. Allen said his 6-5 winning season at Long Beach State this year was the most rewarding of his entire career. The team scored 4-8 the previous season. In an interview last Thursday, Allen said his health had suffered since his players drenched him with icewater to celebrate a season-ending victory over Nevada-Las Vegas. ``We couldn't afford Gatorade,'' he said, smiling. However, Allen had been showing up recently at the practices of the Iowa Hawkeyes, who were holding drills at Long Beach State in preparation for Tuesday's Rose Bowl game against Washington. He was at practice Sunday, and appeared fit and animated. Allen's celebrated coaching career, which covered four decades, began in 1948 at Morningside College in Sioux City, Iowa. In his first year, the team had a 3-6 record. It was one of only three times he had a losing record, the other two coming at Whittier College in 1951 and 1954. He took over the struggling Los Angeles Rams in 1966 and led the team to a 8-6 record, their first winning season in eight years. The next year, the Rams finished first in the division with an 11-1-2 record, Allen's best single-season mark. Allen was known for wild spending to build a winner and trading draft choices for such veterans as defensive linemen Diron Talbert, Ron McDole and Richie Petitbon, earning the Redskins the nickname ``The Over the Hill Gang.'' The nine games he won in his first season were the most Washington had managed in 29 years. ``His basic philosophy was us against them,'' said Petitbon, who played for Allen with the Chicago Bears, Rams and Redskins and became his assistant in Washington. ``He made enemies of everyone - the media, other teams - and it was effective. He was a great motivator. The players loved him.'' Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke said Allen ``was a Trojan for work and for winning. He was one of the indestructibles. Though the Redskins kept winning, Allen was fired after the 1977 season. The late Edward Bennett Williams, who owned the team at that time, said ``George was given an unlimited budget - and exceeded it.'' Allen landed back in Los Angeles, but the Rams fired him just two games into the 1978 exhibition schedule. Allen also had two winning seasons in the now-defunct United States Football League. He coached the Arizona Wranglers in 1984, where he was 10-8, and the Chicago Blitz in 1983, leading them to a 12-6 mark. ``I talked to Coach Allen a few weeks ago and he was just so excited about the winning season he had at Long Beach State,'' said Houston Oilers coach Jack Pardee, who played under Allen as a linebacker with the Washington Redskins. ``Coach Allen always thrived on building something out of very little,'' Pardee said. ``And he was very excited about the continuing challenge that he had at Long Beach.'' ``George really did turn things around for the Rams and got us on a winning track,'' said Hall of Fame defensive lineman Merlin Olsen, who played under Allen. ``He always carried such great enthusiasm with him and was one of the consummate motivators.'' An advocate of physical fitness who competed in marathons, bike-a-thons and triathlons, Allen founded the National Fitness Foundation in 1952. A member of the President's Council on Physical Fitness for several years, he was named chairman by President Reagan in 1981. Allen wrote 11 books on football, one of which was the first encyclopedia of football drills. Allen's friends in Washington included President Nixon. He once used a play Nixon diagrammed for a playoff game against the San Francisco 49ers. The reverse to wide receiver Roy Jefferson went for a loss.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Put Under Islamic Law
DOC.TEXT: Military ruler Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir said Monday he was putting Islamic law into effect at once in all parts of Sudan except the south, dominated by Christians and animists. El-Bashir said the 1,400-year old Islamic Sharia law would cover only administrative and civil cases, and that rules for criminal cases would await application of a federal system here. He did not specify when that would be. He said he was committing himself personally to drafting a ``decisive timetable and administrative measures necessary for realization'' of Sharia law. El-Bashir said Sharia law would also cover banking and financial dealings, abolishing interest payment. It was not immediately clear how that would affect international transactions with this north-central African nation and its population of about 25 million. El-Bashir spoke on the occasion of the 35th anniversary of Sudan's independence from joint British-Egyptian rule. Then-President Gaafar Nimeiri introduced Islamic law in 1983, but it was suspended after Nimeiri's overthrow in 1985. El-Bashir deposed former Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi in June 1989. Nimeiri's introduction of the Sharia was a factor in Sudan's being plunged into civil war. Renegade Col. John Garang and his Sudan People's Liberation Army in 1983 took up arms in the south against the Muslim-dominated government. Many sentences were passed and implemented under Sharia law, including cutting off hands for theft, flogging and public disgrace for adultery. Scrapping Sharia law has been a rebel condition for ending the war. Monday's announcement was broadcast live on television, which showed hundreds of people cheering el-Bashir around the presidential palace in the capital, Khartoum, while shouting, ``We will protect Islam with our blood!'' Referring to southern Sudan, el-Bashir said the present legal system will remain unchanged until the establishement of ``new legislative bodies with power to decide the appropriate legal system befitting the south.'' He told a jubilant crowd, ``It became imperative and inevitable that we should immediately apply the Sharia aw without delay or procrastination in response to the will of Allah and the popular demand.''

DOC.HEAD: NY State's Fiscal Woes Test Cuomo's Presidential Mettle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Cuomo's swearing-in ceremony. Picks up 3rd graf, `Cuomo hopes ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo, scrapping the pageantry of past inaugurations for a simple ceremony befitting New York state's economic hard times, took the oath of office Monday for a third four-year term. Cuomo, widely viewed as one of the Democratic Party's most eloquent orators, gave no inaugural address after he was sworn in by New York Chief Judge Sol Wachtler. The afternoon ceremony at the Court of Appeals building in the shadow of the state Capitol also featured the swearing in of Lt. Gov. Stan Lundine. The inauguration was closed to the public. Cuomo hopes the $70,000 savings on inauguration festivities is symbolic of his commitment to meet what he called the greatest challenge faced by a New York governor since the Depression. ``That's what I have to get done. That's what I ran for,'' Cuomo said of the fiscal problems during his re-election campaign. ``There's no way you could say, `No, that's not really important. I'll solve the problem from Washington,' and then take off and campaign from coast to coast. I couldn't do that and I wouldn't do that.'' Cuomo's chief Republican adversary in Albany agrees that the person often mentioned as the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination must take care of business at home first. ``Clearly what happens in the next year is going to be very conclusive as to his chances as a candidate for national office,'' said state Senate Majority Leader Ralph Marino. For three straight years, the state has run a deficit. New York's credit rating in March dropped from AA- to A, its lowest ever. Only Massachusetts and Louisiana are considered worse investments among states. During the last two years, Cuomo and the Legislature have raised taxes by $2.8 billion - adding to Cuomo's reputation as a big-spending Northeastern liberal. On Nov. 6, Cuomo won re-election with 53 percent of the vote, down sharply from the 65 percent that gained him a second term in 1986. Even during the campaign, Cuomo warned that the state's finances, despite hefty tax increases, were again turning red. After the election, Cuomo said his relatively poor showing conveyed the ``no new taxes'' message New Yorkers wanted to send him. Cuomo then unveiled a plan to eliminate what he estimated was a $1 billion deficit in New York's $50 billion budget. To cheers from the business community and Republican state Comptroller Edward Regan, Cuomo turned away from new taxes. He proposed reducing state aid to schools and firing 2,000 state workers. With a few changes, the Legislature approved Cuomo's plan Dec. 14. Three days later, Regan warned that this year's deficit could balloon to $1.4 billion. And Regan said the state faced a potential deficit next year of up to $4 billion. ``This will be much bigger than '83,'' Cuomo said Friday in comparing the problem he'll face in the coming year to the potential $1.8 billion deficit he faced when he first took office. ``On the numbers, this is the biggest problem the state has faced since (Franklin) Roosevelt'' was governor of New York at the beginning of the Depression. The fiscal balancing act represents a particular challenge to Cuomo, who has tried to build a reputation as a champion of the poor in his first eight years as governor. ``Clearly he's going to come in and make a lot of people unhappy,'' Senate Majority Leader Marino said of the proposed state budget Cuomo must unveil by the end of January. In addition, Cuomo is governor at a time when New York state is losing clout in Washington. The 1990 Census results mean that New York will lose three of its 34 House seats. Cuomo has said the new population count could translate into billions of dollars in reduced federal assistance. While Cuomo insists that he ``has no plans to run for president and no plans to make plans,'' he does remain prominent on the national stage. Two weeks ago, he began his work week with a speech to the National Press Club in Washington and ended it with an appearance on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' Lee Miringoff, head of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, noted that Cuomo spends a good deal of time attacking President Bush and Congress. ``In New York, he's the insider, but outside New York, Cuomo is the outsider,'' Miringoff said. ``It's interesting to watch what lines he's using because were he to be running (for president), he would likely be saying all those things. ``One must reach the conclusion that maybe, in fact, he is,'' the veteran Cuomo watcher added.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie Defends Cancellation of `Satanic' Paperback
DOC.TEXT: Author Salman Rushdie on Monday struck back at the writers who have criticized his decision to embrace Islam and halt any immediate plans for a paperback version of his controversial novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' Over the weekend, writer Alan Sillitoe said Rushdie's decision to cancel a the paperback edition was a ``blow to writers.'' Playwright Arnold Wesker was quoted by The Sunday Times as saying, ``It seems the religious terrorists have won.'' ``The answer to that is, `thanks, Arnold,''' Rushdie said in an interview on Independent Television News. ``Actually, it's none of his business.'' The interviewer noted that Wesker and other critics had supported Rushdie. ``Yes, but presumably they were campaigning on my behalf because they felt I had the right to write whatever I wanted, whatever I thought,'' Rushdie said. ``If I only have free speech if I happen to agree with Arnold Wesker's atheistic position, then that's really not much of a position at all.'' Rushdie, 43, has embarked on a cautious reentry to normal life after two years in hiding under am Islamic death sentence. He was condemned on Feb. 14, 1989 by Iran's late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. ``There's no doubt that the worst part of the past couple of years has been that my son has been obliged to be without a father for two years,'' Rushdie said. ``I'm sure most Muslims in this country would understand that there is a innocent victim in this and that it's time that he was allowed to have a father.'' Rushdie noted that he had supported distribution of the Pakistani film, ``International Guerrillas,'' which portrayed Rushdie as a James Bond-like villain. ``Free speech is not to do with being an atheist or being a believer,'' he said. Speaking about his religious beliefs, Rushdie noted that he had recently been reading Fyodor Dostoevski, the great Russian novelist. ``Dostoevski after all came very close to a firing squad and spent a lot of time locked up. And during that time he wrote in letters to friends that he had come to feel the need for faith like parched earth does, and had found it, because as he wrote, `truth shines in misfortune.''' Rushdie insisted he would not repudiate ``The Satanic Verses,'' which he has characterized as ``a moral fable,'' and would not withdraw it from circulation. ``It seems to me what's very important is that the book should remain in print so that in time it can be appreciated as something other than the book it has been made out to be. I don't repudiate the book. What I've said is, and what I've been explaining over and over again for two years, is that it's been much misunderstood and that I am trying now by canceling the paperback to create what I call a pause for understanding.'' Earlier in the day, Egypt's Religious Affairs Ministry denied reports in The Observer weekly and in Cairo papers that Rushdie had been officially invited to Egypt. Rushdie said Egypt's Islamic affairs minister had suggested it might be appropriate for him to visit Egypt at some point, but said he had no firm plans to go there.

DOC.HEAD: No Celebrations Aboard Aircraft Carrier for New Year's Eve
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD THE USS MIDWAY IN THE GULF (AP)
DOC.TEXT: While fellow Americans were celebrating New Year's Eve the traditional way, the 4,300 men aboard the USS Midway celebrated with ice cream and popcorn at the end of routine 12- to 14-hour workday. ``We're just watching and waiting,'' said 27-year-old Seaman Apprentice Wendell Stephens from Philadelphia. ``I`m looking forward to Jan. 1 because its payday.'' Data Systems Technician Charles Greer, 22, from Casper, Wyo., was ``catching the next plane out'' to Bahrain where he would be flying home to meet his family in San Francisco. The sailor who was being transferred to Naval Command Corps in Vallejo, Calif., was surprisingly quiet while he discussed his plans. ``I am leaving plenty of friends here,'' he said ``I don't think we'll have a party tonight,'' said Terry Toms, 40, commander of the Midway's F-18 Attack Squadron 115. ``It's our job to be here - that's what we're doing tonight.'' As a sign of the normal work routine, planes were taking off all day from the deck of the Midway as squadron members were kept on high alert status. E-2C Hawkeye surveillance planes, EA-6B Prowler electronic attack aircraft, A-6E Intruder medium attack aircraft were also involved in the practices. Even as Toms spoke, his men and planes were continuously practicing takeoffs and landing on the deck as the carrier sailed through the Persian Gulf. Aircraft carriers deployed in support of Operation Desert Shield began sailing inside the narrow waterway only about six weeks ago. Toms' squadron members were still mourning the loss of two of their sailors who were killed last week when their tour bus overturned on a liberty trip in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. ``It's amazing that our first deaths were on shore,'' Toms said wistfully. Added Rear Adm. Daniel P. March, ``Our job is to go to war if President Bush calls us to do so.'' March reiterated the U.S. Navy's commitment to the U.N. resolution calling for a complete withdrawal from Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face possible attack. ``Our goal is clear: Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and the restoration of its legitimate government,'' he said. ``We're going to leave here when all this is over.'' There were no decorations or New Year's cards hanging on the walls and no special activities were planned by the ship's Office of Welfare and Recreation. But the ship's crew, whose age averages 19, had not forgotten their relatives and friends this holiday season. The ship's store had sold 10,000 seasons greetings cards by Christmas, said Lt. Rich Huntoon, 39, the store's sales officer, from Los Angeles. The Midway is the only carrier presently deployed in northern Arabian Sea waters, with forays through the Strait of Hormuz and into the Gulf. Two other U.S. carriers, the USS Theodore Roosevelt and the USS America are on their way. The carriers will be under March's command when they arrive. The Saratoga and the John F. Kennedy are in the Red Sea and the Eastern Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: `Hill Street' Actor Kiel Martin Dies
DOC.TEXT: Actor Kiel Martin, who played shady detective Johnny ``J.D.'' LaRue on the former television series ``Hill Street Blues,'' has died at age 46. Martin, a cast regular on the Emmy-winning series, died Friday of cardiovascular collapse due to lung cancer at his desert home in Rancho Mirage, 100 miles southeast of Los Angeles, said Riverside County Deputy Coroner Michael Werk. He was a regular on the daytime soap ``The Edge of Night'' before joining ``Hill Street Blues'' as a sleazy vice cop always in some kind of trouble, usually involving money. The LaRue character routinely tried to snare his fellow officers at the Hill Street station in get-rich-quick schemes that usually went sour. ``He's a total opportunist and quite unrealistic toward advancement and success,'' Martin once said of the character. ``But he's a very good cop, which is something that not many people mention,'' he added. Martin said he worked ``with a lot of cops'' on getting the character right. In its seven seasons, ``Hill Street'' won more than 25 Emmys and was considered a ground-breaking series that introduced a new level of realism laced with dark humor to the police television drama format. Born in Pittsburgh but raised in Miami, Martin freely admitted that he was ``trouble as a kid.'' According to his studio biography, his father urged a high school drama coach to allow him to try out for a bit role in ``Finian's Rainbow.'' He got the lead instead. Martin began his professional acting career in Florida repertory theater. After moving to New York in the mid-1960s, he became a stand-up comedian, dockworker and musician. Signed to a Universal Studios contract in 1967, his fledgling career suffered a lengthy setback when he crashed his motorcycle into a tree. Martin broke 15 bones in the accident and spent two years recuperating. After the popular ``Hill Street'' series was canceled in 1987, Martin played a dead man given a new shot at life in ``Second Chance,'' a short-lived Fox television series. Also that year, he co-starred in the NBC-TV movie ``Convicted: A Mother's Story'' with Ann Jillian, who plays a mother separated from her two children when she is sent to prison. As her boyfriend, Martin coerces her to ``borrow'' $10,000 from her employer with the promise that he only needs it for a few days and will return it. But he skips town with the money. His film credits included ``The Panic in Needle Park'' in 1971 and ``The Lolly Madonna War'' in 1973. His other television credits included ``Murder She Wrote,'' ``L.A. Law'' and ``The Blue Knight.'' Martin is survived by his mother, Eileen Mueller, and daughter Jesse Martin. There will be no funeral service.

DOC.HEAD: EC to Meet in Emergency Session in New Bid to Avoid Gulf War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further British comment, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 12 European Community nations will meet in emergency session this week and reports Monday said they were ready to start a new diplomatic drive to avert war in the Persian Gulf. An EC source said the foreign ministers will ``look at the role of the (EC) in finding a political solution to the gulf crisis'' at Friday's meeting in Luxembourg. Luxembourg assumes the EC presidency on Tuesday and the nation's foreign minister, Jacques Poos, said he expected some EC states to push for him to meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Poos said in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. he expected contact would be made with Iraq either ``through diplomatic channels or a private talk.'' Poos said he would be ready to go to Baghdad if that was what the EC decided. Asked if he thought he would be meeting Aziz in the near future, he replied: ``Yes, I think so.'' In Bonn, German officials suggested the EC foreign ministers would discuss opening ``indirect talks'' with Iraq. They spoke on condition of anonymity and did not elaborate. The EC ministers agreed on Dec. 18 not to meet with Aziz until after Aziz met President Bush in Washington. The Aziz-Bush meeting was scuttled in a dispute over a date, however. In London, former Prime Minister Edward Heath said a diplomatic push was long overdue and accused the United States of failing to pursue a diplomative initiative. ``Tens of thousands of lives depend on this and the whole of the world order,'' he said on BBC radio. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said on the same program, ``I think there's a chance, not a good chance, there's a chance for peace as long as the issues are clear ... that Saddam Hussein knows that if he stays in Kuwait he will be attacked ... that if he withdraws completely and unconditionally then he will not be attacked.'' Foreign ministers Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany and Gianni De Michelis of Italy conferred with Yugoslav Foreign Minister Budimir Loncar on Monday to examine chances of a new diplomatic initiative. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein met with Loncar on Sunday, but rejected his appeal on behalf of the non-aligned movement to withdraw from Kuwait, diplomats said. A senior Luxembourg official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said some EC member states ``talk about grand initiatives, but we cannot do anything in contradiction with the United States.'' As president of the EC for six months, Luxembourg has considerable sway over the agenda and content of EC ministerial meetings and any European initiative aimed at resolving the gulf crisis. Luxembourg Prime Minister Jacques Santer said Monday his country would not take the initiative to formulate a new EC proposal. He said Friday's meeting should reaffirm EC solidarity with the international coalition opposing Iraq. Santer also expressed opposition to linking the gulf crisis and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Iraq says the two questions should be settled together. ``There should be no linkage,'' Santer said in a telephone interview. However, Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens on Monday held out hope of progress on the Palestinian and Lebanese issues once Iraq had withdrawn from Kuwait. ``If Iraq conforms strictly to (U.N.) Security Council resolutions, the United Nations could contribute to get international talks on other issues under way,'' Eyskens said in a statement. But Santer said the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face the prospect of war ``leaves very little room for maneuver.''

DOC.HEAD: Sugar Bowl Visitors Evacuated During Hotel Fire
DOC.TEXT: A hotel fire on Monday disrupted the New Year's Eve vacation of about 300 tourists, many of them in town to attend the Sugar Bowl college football game, fire officials said. Four people were treated at a local hospital for smoke inhalation or cuts, authorities said. No one was seriously hurt. The fire broke out about 2 a.m. on the seventh floor of the Avenue Plaza Hotel, about a mile from the French Quarter. Although the blaze was confined to one room, the entire 12-story hotel was evacuated. Investigators suspected the fire may have started on a gas stove, said Deputy Fire Chief Ken Trepagnier. The guests who were staying in the room where the blaze started apparently were out at the time, he said. The hotel was full of Tennessee fans in town as part of a special travel package. Tennessee plays Virginia in the Superdome Tuesday night. `We couldn't even breathe,'' said Vivian Caldwell, of Nashville, Tenn., a 1984 Tennessee graduate who was among those led to safety. ``The smoke was very, very heavy.'' ``We crawled out down the hall,'' said Melissa Higgins, of Greenville, Tenn., who had the room next door to where the fire started. ``The smoke was so thick you couldn't see the exit signs.''

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed, 600 Injured in Philippine's New Year's Revelry
DOC.TEXT: Eight people were killed and more than 600 people were injured in New Year's revelry as Filipinos generally disregarded pleas by authorities to avoid celebrating with fireworks and weapons, hospitals and police said Tuesday. A check of 16 public and private hospitals in the capital showed 686 people were treated for burns, lacerations and bullet wounds late Monday and early Tuesday. The dead included three children killed in a fire caused by fireworks in Manila's Arlegui district near President Corazon Aquino's residence. Officials said 13 fires were reported in the city on New Year's Eve and all were caused by fireworks. ``The cause of fire on New Year's Eve is always firecracker explosions,'' said fireman Eddie Macasadug. ``I think firecrackers should be totally banned. I am surprised that some people want to legalize firecrackers here.'' Fireworks have been a staple of New Year's celebrations in the country for years. The custom apparently came from Chinese immigrants, who believed the crackle and pop of firecrackers would scare off evil spirits.

DOC.HEAD: MBTA Driver Fired, Random Drug Tests Ordered After Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS13th graf, `Niederberger said ...' to CLARIFY that passenger got off train half an hour before crash. Picks up penultimate graf,``We had ...'
DOC.TEXT: Transporation officials said Monday they had fired a driver whose blood-alcohol level tested above the legal limit after the trolley he was operating rammed into another rail car last week, injuring 33 people. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority also will start testing its employees at random for alcohol and drugs in the wake of the Friday morning accident, MBTA officials said. Two dispatchers who allegedly were slow to react to a passenger's warning about the driver's behavior that morning have been reassigned, they said. ``We dropped the ball,'' Thomas P. Glynn, the MBTA's general manager, said at a news conference. ``We did not act in time to avert this accident.'' A test after the accident showed the driver, who authorities have not identified, had a blood-alcohol level above the legal limit of .10 percent. The man has not been arrested. ``It is clear that the operator's inability to function was the critical element,'' Glynn said. ``There is no better argument for random drug testing than what we've seen in the last few days.'' The driver initially claimed the brakes had failed, but tests showed there were no equipment problems, officials said. Although trolleys are supposed to slow to 6 mph as they approach the subway platform, the train that crashed was traveling at least 20 mph, Glynn said. Its exact speed at the time of impact had not been determined. Glynn ordered random drug testing of MBTA drivers, door guards and police to begin in a month, despite longtime union opposition. It would affect about 2,350 of the transit system's 5,000 employees. Officials with the Carmen's Union, which represents the transportation workers, did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. During the first half of this year, the MBTA fired 36 workers for drug or alcohol abuse discovered either because of absenteeism or because it was suspected by supervisors. The two dispatchers who received complaints about the driver from passenger Tony Niederberger were reassigned to other jobs, Glynn said. Niederberger, who got off the train half an hour earlier and called the transit authority to report the driver, said his warnings were handled too slowly to prevent the accident. ``We had to be going 70 (mph),'' said Niederberger, who attended the news conference with MBTA officials. ``I honestly thought that we were going to jump the tracks. The man did not seem to be satisfied with how fast he was going.'' The 64-year-old driver, a 20-year MBTA veteran, had no previous incidents of alcohol or drug use on his record, officials said. He also had no lengthy episodes of absenteeism, often a sign of alcohol or drug abuse.

DOC.HEAD: City Says Transit Authority Was Slow to Notify Emergency Agencies
DOC.TEXT: Transit employees were slow in notifying emergency workers about a subway fire that killed two people and injured 188 people last week, a preliminary city report on the accident said Monday. Mayor David Dinkins said the preliminary investigation by his office found that confusion about the exact location of the Friday morning accident also slowed rescue efforts. ``The Transit Authority was slow to notify all of the city's emergency response agencies and, even when it did, gave them inaccurate information with which to respond,'' the report said. ``The lack of proper communication between the Transit Authority and Transit Authority Police resulted in emergency agencies not being fully aware of the exact location of the incident,'' it said. The report said that once emergency workers found the train and victims, they performed well. Transportation Authority President Alan F. Kiepper said transit workers ``gave the best information they had available at the time'' to emergency workers. Kiepper said the authority would conduct its own inquiry and report back in about 60 days. The fire, initially blamed on melting snow that fell down to track level and caused an electrical short, sent thick smoke through a tunnel that runs under downtown Brooklyn and then goes under the East River toward Manhattan. Hundreds of commuters were trapped in stopped subway cars for more than half an hour. Later, they complained of confusing instructions from train crew and delays in getting attention from rescue crews once they got off the train. One passenger died at the scene and a second died the following day. ``Had the smoke condition been worse or had fire broken out in the tunnel, even more lives may have been lost,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Defies Judge's Order in Landfill Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A longstanding dispute over this community's landfill was revived Monday when the mayor announced he would defy a judge's order to contract with a court-approved company to operate the dump. By defying the court order, Mayor Thomas V. Barnes risks a possible 30-day jail term for himself and City Council President Gardest Gillespie, as well as a $1.5 million fine against the city. ``I cannot sacrifice the interests of Gary citizens in order to avoid jail, but we will not accept this order without a struggle,'' Barnes told a news conference. ``We intend to utilize every legal avenue available to set aside the court's order, which represents an unconstitutional infringement on our personal rights and on the rights of every citizen of Gary.'' Gary's municipal landfill has been criticized for decades as an eyesore. State environmental officials sued the city in the late 1970s, claiming the landfill also was a source of air and groundwater pollution. Lake Circuit Judge Lorenzo Arredondo in June ordered the landfill closed and threatened to jail Barnes and Gillespie. Attorneys reached a negotiated agreement whereby Mid American Wastes Management Systems Inc. of Canal Winchester, Ohio, would assume operation of the landfill, reserve 11.5 percent of its gross receipts for the city and begin cleaning it up. But in July, Arredondo rejected the agreement. On Dec. 21, he ordered the city to contract with Indiana Waste Systems, a subsidiary of Waste Management Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill. Barnes accused the judge of conspiring with Waste Management. He said the city would seek to have Arredondo's decision stayed by the Indiana Court of Appeals and to have the judge removed from the case. ``If we don't get satisfaction from the state courts, we'll go to federal court,'' Barnes said.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Warns Bush Against Going to War Without Congressional Consent
DOC.TEXT: President Bush should face impeachment if he leads the nation to war against Iraq without congressional consent, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said Monday. ``There is a way out, and so we must make a further appeal,'' Jackson said. ``If Mr. Bush unilaterally disregards the role of Congress in this deliberative process, he must face the challenge of impeachment. ``There's not a war wherein there is a state of emergency and we must move unilaterally and quickly because bombs are heading our way,'' he said. ``We've had the time to deliberate this process.'' Only two weeks remain before the United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face potential military action by the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the Persian Gulf. ``The focus should be on the goal of getting Iraq out of Kuwait, not on a cutoff date,'' Jackson said. ``January 15 is the birthday of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the apostle of nonviolence, and hope and peace. It shouldn't be the date we start a war.'' Jackson, whose son Yusef plays for the University of Virginia football team against Tennessee in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's night, celebrated his 28th wedding anniversary on Monday with his wife, Jackie, and all of their children.

DOC.HEAD: Opposing Forces in The Persian Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp
By ED BLANCHE
DOC.TEXT:
The U.S.-led 28-nation force in the Persian Gulf, the biggest such force assembled since the Korean War, is expected to have a strength of more than 550,000 personnel by the end of January. Saddam Hussein has an estimated 510,000 troops in occupied Kuwait and southern Iraq and has mobilized tens of thousands more men. Here's a breakdown of the forces confronting each other in the gulf: UNITED STATES: There are about 300,000 military personnel now in the region in Operation Desert Shield. In the next few weeks, that will reach 430,000. At the peak of the Vietnam War in 1968, 545,000 Americans were involved. Ground forces deployed in the first wave include the 82nd ``All American'' Airborne Division, the 101st ``Screaming Eagles'' Airborne Division, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade, 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade, the 1st Cavalry Division and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. The second-wave deployment includes three armored divisions, the 2nd and 3rd from Germany and the 1st from Fort Riley, Kan., that will bolster American offensive capability on the ground for a possible thrust against Kuwait if it is still occupied by Iraq after the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for withdrawal. The U.S. force will have about 2,000 tanks when deployment is completed. Three carrier battle groups built around the USS America, the USS Theodore Roosevelt and the USS Ranger, and the battleship USS Missouri, 300 more combat jets and 45,000 marines from the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade and the 2nd Marine Expeditionary Force will also be deployed in the second phase. Current marine capability is provided by 45,000 men of the 1st, 4th and 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigades who make up the 1st MEF. When deployment is complete, about three-quarters of the U.S. Marine Corps will be committed to Desert Shield. There is a Special Forces contingent from the 1st Special Operations Command. The U.S. fleet already in the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the eastern Mediterranean totals around 55 ships. They include the aircraft carriers Saratoga, John F. Kennedy and Midway, the battleship Wiscnsin with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, five missile cruisers, four destroyers, several frigates, plus supply ships and an estimated 6-8 nuclear submarines. The aircraft carriers now in place have a combined strike force of 180 A-6 Intruder, F/A-18 Hornet fighters and F-14 Tomcats. The Marines have some 60 AV-8B Harrier jump-jets. Those numbers will be doubled when the second-phase formations arrive. Among the 800 Air Force combat aircraft deployed so far are 22 F117A Stealth fighter-bombers and as many as 38 long-range F-111F bombers. There are an estimated 150 F-16s and F-15s, more than 70 A-10 tank-killing Thunderbolts and unspecified numbers of F-4 Wild Weasel air-defense suppression jets and other combat aircraft deployed at 30 airbases in the region. Three squadrons are based in southern Turkey. A squadron of an estimated 26 B-52G strategic bombers is on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. BRITAIN: With 18,200 personnel in the region, and 16,000 more to be deployed by mid-January, Britain will have the second largest Western contingent in the region after the United States with 35,000 men, at least 50 combat jets and a naval armada. It is Britain's biggest military deployment abroad since the Korean War. The three-ship Armilla Patrol permanently in the gulf was beefed up to 16 ships, including three missile destroyers, five missile frigates, three minesweepers with support ships. Four squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar interceptors and ground attack jets are in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Three Nimrod maritime reconnaisance aircraft are in Oman. More Jaguars are expected. The 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the famous ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, with 120 Challenger tanks and 9,500 troops is attached to the U.S. Marine force in northeastern Saudi Arabia in Britain's biggest military operation since the 1982 Falklands war against Argentina. It is being joined by the ``infantry heavy'' 4th Brigade from Germany, with 43 Challengers, scores of armored fighting vehicles, artillery, multiple rocket launchers, 36 attack and scout helicopter and major engineering units whose task will be to breach Iraqi defenses in Kuwait. The two brigades will form the 30,000-man 1st Armored Division. FRANCE: By mid-January it will have 10,000 men in the region, including army formations making up the 6th Light Armored Division. It is the biggest French military deployment overseas since the 1954-62 Algerian War. It has 12-14 warships with some 1,200 men deployed. The warships include a guided-missile cruiser, two missile destroyers, four frigates and a corvette with support vessels. France has sent three squadrons of interceptors and fighter-bombers and another squadron has been commited. Its 4,000-man Rapid Action Force is deployed with Arab forces in the northeastern Saudi desert. It includes the 5th Combat Helicopter Regiment with 42 gunships, the Foreign Legion's 3nd Infantry Regiment with anti-tank missiles, the 1st Spahis Cavalry Regiment with armored vehicles and an anti-aircraft missile unit. France may soon send an additional 1,000-man artillery unit with 24 155mm guns. A second-wave deployment now under way includes a marine artillery regiment, another combat helicopter regiment with 24 Puma gunships and a dragoons regiment with 40 AMX-30 battle tanks. A company of 190 paratroopers equipped for chemical warfare is in the United Arab Emirates. There are 7,300 paratroopers stationed in Djibouti across the Red Sea from Saudi Arabia with a squadron of Mirage fighters. ITALY: The frigates Libeccio, Orsa and Zeffiro and a support ship, the Stromboli, are in the gulf. The corvettes Minerva and Sting are in the eastern Mediterranean replacing U.S. units assigned to the gulf. A squadron of eight Tornado fighters is based near Abu Dhabi, U.A.E., to provide air cover for Italian warships. Six Starfighter jets are to be deployed. No ground force deployment is planned. CANADA: The destroyers Athabaskan and Terra Nova and the supply ship Protecteur are heading for the gulf. A squadron of 18 CF-18 fighter jets from Germany is in Saudi Arabia. NETHERLANDS: The frigates Witte de With and Pieter Florisz are in the Gulf of Oman with the combat supply ship Zuiderkruis. SPAIN: The frigates Nuamancia, Infanta Cristina and Diana are patrolling the Bab el-Mandeb Strait, southern gateway to the Red Sea. AUSTRALIA: The guided-missile frigates Adelaide and Darwin and the supply ship Success are in the Red Sea. BELGIUM: The minehunters Iris and Myosotis with the supply ship Zinnia are in the Gulf of Oman. The Belgians have also commited four C-130 military transport planes. ARGENTINA: The destroyer Almirante Brown and the frigate Spiro are in the Red Sea. A 100-man army unit will also be sent. SOVIET UNION: The Udaloy-class destroyer Admiral Tributs and an anti-submarine ship are in the Gulf of Oman. Moscow has indicated it would send ground forces, but only under U.N. command. GREECE: The frigate Elli is in the Red Sea. Greece is supplying merchant ships for the U.S. sealift. GERMANY: It is providing merchant ships to the sealift, ammunition for the British forces and $2 billion toward the multinational force. Germany's constitution prohibits it commiting military forces. DENMARK: The corvette Olfert Fischer is in the gulf. Danish merchant ships are helping in the U.S. sealift. NORWAY: The Coast Guard cutter Andenes is in the gulf supporting the Danish corvette. Norway has offered anti-chemical warfare equipment. PORTUGAL: The naval support Sao Miguel is carrying equipment and supplies to the British force. Portugal has also allowed U.S. aircraft to refuel at its airbases. POLAND: It will send a military field hospital and a hospital ship to the gulf. CZECHOSLOVAKIA: It has sent a 200-man army unit with anti-chemical warfare equipment, the first Warsaw Pact country to send forces to the gulf. HONDURAS: It is sending 150 troops to Saudi Arabia and possibly 350 more, in the country's first foreign military deployment. BULGARIA: It will send a small detachment of military medical personnel. NEW ZEALAND: It is sending two C-130 transports and an army medical team. THE PHILIPPINES: It will send a small volunteer detachment of military medical personnel.
Allied Arab Forces:
GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Kuwait): A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops is based at Hafr al-Batin, northeast Saudi Arabia, 40 miles south of the Kuwait border. They and allied Arab-Islamic forces form the first line of defense, with the Americans and others south of them. The GCC force has been beefed up with 7,000 soldiers of Kuwait's 20,000-man army who escaped their country when Iraq invaded. Most of their heavy weapons were captured by Iraq, but some combat jets, naval attack craft and tanks were saved. The GCC and other gulf Arab forces total about 150,500 men, 330 combat aircraft, 800 tanks and 36 major naval units, although not all are likely to be involved in Desert Shield. They are supported by:
EGYPT: About 20,000 troops, including paratroopers, commandos, chemical warfare specialists and infantry, are in Saudi Arabia with 400 tanks. The force includes the 3rd and 4th Armored Divisions and the 3rd Mechanized Infantry Division. Another 7,000 men are being sent. About 2,250 troops are in the U.A.E. SYRIA: About 19,000 troops, including elite Special Forces units who fought the Israelis and others in Lebanon, are in Saudi Arabia. Most of the 15,000-man 9th Armored Division with 270 T-62 tanks, have arrived. Another 2,000 troops are in the U.A.E. PAKISTAN: About 5,000 troops are in Saudi Arabia and 2,000 in the U.A.E. with 1,000 advisers. An estimated 5,000 advisers are already attached to the Saudi armed forces. An additional armored division may be commited. MOROCCO: It has 1,200 troops in Saudi Arabia and 500 in the U.A.E. BANGLADESH: It has 2,000 troops, including engineering and infantry units, in Saudi Arabia. SENEGAL: About 500 troops are in Saudi Arabia. NIGER: It has sent 480 troops to guard the holy shrines of Mecca !!!!!!!!!End Of AutoTake(1)!!!!!!!!!!

and Medina in Saudi Arabia.
IRAQ: The army has seven corps totaling 55-60 divisions. There are 555,000 regular troops and 480,000 reserves all of whom are believed to have been mobilized. Regular forces include six divisions of elite Republican Guards. Iraq claims a militia called the Popular Army has 8 million men, but its true strength is estimated at around 850,000. Saddam Hussein has 5,500 tanks, including some 500 high-quality T-72s and 1,000 medium-quality T-62s; 3,500 artillery guns; 200 multiple rocket launchers; an estimated 500 surface-to-surface missiles; more than 330 surface-to-air missile launchers, including captured Kuwaiti systems; some 700 combat aircraft, including Soviet-supplied long-range Su-24 fighter-bombers and advanced MiG-29 interceptors, spread around an estimated 25 heavily protected airbases. Its main naval units are a training frigate with anti-submarine torpedoes, an estimated eight Soviet-built missile-attack craft and six torpedo boats plus several captured Kuwaiti missile craft. In Kuwait, Iraq has an estimated 13 divisions, four of them armored, totalling 280,000 troops, 2,200 T-55 and T-62 tanks and a buildup continues. A further 15-18 divisions, including the Republican Guard divisions with up to 1,800 tanks and 800 guns, are dug-in in southern Iraq as a strategic reserve. This also includes elements of the 1st, 3rd, 4th and 7th Army Corps. All told this force has some 230,000 men with 750 guns. Also deployed in the Kuwait theater are 2,500 armored personnel carriers and 2,700 guns. Saddam is deploying some 250,000 more men - seven new divisions and 150,000 reservists - in Kuwait. Silkworm anti-ship missiles are believed to have been deployed to counter any U.S. amphibious landing in Kuwait. FROG-7 battlefield missiles have also been deployed, including batteries captured in Kuwait, behind formidable defense lines.
