DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Dec. 24-31:
DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Drew Most Public Interest in 1990
DOC.TEXT: The public's attention was riveted to the Persian Gulf crisis more closely than to any other news story in 1990 - a year in which international events overshadowed domestic news. The Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press found that two-thirds of the public closely followed stories about the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the deployment of American forces to the region. By comparison, the historic fall of communism in almost all of Eastern Europe and the economic and political turmoil in the Soviet Union failed to interest most Americans. At no point did more than 30 percent of Americans closely follow these events, according to the center's monthly surveys. The most closely followed domestic news story also had a link to the Mideast crisis. Sixty-two percent of those surveyed said they regularly read stories about soaring gasoline prices in August and September. By comparison, reports in November about the declining economy attracted only 39 percent of the readers on a regular basis. Stories leading up to and including the November general election caught the regular attention of only 38 percent, as did stories last January about the war against drugs. Only one other news event, involving U.S. soldiers fighting abroad, caught the close attention of more than a majority of Americans: Sixty percent of Americans regularly read stories about the U.S. invasion of Panama. Although U.S. forces invaded Panama on Dec. 20, 1989, their presence in the country and numerous news stories continued into this year. The center's figures are based on monthly telephone surveys of 1,200 adults nationwide. Public interest in some issues shifted significantly during the year. Last spring, only 18 percent of the public paid close attention to stories about the first signs of economic problems. The percentage had increased to 29 percent by September and it was 39 percent in November. There was only scant attention to the nation's budget deficit last spring when Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., proposed a deficit reduction plan. During the summer as Congress debated a budget package, 18 percent of the readers were following the issue closely, but public attention increased to 34 percent by the fall amid threats to shut down the federal government. Interest in news concerning President Bush also fluctuated. When Bush attended the drug summit in Columbia last February, only 22 percent of the public paid close attention to stories about the visit. Criticism of the president on his changing position on taxes and his Persian Gulf policy caught the close attention of slightly less than a third of the public. By contrast, three out of four people read last March about Bush's distaste for broccoli. Sensational crimes and trials drew substantial public interest. News about the serial killings in Gainesville, Fla., attracted more public attention - 36 percent - than any other crime story during the year. Twenty-eight percent of the readers followed the drug arrest of Mayor Marion Barry of Washington, D.C., but interest waned. Only 16 percent paid close attention to stories about Barry's conviction on some of the charges. Some stories attracted less public interest than expected. Despite the extensive coverage of the nomination of David Souter to the U.S. Supreme Court, only about 15 percent followed the event closely. And more than half of the people surveyed said they strongly felt too much was written about the marital breakup of Donald and Ivana Trump. Twelve percent of the public said they closely followed the affair.
DOC.HEAD: Editors Vote Gulf Crisis Top Story of 1990
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the heart-stopping standoff that ensued in the Persian Gulf was by far the top news story of 1990, according to an AP poll of newpaper editors and broadcast news directors. In the balloting by 327 news people, the Gulf crisis finished well ahead of the story that placed second, the reunification of Germany. Here are the top 10 stories with vote totals, based on 10 points for an editor's No. 1 choice down to one for the No. 10 pick: 1. Iraq invades Kuwait, making hostages of thousands of foreigners and setting off worldwide military response. 2,506. 2. East and West Germany reunite after more than four decades as separate countries. 1,460. 3. Political and economic reforms throw Soviet Union into turmoil; moves toward sovereignty are afoot in all 15 republics. 1,287. 4. The savings-and-loan bailout grows ever larger, touching one of the president's sons and five senators. 1,073. 5. Relations warm between the United States and Soviet Union. 980. 6. Budget debate between Congress and president drags on for five months before package containing tax increases is approved. 943. 7. U.S. economy suffers a slump; layoffs and foreclosures rise throughout the country. 794. 8. Fledgling democracies in Eastern Europe are threatened by ethnic turmoil, economic hardship. 787. 9. Panamanian President Manuel Noriega surrenders and is brought to the United States to stand trial on charges of accepting bribes from drug traffickers. 647. 10. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher steps down. 549.
DOC.HEAD: `Big Red One' To Get Free Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers of the 1st Infantry Division soon will be getting some news from home. With the cooperation of the U.S. Army, 400 copies of each Sunday edition of The Manhattan Mercury will be sent to division units in the Persian Gulf. The division is based at nearby Fort Riley. ``We're providing the newspapers ... in an effort to create a periodic link between Manhattan and the Middle East,'' said Bill Felber, the newspaper's executive editor. The Mercury will donate the papers as long as the division is assigned to Operation Desert Shield, Felber said. The papers will be delivered to Fort Riley on Mondays and they will be flown overseas and be in the soldiers' hands within days, Felber said.

DOC.HEAD: Indiana Paper Freezing Wages for 90 Days
DOC.TEXT: The Evansville Courier is freezing the wages of its 450 employees for 90 days in an attempt to avoid layoffs at the end of 1991's first quarter. Tom Tuley, president of the paper, said slumping ad revenues and rising expenses were squeezing profits. ``What I'm trying to do is avoid layoffs at this point,'' Tuley was quoted as saying in a story published in the newspaper Dec. 28. Effective Jan. 1, the annual raise reviews of Courier employees will be pushed back 90 days, the newspaper said. An employee eligible for a raise in January will instead be reviewed in April. Those eligible in May could get raises in August. The company has been under a partial hiring freeze since last April, Tuley said. It also is considering cutting the percentage of the newspaper devoted to news and increasing the percentage of advertising, as well as possibly cutting costs in its production department, he said. ``Right now, I don't anticipate we're going to have to lay off people, but I certainly couldn't guarantee that,'' he said. The Courier was purchased in 1986 by E.W. Scripps Co., which reported a 17.2 percent drop in publishing profits for the first nine months of this year.
DOC.HEAD: Norfolk, Va., Newspapers Combining Into All-Day Format
DOC.TEXT: The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star will become an all-day newspaper next September, published and delivered in both morning and afternoon under the single name of The Virginian-Pilot. Associate Publisher Frank Batten Jr. said there will be no significant savings to the company. The change will not affect the number of people the company employs, he said. ``At present, the same reporters write for both newspapers, and many of the stories appear in both newspapers. Having one name on the masthead recognizes that The Virginian-Pilot and The Ledger-Star are almost the same newspaper today,'' Batten said. Subscribers to The Ledger-Star will receive the afternoon editions of The Virginian-Pilot. The all-day newspaper will have fresh news for each edition, Batten said. The afternoon edition will go to press at midday, the current presstime of The Ledger-Star. Advertisements can begin either in the morning or in the evening, as is the case now. The morning paper has a weekday circulation of 157,292 and the afternoon paper 72,066. On Saturday and Sunday the newspapers publish a combined edition with 239,457 circulation on Saturday and 239,189 on Sunday. The newspapers are owned by Norfolk-based Landmark Communications Inc..
DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Papers Boost Newsstand Price 10 Cents
DOC.TEXT: The Pittsburgh Press and the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette are raising their newsstand and vending machine prices to 35 cents from a quarter on New Year's Day. Home delivery prices of both papers and the price of the Sunday edition of the Press will not change, the papers said Dec. 27. The morning Post-Gazette is owned by Block Newspapers and is published Monday through Saturday. The Press is owned by Scripps Howard and is published afternoons Monday through Saturday and on Sunday mornings. The papers operate under a joint operating agreement with shared circulation and advertising departments. A union official said Dec. 28 that about 30 advertising employees had been laid off in recent days because of the slowdown in ad sales. Jim Lowen, president of Local 7 of the Communications Workers of America, said all but two were part-time employees, most of them classified ad workers. Jimmy E. Manis, general manager of Pittsburgh Press Co., declined to comment.
DOC.HEAD: New York Newsday Hikes Newsstand, Home Delivery Prices
DOC.TEXT: The price of New York Newsday increased from 25 cents to 35 cents Dec. 31. The price of the Sunday edition remained unchanged. The suggested retail price of seven-day home delivery rose from $3 to $3.25, Publisher Robert M. Johnson said in a message to readers in the paper's Dec. 30 edition. Johnson said it had been more than three years since New York Newsday last raised its home delivery prices and almost five years since newsstand prices went up. He cited energy and newsprint price increases that helped bring about the cost increase.
DOC.HEAD: Newark, N.J., Paper Raises Daily Price a Dime
DOC.TEXT: The Star-Ledger increased the price of its daily edition to a quarter from 15 cents on Dec. 31. The increase was the first for the state's largest newspaper since 1980, when the price was raised to 15 cents from 10 cents. The newspaper attributed the increase to sharply escalating costs, compounded by reduced advertising revenues. The price of the Sunday Star-Ledger was raised to 50 cents from 35 cents on Oct. 28.
DOC.HEAD: Landmark VDT Ordinance Signed Into Law in San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: A new city law aimed at protecting workers who use video display terminals is likely to be amended to give businesses more time to comply. The law, which affects city workers and private businesses with 15 or more employees, requires adjustable workstations, regular breaks and training on safe use of VDTs. It also recommends transfer to non-VDT work for pregnant women who ask to be moved. ``This legislation ... will ensure San Francisco workers are protected from dangerous injury, without driving away businesses,'' Mayor Art Agnos said as he signed the ordinance Dec. 27. ``It's legislation on the cutting edge of social change.'' The ordinance requires compliance within two years for most businesses, but Agnos worked out a compromise with business and labor leaders calling for a longer period. The amendments proposed under the compromise are to be voted on next month by the Board of Supervisors. The proposed changes are a three-step program for compliance: - After one year, new equipment would have to meet standards in the ordinance. - For existing workstations, retrofitting that cost less than $250 would have to be completed within 30 months. - Retrofitting that cost more than $250 would have to be completed within four years. The legislation was pushed by a coalition of activists who cited dangers to VDT operators, including repetitive strain injury, back and neck pain, deteriorating vision and possible miscarriages. The law will affect an estimated 56,000 workers and will cost about $14 million in the private sector within the first 30 months, said Paul Varacalli, executive director of Service Employees International Union Local 590, which backed the bill. It will cost an estimated $231,552 to bring the city into compliance, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Briefs Filed in College Crime Reports Case
DOC.TEXT: The editor of a student newspaper said she hopes a federal judge will rule on her lawsuit to open campus crime reports in time to publish the information in the paper's next issue on Jan. 18. Lawyers for both sides filed briefs with U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark on Dec. 21. Arguments were filed after lawyers Douglas W. Greene, who represents Traci Bauer and The Southwest Standard of Southwest Missouri State University, and John F. Black, who represents the school, were unable to reach a settlement. The issue centers on whether Ms. Bauer can have access to university crime reports and whether releasing those reports will threaten the school's ability to receive federal funds. In his brief, Greene contends the university's resistance to Ms. Bauer's effort to get crime reports is indicative of the school's refusal to acknowledge crimes occur on campus. He said the university has refused the Springfield Police Department's offer to station two officers on campus. Greene also argues that administrators are more concerned about image than informing students and the public of crimes on campus. He asked the judge to rule that the university is a public body and comes under state open meeting and records laws. Black countered in his brief that a ruling for the newspaper would open the prospect of requiring every university department to make all documents and proceedings available to the public. Past court cases have ruled that while the Board of Regents is a public body governed by the state's open records law, a university is not subject to that law, he wrote. Trying to comply with the federal Family Education and Privacy Rights Act while satisfying Ms. Bauer's demand for access to crime reports would not work because the university would have to notify students an exception had been made to the federal act, Black said. Ms. Bauer has been given oral reports of crimes by campus security officers, Black said. To go beyond that would violate the privacy of others, he said.
DOC.HEAD: Court Throws Out Case Against Omni Magazine
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court threw out a $30 million lawsuit filed against Omni magazine by a couple angered that their family photo illustrated an article about coffee's effect on fertility. The state Court of Appeals said in a unanimous decision Dec. 27 that it was reluctant to second-guess an editorial decision. Trial-level and appellate courts also had rejected the family's lawsuit. Joseph and Ida Finger of Saugerties, N.Y., and their six children were pictured beside an article titled ``Caffeine and Fast Sperm'' in Omni's June 1988 issue. The article discussed medical research that indicated in vitro fertilization rates may be enhanced by exposing sperm to high concentrations of caffeine. ``Want a big family?'' the photograph's caption read. ``Maybe your sperm needs a cup of java in the morning. Tests reveal that caffeine-spritzed sperm swim faster, which may increase the chances for in vitro fertilization.'' The couple, who conceived their children naturally, had been photographed for an article in a Roman Catholic publication, said their lawyer, Paul Gruner. They weren't aware a photo service had given their picture to Omni until a friend showed Mrs. Finger the magazine, he said. ``When it became known in a small community, the children were the subject of some ridicule,'' Gruner said. The couple argued that their civil rights were violated because the picture was used without permission. State law prohibits the use of a photograph without consent for purposes of advertising or trade. Court of Appeals Judge Fritz Alexander noted the courts have consistently refused to apply the civil rights law to news articles, limiting those interpretations to advertising. ``Questions of `newsworthiness' are better left to reasonable editorial judgment and discretion,'' Alexander wrote. He said the Fingers had a misperception about the theme of the article, which the judge said was more about increased fertility than in vitro or ``test tube'' fertilization. The judge said there's clearly a ``real relationship'' between the fertility theme and a picture of six healthy, attractive children who all bear a striking resemblance to their parents. Laura Handman, lawyer for Omni, said the article made it very clear the medical findings are only in the laboratory stages. ``You have to assume a certain degree of common sense by the reader,'' Handman said. ``I don't think there's been any family created by six cases of in vitro fertilization - coffee or no coffee.'' Gruner said the decision would give the press too much freedom to use pictures of people with articles that have nothing to do with them.
DOC.HEAD: Convicted Judge Plans To Sue Dow Jones
DOC.TEXT: Joseph F. O'Kicki, the former president judge of Cambria County who was convicted of corruption, has filed notice that he intends to sue the parent company of The Wall Street Journal. O'Kicki originally filed the notice Nov. 2 in Cambria County Common Pleas Court. A lawyer representing Dow Jones & Co. Inc. had the case moved to U.S. District Court in Pittsburgh last week. W. Thomas McGough Jr., local counsel for Dow Jones, said no actual complaint had been filed by O'Kicki, only a writ of summons that serves as a notice. O'Kicki did not specify in the writ the substance of the complaint. The former judge drafted the one-paragraph writ himself and named as defendants Dow Jones, Journal reporter Milo Geyelin and Dow Jones Chief Executive Officer Warren H. Phillips. McGough speculated in court papers that the complaint would focus on a series of articles the newspaper published about the judge in November and December 1989, while O'Kicki's trial was in progress, and after his conviction. McGough wrote that the complaint seems to be ``based in some manner upon these articles and upon a theory of defamation.'' The former judge was convicted Dec. 16, 1989, of official oppression, bribery and criminal coercion. The jury decided O'Kicki made court employees chop his wood and feed his dogs, solicited $500 from a court officer for a promotion he never granted, sought payment from an attorney after the judge awarded damages to the lawyer's client and demanded that a bank favorably settle his personal loan.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Testifies in Court Fight Over FBI Documents
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter who received copies of confidential FBI documents during the trial of nine organized crime figures said Dec. 27 that he knew who sent him the material and promised the source anonymity. The U.S. attorney's office wants to recover the documents from two newspapers and three television stations so investigators can trace the leak. Initially, six news outlets that received the documents were subpoenaed to give them to a federal grand jury. The Tribune-Review of Greensburg relinquished the documents. Lawyers for The Pittsburgh Press, the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and television stations KDKA and WPXI filed motions seeking to quash the subpoenas. WTAE-TV also received the documents but did not join in the motions. During a hearing, Post-Gazette reporter Mike Bucsko said he received the documents in the mail several weeks before other news organizations did. Bucsko said he knew the source and had promised not to reveal the identity. Assistant U.S. Attorney Linda L. Kelly didn't ask Bucsko to name the source in court. Attorneys for the news organizations argued that relinquishing the documents could ultimately identify the source, whether reporters know the source or not. U.S. District Judge Donald J. Lee took the matter under advisement. The government claims the documents, known as FBI 302 reports, have value as evidence. Prosecutors have said whoever mailed the documents could be prosecuted for obstruction of justice or contempt of court. The reports were capsules of debriefings of federal witness Marvin Droznek. The reports were among many shared by the government with defense lawyers in the trial of nine organized crime figures, who were convicted Oct. 29 after an eight-week trial.
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Asks for Reporter's Testimony
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reporter has been subpoenaed to testify about a jail-house interview conducted with a woman accused of shooting her husband to death. The Dayton Daily News requested Dec. 28 that the subpoena be thrown out, citing the ``critical need to protect the news-gathering process from compelled disclosure.'' The subpoena was issued by Montgomery County Common Pleas Judge William MacMillan Jr. County Prosecutor Lee C. Falke also wants reporter Dwayne Bray to reveal the contents of notes he took during an interview with Joyce Anaga. In a story published Dec. 21, Mrs. Anaga was quoted as saying that her husband had abused her and that she shot him while they were struggling over a shotgun. She said she planned to plead self-defense under a new Ohio law for battered women. Her trial is scheduled for this week. Prosecutors said they want to see all of Mrs. Anaga's comments to Bray. ``If she takes the stand and gives a different story, then it would be very important to know if she said something different ...,'' Falke said. Falke said there are precedents in Ohio courts that allow him to subpoena a reporter to answer questions about an interview. The Ohio Supreme Court ruled in June that a subpoena may be enforced ``over a reporter's claim of privilege, so long as it is persuaded that the subpoena has been requested or issued for a legitimate purpose, rather than for harassment.''
DOC.HEAD: Bolles Case Figure Loses Legal Round
DOC.TEXT: A man charged with murdering investigative reporter Don Bolles in 1976 lost a bid to reinstate a $300 million civil suit claiming Phoenix police destroyed records that could help prove his innocence. In a 3-0 ruling Dec. 27, the state Court of Appeals said the lawsuit was filed by Max Dunlap too long after the fact to qualify under the statute of limitations. Dunlap was convicted in 1977 of killing Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic. Dunlap's conviction was overturned on appeal in 1980, but he was charged again on Dec. 19. He is accused of ordering the slaying at the behest of unidentified higher-ups. He filed his civil lawsuit on July 2, 1982, claiming his constitutional rights were violated when police shredded documents in the case. A Superior Court judge threw out the suit in 1988, saying its filing two years and a month after the dismissal of the first criminal charge was a month too late. Dunlap argued on appeal that he had three years in which to file because the statute of limitations for fraud cases is three years and the suit claims police officers engaged in fraud. But Appeals Judge William Eubank said that the suit really centered on the claim Dunlap's constitutional rights were violated and that such claims must be brought to court within two years. Dunlap's lawyer, Murray Miller, said he had to study the decision before deciding whether to appeal the state Supreme Court.
DOC.HEAD: Prof Plans Service To Give Voters Facts on Candidates
DOC.TEXT: Richard Kimball envisions a future in which voters reject television campaign commercials and select national leaders as they would prospective employees - by reviewing their resumes. He has taken a leave from his job to try to make those resumes and more available to voters by telephone in 1992 on every candidate running for national office from every state. ``The people in Congress are the hired help,'' said Kimball. ``We're saying if you, the voter, are the employer, what do you need to know?'' Kimball, a political science teacher and former Arizona state senator, is directing the Center for National Independence in Politics, a non-profit organization whose honorary co-chairmen are former Presidents Ford and Carter. Kimball says that by 1992, the center will offer a telephone number providing voters: - Basic personal information on each candidate. - Names of people and organizations who have contributed to the campaign. - Ratings of the candidate by special interest groups ranging from the American Conservative Union to the American Civil Liberties Union. The center experimented with its concept in this year's elections in Nebraska and North Carolina. ``We got about 6,000 calls,'' said Kimball. Since the center did no paid advertising, the calls were generated by news stories and word of mouth after one press conference. When people called the 800-number, they got an operator with access to a computer holding the information on each candidate. Kimball said about 50 percent of the callers wanted voting record ratings and 25 percent sought campaign finance information, but operators also got calls seeking a range of biographical details. Kimball says the center needs at least $500,000 to run a nationwide telephone service using toll-free numbers, but he said a self-financing 900-number system would be used if sufficient funds aren't raised. It would cost $3 a call.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Spend Sixth Christmas in Captivity
DOC.TEXT: Americans Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland spent their sixth Christmas in captivity and newspapers printed greetings from Anderson's family and a photo of the daughter he has never held. ``Perhaps our miracle will happen and we'll welcome you home in time to share the beginning of the new year,'' wrote Peggy Say, Anderson's sister. For Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon, it was another grim milestone in his ordeal. The 43-year-old chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press was kidnapped on March 16, 1985. Sutherland, 59, of Fort Collins, Colo., is the second-longest-held American among the 13 missing Westerners. He was dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut when he was kidnapped on June 9, 1985. The other captives are four Americans, four Britons, two Germans and an Italian. Beirut's eight major newspapers carried messages on Dec. 25 for Anderson from Mrs. Say, his 5-year-old daughter, Sulome - born four months after he was kidnapped - and Sulome's mother, Madeleine. The leftist as-Safir daily also published greetings to British hostage John McCarthy from his family and friends on his fifth Christmas as a captive. McCarthy, 34, a London-based television journalist, was kidnapped on April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut Airport to catch a flight for London. The message to McCarthy, in a paid advertisement, urged him to ``stay as cheerful as you can and be assured we all miss you and love you.'' Beirut's independent an-Nahar ran the English text of the letters sent to Anderson with full Arabic translations. The French-language L'Orient-Le Jour carried the text of the two messages from Mrs. Say and Sulome's mother in English and French along with the latest photograph of his youngest daughter. Both newspapers said they hoped the kidnappers would let Anderson read the letters and see the picture of his daughter. ``We are united with you in spirit always. But Christmas and the holidays make it especially difficult to accept the fact of not being with you in body,'' Sulome's mother wrote. ``We are so near you and yet so far. But our hopes are always high for a bright futre and reunion forever. Merry Christmas to all of you.'' Mrs. Say told Anderson that his elder daughter, Gabrielle, was ``a blossoming young woman. ... She's a big girl now and captain of her soccer team. She's attending the school you wanted for her and is doing excellently.'' Mrs. Say expressed her hope that this would be her brother's last Christmas in captivity. ``Your friends have remained committed to your cause and we are all working hard for your release,'' she wrote. ``Especially at Christmas, I received letters from all over the United States telling me of the thousands that work and pray for you every day. ``You and your fellow hostages are not forgotten, Terry, and you will never be. For every day that you suffer, thousands of Americans agonize with you,'' Mrs. Say wrote. ``There is a God, Terry, and although neither you nor I can guess why this terrible situation has been allowed to continue, we must remain secure in the knowledge that some day, some way this will end. ``Until then, please keep well and listen in the quiet for the love and prayers that are sent to you and the others every hour, every day. May God hold you close to him.'' Former hostage Frank Reed said Dec. 30 that he had appealed to Syrian President Hafez Assad to help free the 13 hostages. ``I beg you and all nations within the community of man to reach into their wells of justice and sense of humanity and come to their rescue,'' Reed wrote in a letter to Assad. ``What a perfect season for Syria to demonstrate to all Americans and the world that its sense of humanity and human caring goes beyond standing guard together in the sands of Arabia,'' the letter said. Reed said he gave the letter to Syria's ambassador to Washington on Dec. 14 but had not received a reply. ``Bothering me was the enormous attention paid in the media and by our administration to people who were detained in Iraq and living in special conditions that in no way could be comparable to what the situation was in Lebanon,'' Reed said. ``So I decided to take it upon myself and go to the Syrian government.''
DOC.HEAD: Israeli Labor Court Overrules Paper's Dismissals
DOC.TEXT: A Tel Aviv court reversed the dismissals of 57 employees of the Jerusalem Post, saying the action violated a labor-management accord. The dispute began with the company's announcement in November that it would lay off the employees in economic cutbacks. On Dec. 3, 27 journalists were dismissed. About 70 staffers walked out, demanding that management uphold an October agreement that outlines specific procedures for dismissing workers. It also limits the number of private contracts the company may sign with workers. In response to the walkout, management told some journalists to sign private contracts or leave within 48 hours, staffers said. ``This was an attempt to break the union as well as a flagrant violation of the agreement,'' said Dan Izenberg, a member of the staff committee. An additional 30 journalists were dismissed following the walkout. The labor court ruled Dec. 27 in favor of the staff committee, which filed the complaints. It said the company must operate in keeping with the October agreement. The Post, Israel's only English-language daily, has a daily circulation of about 25,000 nationally. It prints an overseas edition with a circulation of 50,000.
DOC.HEAD: South Korea Bans Ads That Discriminate Against Women
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Ministry banned classified ads that discriminate against women effective Jan. 1 and said employers who place them will be fined $3,500. In a ruling published Dec. 30, the ministry said employment ads calling for ``single'' or ``good-looking'' applicants will be banned. Also illegal will be ads for jobs saying ``only male college graduate wanted,'' ``males welcome'' and ``completion or exemption of military service preferred.''

DOC.HEAD: Italian TV Squelches Saddam Interview
DOC.TEXT: Italy's state-owned television decided Dec. 28 not to air an interview with Saddam Hussein, saying the broadcast might ``disturb the efforts'' for a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. The decision to squelch the broadcast indefinitely drew sharp protest from reporters. The journalist who conducted the interview, Bruno Vespa, threatened to resign. The director-general of RAI television, Gianni Pasquarelli, announced the move in a letter to Vespa, the highly regarded director of the nightly TG-1 news broadcast. ``Italy is president of the European Community and we must avoid, in a moment of extreme delicacy, any act that could contribute to disturb the efforts that are being made to find a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis,'' said the letter, read on the evening news show. It did not say how the interview might have affected peace efforts. Vespa told viewers he disagreed with the decision. ``I expressed to the director-general my surprise and my complete dissent,'' he said. A RAI spokesman said he did not know if the Italian government had asked the network to stop the broadcast. The government finances RAI, and political parties have broad influence in its operation. The editorial committee of the RAI said it supported Vespa in the dispute. ``The invitation (by Pasquarelli) to not transmit the interview appears like an act of self-censorship that the editorial staff of TG-1 can not consider acceptible in any way,'' the committee said in a statement. Pasquarelli, who belongs to the dominant Christian Democrat Party, became director-general of RAI earlier this year after serving as managing director of the state highway corporation. He was previously a television journalist. The Christian Democrats control appointments at RAI-1, the channel that broadcasts Vespa's program. The second-biggest party in the government, the Socialists, have strong influence at RAI-2, another state-owned channel.
DOC.HEAD: `Shevardnadze' Segments Blocked on Popular Soviet TV Show
DOC.TEXT: The state broadcasting committee canceled two segments of one of the country's most popular television programs because of its political coverage, the show's host said Dec. 28. The segments of the weekly ``Vzglyad,'' Russian for ``viewpoint,'' were to include stories about outgoing Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, including a March interview in which he said he considered quitting to protest shootings by Soviet troops in his native Georgia, said the host, Alexander Lyubimov. Shevardnadze resigned Dec. 21, saying he feared hard-line Communist forces were pushing the Soviet leadership into a dictatorship. Program officials contended the cancellation was clearly politically motivated and it indicated a return to state censorship. The segments were to have been in the show's Dec. 28 and Jan. 4 broadcasts, Lyubimov said. Andrei Shipilov, an official at Central Television, said the episodes were canceled ``for political reasons.'' Lyubimov said ``Vzglyad'' could not ignore Shevardnadze's resignation and warning or the Congress of People's Deputies' vote to strengthen President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's powers. ``We are worried about the coincidence between this event and the recent resignations of supporters of the liberal cause on Gorbachev's team and the dramatic events at the Congress of People's Deputies,'' he said. ``Vzglyad'' includes a game show, a historical section, and American rock music in addition to the news segment. Lyubimov said the other segments would be broadcast as usual.
DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Government Sets Plan for Private TV
DOC.TEXT: The government announced plans for ending its 26-year-old monopoly on television, saying it will allow two private channels to operate alongside the two existing official channels. The new channels, which should begin operating in the summer of 1992, will still be closely regulated, spokesman Luis Marques Mendes said Dec. 27. The government will control the length of airtime reserved for news, educational shows and other programming, he said. The center-right government of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva said prospective broadcasters will have three months from Jan. 2 to present their plans and two will be chosen in June or July. A reform of the Constitution in July 1989 allowed the government to end the monopoly of the state-run Radio-Televisao Portuguesa. Initial enthusiasm for the project among Portuguese and foreign businessmen has been dampened by recent studies casting doubt on the local advertising market's capacity to support four channels.
DOC.HEAD: CNN Carries Desert Shield Briefings Live
DOC.TEXT: CNN televised live on Dec. 26 the first of what it said will be weekly U.S. military briefings for reporters who are in Saudi Arabia covering Operation Desert Shield. The briefings are being held in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, said Steve Haworth, a spokeman for CNN. He said CNN will provide full or partial live coverage of each week's briefings, depending on events. The network's reports are seen in 100 countries, including Iraq. Ground rules forbid the disclosure of exactly where in Riyadh the U.S. briefings are held. The Americans and Saudis have set up a joint military command post in Riyadh to direct operations of their troops in the event of war with Iraq. Shortly before Christmas, nearly 360 print and broadcast journalists from various countries were registered with military authorities. Officials said 110 were from CNN, ABC, NBC and CBS.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Begins Round-the-Clock News Feed to Affiliates
DOC.TEXT: NBC News will begin its 24-hour News Channel on New Year's Day, feeding video of late-breaking news, sports and features to network affiliates for use on local newscasts. Until now, the network had been feeding its local affiliates several times a day from New York City. NBC News Channel will feed raw and edited footage, including foreign, domestic and regional material, to local stations, which will then edit the reports for use on their newscasts. ``Local stations want more variety,'' said Bob Horner, head of the Charlotte operation. ``Some smaller companies, like CNN, have been more aggressive in using satellite technology to help individual stations.''

DOC.HEAD: Cable Network Plans Poll Show
DOC.TEXT: Actor David Birney and televison personality Eleanor Mondale have signed on as hosts of a new poll show that the program's backers say will ``capture America's pulse.'' ``The Great American TV Poll,'' scheduled to begin March 4 on Lifetime Television, will do polls on anything and everything to let Americans know what they're thinking. Subjects will range from ``How old is too old for a miniskirt?'' to ``Would you tell your best friend if you knew he or she had a cheating spouse?'' Birney starred in the television series ``Serpico'' and ``Bridget Loves Bernie.'' Mondale, the daughter of former Vice President Walter Mondale, was a reporter for a Los Angeles television station and host of a TV show in Minneapolis.
DOC.HEAD: Johnson Family Radio Stations Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: The family of the late President Johnson has put the KLBJ radio stations on the market again. John Barr, executive vice president of LBJ Co., said Dec. 27 that the family had retained Ted Hepburn Co. to take offers for the AM and FM stations. He said their value had been estimated at $13.5 million. The Johnson family has owned the business for more than 40 years. The family tried to sell it in 1987 for $27.5 million, but the deal fell through when Chase Group, a New York-based investment company, did not meet the deadline to complete the sale. Bill Jamar, whose Jamar and Associates handled the 1987 sales attempt, said it would be hard to get $13.5 million in today's economic climate. But Barr said, ``The stations are basically making money. They always have.''
DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Public Radio Buying FM Station
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Public Radio plans to buy WLOL-FM in a move it said would expand its potential audience from 1.8 million to more than 2.4 million. The $12 million deal requires FCC approval. Addison Piper, chairman of Minnesota Public Radio, said Dec. 26 that the purchase would allow the organization to switch its classical music service from its current channel to WLOL's higher-quality signal and reach more listeners. He said the station would be renamed KSJN.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Sells Majority Ownership of WKYC-TV to Multimedia
DOC.TEXT: The FCC has approved Multimedia Inc.'s purchase of a 51 percent controlling interest in WKYC-TV from NBC, which will retain a 49 percent stake. The companies did not disclose the purchase price in their announcement Dec. 26. Multimedia, based in Greenville, S.C., will take over WKYC's administration and day-to-day business. The company owns four other TV stations, WLWT in Cincinnati, KSDK in St. Louis, WBIR in Knoxville, Tenn., and WMAZ in Macon, Ga.
DOC.HEAD: FTC Staff Again Urges End to `Fin-Syn' Rules
DOC.TEXT: The economics staff of the Federal Trade Commission said Dec. 26 that it again had urged the FCC to abolish rules that keep broadcast television networks from owning program rerun rights. The FTC's Economics Bureau first urged abolition of the rules in September. It expanded its comments to include several proposed modifications of the financial interest and syndication rules, which commonly are called ``fin-syn.'' One proposal would regulate negotiations between program producers and networks, negotiations about which the economists said, ``We do not find compelling reasons to adopt any of the proposed restrictions.'' A proposal that would modify but not abolish the rules ``may lead to a result that is less desirable than either complete elimination or complete retention of the rules,'' the bureau said. ``Our analysis of these options leads us to continue to believe that the best course for the FCC is to repeal completely the existing fin-syn rules,'' the bureau said. The Justice Department also has said the rules should be eliminated. The FCC plans to decide in 1991 whether to keep, junk or change the rules, which were adopted 20 years ago when the broadcast networks had a much larger share of the prime-time viewing audience than they have today. The rules permit the networks to own only the overseas rerun rights to the prime-time shows they produce themselves and bar the networks from any financial interest in other prime-time programs, including off-network or ``syndicated'' showings. The FTC's Economics Bureau comments frequently on proposed regulations of other federal agencies and state agencies, generally urging views that would result in increased competition.
DOC.HEAD: Schumaker Appointed Publisher in Greenfield, Mass.
DOC.TEXT: Tom Schumaker, publisher of the Transcript-Telegram of Holyoke, Mass., was named publisher of The Recorder on Dec. 26. Both papers are owned by Newspapers of New England of Concord, N.H. Schumaker succeeds Alexander C. Hutchinson, who is returning to the Tampa (Fla.) Tribune after 14 years as publisher of The Recorder. Hutchinson began his newspaper career at the Tribune in 1957. Schumaker joined the Transcript-Telegram nine years ago after a decade-long career with Knight Ridder Newspapers, working in Boca Raton, Fla., and Grand Forks, N.D.
DOC.HEAD: General Manager, Executive Editor Named in Tyler, Texas
DOC.TEXT: J.D. Osborn, purchasing manager for T.B. Butler Publishing Co. Inc., was appointed general manager of the newspaper company on Dec. 23. A.J. ``Jim'' Giametta was promoted from managing editor to executive editor, and Thomas Clyde, vice president of finance, was named chief financial officer. The company publishes the Tyler Morning Telegraph, the Tyler Courier-Times and the Sunday Tyler Courier-Times-Telegraph. Osborn, who joined the newspapers in 1985, will have general management responsibilities for the newspapers' advertising, circulation, production, maintenance and certain business operations. Clyde, who has been vice president of finance since 1984, will have primary responsibility for business office operations. Giametta, managing editor since 1988, will be responsible for the editorial department.
DOC.HEAD: Newsday Appoints Ibarguen Senior Vice President
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Ibarguen was named senior vice president of Newsday and New York Newsday on Dec. 27. Ibarguen has been vice president for legal affairs, human resources and labor relations at the two newspapers since 1985. He will continue to oversee those areas and add responsibility for community affairs on Long Island and in New York. The community affairs department formerly reported to Associate Publisher Steven L. Isenberg, who was named executive vice president of the Los Angeles Times, which also is owned by Times-Mirror Co.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Times Editor Named Editor of The Quill
DOC.TEXT: Brian L. Steffens of the Los Angeles Times has been named editor of The Quill, the magazine of the Society of Professional Journalists. Steffens replaces Mike Moore, who chose not to make the move when the organization moved from Chicago to Greencastle. Moore had been editor since 1985. Steffens said he plans to update the magazine's format with more tips and practical advice for journalists. He has been news editor of the daily View section of the Times' Orange County edition, supervising production. He previously was graphics editor of the Orange County edition, and from 1984 to 1987 he was assistant managing editor for graphics at The San Diego Union. Steffens also has served as publisher of the Society of Newspaper Design's Design Journal, Deadline Mac newsletter and other publications since 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Edmund Akenhead
DOC.TEXT: Edmund Akenhead, the editor of the crossword puzzle in The Times of London for 18 years, died Dec. 22. He was 77. Akenhead, who trained as a lawyer, began his career with crosswords while serving in Britain's Colonial Service in Dar-es-Salaam, in what is now Tanzania, where he began setting crosswords for the Tanganyika Standard. Returning to England, he became the third editor of The Times' crossword in 1965. He retired in 1983. He is survived by his wife and two sons.
DOC.HEAD: William Alexander
DOC.TEXT: William ``Skinny'' Alexander, a newspaper columnist and former state legislator, died Dec. 25 after a long battle with throat cancer. He was 56. Alexander was a longtime columnist for The Recorder, a newspaper serving Indianapolis' black community. He was elected to the state General Assembly as a Democrat in 1972 but was defeated in a bid for re-election two years later. He is survived by four daughters and four sons.
DOC.HEAD: Russ Coughlan
DOC.TEXT: Russ Coughlan, a longtime broadcaster in the San Francisco Bay area and one of the founders of Armed Forces Radio, died Dec. 29 of a heart attack. Coughlan, who kept his age a mystery, worked for more than 30 years at KGO-TV, serving at various times as sales manager, talk show host, news anchor, general manager and most recently as a special assignment reporter. He began his broadcasting career in 1940 at radio station KHUB in Watsonville while stationed at nearby Camp McQuaide. During World War II he served in the Pacific and helped found Armed Forces Radio. He is survived by two daughters.
DOC.HEAD: David E. Henderson
DOC.TEXT: David E. Henderson, the top executive of Outlet Communications Inc., died of a heart attack Dec. 27. He was 62. Outlet owns WJAR-TV in Providence and WCMH-TV in Columbus, Ohio. Henderson joined the company 18 years ago and had been chairman, president and chief executive officer since 1989. He spent 42 years in broadcasting, much of it with Group W Productions. While at Group W, he held executive sales and managerial positions at WBZ-TV in Boston, KYW-TV in Philadelphia and WJZ-TV in Baltimore and produced the ``Mike Douglas Show'' and David Frost programs. Survivors include his wife, a daughter and three sons.
DOC.HEAD: Francis McGovern
DOC.TEXT: Francis R. McGovern, who was editor of a short-lived strike paper and founder of a daily newsletter, died Dec. 25 of a heart attack. He was 70. During a 1962 strike at Minneapolis' newspapers, McGovern was asked to be editor of a new paper. Within days, he and 11 others published the first edition of the Minneapolis Daily Herald, a 100,000-circulation newspaper, but financial backers shut it down after the strike ended. McGovern started the Minneapolis Daily American in 1964, but finances caused him to reduce it in 1970 to an eight-page daily newsletter. The last edition will be published next week by a son, Francis. McGovern is survived by his wife and nine children.
DOC.HEAD: Seymour Rosenberg
DOC.TEXT: Seymour Rosenberg, whose columns of opinion and wit entertained readers of the Herald-Journal for 33 years, died of cancer Dec. 30. He was 67. Rosenberg joined the paper in 1956 as sports editor. He was telegraph editor before beginning his column, ``The Stroller,'' in April 1957. He was named Sunday editor and features editor in 1963 and director of special projects in 1980, but he continued his column. He worked at The Shreveport (La.) Times, The Honolulu Advertiser and The Bulletin in Martinsville, Va., before coming to Spartanburg. He is survived by his wife and four children.
DOC.HEAD: Don Wolfe
DOC.TEXT: Don Wolfe, a reporter and editor who was popular for his human interest writing from northwestern Ohio, died Dec. 25. He was 75. Wolfe began his career as a reporter at the Bowling Green Sentinel-Tribune. In 1937, he moved to the former Toledo Times, where he was a police reporter, theater editor, business editor and Sunday editor. He moved to The Blade in 1947 to become the state editor and was responsible for gathering news from about 170 communities in northwestern Ohio and southeastern Michigan. He retired as assistant managing editor on Aug. 6. Survivors include a son, two daughters, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

Arlo Guthrie says he became a folk singer like his father, Woody, in spite of himself - he says he really would rather have been a newspaper reporter. Five years ago he and his wife began a quarterly newsletter, The Rolling Blunder Review, that has grown to a circulation of 60,000-70,000. ... Actor Martin Sheen knows how to get his name in a newspaper - just show up in a newsroom with a camera. Sheen filmed scenes at The Dallas Morning News on Dec. 27 for his new miniseries, ``Touch and Die,'' which is about a reporter who discovers stolen plutonium is being sold to finance a presidential campaign. ... Brent Musburger says life after CBS football has been a series of Sundays spent strolling through art museums and hiking mountains, but not a particularly happy time. ``While I enjoyed being with my wife, I couldn't get the NFL out of my system,'' Musburger told TV Guide. ``This was the first season I didn't have an NFL game or show since I covered the Chicago Bears in 1963 as a newspaperman.'' He'll be covering the NFL playoffs for ABC.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials are applauding a separate European peace initiative amid indications Saddam Hussein may compromise on a date for high-level talks with the Bush administration on avoiding armed conflict. But overtones of war continued to dominate pronouncements from Baghdad. A government newspaper warned Sunday of terrorist attacks if combat breaks out, and the country's information minister boasted that Iraqis would ``show the world America is a paper tiger.'' Saddam Hussein said in a New Year's message that because of the threat of war a ``false happiness'' should pervade any holiday celebrations. ---= WASHINGTON - The Bush administration must try to find a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis before going to war, top lawmakers say. But they disagree over whether to hold back money if the fighting starts without congressional approval. ``A diplomatic effort really needs to be made and has to be made before the decision to go to war,'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Sunday. His thoughts were echoed by the Senate's ranking Republican, Bob Dole of Kansas, who said he would like to see President Bush ``pursue at least one additional time'' a date for U.S.-Iraqi discussions. ``The American people are not yet committed to war, and they want to make certain that President Bush has done everything, pursued every avenue for peace before the firing starts,'' Dole said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ---= MOUNT VERNON, Mo. - The director of the hospital where Nancy Cruzan died won a court order against the father of another patient who wants to remove his brain-damaged daughter's feeding tube. Pete Busalacchi wants to transfer his 20-year-old daughter, Christine, from the Missouri Rehabilitation Center to Minnesota, where she could die under a state provision that recognizes ethical decisions by doctors. The hospital's director fought the move, claiming Ms. Busalacchi has a better chance of recovering than Ms. Cruzan did. Ms. Cruzan died at the Missouri hospital Dec. 26 after her parents won a landmark court battle to have her feeding tube disconnected. ---= WASHINGTON - A presidential commission planning the 500th anniversary celebration of Columbus' voyage to America has been plagued by problems: a tiny budget, few corporate donations and, until this month, almost no publicity. Now add a conflict-of-interest controversy to its list of woes. The panel's chairman, Miami real estate developer John Goudie, resigned amid disclosures that a close friend has ties to a company doing business with the commission. The event's biggest corporate sponsor, Texaco Inc., suspended its donations in September after raising questions about the commission's management. Another potential sponsor, Chrysler Corp., may stay away from the event. ---= WASHINGTON - Whether you were pleased or peeved by the performance of America's legislature last year, get ready for Congress-The Sequel. The cast being sworn in this week for the 102nd Congress is much as it was in the 101st. But the unaddressed problems have grown to the point where those in starring roles must put in much bigger performances. Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., returns as speaker of the House; George Mitchell, D-Maine, as Senate majority leader; and Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., and Bob Dole, R-Kan., as minority leaders of the House and Senate, respectively. Their back-ups, stand-ins and bit players remain the same, too, as another two-year period of governing begins Thursday. The football Redskins, a more popular Washington institution, make more roster changes than the voters make with Congress. ---= PORTLAND, Ore. - Like a patrolman on the beat, Lee Barrett strides into a Chinese restaurant, flashes his ID card and has a look around. ``StyroCop'' is on the trail of illicit carryout containers. The city has gotten a complaint that the restaurant is putting its egg rolls and fried rice in boxes that violate Portland's year-old ban on polystyrene foam fast-food containers. Barrett, 44, a longtime environmental activist, is the ban's enforcer. A local television reporter dubbed him StyroCop - a takeoff on the movie ``RoboCop'' - his first day on the job and he's become something of a celebrity. Barrett believes Americans must go beyond recycling by rejecting products that are overpackaged and becoming accustomed to using things again and again. ``As a recycler, our creed has always been reduce, reuse, recycle,'' he says. ``Recycling is the last thing to do before you throw it away.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Mon PMs, Jan. 7 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Philippines Gains Reputation as Hollywood of the Far East
DOC.TEXT: The Philippines is becoming a budget Hollywood, attracting foreign filmmakers despite deteriorating security and more than its share of natural disasters. James Glickenhaus, producer of ``McBain,'' said varied locations, a professional local work crew and an English-speaking population also make filming here easier. ``All in all, it was an extremely atrractive place for us to shoot,'' Glickenhaus said. ``I would recommend it to other filmmakers. It's a great place to shoot.'' ``McBain,'' which was filmed here through December, is the latest in a series of foreign movies shot in the Philippines. Others include ``Apocalyse Now,'' ``Platoon,'' ``Born on the Fouth of July,'' ``The Year of Living Dangerously'' and Chuck Norris' ``Delta Force'' series. ``McBain'' stars Christopher Walken, who won an Academy Award for ``The Deer Hunter,'' and Venezuelan actress Maria Conchita Alonzo, whose credits include ``Moscow on the Hudson'' with Robin Williams and ``Running Man'' with Arnold Schwarzenegger. Glickenhaus, who is also the film's director and writer, downplayed apprehensions about the security situation in the country, which faces a 21-year communist rebellion and the continuing threat from military extremists who have launched seven armed uprisings in 4{ years. ``The perception of what the political situation here is really a lot worst than I think the reality of it is,'' Glickenhaus said. ``If you read the papers in New York, you'd think it is unsafe and you're going to be shot and you're gonna be blown up. ``Obviously, when you're here, I don't think, I don't feel that I'm going to be shot or blown up.'' His crew started filming here in October at about the same time as a mutiny led by a renegade Army colonel erupted in the southern Philippines, 500 miles south of Manila. The rebellion fizzled out in three days. A series of at least 40 bombing attacks by rightist and leftist extremists have occurred in the Manila area since August. In November, Typhoon Mike swept the central Philippines, killing about 470 people. Walken said foreign members of the film were unaffected by these incidents since they took place in areas far away from where they were filming. ``I've been to many places and it's been quite normal, uneventful here, except for the typhoon,'' Walken said. Glickenhaus said he used several provinces just on the outskirts of Manila to shoot scenes that depict parts of three countries. The provincial capitol of Batangas province, south of Manila, was turned into a Colombian presidential palace. A forest in nearby Cavite province depicted a Vietnamese prison camp. Just west of Manila, the film crew built a Jamaican white sand beach resort in the coast of Zambales province. The film also hired about 500 Filipino crew members and actors, most of whom worked in Hollywood films shot here. The high cost of production in the United States, especially for independent American film producers working on a tight budget, makes shooting in the Philippines attractive. Glickenhaus said ``McBain,'' if shot in the United States, would have cost at least double its $17 million budget. He said the film spent about $200,000 for a scene in which thousands of extras were storming the Colombian presidential palace. That scene would have cost $2 million if if had been shot in Hollywood, he added. Most of the film's $17 million was expected to be spent here, to the benefit of the local economy. Tom Gray, the film's publicist, said the widespread use of English - one of the two official languages - gives the Philippines an advantage over other Southeast Asian countries. He said it is easy to give directions to Filipino actors and crew members because they understand English. ``People still like making movies here,'' Glickenhaus said. ``That's a good thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, Jan. 7, the seventh day of 1991. There are 358 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Jan. 7, 1789, the first U.S. presidential election was held. Americans voted for electors who, a month later, chose George Washington to be the nation's first president. On this date: In 1536, Catherine of Aragon, the first wife of England's King Henry VIII, died. In 1610, the astronomer Galileo sighted four of Jupiter's moons. In 1782, the first commercial bank in the United States, the Bank of North America, opened in Philadelphia. In 1800, the 13th president of the United States, Millard Fillmore, was born in Summerhill, N.Y. In 1927, commercial transatlantic telephone service was inaugurated between New York and London. In 1942, the World War II siege of Bataan started. In 1953, President Truman announced in his State of the Union address that the United States had developed a hydrogen bomb. In 1959, the United States recognized Fidel Castro's new government in Cuba. In 1979, Vietnamese forces that had invaded Cambodia on Christmas Day captured the capital of Phnom Penh, overthrowing the Khmer Rouge government. In 1980, the Soviet Union vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution protesting the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. In 1989, Emperor Hirohito of Japan died in Tokyo at age 87; he was succeeded by his son, Crown Prince Akihito. Ten years ago: President-elect Reagan tapped Utah education official Terrel H. Bell to be secretary of education. China's first official airline flight to the United States since the Communist takeover in 1949 arrived at San Francisco International Airport. Five years ago: President Reagan ordered all Americans and U.S. companies to stop doing business with Libya, and pledged ``further steps'' would be taken if Moammar Gadhafi did not end his ``longstanding involvement in terrorism.'' One year ago: The president of El Salvador, Alfredo Cristiani, said in a nationally broadcast address that military men had committed the massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter the previous November. Today's Birthdays: Actor Vincent Gardenia is 69. Author William Peter Blatty is 63. NBC newsman Douglas Kiker is 61. Singer-songwriter Leona Williams is 48. Singer Kenny Loggins is 43. Thought for Today: ``Funny how people despise platitudes, when they are usually the truest thing going. A thing has to be pretty true before it gets to be a platitude.'' - Katharine Fullerton Gerould, American author (1879-1944).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, Jan. 8, the eighth day of 1991. There are 357 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Jan. 8, 1935, rock-and-roll legend Elvis Presley was born in Tupelo, Miss. On this date: In 1642, astronomer Galileo died in Arcetri, Italy. In 1815, U.S. forces led by Gen. Andrew Jackson defeated the British in the Battle of New Orleans - the closing engagement of the War of 1812. In 1918, President Wilson outlined his 14 points for peace after World War I. In 1959, Charles De Gaulle was inaugurated as president of France's Fifth Republic. In 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a ``War on Poverty.'' In 1965, the Star of India and other stolen gems were returned to the American Museum of Natural History in New York. In 1973, secret peace talks between the United States and North Vietnam resumed near Paris. In 1975, Judge John J. Sirica ordered the release of Watergate figures John W. Dean III, Herbert W. Kalmbach and Jeb Stuart Magruder from prison. In 1976, Chou En-lai, premier of China since the communists took power in 1949, died in Beijing at age 78. In 1982, American Telephone and Telegraph settled the Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit against it by agreeing to divest itself of the 22 Bell System companies. In 1985, the Reverend Lawrence Martin Jenco was kidnapped in Lebanon (he was released after 19 months in captivity). In 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 2,000 level for the first time, ending the day at 2,002.25. Ten years ago: President-elect Reagan told reporters he would feel free to review all hostage negotiations with Iran if the American captives were not free before he took office. Five years ago: A day after acting to halt all American business dealings with Libya, President Reagan ordered all Libyan government assets in the U.S. frozen. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped a then-record 39.10 points, ending the day at 1,526.61. One year ago: Military tribunals in Romania began trying the first captured members of the country's dreaded security forces, who stood accused of resisting the revolution that ended the reign of Nicolae Ceausescu. Today's Birthdays: Actress Butterfly McQueen is 80. Actor-director Jose Ferrer is 79. Actor-comedian Larry Storch is 68. Actor Ron Moody is 67. Comedian Soupy Sales is 65. ABC newsman Sander Vanocur is 63. CBS newsman Charles Osgood is 58. Singer Shirley Bassey is 54. Actress Yvette Mimieux is 52. Rock singer David Bowie is 44. Thought for Today: ``Why is propaganda so much more successful when it stirs up hatred than when it tries to stir up friendly feeling?'' - Bertrand Russell, English philosopher and mathematician (1872-1970).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, Jan. 9, the ninth day of 1991. There are 356 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Jan. 9, 1793, what's generally regarded as the first manned balloon flight in the United States took place as Frenchman Jean Pierre Blanchard traveled between Philadelphia and Woodbury, N.J. On this date: In 1788, Connecticut became the fifth state to ratify the U.S. Constitution. In 1861, Mississippi seceded from the Union. In 1942, the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff was created. In 1945, American soldiers led by Gen. Douglas MacArthur invaded Luzon in the Philippines during World War II. In 1964, anti-U.S. rioting broke out in the Panama Canal Zone, resulting in the deaths of 21 Panamanians and three U.S. soldiers. In 1968, the Surveyor VII space probe made a soft landing on the moon, marking the end of the American series of unmanned explorations of the lunar surface. In 1972, reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, speaking by telephone from the Bahamas to reporters in Hollywood, said a purported biography of him by Clifford Irving was a fake. In 1983, hundreds of residents of the Falkland Islands cheered British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher as she began a surprise tour of the South Atlantic colony, which Britain had wrested back from Argentina seven months earlier. In 1984, a federal judge sentenced former Environmental Protection Agency official Rita M. Lavelle to six months in prison for her conviction on charges of lying to Congress. (Lavelle served five months in 1985.) Ten years ago: 31 people were killed when fire broke out at the Beachview Rest Home in Keansburg, N.J. Five years ago: British Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine resigned, accusing Prime Minister Thatcher of trying to muzzle his campaign against the takeover of a British helicopter company by Sikorsky, an American firm. One year ago: The space shuttle Columbia was launched on a 10-day mission that included the retrieval of a drifting scientific satellite. Today's Birthdays: Former President Nixon is 78. Football hall-of-famer Bart Starr is 57. Actor Bob Denver is 56. Folk singer Joan Baez is 50. Actress Susannah York is 50. Singer Crystal Gayle is 40. Thought for Today: ``One's lifework, I have learned, grows with the working and the living. Do it as if your life depended on it, and first thing you know, you'll have made a life out of it. A good life, too.'' - Theresa Helburn, American theatrical producer (1887-1959).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Friday, Jan. 11, the 11th day of 1991. There are 354 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Jan. 11, 1913, the first sedan-type automobile, a Hudson, went on display at the 13th Automobile Show in New York. On this date: In 1757, the first secretary of the U.S. Treasury - Alexander Hamilton - was born in the West Indies. In 1805, the Michigan Territory was created. In 1861, Alabama seceded from the Union. In 1935, aviator Amelia Earhart began a trip from Honolulu to Oakland, Calif., that made her the first woman to fly solo across the Pacific Ocean. In 1943, the United States and Britain signed treaties relinquishing extraterritorial rights in China. In 1964, U.S. Surgeon General Luther Terry issued the first government report saying smoking may be hazardous to one's health. In 1977, France set off an international uproar by releasing Abu Daoud, a Palestinian suspected of involvement in the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. In 1978, two Soviet cosmonauts aboard the Soyuz XXVII capsule linked up with the Salyut VI orbiting space station, where the Soyuz XXVI capsule was already docked. In 1984, Chief Warrant Officer Jeffry (cq) C. Schwab, a U.S. Army pilot, was killed by Sandinista fire as his helicopter was shot down along the Nicaraguan-Honduran border. In 1989, President Reagan bade the nation farewell in a nationally broadcast address from the Oval Office. Ten years ago: The Philadelphia Eagles and the Oakland Raiders won their respective conference championships to earn berths in Super Bowl XV. (The Eagles, of the National Conference, defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 20-7, while the Raiders, of the American Conference, beat the San Diego Chargers 34-27.) Five years ago: The first black to be elected lieutenant governor of a state since Reconstruction, L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, was sworn into office along with Governor-elect Gerald L. Baliles. One year ago: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Lithuania, where he sought to assure supporters of independence that they would have a say in their republic's future. Today's Birthdays: Actress-director Eva Le Gallienne is 92. TV producer Grant Tinker is 65. Producer David L. Wolper is 63. Actor Rod Taylor is 62. Country singer Naomi Judd is 45. Golfer Ben Crenshaw is 39. Thought for Today: ``If you are ruled by mind you are a king; if by body, a slave.'' - Cato, Roman statesman and historian (234 B.C.-149 B.C.)

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Saturday, Jan. 12, the 12th day of 1991. There are 353 days left in the year. Today's Highlight in History: On Jan. 12, 1945, during World War II, German forces in Belgium retreated in the Battle of the Bulge. On this date: In 1773, the first public museum in America was established, in Charleston, S.C. In 1915, the U.S. House of Representatives rejected a proposal to give women the right to vote. In 1932, Mrs. Hattie W. Caraway became the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate. In 1944, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill and French General Charles De Gaulle began a two-day wartime conference in Marrakesh, Morocco. In 1945, aircraft from U.S. Task Force 38 sank about 40 Japanese ships off Indochina. In 1966, President Lyndon B. Johnson said in his State of the Union address that the U.S. should stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression there ended. In 1971, 20 years ago, the innovative situation comedy ``All in the Family'' premiered on CBS television. In 1987, Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite arrived in Lebanon on his latest mission to win the release of hostages, a journey that would result in his own disappearance. Ten years ago: Iran's parliamentary speaker, Hashemi Rafsanjani, told a news conference ``all roads'' were open to settling the 14-month-old hostage crisis. The Chicago Bears and the New England Patriots won their conference championships, earning them places in the Super Bowl. DOC.HEAD: `Talking with David Frost' - The Short Course in Interviewing
DOC.TEXT: David Frost, preparing for the interview with President and Mrs. Bush that airs tonight on PBS, was delighted to share his knowledge on the art of the interview. Tonight's hourlong `` ... Talking with David Frost'' is the first in a series of six by Frost, 50, a two-time Emmy Award winner known here since the weekly satire ``That Was The Week That Was'' aired on U.S. TV in 1964. It was Frost who, in 1977, won worldwide attention with his series of interviews with former President Richard Nixon. Future ``Talking'' episodes will feature Margaret Thatcher and entertainer Robin Williams. Tonight's interview with the Bushes was not available at press time. Here, then, is the David Frost Short Course on the Interview: ``T.S. Eliot said a work of art has a life of its own,'' Frost said, settling back into his chair. ``Although I wouldn't claim that an interview is a work of art, it does have a life of its own.'' I. Preparation Is Important. ``Some people think the more preparation you do, the more it shackles you to a prepared plan,'' he said. ``The truth of good homework or good research, is it liberates you to go with the flow of the interview. ... ``The less you know the more you have to stick to your set questions. ``The other thing is, it saves you from boring the pants off somebody.'' Frost said he and a staff of four compiled three thick binders of research and background for tonight's interview with the first couple. From that, Frost transposes his questions, background and quotes onto cardboard folders. ``On those folders, there's a game plan - but it ain't sacred,'' he said. For the famed ``Nixon Interviews,'' which yielded six hours of television from 28} hours of interviews over 12 days, Frost said he had four journalists working for a year to prepare for it. II. Know When to Shut Up. ``There are silences in interviews, and in television interviews, silence is an eternity,'' he said. ``There are two sorts of silences. One is where you just sense that if you shut up, the person will go on and say perhaps more than they were going to say. ``And then there's another sort of silence where you realize the person has forgotten completely what the hell they were going to say. And that silence is one that you'd better fill as fast as possible.'' III. The Importance of Listening. ``Obviously, the most important thing is listening. That is so transparently obvious that it seems unnecessary to say it. But so many times people have said to me `It's so good that you really listen.' So I guess not everybody does.'' He recalled being interviewed in England by a radio host who followed a questions list without listening to the answers. Frost said at first he tried to be kind, saying ``I'm glad you got back to that.'' He soon tired of it. ``In the end, it got irresistible. I ended one answer by saying, `And then of course, I married the pope's first wife.' And the guy said, `But what do you feel about the future of the Common Market?''' IV. Turn an Interview into a Conversation as Soon as Possible. ``That's so there's interplay, so that both people become absorbed in the conversation,'' he said. ``I don't mean they become absorbed in the conversation to the point where they forget themselves, but where they forget the cameras, the lights and so on.'' V. On Being Lied To ``There are occasions when you do have to become not just the catalyst but the principal,'' he said. ``And that is when you feel, to use a splendid euphemism, that the facts are being done a disservice - Churchill used the phrase, `When you feel someone is guilty of a terminological inexactitude.' ``In those circumstances, you do have to become a principal, and then you do have to press and then you do have to repeat the question, and then you do have to repeat the facts that you think contradict what the person's just said, and sometimes you have to return to it again and again, and say, `But. Yes, but ...''' VI. On the Roles of the Interviewer ``You do, sometimes, have to adopt varying roles,'' Frost said. He cited the first day of the Nixon interviews, in which Nixon stonewalled questions about the Watergate affair. ``It was prosecution and defense,'' Frost said. ``When he came back on the second day, having realized the total stonewall did not work, he was prepared to volunteer something - not enough, as it turned out - and then suddenly the atmosphere became more of the confessional. ``Then on an entirely different subject, the breakthrough to China, there I was Boswell to his Johnson.'' VII. On Having Paid Nixon to Be Interviewed ``I paid $600,000 for six hours on the air and NBC News, who were the semifinalists as it were, the runnersup, had offered $400,000 for two hours. So I wasn't the only person who doing it. ``So I offered more money, but I got a better rate per hour.'' --- Elsewhere in television . . . AND SPEAKING OF `THAT WAS THE WEEK THAT WAS' DEPT. - NBC's planned debut of ``Sunday Best,'' a comedic review of the week on TV, was to be Jan. 13, a Sunday. Then it was pushed back to Feb. 3, to the suicide slot opposite CBS' ``60 Minutes.'' The network cited ``uncertainties of postseason football games'' that could delay the start of ``Sunday Best,'' and affect the premiere of ``Dark Shadows,'' the four-hour TV movie airing on Jan. 13-14.
