DOC.HEAD: Truckers Who Blew Whistle Unemployed, Feel Ostracized
DOC.TEXT: James and Rikki Pomerenke fought to make the nation's food safer. As a result, they no longer feel safe. The truckdrivers keep five loaded guns in their Yakima home for protection. Unemployed for more than a year, they contend they have been blackballed by the local trucking industry because they exposed the practice of hauling toxic chemicals and food products in the same tankers. With fellow truckers Dave Helzer and Sharon Sonner, they revealed that some trucking companies required drivers to deliver dangerous chemicals in one load, then wash out the tanker and fill it with food grade products on the backhaul. Their whistleblowing resulted in a new federal law signed in early November by President Bush that restricted such cross-hauling practices. The law requires clear labeling to identify tankers for sole use with foods or chemicals. It also gives truckers the right to refuse an illegal backhaul. The law will increase the down time for truckers, making it more difficult to get lucrative backhauls, the Pomerenkes said. Still, Cliff Harvison, president of National Tank Truck Carriers Inc. in Alexandria, Va., said much of the industry supports what the Pomerenkes did. ``They are good, decent, honest moral people,'' Harvison said. ``They did the right thing.'' But doing the right thing has not made life easy for the Pomerenkes. They say they have been ostracized by friends and are running out of money. They claim that they have been threatened, and warned by former co-workers that they could face physical harm. ``We are at the end of our rope,'' said Pomerenke, 45. ``It's real hard for me to deal with,'' said Rikki Pomerenke, 40. ``We don't have any friends anymore.'' The central Washington city of 55,000 is a major producer of fruits and vegetables, with a large trucking industry. ``Down here people didn't have an axe to grind and were not bound economically with the fruit and agriculture community of Yakima,'' Ms. Sonner said. ``There's loose cannons any place and any time.'' Helzer and Sonner have left Yakima; they moved to Hermiston, Ore., after the publicity started to overwhelm them, and after Helzer's truck was broken into twice. While they did not feel they had been blackballed, they thought there were better prospects for steady employment elsewhere, Ms. Sonner said. The Pomerenkes are long-time residents of Yakima. They have family there, and they don't want to move. They contend they have applied to numerous trucking companies for jobs, and are turned down as soon as the employer learns who they are. They declined to name any of the trucking companies. The Pomerenkes acknowledged there has been at least one local job offer, but they turned it down because the pay was less than the prevailing scale. The Pomerenkes live on a $1,500 per month disability check for a hand injury Rikki suffered while operating a jackhammer on a construction job last year. James receives unemployment. Ms. Sonner said neither couple was aware of the attention their whistleblowing would bring. ``In all honesty, I don't think the four of us would have had enough nerve to go through with it,'' Ms. Sonner said. ``It's scary to have someone from D.C. call up and say, `Please testify before Congress.''' The Pomerenkes have filed a lawsuit against their former employer in Yakima County Superior Court. The lawsuit contends that former employer, Premium Transport, has hurt their ability to get work by ``unlawful termination, outrageous conduct, defamation and breach of contract.'' That company is defunct. Former president James Ketchum, also a defendant in the lawsuit, has declined to return numerous telephone messages. The Pomerenkes had been construction workers in the Yakima area for about 15 years when they decided to seek steady employment together as a long-haul driving team in late 1987. ``What we learned in the year and a half made me sick,'' said Mrs. Pomerenke. The lawsuit contends they were asked to lie about their previous load when using tanker washing facilities, and to lie to shippers about their most recent load when picking up food after hauling chemicals. They hauled juice, wine and milk after hauling items like inedible tallow and plastic resin, which is used to make foam insulation. In May 1989, the Pomerenkes refused to haul a chemical from the Midwest to the West Coast. Returning with their empty tanker to Yakima, they were fired. They are angry about the treatment they have received since they went to Washington to testify. ``I'm an American and I love my country and it's obvious from what we've done that we care about it,'' James Pomerenke said. ``It's strange that there are no laws to protect people who step forward.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Jan 7
For release Tues PMs, Jan 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Teens Sentenced By Their Peers in Special Court
DOC.TEXT: The jury was tough on the girl who was accused of trespassing and harassment at a middle school: She was sentenced to 20 hours of community service, and was ordered to stay away from the school. A 15-year-old boy who swore at his science teacher in class received similar treatment: 20 hours of community service, and a written apology - three pages, front and back - to school officials. Each also was sentenced to serve two jury stints in this same court - the Teen Court, a place where teen-agers are tried by a jury of their teen peers. ``These are kids who are just beginning to get into trouble,'' said Janice Church, head of the Denver Bar Association's Teen Court advisory board. ``This is a kind of early intervention program, an alternative forum to correct the behavior of kids.'' The program, launched last month after more than a year of planning, is modeled after ones in Odessa, Texas, and Tarrytown, N.Y. But Denver is the first major city to implement the program. The six-member juries impose real sentences in a real courtroom presided over by a retired juvenile court judge. The lawyers and prosecutors are teen-agers. The court meets twice a month, and though it is limited to three schools at first, it soon will be expanded. The cases involve minor offenses that could wind up before the district attorney's office, as well as serious violations of school policy that could result in a several-day suspension. By opting for Teen Court, the defendants instead face up to 40 hours of community service, up to four tours as a juror and possibly having to apologize - usually in a formal letter - to the victims. David Chaffee, the bar association's Teen Court coordinator, drafts a contract that the teen-agers sign, choosing community service that fits the crime and the defendant. The defendants must complete their sentences of community service and jury duty or face punishment in juvenile court or discipline by school officials. Church said Teen Court gives all participants a chance to feel they are part of the system. And it should make a difference that their peers are the ones who decide the punishment. ``Kids react to negative peer pressure,'' said Church. ``Maybe they'll react to positive peer pressure.'' ``I think kids may hope that people their own age will be more lenient,'' said Lorelei Ockers, a student at Abraham Lincoln High School in southwest Denver and a member of the Teen Court advisory board. The trespasser, an accomplice and the profane boy, all Lincoln students, were the first three defendants. If they were counting on soft treatment, they probably were disappointed. Melanie Lucero, lawyer for the boy who swore at his science teacher, tried to paint a picture of a youth struggling to do the right thing despite an ongoing personality clash with the teacher. ``I was having a bad day, and I was trying to have a very important conversation,'' the 10th-grader explained. But jurors stared at the boy as prosecutor Donnell Vigil made him repeat the two swear words he uttered that day. Judge Roger Cisneros peered sternly at him over his glasses. Vigil, who wants to be a lawyer, exuded indignation as she told the six jurors that no student, no matter how bad his day is going, should swear at a teacher and disrupt the learning process. ``I got more than I wanted,'' said Vigil, after the sentencing. In the other case, lawyer Christa Goetz maintained that her two clients accused of trespassing would not have visited the school after it was closed if they had known it violated school policy. One defendant said she wanted to talk to the principal about her sister. But prosecutor Paul Rodriguez presented letters from the principal accusing the teen-agers of harassing two students. He said both had attended the junior high school, and knew the rules. Though one of the defendants received a stiff sentence, the other got the Teen Court equivalent of a slap on the wrist - eight hours of community service, one jury tour and a written apology. Why the disparity? Goetz, obviously not yet skilled in the lawyerly art of artful dodging, said: ``I feel they maybe picked up that she (the first girl) wasn't telling the truth.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs, Jan 8

DOC.HEAD: Price Gouging or Prudency?
DOC.TEXT: Price gouging at the gasoline pumps? Not at all. Simply prudent behavior. Who says so? Professor McKenzie says so. Richard McKenzie, professor of finance and economics at the University of Mississippi, and somewhat of a rarity in his ability to assemble scholarly data in clarifying popular issues. True, McKenzie is a believer in the ability of the marketplace to make intelligent adjustments to changes in supply and demand, but he assumes that you too believe in that system. Or do you? As a participant in the real estate market - most people are participants, as owners or renters - you might find of special interest this aspect of his argument: ``The charge that producers should not profit from the Iraqi crisis is about as sensible as claiming that homeowners in Los Angeles who bought their houses in the 1950s are morally bound not to profit when selling them.'' If homeowners do not collect their accumulated profits, asks the professor, how will they be able to replace their homes. They cannot, he suggests, declare that the marketplace should accommodate them. Of course not. Besides, if they decline to take profits, that doesn't mean the profits aren't there. It means only that the owner-seller declines to accept them; the profits will be passed on to the buyer, who will collect them on the next resale. Except for his strong belief in free markets, McKenzie has no known reason to defend oil companies. His identification with the subject is academic, as a professor, and as a fellow of the Center for the Study of American Business, based on the campus of St. Louis' Washington University. In that latter regard, he produced ``Working Paper 137,'' detailing his findings and conclusions. -Taking 1967 as a base year, the price of a gallon of gasoline ($1.38 at the time the paper was written) had risen less since 1960 than the price of the basket of goods that goes into the calculation of the consumer price index. -Uncle Sam has a bit to do with those higher pump prices. Gasoline taxes were 10.5 cents a gallon in 1960. They rose to 14.5 cents in 1981 and to 26.9 cents in July 1990. And, of course, they have just risen again. -The quality of gasoline has risen, providing more miles to the gallon and less pollution too. American consumers are now spending a much smaller percent of disposable income on gasoline than in 1970 or earlier decades. In 1989, McKenzie states, ``gasoline expenditures for the `typical' consumer as a percent of his or her disposable income fell precipitously to less than one-half of the 1970 level and to almost a third of the 1980 level.'' McKenzie makes this effort - stressed in his paper - to describe recent pricing events at the pump, which a great many Americans have chosen to call gouging: ``Oil markets must not only account for current reductions in supplies but also must seek to anticipate the prospects of further declines in the oil supplies.'' When production of any good or service involves delivery at a future time, he explains, ``then competitive prices reflect both current and expected future supplies.'' It is like the Los Angeles homeowner who must worry about earning enough on the sale of his present house to buy another, especially if the housing market, like the oil market, is volatile and unpredictable. For oil companies and service stations to deny the future uncertainty of their markets would have been folly, says McKenzie, who repeats: ``The major cost of staying in business is not the past purchase price of any item in inventory but the future replacement cost of that item.'' If there has been collusion with the industry or a conspiracy to gouge the public, McKenzie says that those involved have done a mighty poor job of it.

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Children of Eden, Adv 07,0670
DOC.NOTE: For Release Mon AMs, Jan 7 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: An Anglo-American Team Creates ``Children of Eden''
DOC.TEXT: Stephen Schwartz and John Caird have been involved in some of Broadway's biggest hits, but they were adamant about launching their new show, ``Children of Eden,'' in London. ``It has to do with working style,'' Schwartz, 42, said of the $3.86 million-musical, opening Jan. 8 at the Prince Edward Theater. ``It's a much more pleasant and focused working experience,'' the composer-lyricist said of London's commercial West End. ``There's much less of the power and ego games I've experienced in New York, that frenzy of threats and tears and firings.'' The greater quantity of theater in London than on Broadway means there is less hysteria attached to each individual show. Also, the price is right: ``Children of Eden'' on Broadway would cost double its West End budget, Schwartz said. Schwartz has had three substantial New York hits - ``Godspell,'' ``The Magic Show'' and ``Pippin'' - as well as such flops as ``Working'' and, most recently, the 1986 ``Rags.'' ``Children of Eden,'' which uses the book of Genesis to tell a cautionary tale about the world today, is the first major London opening of 1991. It's the first collaboration of Schwartz, a New Yorker who now lives in Connecticut, and Caird, the English co-director of ``Nicholas Nickleby'' and ``Les Miserables.'' The 35-person cast is headed by Ken Page, the American star of ``Cats'' and ``Ain't Misbehavin','' as God; Kevin Colson, a Tony nominee in June for ``Aspects of Love,'' as Noah; and Frances Ruffelle, a Tony-winner for ``Les Miserables,'' as Yonah. Caird and Schwartz have been polishing ``Children of Eden'' for three years following a 1985 workshop of a separate version of it, entitled ``The Family Tree,'' which did not involve Caird. The London staging was first planned for The Royal Shakespeare Company, where ``Les Miserables'' began in 1984. It shifted to the commercial West End when the Company decided to close its two London theaters for the winter in order to save money. Caird said his new project had the initial appeal of ``Les Miserables,'' which has gone on to become the most internationally successful musical ever. ``I fell hopelessly in love with Stephen's songs on first hearing, just like I did with the score of `Les Mis,''' Caird said in an interview. The first act recounts the Creation and the fall of man. The second act, said Caird, ``is an imaginative version of life in the late 20th century where the children of Eden - man and animals - are no longer living in harmony. ``Each is being cannibalized by the other.'' Schwartz said any similarities to his 1971 ``Godspell,'' his most popular show to date, are coincidental: ``You couldn't really make comparisons.'' But he acknowledged ``Children of Eden'' is a risky venture, not least because no surefire names are attached to it. ``We don't have Julia McKenzie's name up there; we don't have Andrew Lloyd Webber's name up there,'' said Schwartz. McKenzie is the acclaimed current star of Stephen Sondheim's ``Into the Woods'' in London. Lloyd Webber has four long-running musicals on the West End. ``I'm very, very exposed in this show,'' he said. While musicals often postpone opening nights to allow their creators to hone the show further, ``Children of Eden,'' unusually, moved its premiere forward from Jan. 16 to Jan. 8. ``Frankly, it was a financial decision,'' explained Schwartz. ``It's difficult to sell the previews without the notices, and until those notices are out, people are not going to buy tickets.'' If the show clicks in London, Schwartz said he would then brave Broadway. ``It's not that I'm allergic to the air in New York,'' he said. ``Commercially, it's still the best thing that can happen to a show.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Ballet on TV, Adv 10,0815
DOC.NOTE: For Release Thurs AMs, Jan 10 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: The Glory of the Ballerina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Ballerinas: Dances by Peter Martins'' will be broadcast over PBS stations on Jan. 11.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Peter Martins tries to capture the individual spirit of each ballerina when creating works about them for the New York City Ballet company's ballerinas. ``You try to capture what each woman is about, what her virtues are and so forth,'' said Martins, who has been ballet master in chief of the New York City Ballet since the death of George Balanchine in 1983. ``You also try and see if you can bring out something else in them.'' Five ballets or excerpts from ballets choreographed by Martins on five ballerinas will be aired by PBS on Jan. 11 at 9 p.m. EST. ``Ballerinas: Dances by Peter Martins'' is part the Great Performances series. ``I would say for the most part this is basically the way I have seen these women,'' says Martins, who retired from dancing to devote full time to running the company. ``They all used to be my partners. ``When you're dancing with them, you're preoccupied with being a part of a picture yourself. You're much less observant about their particular qualities then. When you take a step back and look at them from a creative point of view, something else emerges.'' All five dances in the TV program were created by Martins after he stopped dancing. He doesn't choreograph on paper in an office. He choreographs ``on the dancers,'' physically having them move in a studio. Kyra Nichols and Adam Luders dance ``Beethoven Romance.'' ``Kyra has such strength and such resilience that you can give her the most difficult things and yet they will come across as looking very easy and simple,'' Martins said. ``She keeps challenging you to do more. She can stay longer on pointe, unsupported, than most. There is a lot of strength there, a lot of power.'' Patricia McBride and Ib Andersen dance ``Valse Triste.'' ``It was toward the end of Patti's career and I saw the softness in her, which had always appealed to me,'' Martins said. ``Patti used to be considered a soubrette, a small dancer who moves very quickly. A lot of ballets Mr. B did on her in her youth were like that. ``It was her lyrical qualities that appealed to me. It's as if nature makes her dance. It is like snow and rain and the wind and the sun. It is all natural, nothing forced. It appears that you put a wand over her and she just moves.'' Heather Watts and Jock Soto dance the second movement of the modern ``Ecstatic Orange.'' ``They all challenge me in various ways. Heather's challenge is much about architecture,'' said Martins. ``It becomes creating images. It is about sculpting bodies. ... There is always a new sculpture emerging. ``Also there is an element of the unknown when you work with Heather, an unpredictability. You may try to get one movement out of her and another one will emerge. That's always fascinating; you get a lot of help.'' Merrill Ashley and Adam Luders are joined by former Paul Taylor dancers Kate Johnson and David Parsons in ``Barber Violin Concerto.'' ``Merrill is the epitome of the classical technician,'' Martins said. ``There was a part of Merrill I have always felt was looming underneath the surface, which was the passionate Merrill. I don't think she has had a dance like that done on her. I wanted to bring that to the surface. This is the passionate Merrill, not the technical Merrill we see every day.'' Suzanne Farrell, in her farewell ballet, and Martins, temporarily back from retirement, dance ``Sophisticated Lady.'' ``Suzanne is in many ways more American than any of them. One of the things she has excelled in is her showgirl aspect, as in `Slaughter on Tenth Avenue.' So, I thought, why not make her a little dance that celebrates that part of her, where she can go out on stage and be Rita Hayworth, gloriously beautiful and not having to do very much. Neither of us was prepared to do a major pas de deux on pointe. I am an old retiree. ``It is she and I playing Fred and Ginger. Anybody who loves dance has somewhere in them a deep, deep admiration for Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire. I wanted for us to play that role for a moment.'' The PBS show is co-produced by WNET and Danmarks Radio. Dances were filmed in Denmark.

DOC.HEAD: Give Me the House, the Car, and Half Your Celebrity Status
DOC.TEXT: It's the same old story. Boy meets girl. Boy gets girl. Boy bills girl for grooming of schnauzer. Girl makes tuna fish for boy, again and again. Boy and girl sit atop the high-powered world of publishing. Girl divorces boy. OK, maybe the story of Richard Snyder and Joni Evans is not the same old story. It certainly has had a novel ending; both sides want a judge to declare the other's ``celebrity status'' a marital asset, give it a dollar value and divvy it up just like the family house, furniture and other belongings. Snyder and Evans each claimed to have made the other what he or she is today. And to prove the point, they were willing to fling major mud. The case has more than gossip value. Divorce lawyers are watching it and similar cases to see whether the courts will agree that fame should be appraised and its value apportioned. ``It's an idea whose time hopefully will never come,'' said attorney Raoul Felder, who's fighting to keep Metropolitan Opera diva Frederica von Stade's husband from claiming a piece of her stardom. But Marvin Mitchelson, who represents Roseanne Barr's ex-husband Bill Pentland, hopes to win the first California case based on the principle. ``The attaining of celebrity status during the marriage ... is a definite asset, just as appreciation of a house or an art collection is an asset,'' he argues. ``I think it is slowly being recognized.'' The story of Evans and Snyder, played out in a New York courtroom last spring, is light on hearts and violins and heavy on the bottom line. Snyder, head of Simon & Shuster, hired Evans as director of subsidiary rights in 1974. She'd advanced to associate publisher by 1976 when they began dating. Two years later, they married at City Hall - during their lunch hour. Theirs was an egalitarian marriage, though he always out-earned her. Bank accounts were separate. His assistant billed her monthly for her share of the food, utilities and schnauzer-grooming bills, she testified. In 1979, Snyder created an imprint (a semi-autonomous shop within a larger publishing house) called Linden Press for Evans to run. It was a success. She says the marriage began to break down in 1985, when Snyder promoted her to president of the trade book division and she was working directly under him again. Snyder, who has publicly complained about her workaholism, testified that the marriage ``went south'' two years earlier. They agreed to separate in 1986 and she filed for divorce in February 1987, resigning from Simon & Schuster at the same time to join Random House. Had they agreed to an out-of-court property settlement, the case might have ended there. Instead, the history of their marriage was recounted in public. Evans said Snyder aimed a tennis ball at her during an argument on the tennis court. Snyder said Evans put him ``in a very humiliating and embarrassing and ... emotionally unhappy position'' by turning her back on him at a publishing convention. The last time they had conjugal relations? ``The weekend of July 4, 1986,'' Evans testified, matter-of-factly. Evans said she cooked and cleaned when the maid was off duty, but conceded she made ``tuna fish 75 percent of the time.'' Even then, Snyder said, he opened the can and removed the tuna, ``because that was the dangerous part.'' Evans, 48, who now heads her own imprint at Random House, contended in her pretrial memorandum she acted as Snyder's ``sounding board,'' entertained his corporate bosses (Simon & Schuster is owned by Paramount Communications), participated in business decisions and served as ``a source of emotional stability and as moral anchor.'' That, she said, entitles her to a share of the marital estate, which she estimates at more than $18 million. On the contrary, answered the 57-year-old Snyder. She would be nothing without him, he argued, so he should get a cut of all her future earnings. ``She is the very opposite of the wife who sacrifices her own career or performs unremunerated services for the benefit of her spouse and family,'' he argued in court papers made available to The Associated Press. ``In significant part as a result of his efforts, she is today one of the highest paid and most powerful executives in the publishing industry.'' Manhattan state Supreme Court Justice Elliot Wilk has reserved decision. A decade ago, the Snyder-Evans contretemps would have been an impossibility. Judges simply awarded property to the spouse who held the title - usually the husband - while providing alimony to the untitled spouse. But in 1980, New York's laws were revised to protect the spouse whose contribution was non-monetary. In New York and 41 other states, judges must now make an ``equitable distribution'' of all property acquired during the marriage, regardless of who holds the title. Then, in a landmark 1985 case, New York's top court ruled that a woman who gave up her career to put her husband through medical school, only to be divorced two months after he got his license, must be compensated with a share of the husband's medical license. A New Jersey judge took that concept one step farther, awarding Joe Piscopo's ex-wife $50,000, or half the value placed on his celebrity status. The state's highest court upheld the award in May 1989. Mitchelson hopes similar logic will prevail in his case against Roseanne Barr. He argues that her ex-husband helped launch her career in comedy clubs, was the main parent and homemaker while she was on the road and auditioning, then worked with her to launch her hit ABC show and wrote some of the scripts. ``Here you've got clearly a career that was made and developed during the marriage,'' he said. Barr's current earnings ``are a thousand times more than they were because of what happened during the marriage.'' Alfred Ferrer, attorney for Frederica von Stade's former husband, Peter Elkus, is appealing a ruling declaring the singer's career was not a marital asset. He too describes marriage in terms more numismatic than romantic. ``Marriage is an economic partnership,'' he said. ``If one's career is enhanced during that partnership, each spouse has a right to participate in that value.''

DOC.HEAD: Its Boom Fades but Northwest Still Shines Above National Gloom
DOC.TEXT: He has no job and no money for rent, but carpenter Reuben Soto still believes the Northwest's economy is tops in the nation. Trouble is, he's right. In the late 1980s, the Northwest became the jewel of the U.S. economy, sparkling atop charts of economic growth and livability. The region still outshines the gloomy national economy, but that's not saying much. As Reuben Soto discovered firsthand, the great Northwest boom is fading. He came from Virginia last summer, a 35-year-old bachelor looking for work and a fresh start in life. He'd heard times were good around Seattle, and sure enough, things started out well. Soto landed a carpentry job and rented a small apartment. But then Seattle's hot housing market cooled and construction slowed. Soto was laid off in November, and he's been hunting for work ever since. ``I'm going through some rough times now,'' he said. ``But I know it will get better. This is still a land of opportunity.'' He's not the only optimist in town. Many economists say the Northwest, though slowing down, is likely to escape the worst of a widespread downturn. A newly diversified economy, growing Asian trade, and banner years for aerospace giant Boeing have stabilized the region, once infamous for sliding to the bottom of national recessions. ``We're not going to be immune to what's happening elsewhere,'' said John W. Mitchell, chief economist for U.S. Bancorp in Portland, Ore. ``But you're still talking about the strongest region in the country.'' Indeed, the strong growth of recent years has put the Northwest on solid footing to face economic challenges: -Measured by employment, the region far exceeded average U.S. growth in the year ending October. Employment in Washington, Oregon and Idaho combined grew at twice the national rate. Add Nevada and Utah, the nation's fastest-growing states, and regional employment grew 3.8 percent, nearly triple the 1.3 percent U.S. rate. -All five Northwestern states last year were among the nation's top 10 in growth of residents' personal income. -In Washington, The Boeing Co. nearly doubled its work force between 1983 and 1990. With more than 100,000 workers, the airplane-maker now accounts directly or indirectly for one of every six Washington jobs. -In Idaho, Oregon and Utah, diversification featuring high-tech electronics and computer industries has evened out the ups and downs of formerly resource-based economies. ``Our growth has been broad-based,'' said Michael Ferguson, Idaho's chief economist. ``We've got the good fortune of having the right product mix.'' So much for the good news. If 1990 culminated several years of heady Northwestern growth, it also was when the region started pulling in its horns. In Washington, Boeing finished its hiring binge. The company is still a strong stabilizing force - it has orders for jets it won't deliver until after the turn of the century - but the impetus behind Seattle's population boom is gone. The housing market has responded accordingly. In 1989, Seattle had the nation's fastest-rising home prices. By the end of 1990, home prices were stagnant, and houses sat on the market for months. New construction fell off sharply. State economists declared in November that Washington had entered a mild recession. They predicted the state would lose 10,000 jobs by June, a .5 percent drop in total employment, and then resume growing slowly. Idaho's rapid growth will slow considerably during the next three years, Ferguson said. Perhaps the most worrisome Northwestern state is Oregon, where more than 30 percent of factory jobs depend on the beleaguered timber industry. A nationwide housing slump has reduced demand for timber, and supply is shrinking due to logging restrictions aimed at protecting the spotted owl, a threatened species. State economists predict 5,400 timber jobs will disappear in 1991. ``The forest industry is Oregon's Achilles heel,'' said Michael J. Parks, editor of Marple's Business Newsletter in Seattle. Economists say such negative factors are cooling the Northwest's hot growth down to a lukewarm prosperity. ``Our economy will behave and grow more like the rest of the country,'' predicted Douglas Pedersen, economist at Security Pacific Bank Washington. ``We'll be growing faster than the nationa average, but the margin will be a little thinner.'' That's still attractive to regions mired in recession. But the Northwest formula may be hard to match elsewhere. Some economists believe this region's fortune hinges on ``industries of the future'' such as software and biotechnology, which benefit more from worker satisfaction than closeness to markets or raw materials. Such ``footloose'' industries are lured by the Northwest's fabled natural beauty and high quality of life, not by tax breaks or other government incentives, said U.S. Bancorp's Mitchell. ``Oregon, Washington and Idaho have three totally different tax structures, but they're all growing,'' Mitchell said. ``It's not policy. We're just lucky.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - David Foster is the AP's Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Putting the Priority on Teaching at Selected Universities
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth Jackson, Frederick Coolidge, Laura Goodwin and Frank S. Pinet belong to an endangered species - college professors designated as superb teachers. Each works at a huge, multi-campus research university where hundreds of millions of dollars flow into research and where faculty prestige comes with out-of-the-classroom projects. Yet each is prized for outstanding classroom skills. ``Great research and great teaching fuel each other,'' said Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University. ``Yet we must acknowledge that great universities like ours are at risk of tilting in favor of research at the expense of teaching. And we must not let that happen. ``In America today, the great teacher is an endangered species.'' Jackson, who has taught at Columbia for 22 years, is one of 10 educators recently appointed to professorships created with gifts of more than $12 million. Coolidge, Goodwin and about 25 other professors working at one of the four University of Colorado campuses are being encouraged to teach and suggest how less-experienced professors can become better in the classroom. The professors are given $6,000 a year for two years and the lifetime title of ``President's Teaching Scholars.'' ``We are more encouraged than ever now to take up our mandate to educate, even though our faculty members do remarkable research,'' aid Mary Ann Shea, the university's program coordinator, who works from the Boulder, Colo., campus. ``Our mandate is to educate students, our mandate is to concentrate more on how students learn and how we can best teach them.'' Pinet is a distinguished teaching professor of business at the University of Kansas, which first established endowed Distinguished Teaching Professorships in 1957. The Lawrence, Kan., school now has more than 125 distinguished professorships, 22 of which explicitly recognize outstanding teaching. At the University of Missouri, President C. Peter Magrath recently created an annual Presidential Award for Outstanding Teaching. The award includes a $15,000 stipend available to tenured faculty members with a record of outstanding teaching for at least 10 years. Lynne Cheney, who chairs the National Endowment for the Humanities, has said emphasis on outside studies is greatest at ``research universities'' where 64 percent of the faculty report spending five hours or less per week on formal classroom instruction and 86 percent report spending six or more hours per week on research. The typical reward for good teaching ``is a couple of thousand dollars and a pat on the back,'' said Peter Smith, a spokesman for the Association of American Universities. ``The Colorado program is clearly more than that.'' Now in its second year, Colorado University - with its four-campus system and 43,000 student population - has an elaborate selection process by which faculty, deans and students participate in selecting tenured professors from the 3,000-member faculty. For 1990-91, 12 scholars were appointed from the campuses. In 1989-90, 15 were appointed. ``The significance of the program is that master teachers work with faculty colleagues, as opposed to working with graduate students, who we know we're going to send off from our institutions. In this case, we're trying to work with faculty members who have never had any experience in talking about teaching with a faculty colleague and learning new ways to teach,'' Shea said. Part of the university's psychology department on its Colorado Springs campus, Coolidge is clearly excited about designing a course for professors and lecturers, entitled ``How to Teach More Effectively.'' His goal, he said, is to help show how humor, stories and parables strategically placed in lectures can create a pleasant learning environment. Rex Burns of the university's Denver campus, said those who will fare best in the classroom are the most empathetic. ``You have to have an ability to put yourself in place of the students looking at the teacher,'' he said, ``and perhaps even listening to yourself in the classroom, as others see you.''

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City Barbecue: Not Just Blowing Smoke
DOC.TEXT: You can argue about whether Memphis or North Carolina or Texas has better barbecue. You can argue about the proper sauce, the proper meat, the proper fuel. But there is no argument about one simple fact: Kansas City takes its barbecue very seriously. Kansas City is home to the world's most famous barbecue restaurant, Arthur Bryant's. Jack Nicholson is known to interrupt coast-to-coast trips to eat there. Writer (and native Kansas Citian) Calvin Trillin, ribs partly in cheek, once called Bryant's the best restaurant anywhere. And some swear the Gates & Sons chain is even better. The sweet aroma of barbecue overwhelms all bus and truck fumes at one busy midtown intersection right next to Ollie Gates' Rib Tech, where future cookers learn the science. There are many other mom-and-pop joints that lay claim to the title of best barbecue around. But the real barbecue, the REAL THING, is cooked by the legion of people who haul homemade smokers to competitions around the region. ``It's a very tight community,'' said Gary Wells, who doubles as an insurance agent when he's not tending to matters of the meat as president of the Kansas City Barbecue Society, which has more than 500 members. ``They are serious about having fun. They are serious about cooking too. They like things that are a little off-center. It's every kind of person. We've got doctors, lawyers, forklift drivers,'' he said. And some are even in unexpected places. KCBS members Jim and Kathleen Tabb recently judged a barbecue contest in Ireland (the food was good) and then moved on to another competition in Estonia, where they had an official visit with the mayor of Tallin in the 14th century Town Hall. There they were treated to classical music and a performance by a soprano who Tabb said sounded as sweet as Loretta Lynn. ``A first, I'd say, for barbecue to blend itself with culture, sophistication and classical music,'' Tabb reported in the ``Bullsheet,'' the official publication of the KCBS. ``Totally fun and bizarre - sort of like taking a Weber or a 55-gallon drum to the opera. ``Later, while toasting champagne around this centuries old long table, an Estonian official whispered in my ear that the last time Gorby was in Tallin, he sat exactly where I was standing. A shiver ran down my spine.'' Estonia is probably the farthest reach of the KCBS, although the smoke from cookers goes up in Canada, Vienna, Bermuda and 40 U.S. states. Back home, Wells said when you think of the center of American barbecue, you can envision a triangle from Kansas City to Memphis to Texas. To KCBS purists, Southern style barbecue doesn't count because those folks only cook pork; real barbecuers cook beef, poultry and lamb as well as pork. ``In Carolina, the sauce is clearer,'' Wells said. ``They use vinegar and peppers. It's a mustard-based sauce. As you go west, it gets redder and sweeter.'' Oh, that's another thing. Never ask a cooker for the recipe to his sauce. You'll be met with stony silence - if you're lucky. ``Barbecuing is the process of cooking meat slowly for a long period of time,'' Wells said. ``You control your heat. Disseminate enough smoke. Add moisture. But really, if it works for you, do it.'' A barbecue competition is judged two ways. Under Kansas City rules, a group of judges are given blind samples. In Memphis, where there is a prestigious competition in June, judges go from barbecuer to barbecuer to taste samples. A typical competition goes like this: The cooking teams arrive Friday and set up shop. At midnight, it's time to put the brisket on. Then comes a night and day of cooking. Some teams split up the duties by having one person cook the chicken while others do the brisket and ribs. Others have a chief cook and people to tend the fire and run errands. Sometimes, significant prize money is involved - as much as $10,000. But mainly, the aim is to have fun. ``You haven't lived until you've been on a field trip with 80 barbecuers,'' said Carolyn Wells, Gary's wife and a past editor of the ``Bullsheet.'' ``It lets us be kids again. There's the camaraderie.'' Each year, dozens of Kansas City area members go out into the cold to barbecue turkeys for the local Harvesters group. This past Thanksgiving, they donated clothing and just under a ton of food. ``That is the spirit of barbecue,'' Wells said. ``They are just plain good folks. They've got a heart of gold. They would do backflips for you. They are generous in spirit.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weds PMs, Jan 9
For Release Weds AMs, Jan. 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With AM-'Cue It Up
So Many Sauces, So Little Time
DOC.TEXT:
There are many barbecue sauces under the sun; each has its partisans. Jeanne Voltz, author of ``Barbecued Ribs, Smoked Butts and Other Great Feeds'' (Knopf, $19.95), says her Texas barbecue sauce is close to the Kansas City variety. The sauce - offered here with her permission - is not used for cooking, but is served at the table after dry-rubbed meat is barbecued.
\ cup butter 1 small onion, chopped 1 clove garlic, minced 3 ribs celery, finely chopped 1 cup catsup { cup cider vinegar 1{ cups water \ cup Worcestershire sauce 3 bay leaves 1 teaspoon freshly ground pepper 1 tablespoon chili powder, or to taste
In a large stainless-steel or enamelware saucepan melt the butter. Add onion, garlic and celery. Cook and stir until onion is tender. Stir in catsup, vinegar, water and Worcestershire sauce. Add bay leaves and pepper. Simmer uncovered 15 to 20 minutes, stirring now and then to prevent sticking. Stir a small amount of sauce into chili powder and blend well. Stir chili mixture into sauce. Remove bay leaves. Let stand at room temperature one hour or longer before serving. Leftover sauce can be refrigerated for several days. Makes two cups.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weds AMs, Jan 9

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Their former leaders are scattered, they are bickering among themselves, and dramatic political upheavals around the globe have overshadowed their cause. China's pro-democracy activists are struggling to keep alive the spirit of Tiananmen Square.

China's pro-democracy movement, which seized the hearts and attention of the world a year and a half ago at Tiananmen Square, is faltering. Internal squabbling, China's re-establishment in the world community and the international media's preoccupation with Eastern Europe and the Persian Gulf have nudged democracy activists out of the headlines. Public interest has waned. The most prominent student leaders of the massive protests that engulfed Beijing now lead low-profile lives, far from the spotlight that made them media stars and one of them a Nobel Peace Prize nominee. Wu'er Kaixi, the eloquent but mercurial firebrand, has been pumping gas near San Francisco. Chai Ling, whose impassioned leadership in the protests' final days won her the Nobel nomination, has left her husband, fellow student dissident leader Feng Congde in Paris, and is quietly attending Princeton University. Without them, the movement has lost much of its cachet. Wan Runnan, newly elected president of the Federation for a Democratic China, concedes that public support has diminished. ``But there are bound to be periods of high and low interest,'' he said in an interview. ``No one can ignore a country that represents one-fourth of the world's population.'' The federation was born amid much fanfare in Paris in September 1989, two months after the bicentennial of the French Revolution. The annual parade down the Champs Elysees was led by some 200 Chinese students on bicycles, momentarily giving Paris' most famous street the look of a Beijing boulevard. Chinese soldiers backed by tanks charged down those Beijing boulevards in the early morning of June 4, 1989, shooting and killing at least several hundred unarmed protesters. The searing images of the bloodshed were etched into the minds of millions who watched the tragey unfold on television. Much of the protests' leadership fled overseas, as had - decades before them - the influential political thinkers Kang Youwei and his disciple Liang Qichao, and Sun Yat-sen, the founder of modern China. All were active in Japan, preaching democracy for China around the turn of the century. Exile abroad was also the lot of former Premier Zhou Enlai, revered by the students at Tiananmen, and recently retired senior leader Deng Xiaoping, despised by the democracy supporters as the mastermind of the crackdown. They began their revolutionary careers in France, where they joined the Communist Party in the early 1920s. The federation has kept its dream of Chinese democracy alive through seminars, demonstrations and criticism of China's authoritarian regime. Its founders include dissidents forced to leave China, such as physicist Fang Lizhi, who hid in Beijing's U.S. Embassy for more than a year before being allowed to leave, and outspoken Marxist theoretician Su Shaozhi, who for years advocated thorough reform of the Communist Party. It has maintained contacts in China and closely monitors what it claims are continuing human rights abuses under China's communist government. Recently it spearheaded denunciations of the trials of top dissidents in China. The federation said the trials violated China's constitution by holding the accused for 13 months without trial and denying them defense lawyers of their choice. Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, who published a dissident magazine, are accused of sedition, which carries a maximum penalty of death. Wang Dan, the student seen as the behind-the-scenes brain of the popular movement, stands accused of ``counterrevolutionary incitement.'' But the dissident movement in exile has lost the momentum that used to attract large crowds - and donations - at its rallies and fund-raisers. ``The formation of the FDC (the federation) came at a high tide for the democracy movement,'' says Andrew Nathan, a professor at Columbia University in New York and author of two books on Chinese democracy. ``There were signs that the Chinese regime would collapse, and the cream of the crop were organizing overseas. There were a lot of expectations, but things didn't happen.'' The federation is regrouping and seeking fresh directions under Wan, elected at the group's annual convention in San Francisco. He directs chapters in 20 countries - formed most recently in Brazil and Greece - from a three-room office in a quiet section of northwest Paris. He insists the group has been effective. ``Without an opposition faction, there will never be democracy,'' he says. ``If the United States didn't have two parties, if Poland hadn't had Solidarity, you couldn't have democracy. There cannot be a rule that the Chinese Communist Party must be in power.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
PARIS: in power.''
DOC.TEXT: His top priority is to persuade foreign governments to pressure Beijing toward greater political liberalization and respect for human rights. He is disappointed that the West has dropped most of the economic and political sanctions imposed against China so soon after the crackdown. ``We understand part of their reasons,'' he says. ``But as for the conditions that brought on the sanctions in the first place - the suppression, the arrests - there has been absolutely no change.'' Wan hopes to strengthen the movement through increased cooperation with overseas Chinese and other opposition organizations. But he faces criticism from rival dissident groups. ``Wan Runnan is short-sighted and an opportunist. He thinks that just by eliminating the Communists' one-party rule you'll have democracy in China,'' says Wang Xiaoyu, a former reporter for the government news agency Xinhua who is now chief editor for the dissident House of Chinese Democracy, also in Paris. ``The blood from June 4 hasn't yet dried, and he's setting up a small clique of intellectuals who consider themselves the government in exile. They make a lot of statements but don't do anything constructive.'' Wan, 46, believes he will see democracy in China within his lifetime. But Wang says that is simplistic, and that ``it could take 200, even 500 years.'' Disagreements arise within the federation itself. On the eve of the San Francisco convention, a faction within the federation criticized Wan. Their candidate to oppose Wan was elected federation vice president. Wan is a former software engineer with the Chinese Academy of Science's Computer Center who in 1984 was named head of the Stone Corp., China's first private high-technology firm. A strong supporter of the students at Tiananmen, he defected while visiting Hong Kong four days after the crackdown when he learned an arrest warrant had been issued for him. He took over as federation president from Yan Jiaqi, who as a former adviser to ousted Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang had respectable credentials but was more theorist than organizer. Among Wan's tasks is addressing problems of the federation's first year. ``The FDC hasn't been particularly effective in lobbying,'' Nathan says. ``Reaching out to the non-Chinese community is something they've proved they're not very good at doing.'' There was also the fiasco of the Goddess of Democracy, a ship which was to broadcast pro-democracy messages into China but is now a tourist attraction drawing mild interest in Taiwan. The mission floundered when neither Japan nor Taiwan would allow the activists to load a radio transmitter on board. The federation's finances reportedly have suffered, more from bad administration than malfeasance. Of the $1 million the federation received in its first year, it spent only 3 percent on expanding democracy activities and 40 percent on travel or consultations, according to the Chinese-language European Daily News. When Chai Ling visited the United States this past summer she raised $40,000, but spent virtually all of it paying for the trip, according to a Chinese paper in the United States. Wan also has to make up for the departure from France of Chai Ling and Wu'er Kaixi, whose youthful zeal made them strong media draws. Yet Wu'er was a dubious asset to the organization because of reports of his flamboyant lifestyle. ``Wu'er Kaixi ruined the FDC's reputation'' by spending too much money on food and taxis, Wang says. Wu'er now works at a gas station near San Francisco and is applying to attend the University of California at Berkeley. ``Things haven't been too tough for me over the past year,'' he said during a recent trip to Taiwan. ``I thought it wouldn't hurt to do something humble for awhile.'' About Wu'er and Chai, Wan says, ``You can't base a political movement on `stars.' Their departure is a maturing process, both for them and for us.'' Wan himself was exploring the possibility of returning to Beijing, according to a U.S. diplomat. He left behind a wife and college-student son. They were not arrested but cannot leave the capital. Wan says only that he considered returning to China to continue working for democratic reforms from within, but abandoned the idea. Yet with limited ability in French and English, he admits thinking often of home. ``People of that age, their lives revolve around China,'' Nathan says. ``They've spent a lifetime achieving a stature that they will never gain overseas. They now have an agonizing choice over what to do with their lives. ``Sitting around drumming their fingers, living off of fellowships - how long can this go on?''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Some Hollywood stars have become almost as well-known for the causes they support as for the parts they play. Jane Fonda, Charlton Heston and Edward Asner come immediately to mind. While those three may represent an older generation, show business today is not without its activists concerned about such issues as the environment, energy, abortion and the homeless.

Academy Awards night typically finds Hollywood in a self-indulgent mood, the stars lavishing themselves with fine clothes, finer praise and the finest food. Some, but not all. As the guests preened for last year's Oscar presentations, actors Ron Silver, Susan Sarandon, Alec Baldwin, Christopher Reeve and Jennifer Beales had more serious business at hand. They are members of an advocacy group called The Creative Coalition and spent all day with New York Gov. Mario Cuomo and state legislators, pushing environmental legislation and sounding the alarm of global warming. In addition to The Creative Coalition, a growing group of entertainment figures are cashiering their fame for good works, performing at benefits and actually embracing causes as if their careers - and sometimes their lives - depended on it. While the stereotype of the ineffectual celebrity do-gooder persists, these performers, writers, directors and executives endeavor to be both dedicated and knowledgeable. ``This is five days a week of two people working regular hours,'' says Robert Foxworth, the former ``Falcon Crest'' star who along with assistant Bobbi Murray produces a weekly issue-oriented radio show with his own money. Ed Begley Jr. (``St. Elsewhere'') is one of Hollywood's most dedicated activists, frequently sacrificing his time (and creature comforts) for energy conservation. Living in a home illuminated by low-energy, 15-watt light bulbs and commuting to work by bus, bicycle or electric car, Begley's lifestyle strives to be as environmentally conscientious as possible. In November, Begley was named chairman of an advisory committee to the Southern California Rapid Transit District, which runs the city's bus system and is building a massive subway network. ``Mr. Begley's commitment to public transit, as well as his involvement in environmental issues, will provide strong leadership,'' says RTD board President Nick Patsaouras. Most actors and actresses say when it comes to choosing between their careers and their causes, employment comes first. Without work, these activists have neither a platform nor money to pledge. What separates real activists from fair-weather warriors is the level of sacrifice. Foxworth's ``American Dialogues'' program, for example, is supported entirely by Foxworth's earnings and ``Falcon Crest'' savings. The 5-year-old show, heard in 75 cities, has Foxworth interviewing experts in a spectrum of social issues, from the war on drugs to campaign finances to Central American politics. ``It's always been a frustration to some extent that the work in film, television and theater hasn't been able to be more focused on issues,'' says Foxworth, sitting in a recording studio built over his garage. ``We have our podium, our pedestal is to some extent our career. It provides some access to people.'' Silver, who was one of the founders of the non-partisan Creative Coalition, says entertainers have a duty to charity. ``I think there's almost an obligation,'' says Silver, the co-star of the film ``Reversal of Fortune.'' ``Many of us are very well compensated for work which a lot of people would love to do. And we also have a lot of leisure time in between jobs. ``The more visible members of our group use their access and utilize their attention-getting abilities to bring a lot of issues to the public's attention,'' Silver says. The 250 show business professionals in the New York-based group lobby local and national politicians about issues such as the environment, freedom of expression, abortion rights and the homeless. ``They say that Hollywood is sex without substance, and Washington politics is substance without sex, so maybe the marriage of the two is mutually intriguing,'' Silver says. There are more than a few celebrities who have become almost as well-known for the causes they support as for the parts they play. Jane Fonda's acting career has been tinged by her activism during the Vietnam War when she appeared on Radio Hanoi and begged American soldiers to stop bombing. To some she is as much ``Hanoi Jane'' as she is the star of 1981's ``On Golden Pond'' or 1989's ``Stanley and Iris.'' During filming of the latter in 1988, a Waterbury, Conn., veterans helped circulate bumper stickers that read, ``I'm Not Fond'a Hanoi Jane.'' ``I'm a good scapegoat,'' Miss Fonda said in an interview not long ago. ``I can be painted into an image which causes a lot of hostility. I may not be that person but that's irrelevant.'' Charlton Heston (``Ben Hur'') donates time to the National Rifle Association and lobbies against government funding for explicit art. Mike Farrell (``M-A-S-H'') is recognized as one of the nation' strongest voices for civil rights. Singer Jackson Browne, whose concerts are loaded with plugs for causes, said that some fans have taken to yelling, ``Just sing!''

LOS ANGELES: ``Just sing!''
DOC.TEXT: Ed Asner is so strongly associated with left-of-center issues that he believes his politics contributed to the 1982 cancellation of his ``Lou Grant'' series on CBS. Mary Tyler Moore, herself a diabetic, is the international spokesperson for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. In the non-paying position, Miss Moore makes speeches, appears in public service announcements and travels to support the foundation. Candice Bergen has adopted several causes. An animal-rights activist, she does not wear furs. And she dedicates her time to the Starlight Foundation, which grants wishes to children dying from cancer. She and her husband, director Louis Malle, hosted a benefit screening of Malle's film ``Au Revoir Les Enfants'' for the Starlight Foundation. Liza Minnelli is on the board of the Institute for the Achievement of Human Potential, an organization that works with mentally handicapped children and their families. Miss Minnelli performs regularly at benefit concerts for the institute. Some labor for causes linked to their on-screen characters. Richard Dysart, who stars as senior partner Leland McKenzie on ``L.A. Law,'' has made two public service announcements advocating equal protection. Roy Scheider (``Jaws''), who appeared in Home Box Office's death-row drama ``Somebody Has to Shoot the Picture,'' hosted an anti-death penalty screening of the film. ``It's a barbaric custom and it doesn't work,'' Scheider says. The compact disc for rock star Phil Collins' new album ``Serious Hits...Live'' is packaged in recycled cardboard. It bears the message, ``Car pool when possible. Tune up your car regularly and keep your tires inflated to the recommended pressure. These steps will conserve energy and reduce air pollution.'' Not bad. But musicians Peter Gabriel and Raffi are insisting that their CDs be issued in no cardboard packaging at all, saving even more trees. Rock star Chrissie Hynde of the Pretenders is an activist for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. She spent one recent morning disrupting hunters as they stalked game in a Maryland corn field. The animal-rights group, whose other celebrity members include k.d. Lang, River Phoenix and Jane Wiedlin, opposes hunting, the fur industry and using animals for laboratory testing. Even sincere Hollywood activists dance in dangerous territory. The preposterous TV advertising line, ``I'm not a doctor, but I play one on television,'' still points up the basic ambiguity of celebrity endorsements: Just because somebody's on camera, why should we think they know anything? When Miss Sarandon (``White Palace'') made a campaign appearance for New Jersey Gov. James Florio, a heckler shouted, ``Go back to Hollywood!'' In one recent debacle, Angela Lansbury of CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote'' was induced to appear in commercials opposing a pair of California initiatives that would limit elective office terms. Miss Lansbury's commercials, which failed a state requirement to identify their sponsors, were later proved inaccurate. The actress' son (and agent) conceded that his mother was misinformed. ``She doesn't really read newspapers,'' said son David Shaw. Foxworth, on the other hand, reads - newspapers included. Despite the heckling of Miss Sarandon, Silver says his coalition tries to protect its members from ridicule. ``What we insist upon in The Creative Coalition - and I think it makes us a little different from a couple of other groups - is that we're very concerned about informing ourselves and articulating the issues so that when we go out, we really know what we're talking about,'' Silver says. Comic Relief is an annual comedy concert held in Los Angeles to raise money for the homeless. Yet principal participants Robin Williams, Billy Crystal and Whoopi Goldberg are more than hosts for the show, says Comic Relief founder and President Bob Zmuda. ``They've taken on Comic Relief as their main charity,'' Zmuda says. ``They write the show, they promote the show and they spend a lot of time visiting homeless shelters.'' A number of serious activists say there will always be some people who join a cause not to bring peace to El Salvador or fight poverty in the inner city, but to meet people and get jobs. ``A lot of people pretend to be involved when they're not,'' says actress Alexandra Paul (``Dragnet,'' ``American Flyer''), a co-founder of the service organization Young Artists United. Most of YAU's 400 members are devoted, she says, but there may be up-and-coming entertainers who believe their careers will take off if they increase their volunteer work. ``But if that really worked, many of my friends in YAU would be superstars by now, including myself,'' Miss Paul says. Daniel Sladek, who in addition to his frantic job as a television production executive, spends more than 10 hours a week running YAU, which he co-founded with Miss Paul. YAU's members - including Sarah Jessica Parker (``Equal Justice'') and Robert Downey Jr. (``1969'') - educate themselves about topical subjects so that they can infuse their future work with more sensitivity. In addition to occasionally painting shelters for runaway kids or serving meals on Skid Row, YAU members speak candidly to students and young people about drug abuse, sexuality and suicide. Miss Paul talks about her own eating disorders. ``We only talk from our own personal experience,'' she says. ``When I talk about throwing up, they forget that I was in a film with Tom Hanks or Jeff Bridges.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - For more than three decades before it closed, the Cotter Corp. mill in Colorado processed uranium for nuclear power plants. It has been cited nearly 100 times by both state and federal officials for allegedly polluting the mill site and the surrounding area. Now residents of one neighborhood near the mill have gone to court with a $550 million lawsuit.

Sitting in the calico-covered swing on their back porch, watching their horse trot around her pen near the red barn, Nard and Sara Claar seem to be living the American dream. Fruit trees and flowers cover their acre of land, and not far away are the Rocky Mountains' cold streams and deep forests. Sara, 38, grew up here in the Lincoln Park subdivision on the edge of Canon City, a city of 13,000 in southern Colorado. She and Nard, 40, never gave much thought to the Cotter Corp. uranium mill less than two miles from their home. Cotter was considered a solid citizen. Next to the state prison system and its half-dozen facilities, the mill was Canon City's largest employer. In its heyday, the mill, owned by Chicago-based Commonwealth Edison, employed 250 people and processed 1,200 tons of rock a day. That was before Sarah became ill and 13 people on their block were diagnosed as having cancer or had died of it. Now the Claars and many of the nearly 400 people who live in Lincoln Park think their neighborhood has been contaminated by Cotter's uranium processing. ``We just thought this was a natural occurrence. Everybody knew somebody who died of cancer,'' says Sara, who only recently became able to work around her home after being bedridden 18 months with immune deficiency problems. Four members of her family have cancer. But now the Claars and their neighbors believe Cotter - whose mill here is listed as a Superfund cleanup site by the Environmental Protection Agency - is the culprit. They note that in its 32 years the Cotter mill has been cited nearly 100 times by both state and federal officials for allegedly polluting the mill site and surrounding areas. The uranium mill has been closed since 1987 because its product - uranium concentrate called ``yellowcake'' for nuclear power plants - is no longer in demand. No date has been set for operations to resume. The mill crushed, ground and leached uranium with acid to convert it to yellowcake, dumping the leftovers into piles next to the mill or in ponds used to control dust. Cotter operated one mill at the site from 1958 to 1979, then opened a newer, bigger one nearby because of growing demand for their product. The mill site also wound up as the repository of 250 kilograms of radioactive leftovers from the first atomic bomb, called the ``St. Louis Airport Cakes'' because that's where the tailings were stored initially. Cotter purchased the cakes in 1968 and shipped the radioactive residue - which contained the rare cancer-causing radioactive isotope thorium-230 - to Canon City in open railroad cars. Cotter processed nearly two-thirds of the cakes to extract their uranium, copper, cobalt and nickel. The leftovers were dumped into a lined holding pond at the mill. A 1986 state report said there were holes in the pond lining that allowed contaminated water to leach into the ground water. Cotter's image as a model corporate citizen began to erode when traces of radioactive uranium began showing up in well water in Lincoln Park. Apparently water contaminated with the uranium had seeped into the ground water beneath the mill and then had migrated to Lincoln Park. Airborne uranium dust added to the problem. About the time Cotter was eyeing a bigger operation to take advantage of rising uranium prices, regulators were starting to take a closer look at Cotter's pollution problems. The Colorado Bureau of Investigation cited Cotter in 1980 for repeatedly overexposing its workers to uranium dust and for falsifying occupational health data in reports to the state health department. The same year, the health department accused Cotter of 23 violations of its state radioactive materials license. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission in January 1981 recommended that several Lincoln Park residents stop using well water for irrigation and their livestock because of possible contamination from the Cotter mill. In March 1986, a study commissioned by the state and done by GeoTrans-Rocky Mountain Consultants Inc. found that mining and milling activities at Cotter had seriously contaminated the surrounding area. In August 1988, the state sent a letter to Fremont County officials saying Lincoln Park residents face a potential health risk because of contamination from the Cotter mill.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
CANON CITY, Colo.: Cotter mill.
DOC.TEXT: Cotter today is cleaning up the mill site as part of an $11 million environmental damage settlement reached in 1988 with the state of Colorado. Phil Stoffey, the on-site cleanup coordinator for the state health department's Radiation Control Division, estimates it will take Cotter 20 years to clean up the site under the remedial action plan. The company also faces a major lawsuit filed by Lincoln Park residents. In August 1989, their anger over what they believe is a high cancer rate and over Cotter's pollution problems spilled over into a $550 million lawsuit filed in federal court in Denver. The lawsuit claims uranium waste from the mill polluted the ground water and was carried on the wind, causing damage to residents' health and property. Nard Claar thinks Cotter was given too much leeway in how much uranium waste it could discharge into the air - 30 tons per year. ``What happens to that? It blows over my house and my neighbor's house,'' he says. ``To my knowledge, the Cotter Corp. didn't use us as guinea pigs. But with 30 tons of uranium being allowed, there was a radioactive cloud over this valley.'' The state cancer register does not show an above-average incidence of the disease among Fremont County residents, and the state does not keep data on individual cities or neighborhoods. State health officials say it is difficult to assess the cancer risk from exposure to Cotter's uranium mill wastes. ``It's long-range and low-level,'' says Ken Weaver of the Radiation Control Division. ``We're not talking about the kind of radioactivity ... where spending a few hours or days in front of the uranium pile will cause cancer. It's the long-range, long-term effects on health.'' A 1981 federal study found evidence of kidney damage in 29 men who worked at Cotter. And a 1987 attorney general's report said Lincoln Park residents are ``receptors at risk'' if they drink contaminated water, eat food irrigated with contaminated water or grown in contaminated soil, or inhale dust or radon from mill sources. The state in 1988 issued a warning that said Lincoln Park residents face a potential health risk by drinking water contaminated by the mill. Many Lincoln Park residents got their water from wells whose water later was found to be contaminated with uranium and molybdenum, a byproduct of uranium processing. While Lincoln Park residents press their concerns in court, opinion is more divided among other Canon City residents. ``Everybody living in Fremont County is not cowering and concerned that they will get cancer,'' says Pat Sherwood, executive director of the Canon City Chamber of Commerce. She says the media have implied that the entire community is concerned about becoming ill, ``and it's just not true.'' Jack Rothfleisch, the Cotter mill manager who is supervising the site cleanup, does not think the cancer rate is any higher in Lincoln Park than anyplace else. ``I think those people would have cancer if they were in the middle of Nebraska, too,'' he says. ``As far as I'm concerned, I don't think anybody has been harmed in any way by the exposure to what we've done out here.'' Cotter officials would not discuss the lawsuit, but they were willing to speak about the company's special relationship with Canon City. ``The relationship of the Cotter Corp. with the community has been a close, enduring one in which the company and the community have shared in some good times and some bad times,'' says Joe McCluskey, Cotter vice president and general manager of the company's Lakewood office. ``The company and its employees have always appreciated the support of the community, and, likewise, the community has enjoyed the support of the Cotter Corp. over many years.'' Meanwhile, Sara Claar is seeking treatment in Denver for her undiagnosed illness. Nard and Sara say one of their greatest frustrations is not knowing what they face. ``I cannot say that Cotter made me sick,'' Mrs. Claar says. ``But I'd like to know what did. We've never been able to get a definite answer. Now, at least they're testing.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - There is a fascination for some, usually the doers of crossword puzzles and fans of Trivial Pursuit, in trifling information. Here is a book of facts great and small, distilled from millions of questions asked of the New York Public Library by people who can't take ``don't know'' for an answer.

In 1857, Elisha G. Otis invented the passenger elevator. Fifteen years after that William LeBaron Jenny designed the first skyscraper, a 10-story structure. Naturally, someone had to invent the elevator before someone could build a skyscraper, but the same year that gave us the skyscraper gave us the commercial electric fan. Cool. If these seemingly distended historical tidbits attract you, then leaf through the New York Public Library's Desk Reference, a book full of surprises. It is based on the more than 5 million questions the library and its 82 branches answer each year. Vartan Gregorian, former president and chief executive officer of the library, writes in his preface, ``...unlike annuals and almanacs that need revising and updating each year, the Desk Reference (Stonesong Press, $34.95) holds a considerable amount of true reference information, unchanging basic facts and background. ``We also hope that our book will be easy to read and fun to browse through.'' It is. For instance, if you know that Thomas Alva Edison invented the phonograph in 1878, you will be pleased to know that L.O. Colvin invented the milking machine the same year, and James J. Ritty invented the cash register the year after that. These were heady times, a veritable cascade of brainstorms. But read further. Every year was like that. For instance, last year was the 110th birthday of the hearing aid, and the 120th for linoleum and the snap button. It was also the 100th anniversary of motion pictures and the electric subway. It was the 90th anniversary of the paper clip. This year is the 100th birthday of the flashlight (by England's Bristol Electric Lamp Co.), the aluminum boat (by Switzerland's Escher Wyss & Co.) and the zipper (by Whitcombe L. Judson). So much for the snap button. The Desk Reference has less esoteric fare. It tells you how to write your congressman, how to call toll-free for rental cars and hotels. There are 15 pages of visa requirements to travel anywhere from Afghanistan to Zimbabwe. There is an illustrated section on the human anatomy and how to play board games from backgammon to Scrabble or cards from blackjack to solitaire. There is simply no way to list all of the tidy bits of information from dietary tables to musical terms and symbols, from extinct animals to semaphore, from etiquette to legal forms, from animal first aid to a directory of poison control centers. More than an almanac or a book of world records, it is a settler of arguments. Take religion. The book says there are 648 million Hindus, 18 million Jews, 840 million Muslims, 158 million Orthodox Catholics, 307 million Buddhists, and 5.6 million followers of Confucius. In the United States, there are 31 million Baptists, 2.7 million Episcopalians, 13.5 million Methodists, 2.8 million Mormons, 8 million Lutherans, 700,000 Jehovah's Witnesses. But worldwide there are 900 million Roman Catholics, the largest Christian Church in the world. It takes 6{ pages to list all the popes. It takes only a line to inform you that Mary Phelps Jacob invented the brassiere in 1914. One thing that strikes the reader is how long ago some of the inventions sprang from the human mind. Another is, what in the world did mankind do before they came along? A third is that, with so many minds at work, progress is inevitable. We were blessed with the screwdriver and wrench about 1550 by unknown gunsmiths. We got eyeglasses from Alessandro de Spina in 1285 and lip reading from Alexander Melville Bell in 1866 and the telephone from Alexander Graham Bell in 1876 and the hearing aid from R.G. Rhodes four years later. In 1855, we got the stopwatch from Edward Daniel Johnson, 345 years after Peter Henlein gave us the pocket watch. In 1862, we got the machine gun from Richard Jordan Gatling and a year later TNT from J. Wilbrand. In 1867, Alfred Nobel gave us dynamite a dozen years after we got the safety match to light it. In 1867, we also got barbed wire from Lucien Smith. Joseph-Michel and Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier gave us the hot air balloon in 1783, 14 years before Andre Jacques Garnerin came up with the parachute. What balloonists did in the interim is not explained. The metal cannon was introduced in 1326 by Rinaldo di Villamagna, the spirally grooved rifle barrel in 1520 by August Kotter, the portable shotgun in 1525 by the Marquis of Pescara. It was not until 1540 that Ambrose Pare invented artificial limbs. That was offset the same year by Camillo Vettelli who invented the pistol.
