DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Not all park rangers roam the wilds, keeping a lookout for forest fires and wayward bears. At Independence Hall in Philadelphia the rangers of the National Park Service are more like classroom teachers than caretakers of nature, and they'd better know their history.

National Park Service rangers at Independence Hall still remember the woman who insisted on seeing the Statue of Liberty. ``People really do think of Philadelphia as the Cradle of Liberty, and some visitors think it's all here,'' says ranger Larry McClennie. ``This lady insisted that the statue was here somewhere. She wanted directions to find it, and `Go 100 miles north and turn right' wasn't what she wanted.'' Even if the No. 1 question is ``Where's the bathroom?'' the rangers who show off the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall need to be ready to answer all kinds of questions from some 1.4 million visitors a year. ``I probably learned more history here than I ever could have imagined,'' says Scott Dawson, who's worked two seasonal stints at the park. A question that comes up a lot is how the bell cracked, after it rang for years in the Statehouse tower to announce important events such as the signing of the Declaration of Independence. ``Cracks in bells were fairly common in those days,'' McClennie explains. ``They were repaired and put back in service, as the Liberty Bell was. But it cracked again and wasn't used after that.'' The park, which encompasses nearly two dozen buildings that figured in the birth of the United States as a nation, has a guide staff of 40 rangers - 70 in the peak months from April through September. Would-be rangers go through a week of intensive training, according to Barbara Pollarine, director of interpretation. They learn about three themes - the American Revolution, Benjamin Franklin and Philadelphia as the national capital. After a day of lectures and exercises, the ranger-students tackle a long reading list. There are standard texts such as ``Miracle at Philadelphia,'' by Catherine Drinker Bowen. Another is ``The Liberty Bell; the Venerable Relic,'' by former park historian Dave Kimball. Rangers are also encouraged to do research in the libraries of the Pennsylvania Historical Society, the American Philosophical Society and the park itself, resources not available anywhere else. By the end of their first week, each new ranger is expected to deliver a brief presentation prepared for the public. The trainees learn the basic history of the buildings, but when they speak to the public as rangers, they add their own flair to the presentation to make it interesting to the visitors, says David Dutcher, chief historian of the park. When Dawson leads a tour of Independence Hall, he explains that so much of the interior is green because it was the cheapest dye in the 18th century. Then he points out his uniform - green - and wonders whether the government is still as ``cheap'' as it used to be. Other rangers tell of the haunted second floor of Congress Hall. The ghost of French Queen Marie Antoinette supposedly lurks there. No one knows how the story got started. But King Louis XVI of France did donate a painting of his wife to Congress and the painting was lost in the move to Washington. A reproduction of the painting now hangs in Congress Hall in Philadelphia. As popular as this park is with the public - it's the biggest tourist attraction in Pennsylvania - many rangers consider it only an entry-level job. Unlike in many other big organizations, the staff yearns for transfers out of the big city to the boondocks. ``The kind of person who wants to work for the National Park Service doesn't exactly envision working in downtown Philadelphia,'' Pollarine says. ``After a year here, many of them are looking for someplace else to work.'' ``Rangers are just like other people,'' says ranger Steve Perlman. ``When they think of the national parks, they think of Yellowstone.'' Besides hearing the call of the wild, park rangers here have to deal with the cost of living in the city. A starting park ranger's salary is about $17,000 a year. While many park service trainees come out of college, an increasing number are retired from teaching or military service. ``A lot of people you meet here are academically very well trained,'' Pollarine says. Philadelphia ranks as a good place for rangers to prove themselves. On busy days, tours are given every 15 minutes at Independence Hall with 85 people going through the building at a time, Dutcher says. ``On the average day, we get about 2,000 to 3,000 people,'' says ranger Bill Kashatus. On peak days in May, it's not unusual for 8,000 schoolchildren to visit the Liberty Bell. The training continues after the rangers go on duty. Every other week, the park has a 45-minute session focusing on a special topic. Because the Bill of Rights will be a hot topic in 1991, its bicentennial year, the rangers will soon hear a speaker on James Madison, who drafted the documents. ``We never feel that we have all the information that we need,'' McClennie says. ``It's a never-ending course of study.'' The rewards may not be tangible, but they are here. ``Not to be corny about it, but this is a very special place,'' Pollarine says. ``It's very important to a lot of people. I've seen people cry during tours.''

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE - Here's an eagle whose picture could be on a postage stamp as a proud symbol of America. But this one went bad. Born in captivity and then released in the wild, he started doing things eagles are not supposed to do, raiding barnyards. But in the land of the free he'll get a second chance.

A young bald eagle that turned chicken thief after he was released in the wild is back in the slammer. State ornithologist Jim D. Wilson has recommended a short stay behind bars for the wayward eagle, but plans to give him a second chance at freedom. The eagle, nicknamed ``E,'' was released at the Schell-Osage Wildlife Area in west-central Missouri in July as part of a Department of Conservation program to re-establish a breeding population of eagles in the state. Seventy-four young bald eagles were raised in artificial nests with only minimal human contact and released into the wilds of Missouri under a 10-year program which just ended. ``E,'' which came from a wild nest in Wisconsin, began doing un-eaglelike things after he or she - it's difficult to determine the sex of an eagle - arrived in Missouri. Although most eagles shy away from humans, ``E'' didn't mind at all that a Daviess County farm family was watching in amazement as he repeatedly killed and ate their tame ducks. Wildlife officials thought the bird had only momentarily deviated from its normal diet, consisting mainly of rodents. So they recaptured the eagle and released it again about 75 miles away at the Squaw Creek Wildlife Refuge in northwestern Missouri. However, ``E'' turned up in late August in southern Iowa, eating dead baby pigs at another farm. The young eagle was captured again and returned to Squaw Creek, only to be caught red-handed a few days later eating a chicken in a farmer's chicken house in Atchison County. This time ``E'' was rounded up and transferred to the Dickerson Park Zoo in Springfield, which specializes in the care of injured eagles and other birds of prey. Bald eagles winter around major lakes and rivers in Missouri by the hundreds, and Wilson plans to release ``E'' near his cousins in February in hopes he will learn proper eagle behavior. ``What apparently happened to this bird is it somehow found out that farmyards were a place you could find some easy pickins,'' Wilson says. ``I'd like to give it one more try. I'll release it with another flock of eagles at a wildlife area where it won't come in contact with humans very easily and where there is an abundant natural food supply. ``If it doesn't adapt to the wild, it will be a zoo bird. I don't really want that; nobody does. There are plenty of zoo eagles.'' Of the 74 eagles the conservation department has released in the state, only one other bird behaved in a similar fashion, Wilson says. That eagle ended up getting killed by a truck in Kansas while eating an animal killed in the road, which is also uncharacteristic of eagles. Overall, the conservation department's efforts to get eagles to nest again in Missouri are showing signs of paying off, Wilson says. Three pairs nested successfully near the Mingo National Wildlife Refuge in southeastern Missouri this year, and another pair nested at an undisclosed location in central Missouri. The eagles are equipped with colored wing tags. More than 40 of the eagles released at the Mingo and Schell-Osage wildlife areas have been observed in surrounding states and as far away as Texas and Colorado. It takes about five years before eagles are mature and ready to nest. ``They are similar to salmon in that they should return to where they were raised to raise their own young,'' Wilson says. Eagles began disappearing in the state as large numbers of settlers moved in around the turn of the century. Ironically, habitat may be better for eagles in Missouri now than ever before. ``For one thing, the eagle is now protected by law and people know it so there's less disturbance of them,'' Wilson says. ``In addition, eagles are water birds and like our abundant reservoirs.''

DOC.TEXT: In the TV series ``Dark Shadows,'' producer-director Dan Curtis faced the problem of how to make a vampire a romantic figure. How do you do that? Well, he made his character, Barnabas Collins, a reluctant vampire, one who's trying to kick the habit. This vampire is no Dracula, nor is he a Stephen King or Anne Rice ghoul. ``Barnabas is a classic romantic figure who is seeking the lost love from 200 years ago that he can never regain,'' Curtis says. ``He hates his existence as a vampire, which is a spell put upon him by a witch. He's a great, dark, brooding, romantic figure.'' A revival of ``Dark Shadows,'' which became a Gothic cult soap opera in the 1960s, begins with a four-hour, two-part miniseries Sunday and Monday on NBC. On Friday it begins as a one-hour series following ``Quantum Leap.'' It's Curtis' first project since ``The Winds of War'' and ``War and Remembrance.'' ``I can't tell you exactly what made it work,'' Curtis says. ``I can tell you what the show is as opposed to what people think it is. It's not horror. It's a romantic fantasy. I think what makes it work are the mythical elements.'' Curtis gleefully concedes that ``Dark Shadows,'' an ABC afternoon soap opera from 1966-71, was inspired by ``Wuthering Heights,'' ``Jane Eyre,'' ``Rebecca'' and other Gothic stories. In the beginning ``Dark Shadows'' was merely Gothic - and about to get the ax from ABC. ``We were about to go off the air when my kids suggested I make it scary,'' he says. ``I introduced a ghost into the show, and the moment the ghost appeared on the screen the ratings went up. Instantly. I then came up with a supernatural story and the ratings went even higher. I decided to see how far I could go. ``I figured if I could get away with a vampire I could get away with anything. I was planning to kill him off, but Barnabas caught on. He was a sensation. The question was how to make a hero out of a vampire. So we made him a reluctant vampire. That was it.'' In the new version of ``Dark Shadows,'' Barnabas Collins is played by Ben Cross. Jean Simmons is the matriarch of Collinwood, an isolated New England manor house. Joanna Going is the beautiful young governess, a reincarnation of Barnabas' 200-year-old love, and Barbara Steele is a doctor who tries to cure Barnabas and falls in love with him. Curtis says the story is virtually the same as it was 25 years ago, but there are substantial changes in the production values. ``Many people have a memory of the show,'' he says. ``I'm not making the show the way it was but the way they remember it. It was a half-hour before. Our budget for five shows a week was about $90,000. We're spending around $1.2 million a show today. ``People have an exaggerated memory of the show. I'm sure they thought the great hall at Collinwood was a great hall. It was a very, very small hall. The new great hall is enormous. We filmed a lot of it at the Greystone mansion in Beverly Hills.'' Curtis was not eager to return to ``Dark Shadows,'' but NBC began pursuing him while he was still working on ``War and Remembrance.'' ``I didn't choose to go back,'' he says. ``NBC came to me. I'm getting some laughs out of it, but it's not like it's close to my heart and I bring all my emotions to it. I can't believe I'm doing this. When I was doing the original show I would have killed to get out of it. It was like I was in jail.'' Curtis spent the 1980s on the two monumental miniseries based on Herman Wouk's books about World War II. Before that he was best known for horror films such as ``The Night Stalker,'' ``Dracula,'' ``The Turn of the Screw,'' ``Frankenstein,'' ``The Picture of Dorian Gray'' and ``Burnt Offerings.'' Currently in the works are a third ``Night Stalker'' movie and a third movie about his childhood remembrances. Dean Jones, who played a character based on Curtis' father in ``When Every Day Was the Fourth of July'' and ``The Long Days of Summer,'' will star in the new film. Curtis is also writing several feature movies. ``It's been tough adjusting after so much time on the two miniseries,'' he says. ``I'd like to go back to `War and Remembrance.' I'd like to be ready to board a plane tomorrow.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 1 b&w photo.)
DOC.TEXT: Onstage in ``Buddy'' on Broadway, Paul Hipp looks like the earnest young rock 'n' roller he portrays, Buddy Holly. Offstage, he comes across more like the brashly flippant, facetious early Beatles. In his Manhattan apartment, which he shares with a West Highland terrier named Dylan, he ignores a visitor who walks in while he's listening intently to a Stevie Ray Vaughan record. Then he looks up to say, incongruously, ``I'm obsessed with Van Gogh. I like Vincent. I was fantasizing about cutting my ear off the other day but it'd take longer to do the makeup. Now all I have to do is put base on and eyeliner.'' Hipp, 25, who has a rock band of his own, was born six years after Buddy Holly died at age 22 and seven years before Don McLean wrote ``American Pie'' about the plane crash that killed him. But he identifies with Holly ``in the way he stuck with his own sound and his own music. And he was a nice guy.'' Hipp took up guitar at 12 and has studied both music and acting. Until ``Buddy,'' he hasn't been famous, though he'd like to be, with parallel careers. ``I see no reason why it has got to be actor or musician,'' he says. ``I came up doing both. It's not like I'm a rock 'n' roller slumming on Broadway. ``One of my main things I want to do is bridge the gap that hasn't been bridged yet and have a serious career songwriting and acting. Sting hasn't done it or David Bowie. Kris Kristofferson is more country music.'' Paul Hipp and the Heroes haven't cut any records yet, but he's talking to record companies now. His acting in New York previously hasn't been Broadway or off-Broadway but ``off-off-off-off.'' ``I did a lot of plays nobody came to see,'' he says. ``This is a nice change of pace for me. It's a wonderful thing to look out and there's people sitting out there.'' People in the Shubert Theater mezzanine and balcony are warned that dancing and standing during the performance are prohibited, but Hipp can see them dancing in the orchestra section's first few rows. ``If there's a pretty girl up front, I can throw her a guitar pick,'' he says. ``Then I have the crew go get her. When I come off stage, the dressing room is filled with a bevy of beauties. The next stop is the hot tub.'' Despite the fact that he's starring in a musical, Hipp says, ``I hate musicals. All that show business, people dancing, ain't my thing.'' Hipp's 20th-floor apartment on Central Park South is his first New York apartment, he says. ``For nine years I couldn't afford one. I lived wherever there was a couch. That's how Buddy Holly has changed my life.'' When he auditioned for ``Buddy'' in England, where he played the role for nine months, he thinks he was chosen primarily for his acting ability. ``But I'm sure the fact I can play guitar didn't hurt.'' Hipp was nominated for a Laurence Olivier Award, which was won by Jonathan Pryce in ``Miss Saigon.'' ``I thought it was fixed,'' he says. ``I don't know. It is fine to be nominated. It beats playing Bleeker Street (in Greenwich Village) for 50 bucks a night.'' In ``Buddy,'' Hipp plays guitar and sings more than 20 Buddy Holly songs, including ``That'll Be the Day,'' ``Peggy Sue'' and ``Oh Boy!''. He did a lot of research on the innovative pioneer rocker from Lubbock, Texas, before he began portraying him. ``The show covers him from 19 to 22,'' Hipp says. ``He had the natural growth any kid goes through. Add rock 'n' roll stardom, it gets quite complicated. To internalize what had happened to him, maintain that innocence and grow gradually was difficult. ``I met a lot of people who saw him on his last tour. Bob Dylan saw him three days before he died, when he went through Minnesota.'' Act 2 of ``Buddy'' re-creates Buddy Holly's last concert, in Clear Lake, Iowa, with Dion and the Belmonts, the Big Bopper and Ritchie Valens. The latter two died on the plane with Holly later that night. ``I wouldn't imagine anyone taped that show,'' Hipp says. ``I would have run into them by now. The Buddy Holly Society knows more about the Crickets (Holly's band) than the Crickets know about themselves.'' Holly's widow, who had a miscarriage after his death, saw ``Buddy'' in London and has been supportive, Hipp says. Hipp is the fourth of five children and uses his real name. He moved to New York from Philadelphia right after graduating from high school. ``The bell rang. I was here. ``I thought about changing my name to Rock Dashing,'' he says. ``I want to work on a soap opera really bad. I want to be Dr. Dashing, have my teeth capped, plastic surgery, a square jaw, blond hair and blue contacts.'' Hipp played a Lower East Side punk in ``China Girl.'' During the filming, he wrote the song ``Midnight for You.'' ``The director liked it and put it in,'' Hipp says. Hipp and the Heroes played it. During the interview, Hipp strums on his guitar, which is autographed by Johnny and June Cash, Duane Eddy, two Crickets and Mrs. Holly. After ``Buddy'' and after his band cuts a record, Hipp hopes to make a movie. ``It won't be music,'' he says. ``There won't be a guitar in sight.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Jan. 5, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Friends, Relatives Puzzled by Allegations Mother Killed Her Children
DOC.TEXT: One by one, Diana Lumbrera buried each of her six children, weeping and fainting as the tiny bodies were lowered into the ground, begging on her knees for her little ones to come back. Each of the children died before his or her fifth birthday, and doctors ascribed each death to natural causes. Diana Lumbrera knew better than that; she had been cursed by her former mother-in-law, she said. But now, authorities say the children's deaths were neither natural nor supernatural. They say that Diana Lumbrera, 32, killed her kids. She has been convicted of killing one 4-year-old son; she faces charges that she killed three daughters, a son and the daughter of a cousin; authorities are investigating the death of another son. Still, her friends and family insist that a terrible mistake is being made. ``She was a loving mother and she took care of those children,'' said her aunt, Elodia Flores. ``She worked hard every day and made those children number one in her life. I just don't believe she killed those children.'' --- Joanna Garza, age 3 months, died Nov. 30, 1976. The cause of death: ``strangulation due to asphyxiation due to convulsive disorder.'' Jose Lionel Garza, 2{ months, died Feb. 13, 1978. The cause of death is listed as undetermined. Melissa Garza, 3, died Oct. 2, 1978, The cause: ``asphyxia due to aspiration of stomach contents.'' Erica Aleman, Ms. Lumbrera's 6-week-old cousin, died Oct. 8, 1980. Medical records are missing. Melinda Ann Garza, 2, died Aug. 17, 1982. The cause is listed as ``heart failure due to increased taxation on a case of congenital heart disease.'' Christopher Daniel Lumbrera, 5{ months, died March 28, 1984 of what doctors said was septicemia - a fatal infection of the blood. Jose Antonio Lumbrera, 4, died May 1, 1990. The cause of death was listed as ``asphyxia due to smothering.'' --- For 14 years, as Ms. Lumbrera's children died one after another, law enforcement authorities in Texas suspected nothing. The death certificates gave them no reason to be suspicious. Then authorities in Garden City, Kans., where Ms. Lumbrera had moved, were handed a murder case. Doctors there attributed Jose Antonio's death to smothering, and a jury agreed in October, taking just 3 hours to convict Ms. Lumbrera of murder. She was sentenced to life in prison. The Kansas charges prompted a massive investigation into the other deaths, resulting in the five murder indictments in three West Texas counties. ``A death certificate may say death due to heart failure. Everyone who dies suffers from heart failure,'' said Parmer County District Attorney Johnny Actkinson, who will prosecute Ms. Lumbrera in an upcoming trial. ``The question is, what caused the heart failure?'' Actkinson says there was no coverup; instead, he suggested that those who issued the death reports probably did not want to think the worst. ``Those kids' deaths were such a horrible state of affairs that no one considered a mother would murder her own children. So the doctors look for another way to explain it. I am not being critical. It's just human nature.'' Lionel Garza, Ms. Lumbrera's second husband and father of four of the dead children, says he was shocked by her conviction in Jose Antonio's death. ``All my life I lived thinking my kids died of natural causes. Now all the doors of question are open and the pain is rushing back in,'' he said. Still, Garza - who filed for divorce from Ms. Lumbrera in 1980, two years after their third child's death - apparently harbored suspicions about his wife, according to authorities acquainted with his grand jury testimony. ``Lionel was suspicious of Diana after the third death,'' said Bovina Police Chief Gary Coleman. ``Especially since he said he was playing with the child (Melissa Garza) early that morning before going to work. ``He said the child was healthy and he didn't detect anything wrong. Thirty minutes after he arrives at work, he's called and told the child has died.'' Garza said the allegations against his wife ``gave me a lot of anger. But now I just want the truth. I want to know if she killed my babies.'' --- Virginia Bribiesca, Ms. Lumbrera's sister, says she was there when Garza's mother cursed her, telling Ms. Lumbrera her children would die at their mother's hands. ``I heard the woman say it,'' she says. Garza denies it ever happened. His wife ``never said anything to me about the children being cursed by my mother,'' he said. Parmer County Deputy Sheriff Richard Bonham, who helped lead the investigation into the deaths of Ms. Lumbrera's children in Texas, says the witchcraft argument is irrelevant: ``In our investigation that holds no water for defense of what she has done.'' But those who know Ms. Lumbrera - a frail former meatpacker - say there is no doubt that she believes in the supernatural. Maria Antillon, a close friend, said the defendant is high-strung, emotional and frequently talked about her fervent belief in spiritual healers and ``curanderos'' - fortune tellers or witchcraft doctors prevalent in Hispanic culture who have the power to bless or curse a person's life. ``She told me several times about witchcraft and things she believed in like curses and things like that,'' said Mrs. Antillon. ``She used to tell me that she felt her mother-in-law had cursed her. She said if you believe in the curanderos they will get to you. If you don't, they won't.'' Mrs. Antillon is one of Ms. Lumbrera's defenders. ``Diana went to church every Sunday when she lived here,'' she said. ``Everybody liked her. She wasn't the type of person that would get in trouble with a neighbor. I never heard that she had gotten into an argument with someone else. And she loved her kids.'' Her aunt, Elva Hernandez, notes that Ms. Lumbrera suffered from polio when she was a child. ``Diana was often sick when she was young. How can they just disregard that the kids could have died because of sickness?'' Other friends and family members are suspicious of authorities' motives in pressing the case. Robert Olvera, 33, Ms. Lumbrera's cousin, says the police have actively pursued the case because the defendant is Hispanic. ``You think this would happen to a Diana if she was white? No way. Absolutely not,'' Olvera said. ``The police are just looking for publicity, if you ask me,'' he said. ``That is the only way you can explain all this coming out so many years later. The doctors ruled the children died of natural causes.'' Ms. Bribiesca fears the Kansas conviction will doom her sister in Texas. ``She didn't get a fair trial'' in Garden City, said Ms. Bribiesca, who resides in Kansas. ``Before this, I think she could have gotten one in Texas, but not now. Not after this. They're going to think she killed all her kids. But Diana's not going to give up, I'll tell you that.'' --- In late January, Ms. Lumbrera faces trial on murder charges in Parmer County in the deaths of Joanna, Melissa and Melinda; the grand jury said she smothered the three children to collect $15,000 in life insurance benefits. She also faces separate trials in Lubbock and Bailey counties in the deaths of Jose Lionel and Erica Aleman. An investigation into the death of Christopher Lumbrera continues. If she is convicted in any case, she could face either life in prison or the death penalty, administered by lethal injection. Gordon Green, Ms. Lumbrera's lawyer, would not allow her to be interviewed. ``It's not an everyday case,'' said Green, refusing to comment further. Ms. Lumbrera is being held in the Parmer County Jail on $300,000 bond. Fifteen miles away, at the Bovina Cemetery, elaborate headstones stand over the graves of five of Ms. Lumbrera's children. Each bears the same epitaph: ``Darling we miss thee.''

DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
American and Vietnamese War eterans Gather in Peace
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The soldier stood at the memorial marked with the names of Vietnam's valleys of death: Khe Sanh and Con Thien, Hue and Quang Tri, An Loc and Xuan Loc. Then Nguyen Ngoc Hung lighted a dozen incense sticks and silently faced his fallen American foes, memorialized in the stone of the Dorchester Vietnam Veterans Memorial: Hain, Gormley, Rabinovitz, Kelly, Burt. Husbands, sons, brothers. Seventy-eight of them. ``I said to those men who have died during the war, `Please lay in peace. The war is over now and I've come a long way for reconciliation.''' Hung, a North Vietnamese combat veteran, had come half way around the world for solemn ceremonies such as this one, and to drink beer and feast on lasagna and meatballs with his former war adversaries. Fifteen years after its end in 1975, American veterans of the Vietnam War are shaking hands with the nameless, faceless foes like Hung whom they fought as young men in the jungles of Southeast Asia. They fought on different sides but now share the common bond of duty to country and the inescapable events of history that first brought them together. And they hope the healing of wounds among the warriors themselves will nudge the U.S. government into diplomatic recognition of its former enemy, financial aid and the lifting of a trade embargo that is strangling Vietnam's bankrupt economy. As a new generation of U.S. combat forces maintains its war readiness in the explosive Middle East, many of the boys of Vietnam are finally standing down from a war that has seemed hauntingly unreal to them. Many are going back to Vietnam in their middle years, sentimental and mellowed by time, needing to retrace the old battlefields that brought them of age. They gather to share the pain of war and to heal its stings with understanding. And they go with their arms outstretched with hammers to build and medicine to heal instead of rifles to kill. ``There comes a time for healing and I think this is the time,'' said Mary Stout, a combat nurse during the war who revisited Vietnam two years ago. ``I think the people who start it have to be the veterans. They understand what war's about and have a common bond. It comes from serving your country.'' Hoping to win diplomatic recognition, the Vietnamese government allowed Hung, a 42-year-old college English teacher who earns $10 a month, to tour 11 U.S. cities during six weeks in November and December. The cities were Washington, Philadelphia, New York, Madison, Wis., San Francisco, Santa Cruz, Calif., Los Angeles, New Haven, Conn., Boston, Pittsburgh and Atlanta. While scores of Americans have been back to Vietnam in recent years to help that country's disabled veterans, who languish in poverty and menial jobs, Hung was the first Vietnam combat veteran to visit the United States. He was invited by the Asia Resource Center and the National Network of Indochina Activists, a loose network of people who support recognition of Vietnam and trade with that country. ``I think Mr. Hung was here at the auspices of the Vietnamese government to try to begin to take steps toward reconciliation with our country,'' said Ms. Stout, president of the 40,000 member Vietnam Veterans of America in Washington, who met with him. While the VVA does not yet fully support diplomatic relations with Vietnam, it has encouraged the beginning of steps toward that goal with the establishment of a small diplomatic office in Vietnam, rather than a full-fledged embassy. Some veterans say the United States should hold out until Americans missing in action are accounted for and there is assurance that Vietnam is holding no prisoners. Others feel the MIA-POW issue cannot be resolved without first establishing diplomatic relations. Hung said the United States was not what he expected. ``I have learned a lot here,'' he said. ``It changed some of the images about America and American people. In the past we thought that American soldiers were professionals. They were trained to kill and they would kill like in the My Lai massacre.'' What Hung found were Americans who welcomed him into their homes, drank beer with him, laughed with him and shared war stories. Americans who were just like him, who had the same fears and joys, whose lives were interrupted by a war that was not necessarily of their choosing. ``I see they are just like me,'' Hung said. ``They suffered enormously because of the killing, so we are just human beings, the victims of the war.'' One recent evening Hung and American veterans who had earlier returned to Vietnam gathered in the home of a Boston police sergeant who fought in the same region as Hung. They talked about how Vietnamese and Americans had suffered. ``After the war I came back, rifle in my hand,'' said Hung. ``And when I looked at what the war had done to my country, very, very sad. A million and a half or 2 million people have died. The forests have been destroyed or defoliated and we haven't been able to do very much about it.'' Nearly 60,000 Americans died in the Vietnam War; 300,000 more were wounded. Many others are still fighting the war on a different battlefield - in their minds. They suffer from post traumatic stress disorder, the delayed shock of combat. ``We've got a lot of veterans out there who are still in the jungles of Vietnam,'' Gumersindo Gomez told Hung. Gomez, who fought in Vietnam in the mid 1960s, is now executive director of the Puerto Rican Veterans Association of Massachusetts in Springfield. ``We are still suffering the consequences here, too,'' said Gomez, who worked in a veterans outreach center. ``We had nightmares and we had flashbacks and other bad things,'' said Hung. Their biggest problem is unemployment, he said. But the Vietnamese veterans, unlike some of their American counterparts, were not plunged into alcohol, drugs and homelessness, Hung said. ``Veterans in Vietnam were given a very warm welcome home,'' he said. ``Because you won?'' asked veteran Paul O'Connell. ``No,'' replied Hung. ``Because we were fighting for the country.'' ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Special Correspondent George Esper, the AP's Northeast regional reporter based in Boston, reported from Vietnam for 10 years, from 1965 through the fall of Saigon in 1975.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday, Jan. 5, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Friendly Foes
A Retrospect on Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam is often seen in retrospect through the eyes of Americans. Rarely is it viewed from the Vietnamese perspective. But an old American foe, former infantryman Nguyen Ngoc Hung, gave some rare glimpses from the North Vietnamese side during a recent tour of the United States. On victory: ``The Vietnamese were determined to carry it to the end. We didn't aim to defeat the Americans ... We fought to drive the Americans home ... And in 1973, the Americans had to withdraw because of the killings. But also it was due to the anti-war movement in the United States. So we didn't actually defeat the Americans. We drove them away.'' On the body count: ``In America, whenever they fought a battle, they say, `OK, one American, 20 Vietnamese (killed), they won the battle.' They won many battles in Vietnam but what was the point here. It is our country. If we lost the war, we have no other place to go. We understood how barbarous the French colonialist system was. And for many Vietnamese, we didn't see any difference between the war against the French colonialists and the war against the Americans.'' On anti-war demonstrations in the United States: ``The war is actually fought not only in Vietnam but also in the United States. It would have been very difficult for the Vietnamese to end this war without the anti-war movement in the United States because I know how strong and how powerful the Air Force and artillery support of the American Army and Navy were during the war.'' Comparing the Americans to their southern Vietnamese allies: ``It was difficult to fight against the Americans. It was not difficult to fight the southern (Vietnamese) Army because most of the soldiers didn't know why they had to fight. They were drafted from schools and from families and nobody wanted to go to war. Most of the (American) veterans told me the same story. They didn't like the southern Vietnamese soldiers and they didn't trust them.''

DOC.HEAD: USDA Sleuths Outline 1991 Plan of Action
DOC.TEXT: Investigators and auditors in the Agriculture Department are sniffing at commodity programs, farm loans and dozens of other nuts and bolts that federal workers operate, jiggle and shift into gear. The specialists work for the department's Office of Inspector General. Auditors check on whether money is spent properly, and investigators look for ways to put people in jail if it isn't. Inspector General Leon Snead says in his agency's annual plan for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 that auditors ``identified about $32.8 million in recoveries and collections'' last year. Further, he said, USDA managers committed themselves to putting $420.1 million to better use. Investigations resulted in 839 indictments, 671 convictions and about $38.8 million in fines, restitutions and recoveries during the year. What about 1991? More of the same, with auditors looking into consumer protection programs such as meat and poultry, large payments to farmers, export credit operations and financial management. Snead said his office also will ``monitor implementation'' of the 1990 farm law this year and will conduct a financial statement audit of the Farmers Home Administration. ``Our investigative priorities include the timely and thorough investigation of threats to the health and safety of the public; employee integrity issues; and fraud in the loan, regulatory and benefit program,'' he said. The 75-page annual report was made available to The Associated Press upon request. According to the audit blueprint for 1991, there will be further looks into operations of various programs operated by the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service and its national network of state and county offices. ``In fiscal year 1990, we continued to find problems with excessive deficiency payments (subsidies) to producers, deliberate circumvention of the payment limitation provisions, payments for ineligible cropland in the Conservation Reserve Program, and incorrect crop yields and payment rates used to calculate disaster payments,'' the report said. Previous audits, it added, also identified weaknesses in producer payment certifications, compliance with cost-sharing agreements and other details of the commodity programs. ``Among the audits of ASCS planned for (fiscal) 1991 are major audits of compliance with payment limitation provisions, the 1989 disaster assistance program, tobacco program operations, claims and debt management activities, and the 1990 emergency feed program,'' the report said. On the investigative side, the report said ``a significant number of staff days'' will be spent in several areas: -Investigation of farmers who have used a ``scheme or device'' to avoid annual crop support payment limitations. -The investigation of false certification by farmers so they could get disaster assistance. -Investigation of shortages of USDA-owned or USDA-mortgaged commodities stored in commercial warehouses. The report said auditors will review marketing opportunities provided by the Support for Eastern European Democracy Act of 1989, compliance with international trade agreements, a follow-through on prior recommendations for export subsidy programs, and implementation of new trade provisions of the 1990 farm law. On the investigative side, the report said this year's efforts will be increased to 3 percent of the office's total staff days from 2.5 percent last year and 0.5 percent in 1988. Most of the investigations involved the Public Law 480 - Food for Peace - program, the Export Enhancement Program, and the Export Credit Guarantee Program, usually involving allegations of false certifications by U.S. exporters

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: `The Long Walk Home'; `Green Card'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Films are currently in limited release nationwide, and will open in more theaters.
DOC.TEXT:
``The Long Walk Home'' (New Visions Pictures)
Like ``Mississippi Burning'' in 1988, ``The Long Walk Home'' has been assailed by some black leaders as being a distortion of the struggle for civil rights in the South. Both films are told from the white point of view, though ``The Long Walk Home'' appears to offer more balance between the races. Taken on its artistic merits alone, ``The Long Walk Home'' is an earnest, often affecting, curiously anticlimactic film. Its major assets are two fully realized performances by accomplished actresses, Sissy Spacek and Whoopi Goldberg. The setting of John Cork's script is Montgomery, Ala., in 1955, when municipal buses were segregated and blacks were forced to sit in the back. A seamstress named Rosa Parks decided one day that she was too tired and took a seat at the front of the bus. She was arrested, and Montgomery blacks staged a one-day boycott that grew into a movement led by Martin Luther King Jr. Buses were integrated a year later following a federal court order. In ``The Long Walk Home,'' nothing has changed in the social structure of Montgomery since the institution of Jim Crow laws following the Civil War and Reconstruction. The back-of-the-bus mentality prevails among the city's white leaders, and the blacks are expected to know their place. The decades of degradation well up, and blacks call a strike on the municipal bus system, a prime source of revenue. Enter two reluctant heroines. Miriam Thompson (Spacek) is a well-to-do matron who accedes to the wishes of her good ol' boy husband (Dwight Schultz). Odessa Cotter (Goldberg) is her dutiful domestic, a woman who has never challenged the social system. But Odessa believes the bus strike is the right thing to do. She is willing to walk the nine long miles to and from work. Mrs. Thompson sympathizes with Odessa and is increasingly appalled by how her husband is influenced by his racist brother (Dylan Baker). The strike escalates into violence, and King's house is bombed. Miriam Thompson decides to drive Odessa to work. Her act brings a climax in her marriage and in the community. Inexpensively but caringly produced by Howard W. Koch Jr. and Dave Bell, ``The Long Walk Home'' carries an emotional impact. Spacek deftly portrays the ethical dilemma of Southern wife and mother. In her most restrained performance, Goldberg again impresses as one of the best actresses around. The other performances are first-rate, especially Schultz as the husband who is incensed to find his values questioned. Richard Pearce directs with a firm touch on the personal scenes, which could have been overwrought. Only in the climax does he stumble, reducing the issues to a simplistic level and mishandling crowd scenes. The Miramax Films release of a New Visions Picture is rated PG for language and intensity. Running time: 97 minutes. By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer. ---

``Green Card'' (Touchstone)
``Green Card'' is a wisp of a movie, a harmless puff of smoke that's pleasing to watch and quickly forgotten. Gerard Depardieu stars as Georges, an illegal alien from France who marries a stranger, Bronte (Andie MacDowell), so he can receive a green card and live in Manhattan. Bronte has her own reasons for marrying. A horticulturist, she wants to purchase an apartment with a greenhouse and reasons that having another name on the lease will persuade the co-op board to let her in. It works, at first, but when immigration officials become suspicious, Georges and Bronte are forced to live together so they can learn as much as possible about each other and present themselves as a true couple. Georges, with shaggy hair and black, baggy pants, is earthy and loveable. He smokes, he eats fatty food, he loses his temper, he hates instant coffee. He's charming, but also cynical: he ran away from home as a child and spent a brief time in jail (Depardieu had the same experiences in his own life). Bronte, who favors green, baggy pants, is well-to-do and idealistic. She is passionate about the environment, and especially about her garden. She's very clean and a little repressed, not unlike her character in ``sex, lies and videotape.'' ``I am like a gutter, and you are like a plant!'' Georges shouts at her at one point. This is the comedy of the mismatch, a reworking of ``It Happened One Night,'' ``Woman of the Year,'' ``The Goodbye Girl'' and many others, when opposites are thrown together and eventually attract. Director Peter Weir takes a low-key approach, applying the same thoughtful style of last year's ``Dead Poets Society,'' offering quiet shots of MacDowell watching the rain and presenting a Manhattan so golden you'd think the lens was dipped in corn oil. Weir also wrote and produced the film. ``Green Card'' is a time-killer for Depardieu, who likes to make three or four movies a year and can currently be seen in the far more demanding ``Cyrano de Bergerac.'' But the French actor, in his first predominantly English-speaking role, does get the most out of a slim part, showing wonderful timing and giving the film a sweet, offbeat quality. The scenes in which Georges and Bronte concoct love letters and put together an album of phony wedding and honeymoon pictures are especially funny, such as when Georges pretends he's writing from Africa and complains the elephants are keeping him awake. The film wants to be liked - and succeeds - but the touch is so light it leaves no mark. Even as Georges faces deportation, there is no real tension in ``Green Card,'' no demands made of the audience, nothing to think about when it's over, a sweet dream that fades away after the lights go on. The Touchstone Pictures Release is rated PG-13. Running Time: 108 minutes. By Hillel Italie, Associated Press Writer. --- Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.

In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Love Is a Strange Hotel'' (RNA) - Gregson and Collister
One problem with people who use acoustic guitars as a primary means of musical expression is inflation - of their songs and themselves. Such self-importance causes folk-rock artists Clive Gregson and Christine Collister to miss a good opportunity with their new disc, ``Love Is a Strange Hotel.'' On the record, the duo abandon their own relatively undistinguished compositions for an eclectic set of cover songs. Their choices show a wide-ranging taste. Unfortunately, a few bad song choices and overwrought performances make this an overall disappointment. When Aztec Camera's Roddy Frame sings his own ``How Men Are,'' it works as a man extending an arm in sympathy to a woman who's been jilted. Switch the sex of the narrator and Collister turns the song into self-pitying male-bashing. Similarly, turning 10cc's ``The Things We Do for Love'' and Paul Carrack's ``Always Better With You'' into acoustic ballads comes off as a misguided attempt to turn pop into poetry. Carrack's song is a soulful shout of joy and needs more exuberance than Gregson and Collister can give it. The performances of Bruce Springsteen's ``One Step Up'' and Jackson Browne's ``For a Dancer'' bring emotional ballads one step closer to New Age background music. Collister has one shining moment that almost cancels out her sins elsewhere. The pain in her voice perfectly captures the heartache of unrequited love on Stephen Fearing's ``The Most Beguiling Eyes.'' Merle Haggard's ``Today I Started Loving You Again'' gives the pair its most effective duet.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: The `Fashionable' Career of Glenn Close
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Hamlet'' opened in limited markets on Dec. 19. ``Sarah, Plain and Tall'' will be aired by CBS on Feb. 3.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Costumes are often forgotten once films are over, but not when Glenn Close is around. Her closet includes suits from ``Jagged Edge,'' an overcoat from ``Fatal Attraction'' and the Marquise de Merteuil's low-cut gownsfrom ``Dangerous Liasions.'' She takes good care of those clothes; she never knows when they'll be needed. Recently, for example, the Fashion Institute of Technology asked her to donate her wardrobe from ``Reversal of Fortune'' for an exhibit on fashion in film. Close was able to oblige. Her costumes are also a reminder of a daring, complicated life on screen, a career spent in coats of many colors, from pure white in ``The Natural'' to shining black in ``Fatal Attraction.'' ``Those characters all stay with me in some way,'' said Close, dressed for a recent interview in a mocha brown, suede jacket and tan pants, an appropriate outfit for a woman who grew up on a 500-acre estate in Greenwich, Conn. ``You have to love your character, even Alex Forrest (of `Fatal Attraction'), who was a very haunting character. You become intimate. You gain an understanding of their behavior and I usually emphasize deeply with them.'' As the reserved, unhappy Sunny von Bulow of ``Reversal of Fortune,'' she favored a sweater outfit with a single strand of pearls. She wore gowns and long earrings for her new film, ``Hamlet,'' portraying Queen Gertrude in the latest version of Shakespeare's classic tragedy. ``Hamlet'' stars Mel Gibson as the Danish prince incapable of making up his mind, and also features Alan Bates, Ian Holm, Paul Scofield and Helena Bonham Carter. Close, a veteran stage actress, was not in awe of portraying Gertrude. She went about it like any other part, reading the play several times, watching other films of ``Hamlet'' and taking a personal approach to analyzing her character. ``I just decided she was married very young and married a man much older than her for political reasons,'' said Close, a five-time Academy Award nominee. ``All the descriptions of her come across as a very tactile, very sensual woman. The ghosts and the king and Hamlet revolved around her. There's something in that woman that's dazzling, necessary, sensual, selfish.'' She was born in 1947 in Greenwich, which her ancestors helped found in the late 17th century. Growing up, Close never dressed like a queen, but remembers years spent in the country playing make-believe in a number of roles: a bride, a cowboy, an orphan, a woman dying of cancer. Helping were her two grandmothers. One had wanted to be a singer, the other an actress. They were perfect coaches, exposing her to opera and ballet, even offering tricks for improving the memory. She also made trips to Manhattan, which gave her a chance to try different kinds of clothes. ``We'd go every year to `The Nutcracker' and go to the circus and we'd also come in to have our eyes examined. It was like going to Oz. We'd always get dressed up. When we were a little older and actually lived in New York, it was a shock to be in jeans and just be comfortable.'' She postponed going to college to pursue a singing career and was briefly married to rock guitarist Cabot Wade. Tired of life on the road, she enrolled at William and Mary College in 1970, majoring in drama. After graduating, she starred in a number of plays for regional theaters, including ``King Lear,'' ``Uncle Vanya'' and ``A Streetcar Named Desire'' among others. Her breakthrough came in 1980 with the Broadway musical ``Barnum,'' for which she earned a Tony nomination as the circus showman's wife and gave over 300 performances. In 1984, she won a Tony for her starring role in Tom Stoppard's ``The Real Thing.'' Close's film career began in 1982 with ``The World According to Garp.'' playing the free-spirited mother of Robin Williams. She was a sympathetic actress at first, inspiring Robert Redford in ``The Natural'' and mourning an old friend's suicide in ``The Big Chill.'' But in 1987, tired of warm smiles and soft tears, Close jumped at the chance to play the sexy, explosive ``other woman'' of ``Fatal Attraction,'' dropping 10 pounds for the role, her sweet image evaporating into a single pot of boiled rabbit. She considers ``Dangerous Liaisons,'' based on the 18th-century novel, her favorite film, admiring the Marquise's cunning and ruthlessness as she spars with the equally formidable Vicomte de Valmont (John Malkovich). The Marquise makes and breaks rules, Close notes, and is controlling her image rather being controlled, an actress born at least 200 years too soon. ``I liked some of those old roles, but they didn't particulary interest me,'' said Close, who plays nice again in ``Sarah, Plain and Tall,'' a children's story to be aired Feb. 3 on CBS. ``I prefer the battles between men and women and what's cliched and what's not. It's one of the great fascinations. It's exhausting emotionally but that kind of exhaustion for me is ultimately very cathartic, exhilarating.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Top Auction Houses Romance the Eastern Market
DOC.TEXT: The world's top auction houses have set up shop in Berlin, seeking to acquire and sell treasures kept hidden during the Communist rule in eastern Europe. Sotheby's, the world's largest art auction house, has chosen a former Prussian palace in eastern Berlin as the site of its new office. The previous tenant was the German-Soviet Friendship Society. Rival Christie's has selected a posh ground-floor setting just off the Kurfuerstendamm, western Berlin's most fashionable shopping boulevard, as its new address in the capital. Both aim to explore the unknown art world of the former Communist east that was largely closed off to capitalist dealers during the Cold War. ``Sotheby's had long thought about going to Berlin. With the opening of the Wall, it became necessary to open,'' said H. Josef Koenig, director of the Berlin office. Koenig says he gets offers every day from eastern Germans seeking appraisals of silver, paintings or antiques they had hidden for years. The objects include old Meissen porcelain, pieces of Biedermeier furniture, silver, jewelry and paintings. Sometimes works of real value appear and can make their owners rich. Shortly before unity Oct. 3, an East German from Dresden showed up at the Frankfurt branch of Sotheby's with a painting he had inherited. The retired worker had hidden the painting after the Red Army fought its way into Germany in 1945 and kept it secret from East German authorities who had forbidden private ownership of art. Experts identified the painting as a portrait by the 20th century German expressionist Emil Nolde. Out of sight for half-a-century, the work had been given up for lost by art connoisseurs. The painting was valued at 1.35 million marks ($900,000). ``Nobody knows what is over there,'' said Koenig. To find out, Christie's hired Peter Betthausen, former director of the National Gallery in what was East Berlin and a specialist in German art of the 19th and 20th centuries, to head its office. Christie's is also staffing its Berlin office with experts to assess the value of objects offered, focusing on silver and jewelry. Sotheby's eastern expansion does not stop in Berlin. An office already exists in Budapest, Hungary, and another is planned for Prague, Czechoslovakia, in 1991. The arrival of the two major auction houses could signal the start of a revival of Berlin's prewar role as Germany's major art center. Berlin began its steep decline as an art mecca in 1933 when Adolf Hitler took power. The Nazis banned many artists, and in 1939 publicly burned more than 1,000 works of art that they deemed ``offensive.'' Socialist Realism was the tune of the day when the Communists came to power in eastern Germany after World War II. Artists who did not conform could not exhibit. The unstable postwar political situation also affected West Berlin. The city found it hard to attract valuable works for museums while the city was divided. But now that the city is open again, both auction houses have spared no expense for the occasion. Sotheby's sponsored a public exhibition that drew large crowds in October to Schloss Charlottenburg to see modern paintings by such artists as Kandinsky, Matisse and Modigliani. Christie's flew in Lord Carrington, a former NATO secretary general who is chairman of Christie's International, for the official Dec. 10 opening of its offices. However, it may take a while for Berlin to become the site of the kind of spectacular auctions held regularly in London. While many foreigners visit the city to look at what is left of the Berlin Wall, most do not come regularly. ``Germans love traveling to London,'' said Angela Hucke, Christie's press officer for Germany. Auctions are also most likely to fetch higher prices in London, which has a more international buying audeience than Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Not the New Madonna, But Something in Common
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Betty Boo, already a star in Britain and riding ``Doin' the Do'' up the charts in the United States, doesn't mind being compared to Madonna - up to a point. ``But I don't want people believing I'm a wannabee. I admire Madonna, like I admire Margaret Thatcher - though I don't agree with her politics - because I like to see strong women, women in control,'' said the feisty, ravishingly attractive 20-year-old. ``I feel weak if I am not in control. I always like to be in the driver's seat. That's why I don't like flying: I always think I am going to crash, I don't trust the pilot.'' She's flying high on her own. In Britain she has had two Top 10 singles, and her album, ``Boomania,'' has made the top five. And she has signed a U.S. recording contract with Seymour Stein of Sire Records, the man who signed Madonna. ``Madonna told Seymour Stein she liked my video, she thought I was cute. She told Seymour, `Oh, she needs a choreographer, she should use Luis''' - Luiscamacho Jose Gutlerez, who did Madonna's ``Vogue'' video. He is helping with Betty Boo's next video, and other connections are happening quickly. She has signed up with Larry Frazin and Larry Tollin, the American managers who also handle Paula Abdul. Half-Scottish, half-Malaysian by birth and 100 percent Cockney in speech, the singer changed her name from Alison Clarkson because someone once remarked that she looked like Betty Boop, the ditzy cartoon character. ``I don't see myself as a bimbo, because I'm headstrong,'' she said. ``I'm not thick. A lot of people think I look good and it helps. But I'm not going to go topless or anything like that.'' She began her music career with two girlfriends as the rap group She Rockers. Three years ago they met Professor Griff of Public Enemy at a McDonald's near their home in the west London working class district of Shepherd's Bush. Griff liked their insulting attitude, and offered to produce a single in New York. ``Give It a Rest'' was the result. But the singer didn't identify with the radical black separatism and hard-core rap she encountered in New York. She returned to England, disillusioned, after a month. Fired with new determination in 1988 after the death of her father, a driver on the London subway, she took a course in studio sound engineering so she could control her own work. She connected with the pioneering British dance label Rhythm King and wrote the rap and sang on ``Hey DJ'' by the Beatmasters, a top 10 song in Britain last year. Her own record deal followed, and the company bought her a keyboard, sequencer and sampler. She mastered the equipment and composed 10 songs in six weeks. ```Doin' the Do' was the first real song I wrote,'' she said. It was aimed at a math teacher who gave her a hard time and sums up Betty's need to be in control and to win. She later ran into the teacher, who asked how she as doing. ``I said I had just received my 10,000 pounds ($20,000) bonus and it made him mad,'' she said. ``I think I show people that a 20-year-old girl with hardly any academic qualifications can be successful. I really wanted to show my teacher. I think he is really pleased for me now. ``Looking back at school, what I did was wrong. I should have studied. But in a way I'm glad I didn't because I wouldn't be doing what I do now.'' Betty Boo's videos reflect her style, sort of a B-movie version of ``Barbarella.'' ``I like the way they did their makeup in the '60s, I like the clothes. They were simple, quite sexy and raunchy, but it still had a hard-edged appeal. It's really tough, like the Emma Peel stuff,'' she said, referring to Diana Rigg's karate-kicking role in ``The Avengers.'' All this toughness is her revenge for growing up as an outsider. ``A lot of people can't tell whether I'm half white or half black, can't tell whether I'm half Puerto Rican or half Japanese, or half this or that. I used to lie. I used to say I was white so I could fit in. Afterwards I was really proud of my looks. I used to see models who looked more like me than the common girls who criticized me.'' Betty Boo is recording her second album and hopes to tour in 1992 with a Hollywood musical-style live show. And she's coping with the stresses of success. ``Being in this business makes me very moody and determined. I want things to be done and I can get very stroppy if they are not done. I can see why Madonna is the way she is. I am going through what she went through 10 years ago. I am quite frightened it will change me.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Words and Pictures in Black and White
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A woman slumped in a phone booth, crying. A cheap motel. The rotting door of an outdoor toilet. This is Carver Country, Raymond Carver Country, stories and poems set in the Pacific Northwest that make ``Twin Peaks'' seem as threatening as ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.'' Couples drink and fight. A man grovels at the knees of his ex-wife. Furniture is sold on the front lawn. ``A little autobiography and a lot of imagination are best,'' Carver once wrote. These bleak images were based on real places and real people. He grew up working class in Yakima, Wash., and wrote about it even when he could afford to live elsewhere. He was a long-time drunk who later composed tough-love stories. ``Carver Country'' (Scribners, $35) collects photographs of the late writer's friends and family and of Yakima and other places he lived. The pictures, fittingly, are in black and white. Some of them are pretty, shots of water and open fields, but the majority show seedy bars, rundown buildings and faces that stare instead of smile. ``He was, from the start, an image-maker,'' Carver's wife, author-poet Tess Gallagher, recalled in a interview. ``That would correspond to writing photographically. He would zero in on some precise detail.'' ``Color doesn't render ideas very well,'' photographer Bob Adelman insisted during a phone interview. ``I think of the broken door in this motel Ray sent me to. God knows what it would look like in color. Or the broken saws in the factory his father worked - they're strong images of things not working out.'' In 1984, Life magazine thought the author might win the Pulitzer Prize and assigned Adelman to spend a couple of months with him. William Kennedy won, but Adelman came up with another project: combine pictures of Carver and the people and places he had known with the writing they helped inspire. Carver died of cancer at age 50 in 1988, but Adelman continued, taking several photographs last year. ``Because Ray's descriptions were often minimal, it was a great opportunity for photographs,'' Adelman said. ``Most of the pictures were based on real things in his stories. You kind of learned what he was familiar with and where his imagination took off from.'' Gallagher, who contributes an introduction to the book, didn't like the title at first. It seemed smug, condescending, a way of taking a vast and complex body of work and reducing it to a catch phrase. But she warmed to it. Like the best of Carver's stories, it was simple, but not simplistic. ``Carver Country'' is a place, but it's also a state of mind, a sense of holding on against bad luck, a resignation to living with debts that no one could possibly expect to pay. His earlier stories were the strong, silent type: flat on the surface, full of mystery and terror underneath. In ``Why, Honey?'' a woman is surprised to learn her son, ``a good boy,'' set off firecrackers in a girl's ears. The eerie ``So Much Water, So Close to Home'' tells of a man who finds a mutiliated body in the river and takes his time letting anybody know what happened. Carver wasn't trying to write ``Who killed Laura Palmer'' thrillers. Mysteries remained mysteries. Important questions were left unanswered, perhaps because the author himself didn't know how to resolve them. ``I met him at this writers conference in Dallas in the 1977,'' Gallagher recalled. ``I had gone home with his books and I was reading aloud one of the stories to my sister. She said, `I don't know what happens at the end of that story, call him up.' ``So I decided I'd call him up. I called him up and said, `We're not satisfied with this story; what is going on here?' He said, `I'm not going to tell you any more.''' But Carver changed, his luck changed. He had nearly died from alcohol; in the mid-1970s, he was suffering from blackouts and depression and was hospitalized several times. Living alone, his first marriage destroyed, Carver joined Alcoholics Anonymous in 1977 and finally stopped drinking. Gratified just to be writing again, he was eager to fill in the blanks. ``Cathedral,'' his acclaimed collection of stories, was published in 1984 and people started talking. In ``Where I'm Callng From,'' two recovering alcoholics comfort each other on the front porch of a drying-out facility. In the title story, two men, one of them blind, sketch a cathedral together. ``His fingers rode my fingers as my hand went over the paper,'' the man who sees explains. ``It was like nothing else in my life up to now.'' ``A Small, Good Thing'' was the peak, the story of a young couple's heartbreaking trip through Carver Country and the lonely baker who gives them hope for a way out. Gallagher received a letter from a woman who had read it on a plane and burst out crying. With the success of ``Cathedral,'' Carver returned to his first love, poetry. He was living with Gallagher and writing more beautifully than ever, but his health broke down. By 1988, he had developed tumors in his brain and in his lungs. He died that August. ``Don't weep for me,'' Carver wrote in ``Gravy,'' one of his last poems, ``I've had 10 years longer than I or anyone expected. Pure gravy. And don't forget it.'' ``All of us who knew Ray are still bumping into walls, trying to get on with our lives,'' said Gallagher, who had married Carver in his last June. ``The feeling has been if you have tough times, tough luck,'' she said. ``If things are rough, you must have deserved it; you didn't work hard enough. He made the educated segment aware that these people had feelings and the dimensions of their suffering became real and palpable.''

DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Lost Job Means New Career for Joe Diffie
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It took the closing of an Oklahoma foundry to get singer Joe Diffie into the country music business. He had long dreamed of having a career in music, and when he was laid off in 1986, he decided to move to Nashville and pursue one. The twist of fate paid off. Diffie's first record, ``Home,'' was a No. 1 hit in November. ``Seeing it come to fruition is very gratifying,'' the 31-year-old performer said in an interview during his third day back in Nashville after a whirlwind, five-week tour of one-nighters. Diffie had been working at the foundry in Duncan, Okla., running a core machine, when he lost his job and his $1,700-a-month salary. ``I never had any hair left on my arms; it was always singed off,'' he recalled about the job. ``I always had burns all over me. I detested every second of the job. I didn't like any aspect of it except the people there. ``It was a blessing in disguise when it shut down. If it hadn't, I'd probably still be there or some place like it.'' After reaching Nashville, he took a job for 1{ years in the shipping and receiving department at the Gibson Guitar factory. ``Home'' spent six weeks in the Top 10 on the country music popularity charts, faring better than tunes by more established singers such as Anne Murray and Eddie Rabbitt. The wistful song is about the values of home life: ``A swimming hole and fishing pole and the feel of the muddy road between my toes ... ``A back yard swing where I wuld sit and mom would sing `Amazing Grace' while she hung out the clothes ... ``An easy chair with my daddy there and the smell of Sunday supper on the stove ...'' Diffie said the song stirred strong emotions. ``I think everybody related to it, regardless of whether they were raised in the country or city, because everybody has a home in their memory. When I first heard it, I got a lump in my throat. It brings back a feeling of when you were younger, safe and secure without any worries and no problems. ``It was a sweet song but not too syrupy.'' The tune is on his first album, ``A Thousand Winding Roads,'' on Epic Records. The LP is a mixture of ballads and up-tempo songs performed in a style described by Billboard Magazine as ``Randy Travis with a Merle Haggard catch to his voice.'' His second single released from the album is ``If You Want Me To,'' a traditional country weeper about a man offering to leave his lover if that's what she wants. Another cut on the LP, ``There Goes the Neighborhood,'' is a ballad about marriages dissolving. The cut ``Almost Home'' is about the decline of an aging parent. Diffie, who co-wrote four of the songs on the album, says he's taken advantage of a new era in country music. ``There's been a changing of the guard in country music: the listeners, the artists, the radio stations and the people producing the records,'' he said. ``The songs are getting better and better with the new songwriters coming in. That's not to say the old ones are bad. But it's almost like country music has got a little edge to it now. ``Some of the more sensitive matters are being touched upon.'' Diffie is a native of the Duncan area and spent much of his life there. His father had a huge collection of country music and his parents instilled in him a love of the music. He remembers singing ``Amazing Grace,'' ``You Are My Sunshine'' and ``Peace in the Valley'' with his two sisters while they traveled in the family pickup truck. He briefly attended Cameron University in Oklahoma and eyed a career as a heart surgeon or chiropractor, but he was more interested in music. He has a six-piece band and a fan club with the catchy name ``Diffie Cult.'' Keeping things in the family, his mother is its president.
