DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Riot police club left-wing demonstrators in a picturesque Rome piazza as two Americans flee. It is the height of the years of political violence in Italy, brought to life more than a decade later in a new film by director John Frankenheimer. ``Year of the Gun'' stars Andrew McCarthy, Sharon Stone and Valerie Golino in a thriller about a journalist who becomes involved in a political maelstrom. Apart from the interiors, which were shot at Rome's Cinecitta studios, most scenes in the ``Year of the Gun'' were filmed in the piazzas and alleys of the Eternal City. The new film is based on Michael Mewshaw's book of the same title. Frankenheimer has brought other books to the screen, including Thomas Gladdis' ``Birdman of Alcatraz,'' Fletcher Kenbel's ``Seven Days in May'' and Richard Condon's ``The Manchurian Candidate.'' For Mewshaw, Rome is the principle character of the novel. ``The political background, the journalistic process and the interaction between the different characters and Rome form the action line,'' he said. ``Given that Rome is such a source of wonder, the movie has the potential to portray its seductive charm and visual beauty.'' The $15 million film is expected to reach theaters in August. ---= PALM SPRINGS, Calif. (AP) - The Palm Springs International Film Festival will screen 22 movies during its second annual event on Jan. 9-13. The list of international films - including titles from Europe, Japan, China and New Zealand - includes the world premiere of ``Delusion,'' a black comedy-thriller by American director Carl Colpaert. Five films are being submitted as their home country's official entry for an Academy Award nomination as best foreign language film: the Soviet Union's ``Taxi Blues,'' China's ``Ju Dou,'' Italy's ``Open Doors,'' Austria's ``Requiem for Dominic'' and Hungary's ``Diary for My Father and Mother.'' The 1991 Film Festival, which will also present documentaries and student films, will screen its films at five theaters in Palm Springs. Many of the movies, including ``Ju Dou'' and ``Taxi Blues,'' showed last year at other film festivals and have been in limited release in art houses. --- RUIDOSO, N.M. (AP) - Five Soviet artists will exhibit their works at the Second Annual Hubbard Art Award for Excellence competition to be held in June. They will be joined by 48 Americans who are widely considered to be among the finest representational artists in this country. Works created for the 1990 Hubbard Art Award are currently on exhibit in Moscow. The 40 works displayed are by prominent American painters and sculptors working in realism. This cultural exchange was initiated by Fort Worth businessman R.D. Hubbard, founder of the Hubbard Art Award. The $250,000 prize, which is the largest given in the art world, was created to recognize excellence in American representational art.

The government's chief economic forecasting gauge dropped again in November for the fifth consecutive monthly decline, the government said in a report that offered little hope the slumping economy would recover soon. The 1.2 percent plunge in the Commerce Department's Index of Leading Economic Indicators, reported Friday, followed an even worse 1.3 percent drop in October. That decline was the worst since November 1987. The steep drop follows a spate of gloomy economic news for the month and was seen as a sign the economy would continue to deteriorate. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Cash-strapped Pan Am said it has had no word from TWA owner Carl Icahn on whether his takeover proposal still stands and whether the ouster of Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett was a condition for the deal. Unidentified sources quoted in Friday's editions of the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times said Plaskett's removal was on a list of terms attached to a proposed merger of the two carriers. Officials at Trans World Airlines' suburban Mount Kisco, N.Y., offices did not return several phone calls seeking confirmation of that caveat. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Fees earned on Wall Street for underwriting corporate stocks and bonds plunged in 1990 to a six-year low, providing further statistical evidence that the booming 1980s have died. Investment banking fees from new issues of stocks and bonds plunged 38 percent to $1.93 billion from $3.09 billion in 1989, Securities Data Co. reported Friday. Combined with a sharp drop in other critical investment banking activity and thousands of layoffs, analysts said the figures signal losses at many securities firms for the year. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Japan's largest electrical company closed its $6.6 billion purchase of entertainment colossus MCA Inc., completing the largest Japanese acquisition of an American firm. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. acquired about 77.7 million shares of MCA stock at $66 per share, Matsushita said in a statement Saturday. Its acquisitions amount to about 97 percent of outstanding MCA shares. U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia on Friday rejected an emergency request by Go-Video Inc. to block consummation of the deal. Go-Video sought a postponement until a formal antitrust challenge could be mounted. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - ``Keating Five'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. is asking the Treasury Department to study the condition of the insurance industry, warning that the nation cannot afford to ignore the development of problems similar to the savings and loan debacle. Riegle, D-Mich., who chairs the Senate Banking Committee asked the Treasury Department to examine whether insurance companies have made too many risky investments and to estimate the risk to the economy of a major insurance company failure. Riegle made the requests in a letter dated Dec. 20 and released Thursday. --- PARIS (AP) - The French government has approved plans by Barclays Bank of Britain to acquire Europeenne de Banque for 1.5 billion francs, or $300 million, bank officials said in a joint release. The British banking group will acquire 51 percent of Europeenne de Banque initially and purchase the remaining 49 percent early next year, Friday's statement said. The acquisition will give Barclays some prestigious real estate in central Paris, 16 branch offices throughout France and a financial distribution network through Europeenne de Banque's subsidiary Lafitte Investissement. --- SEOUL, South Korea (AP) - Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a $535 million (U.S.) contract to build a nuclear power plant for Korea Electric Power Corp. Friday's deal is a coup for the Canadian government and caps more than 10 years of sales efforts by its Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd., or AECL. It will be the second Canadian reactor built in Korea. --- WHEELING, W.Va. (AP) - Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. says it will take a $170 million one-time charge against fourth-quarter earnings to adjust for retiree health benefits. Wheeling-Pitt said Friday the charge was required to show the company's expectations of medical costs and to reflect accounting changes. The Financial Accounting Standards Board recently approved a new rule, effective in 1993, that requires companies to subtract from earnings a portion of the costs of benefits they have promised to future retirees. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Orion Pictures Corp. agreed to give its majority shareholder a cut of profits from the movie ``Mermaids'' in return for a $23 million investment. Shareholder John W. Kluge and his partner Stuart Subotnick, executive vice president of Kluge's Metromedia Co., will receive up to 64 percent of certain profits from the movie, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The romantic comedy starring Cher and Winona Ryder grossed $8.3 million over the Christmas holiday weekend. ---

The stock market finished mixed Friday in a session dominated by worries about the prospective length and severity of the economic slump. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a 3.71 gain at 2,629.21. Bonds fell. The dollar dropped sharply. Gold rose strongly. Crude oil futures rallied, grains and soybeans fell, orange juice retreated and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: New Year Brings Higher Gas Taxes, Recycling, Laws on Ethics and Guns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Longer version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: At gasoline pumps and city dumps, new state laws take effect Jan. 1, raising taxes on motorists in California, Delaware, Florida and Massachusetts and imposing mandatory recycling in Connecticut and Wisconsin. A higher income tax, expected to generate $1.3 billion, goes into effect in New Jersey. Democratic Gov. Jim Florio says the highly unpopular plan will give homeowners property tax relief and address imbalances in rich and poor school districts. Strapped states continue to search for revenue. Washington state is imposing a $10 a pack penalty on untaxed cigarettes, often illegally bought by non-Indians on Indian reservations. Delaware is raising its cigarette taxes 5 cents a pack. Gasoline taxes go up 4 cents in Massachusetts and Florida, 3 cents in Delaware, but only 1 cent in California, which prefers the gradual pain of adding a penny each year through 1994. Just a month ago, the federal government got a nickel-a-gallon gas tax increase, and Congress has raised alcohol and cigarette taxes nationwide effective Jan. 1. To find a tax going down, you'd have to go to Indiana, where drivers were registering their vehicles out of state to avoid excise taxes. That tax will be cut from $413 to $289 for the first year on a $15,000 car. A Florida law bans state legislators and some 30,000 other public officials from soliciting or accepting any gift over $100 from a lobbyist, a lobbyist's employer or a political action committee. On the environmental front, Connecticut is telling residents and businesses to separate corrugated cardboard, newspapers, office paper, glass and metal food containers, leaves, scrap metal, storage batteries and waste oil for recycling. Wisconsin is phasing in mandatory recycling with a ban on disposing of car batteries, waste oil or major appliances in landfills or incinerators. Indiana is requiring stores that sell automotive batteries to accept customers' used batteries for recycling. Michigan is attacking the problem of tire dumps, which have been sites of major fires and Asian Tiger mosquito infestations. The law will require scrap tire haulers and collection sites to register with the state. Tennessee is imposing a $250 fine for anyone releasing more than 24 balloons of the non-biodegradable kind that choke sea animals. Some lawmakers tried to poke holes in the measure by noting that a crowd in the University of Tennessee's 95,000-seat football stadium could still legally release about 2.3 million balloons. Shoppers in Maine can go to malls and large stores on Sunday year-round as a result of an initiative approved by voters in November. The old ``blue law'' had so many loopholes that opponents attacked its fairness.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways, KLM and Sabena Abandon Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: British Airways PLC, KLM Royal Dutch Airways and Belgium's Sabena World Airways announced Monday they are scrapping their plans jointly to form a regional airline with a hub in Brussels. The three carriers in a joint news release cited ``practical difficulties involved in implementing the original objectives.'' A KLM spokesman acknowledged that uncertainty over obtaining European Community regulatory approval was a factor. The three airlines had intended to develop their venture into a regional European airline, using Brussels' Zaventem airport as the center of a hub-and-spoke route network linking 75 cities throughout Europe. British Airways specified in its own news release that ``Sabena SA has made it clear that the group requires recapitalization and reorganization of a kind which the present minority investments agreed by British Airways and KLM could not solve.'' Under the original terms of the deal, British Airways and KLM each had agreed to buy a 20 percent stake in the joint venture for about $66 million apiece. The Belgian-government controlled Sabena SA was to have held the remaining 60 percent. Current plans call for Sabena to take back the shares held by British Airways and KLM. The capital already invested is being converted into a loan for repayment on Dec. 31, 1991, the airlines said. British Airways said it already had contributed 17 million pounds, or $33 million. In Amsterdam, KLM spokesman Peter Wellhuner said many factors led to the decision. In addition to high fuel costs, he cited the uncertainty of regulatory approval. ``We have had ample consultation with the European Commission on this case and up until now we haven't had any certainty of its approval,'' Wellhuner said. The European Commission, which safeguards competition, decided in June that the deal could hurt competition at the Brussels airport, and offered to negotiate a settlement. The airlines refused, and instead prepared legal arguments supporting the arrangement. The British government cleared the deal in July, finding that travelers would benefit from the hub the airlines wanted to create. British Airways said the decision to scrap the joint venture wouldn't result in any capital loss for the company.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Company Completes Purchase Of MCA
DOC.TEXT: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd. has closed its $6.6 billion purchase of entertainment giant MCA Inc., completing the largest Japanese acquisition of a U.S. company. Matsushita, Japan's largest electronics company, said it acquired about 97 percent of MCA's outstanding shares for $66 a share, Matsushita said in a statement released Saturday. MCA shareholders also are entitled to stock in a newly-created company MCA is spinning off that will own is WWOR television station in Secaucus, N.J. Federal regulations prohibit foreign companies from owning a U.S. television station. MCA owns Universal Studios, maker of such films as ``E.T. the Extra-Terrestial'' and ``Jaws.'' It also produces television series and holds recording contracts with such artists as Elton John and Guns N' Roses. MCA shareholders filed a lawsuit to block the sale but a federal judge in Los Angeles rejected the bid Friday. U.S. District Judge Manuel Real did not dismiss the suit, but said there was insufficient evidence presented to block the deal. In a separate matter, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia denied a last-minute motion Friday in an antitrust suit filed by Go-Video Inc., maker of dual deck VCRs. Matsushita products are sold in the United States through such brand names as Panasonic, Technics and Quasar.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended lower in an abbreviated session Monday on London's Stock Exchange. The market closed about four hours earlier than normal on New Year's Eve. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 16.9 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,143.5. For the year, the 100-share index fell 279.2 points, or 11.5 percent from its 1989 closing level of 2,422.7. Closing volume was 129.9 million shares. The market has been plagued with worries about Britain's economic downturn, and the country's high interest rates which currently stand at about 14 percent. In recent months, the market also has been nervous about the Gulf crisis. These concerns have made investors shy away from the market, and business, as a result, has been persistently slow. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 11.5 points from Friday to end the year at 1,673.7. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 7.21 points from Friday to close at 1,137.75.

DOC.HEAD: BellSouth to Acquire Graphic Scanning For $180 Million
DOC.TEXT: BellSouth Enterprises has agreed to acquire Graphic Scanning Corp., a New Jersey-based cellular telephone and paging service provider, for $180 million, the two companies announced Monday. BellSouth, which signed a definitive agreement to pay $5.50 for each of the 32.4 million outstanding shares of Graphic stock, said the deal is expected to close in mid-1991. It is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval. Atlanta-based BellSouth said the acquisition would enhance its standing as an international provider of wireless telecommunications services. Graphic, based in Teaneck, N.J., operates in the United States and the United Kingdom. The Graphic deal will increase BellSouth's paging business to more than 1.25 million pagers worldwide. In a related action, BellSouth said it had entered into a revolving credit agreement with Cellular Mobile Systems of Indiana Inc. under which BellSouth will make secured loans of up to $60 million to refinance existing debt and for general corporate purposes. CMS is the Graphic Scanning subsidiary which is BellSouth's partner in the Indiana Telephone Co., a non-wireline cellular carrier. As part of the loan transaction, BellSouth will assume operational control of ITC.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 370.31 down 0.89 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Data General Drops Agreement With Japanese Firm
DOC.TEXT: Troubled Data General Corp. has dropped a product development agreement with Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp., company officials said today. The agreement with NTT to build high-speed hubs for private data communications networks was announced in 1987. The communications systems were to link voice, data and computers in large, private communications networks such as those used by corporations and universities. NTT executives said then that the company planned to buy about $130 million of equipment to be developed by Data General. The purchases were to be made in a five-year period beginning in 1989. But the project was scrapped after research showed there was not a strong market in Japan for such systems, said Jim Dunlap, a spokesman for Data General. ``As a result of the review of the market place, and the potential for the product, Data General and NTT reached a mutual agreement to drop the plan,'' Dunlap said. Barry Willman, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein in New York, attributed the dropped deal to Data General's mounting financial pressures, a shift in the computer market and the firm's increased emphasis on its Aviion workstations. ``The program had been under review for awhile,'' Willman said. ``It had encountered delays during the years, and with Data General's continuing financial pressures there came a time when a prudent decision was made to terminate the project.'' Data General has not had a profitable year since 1985, when its employment peaked at 17,700. Since then the firm has suffered a string of losses and employment has continued to decline. Dunlap said the firm had eliminated about 2,300 jobs in 1990 through cuts and attrition. The company announced in August that more than 2,000 workers would be laid off. Data General lost $139 million in its most recent fiscal year. Revenues were $1.22 billion, compared with $1.31 billion the year before. Analysts say the minicomputer slump has acted as a drag on earnings and hampered the company's efforts to become profitable.

DOC.HEAD: Star-Ledger Raises Cover Price of Daily Editions
DOC.TEXT: The Star-Ledger boosted the cover price of its daily editions on Monday by a dime to 25 cents. The increase is the first for the state's largest newspaper since 1980, when it was raised to 15 cents from 10 cents. The newspaper attributed the increase to sharply escalating costs, compounded by reduced advertising revenues. The price of the Sunday Star-Ledger rose to 50 cents from 35 cents on Oct. 28.

DOC.HEAD: USG Refinancing Debt, Selling Subsidiary in Construction Downturn
DOC.TEXT: USG Corp., one of the nation's largest building products manufacturers, said today it is postponing debt payments and selling a major subsidiary because of the declining construction industry. The company said its major bank lenders have agreed to cooperate in the refinancing plan. In the interim, USG will defer payments of $105 million in principal due today to its senior lending banks. It also will not make interest payments on $40 million in loans from subordinated bondholders. The company said it is not making these payments in order to strengthen its cash position so that it can pay its trade and operating expenses during the financial restructuring. It said it also is seeking an equity investor. The plan also includes the proposed sale of DAP Inc., a producer of caulks and other specialty chemical products. DAP had annual sales of $186 million in 1989, with an operating profit of $12 million. For the first nine months of 1990, USG lost $2 million while sales skidded 6 percent, to $1.6 billion from $1.7 billion. ``The decision to begin financial restructuring now, rather than simply seeking short-term amendments to our bank loan covenants, is dictated by the continuing slowdown in construction markets,'' said USG Chairman Eugene B. Connolly.

DOC.HEAD: Government Investigating Alleged Baby Formula Price Fixing
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with reaction and background. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities subpoenaed the records of the nation's biggest baby formula manufacturers after state welfare officials and consumer advocates made allegations of price fixing, representatives of one of the companies and a professional association said today. Officers of Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories and the American Academy of Pediatrics said their records were subpoenaed several weeks ago and they either had responded or were doing so. Debbie Feinstein, assistant to the director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Competition, said the bureau began the investigation late in May, at about the time its director, Kevin J. Arquit, testified before a Senate subcommittee on the issue. Ms. Feinstein said she could not confirm that subpoenas had been issued. ``This is a top-priority, front-burner investigation,'' Arquit told The New York Times. He said authorities have not concluded that price fixing occurred. The companies denied the allegations. The Times reported that records were subpoenaed from: Ross Laboratories, a division of Abbott Laboratories; the Mead-Johnson Nutritional Group, a division of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.; Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corp.; the Carnation Co., a subsidiary of Nestle S.A.; and the Gerber Products Co. The American Academy of Pediatrics was also subpoenaed, it said. Ross, Mead-Johnson and Wyeth-Ayerst account for about 95 percent of all baby formula marketed in the United States, while Carnation and Gerber account for about 5 percent, the newspaper said. The domestic market is worth about $1.3 billion a year, it said. Wyeth-Ayerst spokeswoman Audrey Ashby said the company received the FTC subpoena in September and has begun turning over the requested documents. ``We set prices independently and compete vigorously and independently in all aspects of the infant formula business,'' Ms. Ashby said. She said she had no further information on the investigation. Efforts to get comment from other companies were not immediately successful. There was no answer this morning at Bristol-Myers Squibb, and a woman answering the telephone at Gerber Products Co. in Fremont, Mich., said all corporate offices are closed until Wednesday. In Washington, Antoinette Parisi Eaton, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, confirmed that records of the academy, mainly its policy statements in opposition to infant formula advertising, had been subpoenaed. She said the academy responded to the subpoena about six weeks ago. ``Our position has been that we are speaking out and have an obligation to speak out in the best interests of the public health of infants in this country,'' Ms. Eaton said. ``Our concern is that breast feeding will be reduced by infant formula advertising. Breast feeding rates in this country are already going down.'' Ms. Feinstein said, ``We are not taking a position on whether or not advertising is good or bad or infant formula is good or bad, but the things we have heard are that infant formula is a very concentrated industry and one of the reasons it might be hard for people to enter is because there is not any advertising.'' At a hearing held by the antitrust subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee in May, Democratic Sens. Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio and Patrick Leahy of Vermont charged that three companies used nearly total control of the infant formula market to keep prices high and rebates to state-run programs for poor children low. The companies named were Mead Johnson, Ross Laboratories and Wyeth Laboratories. Industry officials said their prices were fair. Infant formula is a major ingredient in food packages given to low-income families who qualify for the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children. The program serves about 4.4 million people a month and accounts for one-third of the infant formula sold in the United States. The program's funds are limited and higher costs mean fewer people benefit, Arquit said. Dennis H. Bach of Iowa, who heads the National Association of WIC directors, said baby formula prices ``have seemed to go up in lock step over the last 10 years.'' Betsy Clarke, director of the WIC program in Oregon, said prices have tripled during the past 15 years, with different companies raising prices by the same amounts within days of each other. Current retail prices range from $1.80 to $2.30 for a 13-ounce can of concentrated formula.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Higher, Wheat and Corn Steady
DOC.TEXT: Grains closed lower and soybeans were higher Monday at the close of an abbreviated pre-holiday session on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans bounced back from sharp losses on Friday, when futures prices dipped to new contract lows, reflecting expectations for heavy deliveries this week. The complex posted moderate gains after commercial firms reported an unexpectedly low number of deliveries, said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president for grains for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``There really was not much news or anything of consequence except that deliveries were much lighter than expected,'' Lespinasse said. Wheat gained on early support from soybeans and word that the U.S. Agriculture Department is subsidizing some wheat purchases. It later fell, however, amid a flurry of professional selling. Corn had some support from wheat and soybeans but later was weighed down by light export demand. Wheat futures prices closed 2 cents to 1\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $2.60{ a bushel; corn futures were 1\ cents lower to unchanged with March at $2.32 a bushel, oats were } cent to { cent lower with March at $1.12 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 4{ cents higher with January at $5.61{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures closed mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. A weak tone in the beef industry was the cause of sluggish trading. Pork futures traders were awaiting this weekend's release of the government's quarterly hogs and pigs report. Cattle futures prices were .07 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 77.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .02 cent lower with January at 89.15 cents a pound; hogs were .30 cent lower to unchanged with February at 49.02 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to .27 cent lower with February at 63.00 cents a pound.

DOC.NOTE: For Release Sunday Jan. 6 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Welfare State's Future Questioned As Recession Looms
Graphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: To some, the welfare systems in northern Europe are the world's most humane. To others, they're a wasteful gravy train, supporting thousands of people who could work if they had to. Now, an economic downturn is threatening the generous systems and some people living off them will feel the pinch. ---

Some of Northern Europe's welfare states wonder how to keep their cradle-to-grave safety nets from fraying in the impending recession. In the post-World War II boom years, the Scandinavian countries, the Netherlands and West Germany introduced programs that spend up to a quarter of the gross national product on welfare. Welfare spending now is outstripping the industrial growth that was supposed to pay the bill. With growth slowing in many European countries, some governments are considering cutbacks. With less money available for welfare, government officials complain more loudly about people abusing the system. Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers says his nation's welfare system, which will cost the government 132.3 billion guilders ($79.6 billion) in 1991, is out of hand. In a recent report, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, citing Holland's high income taxes and generous welfare benefits, concluded that incentives to work are low. The nation has an 11 percent unemployment rate. Dutch authorities recently failed to lure jobless Amsterdam residents to the understaffed flower industry, even after the government offered a car for every four workers to use for commuting, as well as personal use. Denmark spends 40 percent of its budget on the 1.4 million people - 28 percent of the population - who live on welfare. The center-right coalition government of Prime Minister Poul Schlueter hopes it can reduce welfare dependency by stimulating private industry. Denmark has 20,000 people under 40 years of age getting permanent government pensions of 3,709 kroner ($662) a month because of drug or alcohol problems. In Europe, welfare helps the employed as well as the jobless. The system commonly includes free medical insurance, sick pay, disability and old age pensions, and child-care and unemployment benefits. In Sweden, parents can qualify for benefits for taking time off to nurse a sick child. ``The basic thing is that everyone should have basic opportunities to ... take part in all activities within our society,'' said Annchristen Filipson of the Swedish Social Affairs Ministry. Scandinavian taxpayers can hardly be expected to dig deeper in their pockets to pay a greater share of the welfare costs. Their tax rates of more than 50 percent already are highest in the industrialized world. Last October, Sweden's ruling Social Democratic Party made the first cuts ever in a social welfare system now costing 251.39 billion kronor ($45.13 billion), just over one-fifth of the GNP. The government is expected to cut 15 billion kronor ($2.69 billion dollars) from the welfare budget in 1991. The government is also planning to cut sick pay rates from 100 percent to 75 percent of a worker's salary for the first three days in an effort to discourage malingering. Workers take an average 25 days of sick leave a year. The welfare programs are usually funded by taxes paid by employers and employees, and some are getting fed up. Ove Danemar of the Swedish Employers' Federation criticized ``the whole system'' because ``it stimulates people to work less and to take more leisure time. ``The private sector can't bear it any longer,'' he said. ``It's no longer consistent with a modern economy.'' Critics say many of the benefits were begun in good faith but have ended up being abused. During more favorable economic times, the abuse was widely tolerated. But with the Continent entering a recession, there is more clamping down on wasteful spending. Lubbers has vowed to curb Holland's Unsuitability for Work Act, under which nearly 900,000 people get life-long disability pensions of up to 70 percent of their last-earned pay. In the late 1970s, some companies used it by dismissing unproductive employees, passing the social cost on to the government. About one-third of the program's beneficiaries claim psychological reasons for being unable to work. In a recent speech, Lubbers said wryly: ``Looking at the statistics ... one has to admit that ours is a sick nation.'' This spring, the Dutch government is expected to make deep cuts in the housing, education and cultural subsidies that complement the welfare handouts, themselves equal to at least 70 percent of the minimum wage. It has borrowed heavily and diverted money from other programs to cover welfare costs. Only Germany is making large welfare increases, to pay millions of former East Germans who are unemployed. Norway is slightly expanding its 125.8 billion kroner ($21 billion) welfare system, on which almost a quarter of the population depends in some form or other. The Labor government has added about one billion kroner ($166 million) to the bill since coming into office last month and even the right-leaning opposition Progress Party favors the expansion.

DOC.HEAD: No Duty-Free Smokes for Arriving Passengers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figure in 7th graf, `Barred previously ...,' is U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A new front in Singapore's war on smoking opens New Year's Day when duty-free cigarettes will no longer be sold to passengers arriving at the airport. Covering foreign visitors as well as citizens, the ban is part of a campaign to make this island of 2.7 million people a nation of non-smokers. It is also part of a growing drive in Asia against tobacco companies, which have been accused of targeting women and children. Some U.S. tobacco companies, facing declining domestic sales, have stepped up efforts to increase exports to the region. No breakdown was available on cigarette sales to passengers arriving at Changi Airport since the same outlets also serve passengers changing flights. Duty-free cigarettes sold aboard incoming aircraft are not affected, nor those bought by passengers bound for overseas. As a blow against tobacco, the ban is not as sweeping as many past moves in Singapore, which already has the region's toughest controls. Smoking already is barred in restaurants, supermarkets, department stores, museums, pool halls, public bathrooms, libraries, indoor sports arenas and other public halls, cinemas, fast-food outlets, taxis, buses, subways, government offices, hospitals and clinics. Violators face a $289 fine. Smoking is is frowned upon but not yet against the law in private offices and clubs. Smokers may light up in bars, but only during hours in which no food is served. Singapore Airlines, which barred smoking on short flights in 1988, extended the ban in October to all regional flights of four hours or less. Tobacco advertising has been prohibited in Singapore media since 1970. Another law last New Year's Day barred the display of point-of-sale ads for cigarettes in stores. Cigarette names and trademarks also are banned from motor vehicles, souvenirs and gifts. Free cigarette samples are illegal and tobacco products cannot be given as prizes in lotteries or other contests. Manufacturers must rotate four different health warnings on their packs quarterly: ``Smoking causes heart disease,'' ``Smoking causes cancer,'' ``Smoking damages your lungs'' and ``Smoking harms those around us.'' ``The most important strategy against lung cancer is avoidance of smoking,'' Health Minister Yeo Cheow Tong said recently in announcing the duty-free sales curb. The lung cancer incidence rate increased from 18 cases per 100,000 people in 1972 to about 30 per 100,000 in 1987, he said. Smokers are believed to comprise only 13.6 percent of the population age 15 and above. But health experts were dismayed to discover an increase recently in the number of smokers between ages 15 and 19. Tobacco companies joined the campaign this year to discourage youngsters from smoking. ``We are not here to promote smoking to children but to provide the choice to adults who want to smoke,'' said Richard Png, executive director of the Tobacco Manufacturers and Importers Association. Posters bearing the message ``Children, don't smoke'' were distributed to 8,000 retail outlets. Other nations in the region also have cracked down on smoking. Indonesia last month banned smoking in primary and secondary schools. Hong Kong stopped televised cigarette ads Dec. 1. Hong Kong's legislature has urged the government to ban children under the age of 15 from smoking in restaurants. Malaysian Airlines, Philippine Airlines and Pakistan International Airlines forbid smoking on domestic flights. The World Health Organization says nine of the 10 countries where smoking is most widespread are in the Asia-Pacific region. It warned that more women and young people are lighting up in this area despite the spread of lung cancer and other tobacco-related diseases. Papua New Guinea, where 85 percent of men and 80 percent of women smoke, tops the WHO list. The others are Fiji, Nepal, the Philippines, Indonesia, Bangladesh, South Korea, Japan and China.

The stock market pulled back slightly today in a quiet final session of an uninspired year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 123.99 points from last New Year's through Friday's close, slipped 6.19 to 2,623.02 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 9 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 668 up, 868 down and 448 unchanged. Activity was expected to be light throughout the session in a holiday atmosphere. The markets will be closed on Tuesday for New Year's before starting 1991 on Wednesday. Analysts said traders felt little urgency to make any fresh commitments, pending developments in the weeks ahead on the showdown in the Persian Gulf. Stocks didn't get much benefit from declining interest rates in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the neighborhood of 8.27 percent. Losers among the blue chips included DuPont, down \ at 36{; Ford Motor, down \ at 26{; International Business Machines, down ] at 113, and Exxon, down [ at 51{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .39 to 179.26. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .73 at 303.92. Volume on the Big Board came to 73.32 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Say Gulf-Crisis Costs Eating Up Money
DOC.TEXT: Military costs in the Persian Gulf crisis have outrun Saudi Arabia's extra revenue derived from higher petroleum prices and production, the government said Monday. The kingdom said it was delaying promulgation of its 1991 budget because the uncertainty created by the crisis has made it difficult to project how much revenue it will get from oil. The world's largest oil exporter said the financial burdens it had to bear because of the emergency circumstances create by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of neighboring Kuwait were ``much more'' than the extra oil revenues. Under the 1990 budget, which took effect last Dec. 31, the government revenues were forecast at 118 billion riyals or about $31.4 billion. Expenditures were set at 143 billion riyals or $37.6 billion. The difference of 25 billion riyals was to be covered through issuing government development bonds. In a statement to the official Saudi Press Agency, Information Minister Ali al-Shaer said ``Iraq's flagrant aggression'' on Kuwait and the threats it posed to Saudi territories have led the government to reinforce its military and upgrade services and public utilities. ``The presence of sisterly and friendly forces has also entailed extra spending on the services and infrastructure needed by these forces,'' Shaer said. The statement said the rise of oil prices, which have increased to the $28-$30 a barrel range from less than $22 prior to the crisis, have helped the government's added expenses. During part of October, oil briefly surpassed the $40 a barrel level. However, the increase in expenditures for the Saudis due to the Gulf crisis ``was much more than the increase in petroleum revenues,'' said Shaer, without giving further details. The statement said it was difficult to assess anticipated revenues because of the unpredictability of circumstances that will decide the level of production and prices during the next 12 months. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Saudi oil production has risen to around 8 million barrels a day, from around 5.4 million barrels a day earlier in the year. But Saudi leader King Fahd noted recently that his grade of oil never hit the $40-a-barrel figure in the first two months of the invasion, which was for actively-traded U.S. and North Sea grades of oil. He said his best grades never exceeded $26 a barrel and his heavier crude oil sold for as low as $15 a barrel. Saudi Arabia has agreed tound $8 billion to the costs of the multinational military deployment opposing the Iraqis. Most of that force has come from the United States. Economists at the Bahrain-based Gulf International Bank have calculated that the Gulf crisis has cost Saudi Arabia around $21 billion, compared with extra revenues of $16 billion.

The stock market showed a small loss today in a quiet final session of an uninspired year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 123.99 points from last New Year's through Friday's close, slipped 2.97 to 2,626.24 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders felt little urgency to make any fresh commitments, pending developments in the weeks ahead on the showdown in the Persian Gulf. Stocks didn't get much benefit from declining interest rates in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds rose nearly $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the neighborhood of 8.27 percent. Losers among the blue chips included DuPont, down [ at 36|; Ford Motor, down \ at 26{; International Business Machines, down [ at 113\, and Boeing, down | at 45\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .16 to 179.49. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .21 at 304.86. Volume on the Big Board came to 85.72 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: USG Refinancing Debt, Selling Subsidiary in Construction Downturn
DOC.TEXT: USG Corp. said the anemic construction industry is forcing it to defer debt payments, restructure finances and sell a major subsidiary. The company, one of the nation's largest building products manufacturers, said it would not make a $105 million payment on principal that was due Monday, putting it technically in default and subject to court action by lenders. USG said, however, that major bank lenders have agreed to go along with the restructuring plan while it continues to make interest payments on the $105 million. The company also said it will not make interest payments due Jan. 15 on $40 million worth of bonds. Spokesman Matthew Gonring said officials will be in contact with the major bondholders, but he declined to say if USG has sought assurances that the bondholders will not file bankruptcy petitions against the company. The company said in a statement that it does not intend to file for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. ``An out-of-court restructuring is the best solution ...,'' the company said. The USG announcement reflected a steep downturn in demand for construction of homes and commercial real estate that has gripped much of the country. Sales of new homes, for example, are now at their lowest levels since the 1981-82 recession, with little improvement expected anytime soon. USG lost $2 million during the first nine months of 1990 while sales skidded 6 percent, to $1.6 billion from $1.7 billion. In the past two years, the company has laid off 1,100 workers because of economic difficulties. Additional employees were lost in the sales of subsidiaries. USG said that as part of its restructuring it will offer for sale DAP Inc., a producer of caulks and other specialty hemical products. DAP had annual sales of $186 million in 1989, with an operating profit of $12 million. USG said it also is seeking an investor willing to give the company a major infusion. ``We believe there are a number of investors who might be interested in making an equity investment in the company,'' Gonring said, adding that there have been talks with potential investors. He didn't identify any. The company said its cash position at year-end is ``very strong and that it will pay its trade and operating expenses in a timely manner throughout the restructuring process.'' It said it is not making the loan payments in order to assure liquidity during restructuring, which it expects to complete before the end of 1991. ``The decision to begin financial restructuring now, rather than simply seeking short-term amendments to our bank loan covenants, is dictated by the continuing slowdown in construction markets,'' said USG Chairman Eugene B. Connolly. The company has retained Salomon Brothers and Lazard Freres investment banking firms to help in the restructuring.

DOC.HEAD: Business Execs Top Most Powerful Sports Figure List
DOC.TEXT: His name doesn't show up in the daily box scores, but CBS Inc. Chairman Laurence A. Tisch landed the top spot in one magazine's new listing of the most powerful figures in sport. The Sporting News leaned toward businessmen like Tisch, who has agreed to spend almost $3.9 billion on acquiring the rights to broadcast major sporting events on the CBS Television Network, in assmbling its list. Only three athletes - golfers Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer and basketball standout Michael Jordan - were chosen for the 100-member roster. Ranking second to Tisch was Dick Ebersol, president of NBC Sports, followed by the commissioners of three major professional sports: Paul Tagliabue of the National Football League, Fay Vincent of major league baseball and David Stern of the National Basketball Association. The full list appears in the Jan. 7 issue of the weekly sports publication that goes on newstands on Wednesday. Sporting News said in a statement that the ranking of entrants was determined by the editorial staff. It did not elaborate on the selection process. But Editor John Rawlings was quoted as saying the list ``clearly indicates that the real muscle of sports lies not with the athletes but with the behind the scenes power brokers.'' Under Tisch, CBS has agreed to pay almost $3.9 billion for sports broadcast rights, including $1.06 billion for major league baseball, a similar amount for National Football League games, more than $1.2 billion for college basketball and football and $543 million for the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympic Games. Tisch's competitors at the other networks have argued that CBS offered to pay much more for the broadcast rights than the network could reasonably expect to recover in advertising sales from the programs. CBS has contended that the high-profile sporting events will give it a chance to promote its other shows to a large audience. The company recently announced it lost $55 million after taxes on its first year of baseball and would charge another $115 million against earnings to reflect anticipated losses in the next three years of the baseball contract. ``There's no doubt Tisch's actions have changed the face of sports,'' Rawlings said. ``For better or worse, the acquisition of major broadcast properties by CBS will have a domino effect on the entire sports industry - including athletes, owners, fans, agents, advertisers and all other parties - for years to come,'' he said. He said the effect of higher rights payments is reflected in more revenue for sports owners, bigger salaries for players, steeper ticket prices for fans and rescheduled game tmes to suit television's need for large audiences. Rounding out the top 10 members of the list is Mark McCormack, head of International Management Group, a sports agency and promotion firm; Dennis Swanson, ABC Sports president; Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee; boxing promoter Don King and Donald Dell, founder of the sports management firm ProServ. Only two women appear on the list - No. 29 Ellen Merlo, vice president of marketing services at Philip Morris whose brands Marlboro and Virginia Slims cigarettes and Miller beer are major sports sponsors and advertisers, and No. 31 Anita DeFrantz, president of the Amateur Athletic Foundation of Los Angeles and the first black woman named to the International Olympic Committee. The three athletes on the list have connections to business and sports. Nicklaus, who ranked 61st, is a golf course designer and manufacturer as well as a golfer. Jordan, who placed 79th, has appeared in a number of product commercials for cereal, shoes and fast food. The golfer Palmer, ranked 93rd, is a course designer and entrepreneur.
Stock prices inched ahead today near the close of a sluggish final session of 1990. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up .49 at 2,629.70.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Flat or Lower
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were unchanged to lower in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $10.02 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.52 percent, the same as in the last auction on Dec. 21. Another $10.04 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 6.48 percent, down from 6.57 percent on Dec. 21. The rate on three-month bills was last lower when they sold for 6.51 percent on June 20, 1988. The six-month rate was the lowest since May 2, 1988, when it averaged 6.41 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 6.72 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,835.20 and 6.79 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,670.60. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 6.95 percent last week, down from 6.96 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices End Year Up In Quiet Trading
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices closed higher in quiet trading Monday, while the rate for overnight loans between banks skidded sharply after the Federal Reserve moved to offset a predicted short-term credit crunch. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond rose 11-16 point, or $6.88 per $1,000 in face amount, at closing Monday. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, was 8.24 percent, down from 8.30 percent late Friday. Yields for the 30-year bond posted a slight gain in 1990, ending up about \ percentage point above 1989's closing figure of 7.97 percent. The federal funds rate, the bank overnight loan rate and a closely followed indicator of the Fed's activities, fluctuated throughout the day. Economists attributed the swings to the Fed's injection of funds into the banking system on Thursday and Monday to ease a projected drought in short-term credit. ``The Fed seems to have bent over backwards to provide reserves to the banking system,'' said Douglas McAllister, a bond trader for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The rate fluctuated in a range of 6 percentage points but didn't skyrocket as some economists had expected. It traded around 2 percent late Monday, down from 7{ percent late Friday, according to the Telerate Inc. financial information service. At the end of the year, banks aggressively borrow short-term funds to shore up their balance sheets - a practice known as ``window dressing.'' This sudden surge of banks' short-term borrowing can causes the fed funds rate to jump dramatically based on the simple dynamics of supply and demand. The intense appetite for fed funds pushed the rate to 100 percent briefly Wednesday night, said Carol Stone, senior economist for Nomura Securities International Inc. The Fed's perceived target for the rate is 7 percent. The wild swings didn't surprise bond analysts. ``It is nothing out of the ordinary this time of year to get those wild gyrations,'' said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Traders offered a range of explanations for the rise in bond prices. Some felt the market was correcting itself following a sharp sell-off Friday based on an erroneous report of shots fired in the Persian Gulf. Others felt the bond rallied on news of a European peace initiative in the gulf crisis. But Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities Inc., said that with such light trading, ``I would caution into reading too much into one day's numbers.'' Trading concluded at 3 p.m., earlier than normal because of the New Year's holiday on Tuesday. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 3-16 point to 9-32 point, intermediate maturities rose ] point to 7-16 point and long-term issues were up 17-32 point to 11-16 point, Telerate Inc. reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.16 to 1,184.10. The index fell 4.31 points in 1990. Yields on three-month Treasury bills held at 6.62 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 6.44 percent. Yields on six-month bills were down to 6.71 percent as the discount fell 12 basis point to 6.42 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 6.80 percent as the discount fell 10 basis points to 6.39 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose 1-32 point to 91 9-32. The average yield to maturity held at 7.47 percent, unchanged from Friday. The index is down from the 1989 closing rate of 93 14-32.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Advance in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices closed out a tumultuous year by advancing Monday in light and abbreviated trading dominated once again by concerns about the Middle East. The February contract for light, sweet crude, the benchmark grade of U.S. oil, rose 87 cents to $28.44 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and subsequent months posted similar gains. Monday's session ended early as traders left for the New Year's holiday. Analysts reported the market was preoccupied with the Middle East and the possibility that war could break out if Iraq has not withdrawn from Kuwait before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the U.N. Security Council. Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said the market shrugged off a planned peace initiative by the European Community and focused instead on the ``fast approaching'' deadline. Traders fear that a war in the Middle East would disrupt oil supplies from the area. As tensions in the area have increased in recent months, so have oil prices. On Aug. 1, the day before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, light, sweet crude closed at $21.54 a barrel. It then rocketed $1.57 higher to close at $23.11 on Aug. 2 and began to fluctuate wildly in the following weeks, with price changes of $1 or more becoming the norm. The price of crude peaked at $40.42 a barrel on Oct. 12 before retreating to its current level. Crude oil prices had ended 1989 at $21.82 a barrel Prices for refined products have advanced in response to the gains posted by crude. On Monday, heating oil and gasoline prices also moved higher on technical factors as the January contracts for each fuel expired. The January contract for heating oil rose 1.53 cents to settle at 81.31 cents a gallon, and later months also advanced sharply. Heating oil has traded lower than might be expected for this time of the year because of the unusually warm fall and winter. Although temperatures have fallen in many parts of the country, heating oil supplies are adequate and this has kept prices down, Lebow said. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for January delivery picked up 1.36 cents to close at 70.92 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also moving higher. In natural gas trading, the February contract closed at $1.950 per 1,000 cubic feet, unchanged from Friday.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: 8.24 percent.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 4.45 to 2,633.66, closing out the year with a net loss of 119.54 points, or 4.3 percent. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 9 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,023 up, 571 down and 438 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 114.13 million shares, against 111.04 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index gained .84 to 180.49.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Ends 1990 Lower; Gold Up Slightly But Down for the Year
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly lower on the final day of 1990, finishing a year of marked weakening against other currencies due in large part to the reunification of Germany and a slumping U.S. economy. Gold was marginally higher on Monday, but ended the year down moderately. The metal closed up 20 cents to $394.20 a troy ounce from Friday's close on the New York Commodity Exchange. That compared with the gold's last quote on the final day of 1989, $402.50 an ounce. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $393.25 a troy ounce, up 25 cents from late Friday but down from 1989's last late bid of $402.50 an ounce. Currency analysts said the loosening of communism in Eastern Europe also contributed to the dollar's fall by strengthening the German mark. ``Germany is the big story in 1990,'' said David Marshall, currency analyst at MMS International. ``The dollar did worse than people expected it due to the quickness with which the reunification of Germany went through and the strength of the unwinding of Eastern Europe.'' In addition, he said, ``no one expected the U.S. economy to be as soft as it now seems to be.'' On Monday in New York, the dollar closed against the German mark at 1.4885 compared with 1.6950 marks at 1989's end. Late Friday the dollar was quoted at 1.4935 marks. Analysts said the dollar's year-to-date loss against currencies other than the mark was not as pronounced, in part because the Middle East conflict seemed to hurt some other denominations more than the dollar. In New York, the dollar ended the year at 135.50 Japanese yen, down from 143.85 yen at the end of 1989. But Monday's dollar ended stronger than Friday's closing 134.90 yen. The British pound also strengthened overall against the dollar, closing the year at $1.9345 in New York compared with $1.6105 at 1989's close. On Friday, sterling was quoted at a closing $1.9282. In London, the pound rose to $1.9280 from $1.9220 late Friday. The pound traded in London for $1.6115 at the end of 1989. The dollar's slight fall on Monday was due partly to a fresh peace initiative from the European Community. Luxembourg's foreign minister, Jacques Poos, said he may meet with Iraqi counterpart Tariq Aziz. Luxembourg will take over the European Community's rotating chairmanship on Tuesday. Heightened peace prospects in the Persian Gulf tend to diminish the dollar's value because the investment is considered a safe haven in times of war. Despite the EEC's peace-feeling foray, earlier news of a hostile-sounding New Year's message from Iraq's Saddam Hussein offset much of the dollar's fall, said Marshall. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.65 Japanese yen to 135.40 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 135.55 yen. The dollar finished at 143.40 yen in Tokyo at the end of 1989. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates and with 1989 yearend rates in parentheses included: 1.2668 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745 (1.5420); 5.0685 French francs, down from 5.0810 (5.7805); 1.1599 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1601 (1.1588); 1,122.75 Italian lire, down from 1,126.50 (1,267.00). Other late dollar rates in Europe compared with late rates Friday and with 1989 yearend rates in parentheses included: 1.4965 German marks, down from 1.4970 (1.6923); 1.2760 Swiss francs, down from 1.2780 (1.5430); 5.0990 French francs, up from 5.0930 (5.7860); 1.6885 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6890 (1.9100); 1,130.50 Italian lire, up from 1,127.75 (1,270.00), and 1.1605 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1607 (1.1587). Gold rose in London to a late bid of $391.50 a troy ounce from $385.75 late Friday. It closed at $401 an ounce at the end of 1989. The Zurich gold market was closed Monday for an extended New Year's holiday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.22 an ounce to close at $390.65. Silver rose .2 cents a troy ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange to $4.192. That was down from the metal's last late bid of 1989 of $5.208 a troy ounce. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $4.19 a troy ounce from Friday's $4.14. Silver in London ended 1989 at $5.18.

DOC.HEAD: Slump in 1990 Pinned to Gulf, Economy, Eastern Europe
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Instability in Europe, the threat of war in the Middle East and economic woes everywhere pushed world stock markets down sharply in 1990, and strategists said the new year hinges on the course of those events. In major markets, Japan tumbled on overvalued stocks and high interest rates and Germany sank as the effect of abosorbing its formerly Communist eastern neighbor set in, while Britain benefited from a weak dollar. According to an index of 20 major markets by Morgan Stanley Capital International, world stock markets tumbled 23 percent in 1990 through Friday as measured in local currencies. The U.S., Canadian and British stock markets were open Monday, but most 1990 trading worldwide ended Friday. Excluding the United States and Canada, the decline for U.S. investors playing foreign markets translated to 24.4 percent in 1990, compared to a 9.1 percent increase in dollar terms in 1989, Morgan Stanley said. ``Bascially we had a year where the consequences of high real interest rates came out,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist with Barclays de Zoete Wedd. He said higher rates in Germany and Japan were felt worldwide. Market strategists said Monday that the world developments that shaped 1990 will spill over as the dominant themes of 1991. Among the key questions: -Will the United States go to war with Iraq? Rising oil prices had a bad inflationary effect on equity markets from Stockholm to Singapore, and trading closely followed the movements of oil prices. -How bad will the world financial crisis get? The pace of slowdowns in Europe and Japan and recessions in the Britain and the United States, and the movement of interest rates, particularly in Germany, are considered keys to stock market performance in 1991. -Will the tinder box politics of the Soviet Union ignite? Will Eastern Europe become more than an economic drain for the West? Economists said the potential for quick gains there is slim, but that disaster could depress stock markets. In the Morgan Stanley index, Japan's stock market dropped 39.9 percent in yen terms in 1990, the world's second worst performance behind a 40.2 percent fall in Finland. Germany declined 20.9 percent, France fell 25.2 percent and Italy lost 29 percent in their local currencies. The declines were smaller when measured in U.S. dollars, which fell against European currencies for the year. The best performer in local terms was the Hong Kong market, which rose 4.6 percent. The Austrian market lost just 6.9 percent in local currency and rose 4.9 percent in dollar terms. Britain dropped 10.7 percent in pounds and rose 6.1 percent in dollars. The U.S. market was down 5.9 percent, according to Morgan Stanley. In Japan, the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks plunged from a record high of 38,915.87 at the end of 1989 to below 20,000 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. The index recovered somewhat to end the year at 23,848.71. A sharp rise in Japanese interest rates helped depress equity investment there, Hoey said. That combined with what was widely considered an unsustainable market level spurred the sell-off. Major factors in 1991 are the real estate prices and whether economic malaise will increase. Interest rates played the primary role in Germany, with the powerful Bundesbank, the nation's central bank, dictating action in other European capitals. The Frankfurt stock market soared in the spring amid optimism over Eastern Europe before the cost of German reunification took its toll. The German government hiked interest rates to offset the inflationary impact of pouring billions of dollars into former East Germany. Higher interest rates dampen corporate expansion and economic growth generally. ``It's almost as if they flew an airplane over East Germany and threw deutsche marks out the window,'' Hoey said. ``The consequence was a widening budget deficit, increased financing pressure and the anti-inflationary response of the Bundesbank.'' Smaller foreign markets were affected by the interest rate rise. The Netherlands' stock market, for instance, lost 17.4 percent in 1990 in local terms, according to Morgan Stanley. The U.S. recession also damped enthusiasm for investing in companies that do business in the United States. ``The Dutch have a saying - when it rains outside Holland they too sometimes get a little wet,'' said Palmer Davidsen, who watches the Dutch market for ABN-AMRO Securities New York, a subsidiary of a Dutch bank. ``People are starting to think twice about buying stocks that have big dollar exposure or big economic exposure (in the United States),'' she said. Also, the widely hoped-for benefits of investment in the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe didn't materialize for European companies, analysts said. They said improvements there could help European markets, but warned that political instability in the Soviet Union could trigger a world financial crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans, Precious Metals, Energy Future Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybeans staged a moderate comeback Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid an unexpectedly low number of deliveries during an abbreviated pre-holiday session. On other markets, energy futures gained; precious metal futures were slightly higher; livestock and meat futures were mostly lower; and grains slipped. The markets had shortened New Year's Eve sessions. Soybeans futures prices settled 0.5 cent lower to 4.5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January at $5.61{ a bushel. Soybeans bounced back from losses on Friday, when the future dipped to new contract lows, reflecting expectations for heavy deliveries this week. The complex posted moderate gains after commercial firms reported only three million bushels delivered, as opposed to the 10 million expected, said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president for grains for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``There really was not much news or anything of consequence except that deliveries were much lighter than expected,'' Lespinasse said. Wheat gained on early support from soybeans and word that the U.S. Agriculture Department will meet with officials from the Soviet Union on Friday to subsidize some wheat purchases. It later fell, however, amid a flurry of professional selling. Corn had some support from wheat and soybeans but later was weighed down by light export demand. Wheat futures settled 2.25 cents lower to 0.25 cent higher with March at $2.60{ a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent lower to unchanged with March at $2.31} a bushel, oats were 2.5 cents to 0.5 cent lower with March at $1.10\ a bushel. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, energy futures showed a higher-than-expected level of activity as tension mounted over U.N.'s Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to unconditionally withdraw from neighboring Kuwait. War rhetoric from Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein also contributed to the gains. Light sweet crude settled 10 cents to 91 cents higher with February at $28.44 a barrel; heating oil settled 1.29 cents to 2 cents higher with January at 81.31 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled .90 cent to 1.36 cents higher with January at 70.92 cents a gallon; and natural gas was unchanged to .02 higher with February at $1.950 per cubic feet. Gold and silver settled slightly higher on New York's Commodity Exchange as traders squared their books for the start of the new year, analysts said. Gold settled unchanged to 20 cents higher with January at $394.20 an ounce; silver settled .30 cent to .20 cent higher with January at $4.19 an ounce. ``There was very little trading range,'' said Frederick Demler, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc. ``There was a little concern about the gulf crisis, but it was mainly book-squaring at the end of the year.'' ``Precious metals also were supported by a slight easing of the U.S. dollars,'' added Bette Raptopoulos, senior metals analyst at Prudential Bache Securities Inc. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. A weak tone in the beef industry was the cause of sluggish trading. Pork futures were awaiting this weekend's release of the government's quarterly hogs and pigs report. Cattle futures prices settled unchanged to .20 cent higher with February at 77.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .23 cent higher with January at 89.40 cents a pound; hogs were .32 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 48.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent lower to unchanged with February at 63.10 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economic Outlook Bjt
Thrift Failures Leveled Off in '90, Report Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, The failure ..., to CORRECT percentage to 29 sted 41; PICK UP 5th graf, Analysts, however ...; Version moving on general news wires as AM-Bank-S&L Failures.
DOC.TEXT: The number of bank and savings institution failures declined in 1990 for the first time in seven years, but the foundering economy may prevent any sustained improvement. In 1990, 169 commercial and savings banks failed, including one bank that remained open only with an infusion of government cash, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said Monday. Additionally, 211 savings and loans went insolvent, the Resolution Trust Corp. said. That included 207 seized by the government and put into conservatorship and four kept open with taxpayer money. The failure total in 1990 - 380 - represents a 29 percent drop from 535 in 1989, a post-Depression high. It marks the first decline since 1983, when 84 of both types of institutions failed, compared with 105 the previous year. Analysts, however, are drawing no encouragement from the improvement. The sharp deterioration in real estate values, particularly in New England and New York and New Jersey, have yet to make their full impact on the failure rate, they said. Nor have the effects of the economic slowdown since the summer. ``1990 in a way was really a lull year,'' said financial institutions analyst Bert Ely of Alexandria, Va. ``Every indication is that in 1991 we're going to see a significant increase.'' The geographic pattern of failures shows they reflect old problems from the mid-1980s in oil-producing states in the Southwest rather than new problems in the Northeastern states where real estate markets are weakest, he said. Although 1990's failures were spread among 38 states and the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico, more than a third - 140 - were in Texas. Ten other states had 10 or more failures. They were California and Florida, 21 each; Illinois, 18; Louisiana, 17; New Jersey, 14; Oklahoma, 13; New York, 12; Massachusetts and Colorado, 11, and Mississippi, 10. ``What's going to be interesting in 1991 is to see what will happen in New England. That's where the next wave of problems is,'' Ely said. According to economist Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, the most significant difference between bank problems in the 1980s and bank problems of the 1990s is that this time some of the nation's largest S&Ls are under stress. ``Through the 1980s, the problems were largely concentrated in small banks, with a few isolated exceptions,'' he said. ``Today the weakness is concentrated in large banks.'' That is reflected in FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman's forecast that 180 banks will fail in 1991. Although that is only 10 more than in 1990, the agency says assets held by the insolvent institutions will total $70 billion, up from around $16 billion in 1990. The S&Ls toppling into insolvency in 1990 had $117 billion in assets. Meanwhile, according to the Office of Thrift Supervision, an additional 184 institutions, with around $150 billion in assets, are all but certain to fail and 356 S&Ls with $190 billion in assets are in danger of failing. If all of the endangered S&Ls fold, only around 2,000 privately-managed S&Ls would be left operating. If Seidman's bank failure prediction proves accurate, the number of commercial and savings banks operating would be reduced to around 12,700. The big danger, according to economists, is that regulators will hesitate to seize failing institutions and sell them off to new investors. Seidman said the FDIC has enough money to handle bank failures through this year, but the insurance fund would begin 1992 dangerously diminished to around $4 billion. Seidman is proposing that healthy banks contribute around $25 billion to shore up the fund. Resolution Trust Corp. officials, meanwhile, estimate they will be out of funds unless Congress expeditiously acts to provide more. After spending most of the $50 billion that Congress appropriated for the S&L bailout in 1989, the Bush administration estimates it needs at least another $40 billion to cover losses in 1990. The RTC spent $32 billion in 1990 to protect depositors in 320 S&Ls, including some that were closed and others turned over to new owners. That total includes institutions seized in 1989 as well as in 1990.
